albums.label: Touch and Go
albums.description: Culled from the band’s sessions at Maida Vale Studios in 1994 and 2004, this double-LP that captures, in great fidelity, the acerbic personality and power of Steve Albini’s trio.

albums.title: Work
albums.label: West End
albums.description: The New York duo jump-starts iconic disco label West End Records with a love letter to classic dance, but the mood is strangely sour.

albums.title: Patience
albums.label: Epitaph
albums.description: On their third record, the Philly band has achieved a balance between seething chaos and quietly devastating vulnerability. It’s one of the best punk rock records of the year.

albums.title: Fog FM
albums.label: Incienso
albums.description: Tough, upfront, and often bruisingly physical, Fog FM is the New York producer’s most substantial piece of work by a considerable margin.

albums.title: On Avery Island
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the oft-overshadowed debut from indie rock icons, a smaller and more intimate look into the mercurial world of Jeff Mangum.

albums.title: III
albums.label: Loma Vista
albums.description: Kevin Devine and Manchester Orchestra’s Andy Hull used to record collaborations that sounded like reworkings of their respective catalogs, but they’ve finally articulated what this band is about.

albums.title: How Am I Not Myself?
albums.label: Danger Collective
albums.description: On their second album, the cheerfully subversive L.A. art-punks critique societal norms as they revel in their own absurdity (and saxophone).

albums.title: An Obelisk
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: Where Titus Andronicus once made great statements out of bloat, on their sixth album they do it with refreshing brevity.

albums.title: 7 EP
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: The songs on the debut EP from the viral rap and country star do not even come close to the pure magic of “Old Town Road.”

albums.title: Turn Off the News (Build a Garden)
albums.label: Fantasy
albums.description: The son of Willie Nelson has led a charmed life, playing with Neil Young and inspiring Bradley Cooper in A Star Is Born. His own band’s throwback roots-rock toes the line of escapism.

albums.title: Empathy EP
albums.label: EMPIRE
albums.description: The Chicago rapper and singer makes a name for herself with an airy, flexible voice that flows effortlessly between the sensuous and the sorrowful.

albums.title: Big Dread Moon
albums.label: Orindal
albums.description: Claire Cronin’s latest record connects her lifelong love of horror movies to her simple, creaky songs.

albums.title: Am I Who I Am
albums.label: Trip
albums.description: The Russian duo’s frenetic approach is more techno egg-and-spoon race than tech-house marathon, packed with improbable sounds, intriguing blind alleys, and eyebrow-raising quirks.

albums.title: Endorphins
albums.label: Black Butter
albums.description: The rising London rapper flexes his versatility with a musically diverse set that feels more like a major studio debut than the mixtape it’s billed as.

albums.title: Long Live Mexico
albums.label: Young Stoner Life
albums.description: The Atlanta rapper finally steps out of Young Thug’s shadow and showcases his own style and versatility.

albums.title: A Bath Full of Ecstasy
albums.label: Domino
albums.description: The band’s seventh album is compulsively listenable, oddly moving, and stranger than it first appears.

albums.title: Become Desert
albums.label: Cantaloupe
albums.description: The Pulitzer Prize-winning composer’s latest installment in his Become trilogy is expansive and inviting. The piece explores resonance and the way sounds mutate, stick in our heads, or just disappear.

albums.title: Nighttime Stories
albums.label: Southern Lord
albums.description: The instrumental metal quartet’s first album in six years grapples directly with loss and grief, channeling dueling guitars and pummeling rhythms into a dire, haunted sound.

albums.title: The Complete Birth of the Cool
albums.label: Blue Note
albums.description: A modern-jazz touchstone that opened the door to the sleek introspection and sophisticated aplomb of 1950s cool jazz gets an exquisite and essential vinyl reissue.

albums.title: Diaspora
albums.label: Squaaash Club
albums.description: GoldLink’s second album stretches far beyond his home in the DMV. It is a confluence of black music; hip-hop tracing its way back to the universal sounds of Africa.

albums.title: Cages
albums.label: New Age
albums.description: The St. Louis metalpunks put their politics at the forefront of their music—except they’ve also got riffs, and they can write the hell out of a catchy, confrontational punk song.

albums.title: Klaus Nomi
albums.label: Real Gone
albums.description: A reissue of the Downtown fixture’s 1981 debut album is a reminder that despite his striking look, campy repertoire, and operatic range, the onetime Bowie collaborator was no novelty act.

albums.title: Madame X
albums.label: Live Nation
albums.description: Madonna’s 14th album feels stretched thin all over the globe, layered with an ambitious concept that ends up muddled and convoluted.

albums.title: CHORDS
albums.label: Subtext
albums.description: On the follow-up to her 2017 album For organ and brass, the Swedish composer delves even deeper into microtonal interplay, balancing heady theoretical terrain with a rare emotional resonance.

albums.title: Loom Dream
albums.label: Whities
albums.description: The resident DJ at the UK-based Freerotation festival releases a dreamy, bucolic ambient LP, full of lush textures and birdsong.

albums.title: TEARS IN MY HENNESSY
albums.label: Coming for Blood
albums.description: The Bronx-born DJ melds genres at breakneck speed on a disconsolate and deeply personal breakup record.

albums.title: Jinx
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: The New York City psych-rock quartet’s debut full-length beckons the listener with dreamy keyboards, twinkling guitar, and a recognizable buzz of stoic anxiety.

albums.title: Years to Burn
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: It took more than a decade to follow up In the Reins, but its successor reveals musicians who’ve learned to corral swarms of instruments and styles into a newly complex sound.

albums.title: Back in Black
albums.label: Leidseplein Presse B.V.
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the classic rock staple from a band who rebounded from tragedy to record one of the biggest albums ever made.

albums.title: Black Star Dancing EP
albums.label: Sour Mash
albums.description: On his new EP, Noel Gallagher breaks free—a little—from his six-string to embrace the Big Beat of his youth.

albums.title: The Age of Immunology
albums.label: Fire
albums.description: Drawing on its members’ diverse backgrounds and distinguished resumes—including work with Broadcast, Gruff Rhys, and Zongamin—the London band tilts its psychedelic pop toward a utopian future.

albums.title: This Land Abounds With Life
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: Interpolating field recordings and birdsong, the Cuban-born jazz pianist's fourth album explores the sounds of his home country with warmth and fervor.

albums.title: Sonic Youth: Battery Park, NYC: July 4, 2008
albums.label: Matador
albums.description: Three years before they split, at an Independence Day concert in a downtown park, the band tore through its earliest work with the polish of seasoned pros.

albums.title: Derretirse EP
albums.label: Dekmantel
albums.description: Lush, heady, and shot through with an undercurrent of wistful contemplation, producer Brian Piñeyro’s “deep reggaetón” sound can’t be called lo-fi anymore.

albums.title: Happiness Begins
albums.label: Republic
albums.description: The former teen heartthrobs’ first album in almost 10 years is by no means extraordinary, but it’s a respectable showing from a group that has long deserved more respect than they got.

albums.title: Western Stars
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: Bruce Springsteen returns with elegiac and wise songwriting conjuring the golden expanse of the American West; it’s his best studio album in years.

albums.title: Bob Dylan: Rolling Thunder Revue: The 1975 Live Recordings
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: A mammoth, 14-CD box set released to accompany Martin Scorcese’s documentary captures the 1975 tour in all its ragged glory.

albums.title: Shepherd in a Sheepskin Vest
albums.label: Drag City
albums.description: A peerless storyteller gazes deep into domestic life and offers a long, sun-warmed double album that is a highlight of his career.

albums.title: SAVE ME EP
albums.label: Epic
albums.description: His latest EP proves he’s still a master of melancholic detail, but thematically and sonically, the Atlanta superstar has hit a wall.

albums.title: Erotic Reruns
albums.label: Yeasayer
albums.description: A slight and unwaveringly safe 30 minutes, Yeasayer’s latest goes down easier than anything the band has ever done, while making less of an impression.

albums.title: TIM
albums.label: Universal Records
albums.description: The Swedish EDM superstar’s posthumous final album purports to reveal Tim Bergling as he’s never been seen, but the scrum of co-writers and guest singers leaves more questions than answers.

albums.title: Grass and Trees
albums.label: Kranky
albums.description: Jacob Long’s vaporous, lo-fi ambient tracks feel like snapshots of stillness made of moving parts.

albums.title: Die a Legend
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: Polo G blends pop and drill with ease and delivers a standout Chicago street rap debut that is meticulously crafted and honestly told.

albums.title: Midnight
albums.label: Saddle Creek
albums.description: The Detroit indie rocker’s second album fluctuates between alt-rock and garage pop, turning up her amp and doubling down on her uncompromising style.

albums.title: Islands
albums.label: Keeled Scales
albums.description: The singer-songwriter and pianist writes quietly epic songs about heartbreak, determination, and loneliness.

albums.title: Black Mirror: Smithereens
albums.label: Milan
albums.description: The electronic musician and veteran soundtrack composer turns his interpretive abilities to a single episode of Charlie Brooker’s dystopian Netflix series, to subtle yet compelling effect.

albums.title: Black Friday
albums.label: Polyvinyl
albums.description: Guitarist and bandleader Ellen Kempner’s third record breaks down the walls around her wiry, anxious riffs, opening space for levity and the thrill of new love.

albums.title: Old Star
albums.label: Peaceville
albums.description: With their true Norwegian black metal days behind them and nothing left to prove, the longrunning duo trumpet their joyful debt to classic heavy metal.

albums.title: Paradise
albums.label: Company Records
albums.description: The twin-brother jazz duo are experts at channeling the sounds of light and ease, and there’s something almost alchemical about their mutual precision.

albums.title: Widow’s Weeds
albums.label: New Machine
albums.description: For a rock band who excels at high-intensity drama, their latest is set of mid-tempo snoozers that are over-refined, hermetically sealed, and safe.

albums.title: Mirroring
albums.label: Orchid Tapes
albums.description: On her second album, singer and songwriter Johanne Swanson is wiser, steadier, and more willing to explore. Her music now feels like an expression of emotional epiphanies.

albums.title: Sirens
albums.label: Room40
albums.description: The low-end mastermind behind the Bug and King Midas Sound turns his gut-rumbling frequencies and queasy atmospheres to the terrors of new parenthood.

albums.title: Never Say Goodbye
albums.label: Emperor Jones
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the lo-fi acoustic recordings of Roky Erickson, a rare glimpse at his stark and fragile songwriting.

albums.title: Personal Best / Captain My Captain / Choices, Chances, Changes: Singles & Comptracks 1994-2000
albums.label: Jealous Butcher
albums.description: A new reissue collects the work of the pioneering icons of queer punk, whose uncompromising approach and knowing intimacies made them pre-Tumblr beacons of community.

albums.title: Pale Bloom
albums.label: W.25TH
albums.description: The Canadian composer turns from electroacoustic minimalism to contemplative, deeply focused compositions for piano, organ, voice, and strings.

albums.title: Weeping Choir
albums.label: Relapse
albums.description: On their Relapse debut, the infernal Full of Hell crack apart metal genres like oracle bones.

albums.title: Spiritual 2
albums.label: Beyond Beyond is Beyond
albums.description: The Seoul duo taps into devotional music’s focused intensity in trance-inducing pieces that draw on new age, krautrock, and folk.

albums.title: What the Brokenhearted Do...
albums.label: Jagjaguwar
albums.description: The comedian and musician brings his dry absurdity and taste for 1970s singer-songwriters to a novel venture: a fake breakup album.

albums.title: Originals
albums.label: Warner Bros.
albums.description: Hearing Prince sing these songs that he gave to other performers brings you close to the pulse of his artistry: transgressive, funky, sexy, a testament to his genius even in the form of demos.

albums.title: Lust for Youth
albums.label: Sacred Bones
albums.description: Hannes Norrvide's long-running coldwave synth project breaks into the greener pastures of Depeche Mode-style new wave.

albums.title: Venq Tolep
albums.label: Pampa
albums.description: The German producer offers his prettiest, silkiest, and most poignant minimal electronic music ever.

albums.title: Out of Sight
albums.label: Paradise of Bachelors
albums.description: Neither rigidly authentic nor conspicuously modern, the North Carolina folk scholar honors the past through transformation rather than reinvention.

albums.title: Leak 04-13 (Bait Ones)
albums.label: XL
albums.description: The decade’s most tantalizing pop enigma officially releases a trove of unfinished material that was originally leaked online six years ago.

albums.title: April is the Cruellest Month
albums.label: Blank Forms
albums.description: Unreleased at the time, the Japanese guitarist's elemental free jazz opus provides the missing link between Albert Ayler, Merzbow, and Acid Mothers Temple.

albums.title: Mandy & the Jungle
albums.label: Monster Boy
albums.description: The omnivorous Nigerian rapper-singer makes smoothly effortless genre hybrids that feel like everywhere and nowhere all at once.

albums.title: Introducing Juan Pablo
albums.label: Captured Tracks
albums.description: The Uruguayan-American singer-songwriter's latest is a charmingly loose grab bag, dotted with field recordings and snippets of sampled conversation.

albums.title: She Is Coming EP
albums.label: RCA
albums.description: The first EP of a forthcoming trilogy from the pop icon is all over the place. It misuses her talents and makes for a largely unrewarding listen.

albums.title: solipsisters
albums.label: Run for Cover
albums.description: The Australian bedroom-pop artist’s third album demonstrates that her attention to how her songs start, end, and connect has never been keener or better controlled.

albums.title: Hot Spring
albums.label: Run for Cover
albums.description: The more relaxed, country-adjacent follow-up to 2017’s Enjoy the Great Outdoors pairs pastoral modes with surreal meditations on a warming world.

albums.title: The Peyote Dance
albums.label: Bella Union
albums.description: Over field recordings sourced from the Mexico of Antonin Artaud’s travels, the New York singer gives voice to the French poet’s hallucinogenic visions.

albums.title: In the West
albums.label: Comedy Minus One
albums.description: Though the Seattle band would produce more focused efforts, In the West is a fascinating document of nascent indie rock that sounds revelatory 25 years later.

albums.title: ZUU
albums.label: Loma Vista
albums.description: The South Florida rapper puts on for his city and delivers the best, most dynamic, and altogether hardest album of his career.

albums.title: Where Future Unfolds
albums.label: International Anthem
albums.description: The Chicago-based improvisational artist layers politically charged sound collages over drum machines and a children’s choir. The result is uplifting activist jazz for tumultuous times.

albums.title: Pianoworks
albums.label: Temporary Residence
albums.description: Matthew Cooper's second solo piano record in 15 years glows with a childlike wonder underscored by mature regret.

albums.title: Rocketman (Music From the Motion Picture)
albums.label: Interscope
albums.description: The music from Elton John’s life sinks into the uncanny valley with a studio band, a substitute singer, and a silver-screen production that misses the finer points of the legendary performer’s career.

albums.title: Run Around the Sun
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: The Scotland-based duo delight in controlled chaos, interweaving arguments and anxieties with their most exuberant work to date.

albums.title: Terror Twilight
albums.label: Matador
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Pavement’s divisive final album, full of clamor and clarity that presaged the end of the underground.

albums.title: Dispassionate EP
albums.label: Nettwerk
albums.description: The California surf-garage rockers extend their recent series of EPs, and succumb to their own sense of anhedonia.

albums.title: Water Memory / Mount Vision
albums.label: Rvng Intl.
albums.description: The L.A.-based Sprague steps away from her indie pop trio Florist for rippling, patient, and redemptive ambient drone works for modular synthesizers.

albums.title: From Here to Eternity
albums.label: Past Inside the Present
albums.description: The Montreal ambient musician’s albums all resemble each other in their broad strokes and abiding stillness. They are beautiful, terrifying, and bittersweet all at once.

albums.title: Boat
albums.label: Heavenly
albums.description: The Dutch quartet undercut their perky, grunge-lite melodies with just the right amount of pop-fuzz aggression.

albums.title: Ignorance Is Bliss
albums.label: Boy Better Know
albums.description: Three years after he galvanized a new class of grime MCs, the UK rapper tries to meet the high bar he set for himself.

albums.title: Swim Team EP
albums.label: Father/Daughter
albums.description: The Congolese American songwriter and guitarist’s debut EP winds in circles, tracing vast spaces that couch thorny emotional quagmires.

albums.title: Rainford
albums.label: On-U Sound
albums.description: After years spent trading on a bulletproof back catalog and eccentric persona, the Jamaican titan teams up with UK dub heavyweight Adrian Sherwood for a welcome return to form.

albums.title: REMEMBER THE FUTURE
albums.label: To whom it may concern.
albums.description: On the follow-up to her debut solo album, the former iamamiwhoami member tilts her off-kilter electro pop toward compellingly dystopian visions.

albums.title: 43VA HEARTLESS
albums.label: N-Less
albums.description: The consistent Memphis rapper continues his workmanlike grind to the top.

albums.title: Falaw
albums.label: Sahel Sounds
albums.description: The Malian producer employs ngoni and other regional sounds in hip-hop-inspired fusions that, at their best, suggest a West African beat tape.

albums.title: Apollo XXI
albums.label: 3qtr
albums.description: The singer and guitarist’s debut solo album offers an introspective blend of R&B, hip-hop, & lo-fi pop but feels reluctant to claim the spotlight.

albums.title: Escape From New York
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: On their first album as a collective, Beast Coast attempt to move beyond the boom-bap revivalism that made them famous.

albums.title: Full Upon Her Burning Lips
albums.label: Sargent House
albums.description: The minimalist drone-riff masters pare away excess and focus on the seismic repetition that made their best work so resonant, creating a new peak in their long discography.

albums.title: Atlanta Millionaires Club
albums.label: Secretly Canadian
albums.description: The 21-year-old singer-songwriter’s third album is serene folk-pop with a mellow soul tinge and the melancholy clarity of someone twice her age.

albums.title: i'll show you stronger
albums.label: Rhyme & Reason
albums.description: The Brooklyn-based musician’s long-percolating debut is a collection of small dream-pop ditties that only feel cheery on the outside.

albums.title: Destroyer
albums.label: Jagjaguwar
albums.description: Reinvigorated with a whole host of new members, the metal outfit prove there's plenty of life left in their road-trip rock.

albums.title: Zoospa
albums.label: Innovative Leisure
albums.description: The first collaborative full-length by producers Machinedrum and Jimmy Edgar bounces across genres and eras, but the real magic comes from the guest vocalists.

albums.title: Support Alien Invasion
albums.label: Cómeme
albums.description: The Chilean-German producer’s steely, slinky polyrhythms are a repudiation of borders and a celebration of the freedom of movement.

albums.title: Reward
albums.label: Mexican Summer
albums.description: On her fifth album, the Welsh musician is at her best. The more elaborate and eccentric her music becomes, the more she sounds like herself.

albums.title: Act Surprised
albums.label: Dangerbird
albums.description: Where 2013’s cautious Defend Yourself attempted a belated recovery from a disappointing major-label debut, the indie-rock icons’ latest sounds like the work of a band refreshingly free of baggage.

albums.title: Paradox
albums.label: Profound Lore
albums.description: The cult death metal act returns with a fresh blast of hellish air, full of joyously absurd keyboards, hyper-technical guitars, and apocalyptic sci-fi visions.

albums.title: Forever Breathes the Lonely Word
albums.label: Creation
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the misanthropic pop perfection of the indie British band’s sixth and best album.

albums.title: Diviner
albums.label: Domino
albums.description: The former Wild Beasts singer embarks on a new direction on his soul-searching solo debut, stripping back his songwriting to a reverent hush.

albums.title: Dozakh: All Lovers Hell
albums.label: YEAR0001
albums.description: The debut album from the Iranian-Swedish artist offers a fascinatingly dark take on romantic love, filled with images of violence and devastation.

albums.title: California Son
albums.label: BMG
albums.description: Morrissey and some (barely audible) high-profile guests rework 12 of his favorite ’60s and ’70s songs by American artists to mixed results.

albums.title: Brown Rice
albums.label: Verve
albums.description: Reissued on vinyl some 40 years after its initial release, Don Cherry’s sprawling, free, ecstatic masterwork defined what came to be known as “world” music.

albums.title: We Get By
albums.label: Anti-
albums.description: The legendary singer has lost little expressiveness with age, but these songs are about the small, quiet spaces where she can catch her breath and steel her nerves.

albums.title: Amyl and the Sniffers
albums.label: ATO
albums.description: The Aussie rockers’ unabashed fetishization of 1970s staples like punk, glam, and their country’s sharpie scene only helps fuel the invigorating rush of their music.

albums.title: Flamagra
albums.label: Warp
albums.description: On Steven Ellison’s sixth album, his sweeping jazz-funk feels limitless. It sounds more like a sketchbook with FlyLo crafting each minute with great care and technical dexterity.

albums.title: 4REAL 4REAL
albums.label: Def Jam
albums.description: YG pays heartfelt tribute to the late Nipsey Hussle on his latest while still reserving plenty of vitriol for his favorite targets: broke dudes, snitches, broke dudes who also snitch.

albums.title: STFU II EP
albums.label: Glydezone
albums.description: Picking up where his DJ-Kicks mix left off, the L.A. funk auteur’s newest release explores peace and love through body-rock.

albums.title: Ecstatic Computation
albums.label: Editions Mego
albums.description: The Italian synthesizer composer explores new dimensions of her algorithmic, arpeggiated sound, playing with tempo, duration, and pacing to toy with listeners’ sense of perception.

albums.title: Fever
albums.label: 1501 Certified
albums.description: Megan Thee Stallion’s debut is steeped in sex, pimpin, and power; it sounds like a once and future Houston rap classic.

albums.title: We Fall
albums.label: The Sound of Sinners
albums.description: On her debut solo album, the Breeders’ original bassist blends her signature instrument with minimalist electronics and rippling pools of piano, Mellotron, and acoustic guitar.

albums.title: Radiant Dawn
albums.label: Last Gang
albums.description: Crosswiring ’80s-Springsteen valor with contemporaneous synth pop, the second album from Dan Boeckner’s disco power trio channels the crushing fear of imminent collapse.

albums.title: A Fine Mess EP
albums.label: Matador
albums.description: Culled from last year’s Marauder sessions with Dave Fridmann, there’s still a sense that the production actively tries to disrupt what Interpol does well.

albums.title: Injury Reserve
albums.label: Loma Vista
albums.description: The oddball Phoenix rap trio traffic in wild, boundary-pushing production and playfully anarchic bars.

albums.title: Father of Asahd
albums.label: We the Best
albums.description: DJ Khaled has ranged from summertime hitmaker to self-help guru, and neither are all that interesting on his latest guest-filled album. There are plenty of voices but no clear message or intention.

albums.title: Galazy EP
albums.label: Young Ethics
albums.description: On the first release on his new label Young Ethics, the Swedish producer steps outside his hazy comfort zone.

albums.title: 13th Floor
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: With hard-nosed bars and ominous, bass-heavy beats, the Canadian rapper’s debut album is her most cohesive and narratively ambitious effort to date.

albums.title: I Am the Last of That Green and Warm-Hued World
albums.label: Hausu Mountain
albums.description: Within an album that often sounds like an alien world, small moments of familiarity become breadcrumbs leading to a shared musicology.

albums.title: Nothing Great About Britain
albums.label: True Panther
albums.description: The Bajan-British rapper’s debut tackles the UK’s pressing crises—a looming Brexit, class hostility, widening poverty—with great jokes and writerly candor.

albums.title: Origin EP
albums.label: Warp
albums.description: The New York pianist’s stripped-back companion piece to her electronic-tinged 2018 album Ultraviolet is an engrossing ode to the act of creation.

albums.title: Pacific Breeze: Japanese City Pop, AOR & Boogie 1976-1986
albums.label: Light in the Attic
albums.description: This compilation of extra smooth, funky, and sometimes very odd songs from the heydey of Japan’s technological boom is a broad yet nuanced introduction to the genre of city pop.

albums.title: IGOR
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: Tyler, the Creator’s sixth album is impressionistic and emotionally charged, the result of an auteur refining his style and baring more of his soul than ever before.

albums.title: Living Theatre
albums.label: Trouble in Mind
albums.description: The Brooklyn group’s second album frames heavy questions in lovely, deceptively serene psych rock.

albums.title: Spice
albums.label: Virgin
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the sleek pop, British nationalism, and commercial girl power of the Spice Girls’ debut.

albums.title: Natty Light
albums.label: JABS
albums.description: This collection of 7"s and compilation tracks documents the band’s formative years, in which frenzied hardcore and proto-screamo was rapidly churning toward more radical strains of noise.

albums.title: Le personnage principal est un peuple isolé
albums.label: Stroom
albums.description: STROOM, a Belgian label whose releases are not so much reissues as alternate histories of avant-garde pop, surveys the dreamlike soundscapes of a fringe figure from the 1980s.

albums.title: Spirit
albums.label: Loma Vista
albums.description: Playing a baby grand piano, Mike Milosh’s eight-song album reflects a sense of ritualistic quiet; it’s intimate without being heavy-handed.

albums.title: The Movie
albums.label: Dog Knights
albums.description: The Gothenburg emo band specialize in commiseration rock, crafting combustible rallying cries for the overwhelmed and underemployed.

albums.title: Matchy Matchy
albums.label: Fika
albums.description: With their first album in six years, New York City indie-pop duo the Ballet question the complexities of modern queer life but offer no easy answers.

albums.title: Dedicated
albums.label: School Boy
albums.description: On her fourth album, the Canadian pop star is doing what she does best, calibrating lovesick or lovelorn synthpop that’s neither too hot nor too cold—and sometimes, regrettably, only lukewarm.

albums.title: The Best of Luck Club
albums.label: Dead Oceans
albums.description: The Australian pop-punk musician’s second album is a welcome and wide-open look at mid-twenties inertia and queer romance.

albums.title: Ryan Pollie
albums.label: Anti-
albums.description: The L.A.-based singer-songwriter recorded the first album under his own name from the trenches of chemotherapy and a breakup, but the result is an exercise in gentle vulnerability and winsome grace.

albums.title: Sombrou Dúvida
albums.label: OAR
albums.description: The Brazilian psych band transition from the oft-playful homage and stage-ready jams of previous releases to a serious attempt at tight, kaleidoscopic grooves.

albums.title: Water
albums.label: Fire Talk
albums.description: The Chicago indie-rock trio scrape away 90 percent of what goes into a guitar album and come away with something effortless and uncomplicated.

albums.title: Beauty Marks
albums.label: Beauty Marks
albums.description: The singer’s seventh album moves between frothy pop-R&B and stale empowerment anthems that leave her talents largely underused.

albums.title: Sings Music for Daydreaming
albums.label: Salinas
albums.description: Sam Cook-Parrott returns to his beginnings as a solo artist, an experiment that yields playful piano compositions and introspective lyricism.

albums.title: I Am Easy to Find
albums.label: 4AD
albums.description: With a cast of female vocalists guiding and redirecting the songs, the National’s eighth album is their largest, longest, and most daring.

albums.label: Goner
albums.description: The Memphis post-punk band’s third album wages guerrilla warfare against the patriarchal surveillance state.

albums.title: Shea Butter Baby
albums.label: Dreamville
albums.description: The debut album from the neo-soul singer-songwriter is driven by warm funk and soul and has the healing familiarity of hanging out on the couch commiserating with a best friend.

albums.title: LEGACY! LEGACY!
albums.label: Jagjaguwar
albums.description: The Chicago artist marries political commentary with deep introspection, resulting in a richly composed R&B album about the echoes of the past and the promise of the future.

albums.title: Divided by Darkness
albums.label: 20 Buck Spin
albums.description: Led by young oracle Nate Garrett, the second album from the Arizona heavy metal band carries the torch of their forebears and revives the genre with impressive songwriting and ambition.

albums.title: Hexhammaren
albums.label: Southern Lord
albums.description: Eighteen years into its existence, the Swedish band continues to find ways to make a familiar fusion of melodic death metal, crust punk, and d-beat sound fresh.

albums.title: Age Hasn’t Spoiled You
albums.label: Carpark
albums.description: On their first new album in eight years, the Toronto punk band tear down everything they’ve ever known about making music and rebuild themselves for the better.

albums.title: PROTO
albums.label: 4AD
albums.description: Created with a choral ensemble and a nascent AI, the Berlin-based electronic musician’s third album is a meditation on community, technology, and the future of, and beyond, the human species.

albums.title: LOVE&JETT
albums.label: Third Man
albums.description: On their 13th album, the Japanese rock’n’rollers reaffirm what they do best: making the once-rebellious sounds of surf, rockabilly, and CBGB punk seem dangerous again.

albums.title: Young Enough
albums.label: Barsuk
albums.description: The Brooklyn band’s second record is bigger and darker, amplifying their ’80s new-wave sparkle into ecstatic triumph.

albums.title: Wheeltappers and Shunters
albums.label: Domino
albums.description: The art-punk eccentrics’ first album in six years is a woozy celebration of Britain’s sleazy past, and it sounds like nobody other than Clinic.

albums.title: Phantom Forest
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: The ever-ambitious Toronto composer tackles big themes on her environmentally minded song cycle, but keeps things refreshingly immediate and small-scale.

albums.title: Stolen Youth
albums.label: Blacksmith
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Mac Miller and Vince Staples’ 2013 mixtape, a fledgling but important document of freeform creativity.

albums.title: DOLO 4
albums.label: Future Times
albums.description: The Washington D.C. producer’s drum tracks are bold, burly numbers that move with abandon. Even without melodies, no two sound remotely alike.

albums.title: are SING SINCK, SING
albums.label: Constellation
albums.description: This joint project from Efrim Manuel Menuck and Kevin Doria has an overwhelming radiance to match Menuck's work in Godspeed You! Black Emperor.

albums.title: Failed Entertainment
albums.label: Run for Cover
albums.description: The O.C. hardcore band level up their sound on their second album but remain gruff, guttural, and ferocious.

albums.title: Eat My Pussy Again
albums.label: Machine Entertainment Group
albums.description: On the sequel to last year’s Eat My Pussy, the Chicago rapper’s songwriting is at times more brazen and at others more introspective.

albums.title: Here Comes the Cowboy
albums.label: Mac’s Record Label
albums.description: The latest from the indie rock rapscallion is an often pretty, occasionally frustrating record that was recorded quickly, but still sounds labored over.

albums.title: Emerald Valley
albums.label: Kill Rock Stars
albums.description: The second album from Corin Tucker and Peter Buck’s alt-rock supergroup can’t match the urgency of pre-apocalyptic protest.

albums.title: Anoyo
albums.label: Kranky
albums.description: The follow-up to last year’s Konoyo—recorded, like its predecessor, with a Japanese gagaku ensemble—functions as a counterbalance to that album: a kind of photo negative, more subdued but no less overwhelming.

albums.title: A Thousand Leaves
albums.label: Geffen
albums.description: After a string of surprisingly and contentiously accessible albums, SY attempted to balance their pop curiosity with its experimental instincts.

albums.title: EVOL
albums.label: SST
albums.description: The core elements of Sonic Youth were still scattered all over their 1986 album, but its dark and sordid sound brilliantly captured the essence of an “underground” band coming to life.

albums.title: Experimental Jet Set, Trash and No Star
albums.label: Geffen
albums.description: Somewhere between a sorta-pop stab and pointedly hook-free, SY’s eighth album is ambivalent and shaggy by design.

albums.title: Washing Machine
albums.label: Geffen
albums.description: SY’s ninth record marked a new era for the band. While they didn’t leave the freaky stuff behind entirely, they started serving it up with a spoonful of sugar.

albums.title: Sister
albums.label: SST
albums.description: At turns paranoid and explosive, Sister marks a climactic finish to the early albums that carved the New York band’s sound into punk and alternative culture.

albums.title: The Dots
albums.label: Marathon Artists
albums.description: The English six-piece’s debut is a high-wire act combining jazz fusion, disco rhythms, and high-gloss art rock.

albums.title: Sli’merre
albums.label: Paradise East
albums.description: On one of the best rapper/producer collaborations of the year, the Atlanta MC remains a perfect fit for Pi’erre Bourne’s weird and heavy beats.

albums.title: there is no Other
albums.label: Nonesuch
albums.description: The singer and multi-instrumentalist joins jazz musician Francesco Turrisi for a thoughtful and ambitious album that spans opera, Appalachian bluegrass, gospel, and traditional Italian music.

albums.title: KOD
albums.label: TF
albums.description: The BandGang crew is at the center of Detroit’s rap renaissance, and Lonnie Bands’ latest is a great showcase of its sound and energy.

albums.title: Poltergeist Slim
albums.label: Lost Appeal
albums.description: The Baltimore rapper switches between singing, rapping, mumbling until there's almost no difference between the words and the beats.

albums.title: Voicemails
albums.label: Winter's Diary
albums.description: The Chicago singer/rapper known for her diaristic, relationship-dissecting R&B builds her new mixtape around inherently private and frequently drama-filled voice messages.

albums.title: Enderness
albums.label: Fat Possum
albums.description: On his first album in eight years, the Alabama singer-songwriter turns from folk music to synths, drum machines, and internet speak, but the sorrow at the heart of his music is timeless.

albums.title: YU
albums.label: Caroline International
albums.description: The smoky-voiced R&B multi-instrumentalist charts the ups and downs of a relationship with the help of guests like Jay Electronica and Floating Points.

albums.title: Active Listening: Night on Earth
albums.label: Get Better
albums.description: The Philadelphia quartet’s full-length debut showcases their defiant brand of noise-pop, a big rainbow of chaos.

albums.title: U.F.O.F.
albums.label: 4AD
albums.description: The third album from the Brooklyn quartet is an intimate and surreal experience, a true masterpiece of folk music from a band working together at the highest level.

albums.title: Useless Coordinates
albums.label: Captured Tracks
albums.description: The ferocious Leeds trio treat post-punk like a game of Tetris, joyfully flipping and rearranging the elements into new patterns.

albums.title: This Mess Is a Place
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: The Seattle band’s fourth record, their first for Sub Pop, is forward-thinking pop-punk that successfully—albeit narrowly—manages to dodge the obvious pitfalls.

albums.title: Your Need
albums.label: 2MR
albums.description: Crafted in tandem with the Gost Zvuk affiliate Flaty, the Moscow producer’s second album balances streamlined electro pop with a hint of rave mayhem.

albums.title: Selected Ambient Works Volume II
albums.label: Warp
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit an album that changed ambient music forever.

albums.title: KingMaker
albums.label: Blue Note
albums.description: The 23-year-old vibraphonist shines on his debut album with an approach that feels sly and mysterious; he also proves himself a sharp bandleader attuned to the importance of group dynamics.

albums.title: Anger Management
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: Just 18 minutes with Kenny Beats shows Rico Nasty evolving. She remains one of the heaviest hitters in the no-rules arena of rap.

albums.title: Night Pass
albums.label: Infinite Companion
albums.description: After being dropped from their label, the Portland duo flout despair with a wall of nostalgic, over-the-top sound.

albums.title: Covered N Blood
albums.label: Glizzy Gang
albums.description: As with all of his best work, the D.C. rapper’s latest finds him grappling with trauma, haunted by the specter of death at every turn.

albums.title: Violet Street
albums.label: Loma Vista
albums.description: The L.A. band has long carried the flag for a particular strain of SoCal indie, but the follow-up to 2016’s fashionably yearning Sunlit Youth sounds both more personal and more timeless.

albums.title: Scatter the Rats
albums.label: Blackheart
albums.description: The grunge act's first LP in 20 years fails to summon the revolutionary fire that made them such a force of nature in the mid-'90s.

albums.title: Father of the Bride
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: Vampire Weekend return with a shaggy, sprawling double album all about rebirth, contentment, and the reclamation of light.

albums.title: Green and Gray
albums.label: Exploding in Sound
albums.description: The seventh album from the Boston noise-rock band revels in a heightened level of studio ambition without losing its snarling ferocity.

albums.title: Preacher to the Streets
albums.label: Sick Wid It
albums.description: The Sacramento rapper spends most of his second album conscience-stricken, trying to explain the difference between being immoral and being corrupted.

albums.title: Run Fast Sleep Naked
albums.label: Downtown
albums.description: The second album from the musician formerly known as Chet Faker is at once overstuffed and underwhelming.

albums.title: Mettavolution
albums.label: ATO
albums.description: The Mexican duo’s first album in five years applies their customary virtuoso fusion of classical guitar and contemporary rock to six short originals and a 19-minute cover of Pink Floyd’s “Echoes.”

albums.title: ARIZONA BABY
albums.label: Question Everything
albums.description: The BROCKHAMPTON star’s latest solo album is an often powerful document by a queer artist who has weathered life’s bruises.

albums.title: Music for Donuts EP
albums.label: Thrilling Living
albums.description: The Mississippi punk four-piece celebrate slugs, butter, lard, chewing gum—the important things.

albums.title: LuvHz EP
albums.label: Luminelle
albums.description: The Mexican American electro-pop artist’s debut EP, produced with Panda Bear collaborator Rusty Santos, is a restless patchwork of genre-smashing sounds.

albums.title: Take Off Mode
albums.label: Planet Mu
albums.description: As he returns to the intricate polyrhythms and hypnotic vocal chops of footwork, the Chicago producer’s approach remains almost single-minded in its focus.

albums.title: Oh My God
albums.label: Dead Oceans
albums.description: Morby's spare fifth solo album conjures memories of gospel-phase Dylan.

albums.title: What Life
albums.label: Tiny Engines
albums.description: The Oakland quintet’s debut album is a spirited indie-emo blend driven by intricate underlying themes, channeling a slew of influences even as it exists in a space of its own.

albums.title: Organism EP
albums.label: Majia
albums.description: The Chicago producer plays with oceanic imagery and a collage-like swirl of influences on a four-track EP that spills over the limits of club music’s conventions.

albums.title: In League With Dragons
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: John Darnielle explores the humanity of wizards, sports legends, Ozzy Osbourne, and other folk heroes and beacons of hope.

albums.title: CrasH Talk
albums.label: Top Dawg
albums.description: The L.A. rapper’s latest is comforting if not entirely exciting. It finds Q and host of guests in a good place with nothing to prove.

albums.title: You Can't Sit With Us
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: On their first project in five years, Saba's crew sounds like a bunch of friends at the lunch table trying to out-rap each other for fun.

albums.title: For the Throne (Music Inspired by the HBO Series Game of Thrones)
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: Instead of nerding out or having any kind of fun, a host of pop stars turn in a dour, stone-faced compilation of songs inspired by the ubiquitous fantasy saga.

albums.title: Itekoma Hits
albums.label: Damnably
albums.description: The Kyoto punk quartet unleashes a tornado of defiance at the prospect of romance, monotonous office work, and people who feel entitled to women’s time.

albums.title: Love + Fear
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: Marina Diamandis’ first album since shedding her “Marina and the Diamonds” identity slides from affecting poetry to cold calculation.

albums.title: I Need a New War
albums.label: Partisan
albums.description: The Hold Steady frontman's solo work continues its twilit exploration of frail hopes, wasted lives, and quiet battles against despair.

albums.title: The Jewel in the Lotus
albums.label: Universal Records
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit a confluence of jazz’s past and present, an unsung modernist classic from 1974.

albums.title: The Secret of Letting Go
albums.label: Cooking Vinyl
albums.description: The veteran trip-hoppers once stood out by virtue of their idiosyncratic sound, but two decades later, they’ve resorted to playing things frustratingly straight.

albums.title: Exit
albums.label: Sleeping Giant Glossolalia
albums.description: Always one for gender subversion, the Toronto songwriter invites a cast of men to sing her songs, resulting in some of the project’s most deviously playful music ever.

albums.title: Seeing Other People
albums.label: ‎Jagjaguwar‎
albums.description: The troubled outfit's latest album bitterly recounts the Decline of Foxygen.

albums.title: Fly Times, Vol. 1: The Good Fly Young
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: One of the most quietly influential rappers of the last ten years maintains cruising altitude.

albums.title: Designer
albums.label: 4AD
albums.description: The third album from the impressionistic New Zealand singer-songwriter eludes easy classification, which makes her delicately built and beautifully rendered songs all the more alluring.

albums.title: Blood
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: Featuring collaborations with Skrillex and Jamie xx, the West Coast transplant’s debut album flips the chamber-folk cello of her debut EP into a contemporary, decidedly Los Angeles hybrid sound.

albums.title: Fishing for Fishies
albums.label: ATO
albums.description: The idiosyncratic Australian band’s most streamlined album to date is risky only in that it is their first to be downright boring.

albums.title: Truck Music
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: Christopher Taylor’s genre-colliding mutant pop proves everything can fit if you don’t give it enough time to sound wrong.

albums.title: 2nd
albums.label: Dots Per Inch
albums.description: The Queens-based songwriter offers nervy lo-fi synth pop that buzzes with everyday anxiety.

albums.title: A Quiet Farwell, Twenty Sixteen to Twenty Eighteen
albums.label: Grand Closing
albums.description: The New York producer’s ambitious album is a dark, surreal, jazzy collage about resistance and hope.

albums.title: Life Metal
albums.label: Southern Lord
albums.description: The titanic drone metal duo returns with Steve Albini for an enormous, meticulous, back-to-basics album that shows just how compelling those basics can be.

albums.title: Jade Bird
albums.label: Glassnote
albums.description: The British singer-songwriter’s debut fortifies her early promise as a confident young voice of country-charred rock

albums.title: Stockholm Marathon
albums.label: Studio Barnhus
albums.description: The Swedish producer’s second full-length album is streaked with bright, bold melodies yet marked with a lightness of touch that’s unusual in dance music.

albums.title: Internet Arms
albums.label: Polyvinyl
albums.description: On his third release as the genre-bending alter ego Diane Coffee, Shaun Fleming explores the trap of online intimacy.

albums.title: Wooh Dang
albums.label: Superpuma
albums.description: The hermetic Swedish bedroom-pop auteur spins out songs of electric uplift and dreamy solitude on his first international release.

albums.title: Still Summer in the Projects
albums.label: Alamo
albums.description: The incarcerated Watts rapper’s latest release, a collaboration with Mustard, is exultant and Dionysian.

albums.title: Absolute Zero
albums.label: Thirty Tigers
albums.description: Jazz fusion, chamber pop, modern classical—if your awareness of Hornsby stops at the lite-FM radio dial, prepare to be disoriented.

albums.title: Family Not a Group
albums.label: Def Jam
albums.description: The Bay Area rap crew’s collaboration with Hit-Boy catches them in a moment of furious flux.

albums.title: I Love You. It’s a Fever Dream.
albums.label: Rivers/Birds
albums.description: As he explores the banalities and oddities of tour, Kristian Matsson seeks answers to a bigger question: How best should he move through the landscape of his life?

albums.title: Industrial Accident: The Story of Wax Trax! Records
albums.label: Wax Trax!
albums.description: The soundtrack to a documentary about the flagship indie label features early material from Ministry, My Life With the Thrill Kill Kult, and other industrial icons.

albums.title: Akron, Ohio
albums.label: Tee Pee
albums.description: The Black Keys’ Patrick Carney and longtime indie-rock journeyman John Petkovic team up on a graceless, unsubtle pastiche of rock’n’roll indulgence.

albums.title: Raw Honey
albums.label: Mexican Summer
albums.description: L.A.-based auteur Michael Collins crafts a pristine portrait of early-’70s AM radio by taking inspiration not only from the period’s definitive artists, but its discarded pop detritus, too.

albums.title: Cuz I Love You
albums.label: Nice Life
albums.description: The shiny soul-pop of Lizzo’s major label debut is something of a thesis on internalized and externalized confidence—so much so that the music can feel like a means to a greater end.

albums.title: Covert Contracts
albums.label: Get Better
albums.description: On their debut album, the anarchic Philly hardcore trio muster a raw, thrilling assault against complacency.

albums.title: Floral Shoppe
albums.label: Beer On The Rug
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the banal ennui of vaporwave with its pioneering document from 2011.

albums.title: Intellexual
albums.label: Fantasy
albums.description: The Social Experiment members reintroduce themselves as earnest singer-songwriters, but their post-genre mashup production produces more vibes than actual songs.

albums.title: A Black Market Album
albums.label: Sunthings
albums.description: The Belgian beatmaker ups his game, roping in guest vocalists Siifu, Spote Breeze, and Mamoyo on a breezy, 22-minute album that, at its best, recalls golden-age Slum Village.

albums.title: Orange
albums.label: New Amsterdam
albums.description: The Pulitzer Prize-winning composer returns with a wild and free-ranging collection of chamber pieces.

albums.title: ~~~ EP
albums.label: Leaving
albums.description: The Los Angeles-based ambient musician’s EP is restful and restorative, using lo-fi tones and textures to create a work that subtly transcends.

albums.title: Homecoming: The Live Album
albums.label: Parkwood
albums.description: Beyoncé’s historic Coachella set is preserved as a stunning live album that captures an artist at her peak, flexing her catalog and shining a light on the genius of black artists that came before her.

albums.title: No Dados
albums.label: Suah Sounds
albums.description: The North Carolinian singer comes roaring back from multiple strokes to deliver a raw and thrilling solo debut.

albums.title: Utopía
albums.label: Sony Latin
albums.description: The Dominican bachata king follows his chart-topping Golden with a celebration of the genre's rich history, lifting up his forebears and revealing his musical DNA.

albums.title: Grim Town
albums.label: Rough Trade
albums.description: On her second album, the Northern Irish musician graduates from lonesome singer-songwriter to bold art-pop auteur; her growing confidence translates to emotionally probing songs of startling candor.

albums.title: High Highs to Low Lows
albums.label: Keep It On the Lolo
albums.description: Don’t be fooled by the of-the-moment pop sound: The 24-year-old singer’s debut album is the showcase for a refreshingly original perspective.

albums.title: Invitation
albums.label: Western Vinyl
albums.description: Three albums in, the Oregon-based multi-instrumentalist still sounds as though she’s composing music en plein air.

albums.title: Laughing Matter
albums.label: Drag City
albums.description: As they pare away at their sound, Wand move further away from psych-rock and closer to true psychedelia.

albums.title: Where Polly People Go to Read
albums.label: AWAL
albums.description: The debut from the it-boy bedroom pop auteur manages to feel both excitingly personal and a bit disingenuous.

albums.title: Let’s Try the After Vol. 2 EP
albums.label: Arts & Crafts
albums.description: On the second half of their paired EPs, the Toronto collective settles into comfortable territory that soon proves stale.

albums.title: I Must Be the Devil
albums.label: Bel-Air Glamour Records
albums.description: The former múm frontwoman steps out with a set of airy, orchestral folk that resembles early Kate Bush or Joanna Newsom.

albums.title: Dogrel
albums.label: Partisan
albums.description: The steely Dublin post-punk band infuse the bitterness and rage of The Fall with punch-drunk romanticism.

albums.title: Rose Gold
albums.label: Pretty Wavy
albums.description: With low-stakes dance-pop that simmers just beneath the surface, the artist formerly known as Kitty Pryde attempts to transcend her internet bubble.

albums.title: LSD
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: Diplo, Sia, and Labrinth combine forces for an album of truly forgettable pop music that is too tired to be wired.

albums.title: Song Feel
albums.label: Night Slugs
albums.description: Nearly a decade after helping revolutionize the sound of UK bass, the veteran Night Slugs producer struggles to maintain the radicalism of his early music on his debut album.

albums.title: Imperial Flood
albums.label: Different Circles
albums.description: A pioneer of what he once termed “weightless” bass music moves toward the outer fringes of club aesthetics on an album imbued with the apocalyptic overtones of sci-fi and speculative fiction.

albums.title: WARMER
albums.label: dBpm
albums.description: Recorded at the same time as last year’s WARM, the companion album showcases Tweedy’s aged songwriting that continues to be humble and revealing.

albums.title: Everybody Split
albums.label: Hobbies Galore
albums.description: The unassuming Melbourne five-piece build garage-jangle guitars and blunt-edged harmonies into strangely hypnotic arrangements that feel simultaneously long and short.

albums.title: Sulphur English
albums.label: Relapse
albums.description: The Richmond metal quintet’s fourth album is its most intense and most rewarding: a virtual symphony of pummeling, dissonant riffs sculpted with unrelenting precision.

albums.title: MAP OF THE SOUL : PERSONA
albums.label: BigHit Entertainment
albums.description: The biggest K-pop group in the world try to move their sound forward but spend too much time leaning on their past.

albums.title: All Time Present
albums.label: No Quarter
albums.description: Accompanied by a handful of his Solar Motel Band collaborators, the Philadelphia guitarist seeks the third path between classic-rock peaks and floating experimentalism.

albums.title: Mandatory Reality
albums.label: Eremite
albums.description: The Chicago bassist and guimbri player turns in a minimalist mountain of an album, one whose slow pace and gradual changes prove unusually mesmerizing, even sublime.

albums.title: Who Is Jill Scott?: Words and Sounds, Vol. 1
albums.label: Hidden Beach
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the 2000 debut of Jill Scott, a neo-soul chronicle that brought love and sex to the everywoman.

albums.title: Personal Rock
albums.label: Faitiche
albums.description: Twenty years ago, the German electronic musician Jan Jelinek’s tools were rustier, his loops lumpier, yet his vision for a transcendent music of digital failure was very much intact.

albums.title: Only You Can See It
albums.label: Carpark
albums.description: The Brooklyn-based pop polymath writes, performs, records, mixes, and engineers her most ambitious and electrifying collection of songs to date.

albums.title: Essentials
albums.label: Fire Talk
albums.description: The Brooklyn post-punk trio’s debut full-length reveals an instinct for scrappy, empathetic songwriting.

albums.title: El Chan
albums.label: Deutsche Grammophon
albums.description: Indie rock’s preeminent classical composer offers a selection of piano pieces from minimal, to rousing, to a heroic concerto for two pianos backed by a full orchestra.

albums.title: Ventura
albums.label: 12 Tone
albums.description: After the hard left turn of Oxnard, Paak sinks back into the bubbly smooth grooves that got him noticed.

albums.title: Brutalism
albums.label: Anti-
albums.description: The latest album from the Drums—now just frontman Jonny Pierce—is his most honest and most unvarnished.

albums.title: No Geography
albums.label: Astralwerks
albums.description: Blending psychedelic sensory overload with riotous club bangers, the shape-shifting electronic duo’s ninth album is their most entertaining in years.

albums.title: Ribbons
albums.label: Warp
albums.description: After drifting into ambient drone on his last album, Stephen Wilkins returns to his chill, bucolic stomping grounds.

albums.title: Long Story Short
albums.label: Below System Records
albums.description: With a nonchalant flow, Eto paints a grim and familiar world where only survival-of-the-fittest tactics prevail alongside sumptuous production from Superior.

albums.title: Kill This Love EP
albums.label: YG
albums.description: The K-pop girl group’s enjoyable but weirdly dated EP offers a mishmash of EDM styles ahead of their big Coachella debut.

albums.title: What a Boost
albums.label: Memphis Industries
albums.description: Like a half-forgotten dream, the English singer-songwriter’s combination of minimalist blues and free-floating jazz feels just out of reach.

albums.title: Even in the Tremor
albums.label: Ba Da Bing Records
albums.description: The Brooklyn singer-songwriter’s third album takes a microscope to the messy business of being human, finding revelatory moments of empathy in the smallest everyday details.

albums.title: Signals Bulletin
albums.label: Faitiche
albums.description: The German experimental musician teams up with a Japanese organist prone to taping down the keys of his instrument; together, they conjure massive, buzzing slabs of drone.

albums.title: Free Spirit
albums.label: Right Hand Music Group
albums.description: The second album from the historically inoffensive singer is another genreless collection of safe choices for a pop star in the making.

albums.title: Saturday the 14th EP
albums.label: Father/Daughter
albums.description: The Canadian power-pop duo take underappreciated micro-genres for a test drive in a bid to make music that’s as funny as their lyrics.

albums.title: Pantame
albums.label: Everlasting
albums.description: The unclassifiable Spanish duo span 1990s-inspired alternative rock, glitching electronic percussion, mournful Andalusian flamenco, and the dread empty spaces of post-punk.

albums.title: Just Another Gangsta
albums.label: Cash Money
albums.description: A decade-plus after splitting from Cash Money, Juvenile reunites with Birdman for a shockingly strong late-career-reunion record.

albums.title: Ambitions
albums.label: Smalltown Supersound
albums.description: The Norwegian producer rediscovers the simple joy in his space-disco sound on his most cohesive LP in years.

albums.title: وين كنيت بي ١١​/​٩؟? “Where Were You on 9​/​11​?​” EP
albums.label: Toxic State
albums.description: The New York agit-punks’ latest EP is another menacing, distorted call to arms.

albums.title: Haunted Items
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: Four short EPs from Greta Kline feature the singer-songwriter at a piano singing her detailed and deeply felt songs with newfound conviction.

albums.title: The Shape of Your Name
albums.label: Next Door
albums.description: With a delivery as authentically conversational as her songwriting, the Toronto-based musician treats even the broadest themes on a person-to-person scale.

albums.title: We Need to Talk
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: A songwriter best known for her work penning hits for Ariana Grande, Khalid, and Panic! At the Disco claims the spotlight for herself, but she struggles to define what makes her unique.

albums.title: The Seduction of Kansas
albums.label: Sister Polygon
albums.description: The Washington, D.C. band’s second album is dense with ambiguities, sacrificing their debut’s quotable one-liners in favor of character sketches about the everyday banality of evil.

albums.title: Dog Whistle
albums.label: Loma Vista
albums.description: The hardcore trio grapples with the ongoing death of their NYC home in their most cohesive work to date.

albums.title: Hiding Places
albums.label: Backwoodz Studioz
albums.description: On his bracing collaboration with L.A. producer Kenny Segal, woods gets painfully real about his fears, his doubts and irritations, and even his mortality.

albums.title: The Slider
albums.label: Spirit Records
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the peak of Marc Bolan’s career, the extravagant and near-perfect The Slider.

albums.title: Deserted
albums.label: Bloodshot
albums.description: The legendary band's first full-length in eight years is a besotted concept album about the desert, once again revealing the depth of their imagination.

albums.title: Thalassa
albums.label: Sargent House
albums.description: The Io Echo singer’s debut solo album expands on the gothy, mythical undertones of her earlier work.

albums.title: Natural Facts
albums.label: Beyond Beyond is Beyond
albums.description: The second album from these New Jersey-based Grateful Dead devotees is still indebted to familiar reference points, but finds the band pushing to expand.

albums.title: Autoclave
albums.label: Dischord
albums.description: Mary Timony and Christina Billotte’s early band operated for less than two years, but the appeal of their jagged, math-rock-adjacent punk has lasted decades longer.

albums.title: Titanic Rising
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: Natalie Mering’s fourth album is a grand, sentimental ode to living and loving in the shadow of doom. It is her most ambitious and complex work yet.

albums.title: Crackheads Live Longer Than Vegans
albums.label: New Deal Collectives
albums.description: The prolific Chicago rapper’s recent project is his loosest, funniest, and most invigorating to date, full of hard left turns and sly wit.

albums.title: Triad
albums.label: Presto!?
albums.description: On his second album with producer Palmistry, the elusive London vocalist delivers a surreal blend of singing, rapping, and voiceover narration.

albums.title: Morbid Stuff
albums.label: Rise
albums.description: On their long-awaited follow-up to their breakthrough sophomore effort, the pop-punk band embraces the liberating power of anger.

albums.title: In the Shape of a Storm
albums.label: Mama Bird
albums.description: The singer-songwriter’s intimate 14th studio album strips down to spare acoustic guitar, lingering on the moments when the buzzing world around all but fades away.

albums.title: Symphony of Sorrowful Songs
albums.label: Domino
albums.description: The Portishead singer and conductor (and film-music icon) Krzysztof Penderecki deliver a surprisingly disquieting take on Górecki’s canonical symphony, a piece so familiar that it’s often taken for granted.

albums.title: Supermarket
albums.label: Def Jam
albums.description: From clumsy stadium rock to unacceptable ska, Logic’s overly ambitious album is a painful slog.

albums.title: Spying Through a Keyhole
albums.label: Rhino
albums.description: This assemblage of strange outtakes and demos—including what may be the first demo of "Space Oddity"—find Bowie in his tentative folkie phase, about to blast off.

albums.title: Fucking Bliss
albums.label: Run for Cover
albums.description: The album Sam Ray envisioned as his last begs close listening, but punctuated with impenetrable harshness, it is almost prohibitively scattered.

albums.title: The Big Freeze
albums.label: Don Giovanni
albums.description: On her fifth solo album, the New York musician both evolves as a singer-songwriter and grows in confidence, addressing heavy emotional themes with candor and grace.

albums.title: Lifelike
albums.label: Trouble in Mind
albums.description: On their second release, the Disappears alums turn mercurial, whipping their habitual post-rock into more impressionistic, unpredictable forms.

albums.title: Crux
albums.label: Modern Static
albums.description: The Long Island prog-metal band bursts with enthusiasm and rabid energy, as if Mastodon's apocalyptic visions were replaced with cosmic wonder.

albums.title: You’re the Man
albums.label: UMG
albums.description: Recorded in 1972, this largely unreleased “lost” album is a fascinating glimpse into what one of the great 20th-century artists strategically allowed the culture to see.

albums.title: Tuez-Les Tous
albums.label: Soul Assassins
albums.description: The cryptic and elusive New Jersey rapper teams with DJ Muggs, who is enjoying a career renaissance as the go-to producer for glowering, throwback East Coast street rap.

albums.title: Agora
albums.label: Touch
albums.description: The experimental musician’s sweeping, ambient album works in small, fascinating ways from moment to moment but has a cumulative force that is unlike anything he’s done in years.

albums.title: The State Between Us
albums.label: Accidental
albums.description: The producer and DJ’s guest-packed “Brexit album” conjures a great sprawl of humor and tragedy that makes for Herbert’s richest album in years.

albums.title: A Guide To Being A Partying Freshman
albums.label: 8Jency
albums.description: With its tinny mix, infectious chant raps, and Fruity Loops-style beats, this Texas dance rap king's debut has a refreshingly unforced charm.

albums.title: Guns
albums.label: Mello Music Group
albums.description: Quelle Chris examines how words, fear, and skin color are weaponized, and how one’s community can dictate their relationship to firearms.

albums.title: English Rose
albums.label: Virgin EMI
albums.description: At turns soulful and spirited, the debut album from the British singer balances rabble-rousing political energy with a nonchalant chumminess.

albums.title: Mise En Abyme
albums.label: Constellation
albums.description: French-British producer Jean Cousin draws despair and wonder from within the vast unfeeling of digital communication.

albums.title: Ilana (The Creator)
albums.label: Sahel Sounds
albums.description: The Tuareg musician’s first full-band studio album is an incandescent set of guitar music with a spontaneous, celebratory air—and a latent urgency reflecting the region’s very real difficulties.

albums.title: Damita Jo
albums.label: Virgin
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Janet Jackson’s 2004 album, a lush and preeminently sex-positive album that deserves a reappraisal.

albums.title: The Quanta Series
albums.label: K Á R Y Y N / ANTEVASIN
albums.description: The Syrian American producer lingers with grief and horror on her past while the music accelerates into the future.

albums.title: Cruising OST
albums.label: Waxwork
albums.description: The soundtrack for William Friedkin's controversial and problematic 1980 thriller features a stunning array of hardcore punk and hard funk, including rare songs by the Germs.

albums.title: Late Night Tales
albums.label: Late Night Tales
albums.description: The UK DJ and producer taps the depths of his record collection in a gorgeous, moody mix that runs through ambient, jazz, psych pop, and vintage soul.

albums.title: Deforming Lobes
albums.label: Drag City
albums.description: Taken from a three-night stint in L.A. and recorded by Steve Albini, this live album disavows almost all the rules of the form.

albums.title: Antidotes 1 EP
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: On her debut solo EP, the cellist and vocalist explores a vaporous middle ground between R&B and chamber pop.

albums.title: It’s Real
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: The second album from Mary Timony's band suggests that the hard rock of debut Rips was no dalliance: This time, they mine the denim-clad AOR of Billy Squier and Foreigner.

albums.title: The World Is Yours 2
albums.label: Interscope
albums.description: The perpetual Atlanta B-lister sounds like a guest on his own albums, outshone by features from Gunna, Young Thug, Offset, Big Sean, and more.

albums.title: When We All Fall Asleep, Where Do We Go?
albums.label: Darkroom
albums.description: The debut album from the meteoric pop star lives in a world of its own: gothic, bass-heavy, at turns daring and quite beautiful.

albums.title: Cosmic Wind
albums.label: Lion Babe Music LLC
albums.description: The second album from the singer/producer duo aims for laid-back but stalls out at sleepy.

albums.title: Ancestral Recall
albums.label: Ropeadope
albums.description: The New Orleans trumpeter and composer’s latest album continues to stretch the language of jazz, further embracing electronics and an increasingly broad approach to rhythm.

albums.title: This (Is What I Wanted to Tell You)
albums.label: Merge / City Slang
albums.description: Kurt Wagner uses restraint with a masterful touch on his latest record, applying a light vocodor touch to his voice to illuminate the intimacy of his understated songwriting.

albums.title: Bad Habits
albums.label: XO
albums.description: The Punjabi-Canadian MC returns from his eight-week retirement with a droning collection of listless would-be bangers.

albums.title: New Rain Duets
albums.label: Three Lobed
albums.description: On their collaborative record, Superchunk frontman Mac McCaughan and harpist Mary Lattimore lead each other through misty, evocative improvisations.

albums.title: Cows on Hourglass Pond
albums.label: Domino
albums.description: Dave Portner’s latest solo excursion stakes out a middle ground between the exterior and interior, between direct melodies and the oblique music they float on.

albums.title: Ancestor Boy
albums.label: CONCORDIA
albums.description: The singer-producer’s debut album splits the difference between proudly rootless and profoundly lost.

albums.title: Capsule Losing Contact
albums.label: Numero Group
albums.description: Duster’s debut was barely a blip on the radar—and then, like a comet, they reappeared. A comprehensive box set from Numero Group revisits the spacey, unassuming band with new perspective.

albums.title: We Wanna Be Hyp-No-Tized
albums.label: Nine Mile
albums.description: Clunky lyrics and inept political analysis hinder Scott Kannberg’s most enjoyable solo album to date.

albums.title: Bodyguard
albums.label: TT Label
albums.description: The co-founder of Oakland’s Club Chai merges samples of Turkish and Middle Eastern music with club beats on an EP that casts a skeptical eye on club culture’s promise of personal liberation.

albums.title: Eraserland
albums.label: Dead Oceans
albums.description: Fusing post-punk touchstones with his heartland-rock heroes, a reinvigorated Timothy Showalter comes back to the light.

albums.title: Hi This Is Flume
albums.label: Future Classic
albums.description: The Australian electronic-music producer and streaming behemoth signals a shift in his approach with a surprise mixtape featuring appearances from JPEGMAFIA and SOPHIE.

albums.title: Le Mal
albums.label: Boiled Records
albums.description: On their second proper album, the already-bizarre Quebec experimentalists splice and reformulate their DNA to become even more aggressively strange.

albums.title: My Finest Work Yet
albums.label: Loma Vista
albums.description: After a string of releases that sometimes felt like hearing Bird think himself in circles, the singer-songwriter relaxes into his most plainly and darkly funny album in a long time.

albums.title: Significant Changes
albums.label: Ninja Tune
albums.description: The Canadian DJ, producer, and marine biologist bridges worlds on her debut album, weaving orcas’ songs and conservationist messages into deep-diving tracks aimed at inclusive dancefloors.

albums.title: Songs of Faith: Aretha Gospel
albums.label: Geffen
albums.description: The very first recordings of Aretha Franklin, captured in Detroit when she was all of 14 years old, are remastered and offer a window into the early sounds of a genius.

albums.title: On the Line
albums.label: Warner Bros.
albums.description: The fourth album from the California indie rock icon features some of her strongest songwriting, sung gorgeously and told with piercing detail.

albums.title: When the Pawn...
albums.label: Sony
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Fiona Apple’s second album, full of diamond-sharp writing that mines the depths of her psyche and emotion.

albums.title: Matamoros
albums.label: 12XU
albums.description: USA/Mexico are sludgy, nasty, and unclassifiable, meaning they fit perfectly into Austin's coterie of noise-rock misfits.

albums.title: I Trawl the Megahertz
albums.label: Sony UK
albums.description: This lost Prefab Sprout album, previously issued as a Paddy McAloon solo LP, finds the singer receding into a vivid dream world unlike anything in his catalog.

albums.title: Dreaming the Dark
albums.label: Dero Arcade
albums.description: On her new album, Tamaryn aims for sky-high '80s-goth melodrama.

albums.title: DJ-Kicks
albums.label: !K7
albums.description: On her first commercial mix album, the producer crafts an unbroken stretch of shapeshifting grooves and psychedelic fireworks.

albums.title: Run Wild Run Free
albums.label: Top Dawg
albums.description: After snagging everyone’s ear on Kendrick’s “LOVE.,” the 22-year-old TDE signee Zacari struggles to hold our attention.

albums.title: Inside the Rose
albums.label: BMG
albums.description: On their fourth album, the visionary English experimenters conjure a sinister and beguiling new world.

albums.title: Miss Universe
albums.label: ATO
albums.description: The rapturous debut from the British singer-songwriter takes adventurous pop-rock crucibles to new heights with her illusory songwriting and stunning voice.

albums.title: Electric on the Eel
albums.label: Round
albums.description: A new six-disc box set featuring performances from the late ‘80s and early ‘90s offers the definitive document of the latter-day Jerry Garcia Band.

albums.title: LIL BIG MAN
albums.label: Def Jam
albums.description: The L.A. rapper grapples with uncertainty and depression over warm, creamy, lo-fi beats.

albums.title: Jag Trax
albums.label: Derwin.FM
albums.description: Gold Panda’s Derwin Dicker adopts a new alias and a new sound, trading his typically lush, sampledelic style for clean-lined house music with a dry sense of humor.

albums.title: Confetti in the Sky Like Fireworks (This Is Bate Bola OST)
albums.label: International Anthem
albums.description: On his soundtrack for the film This Is Bate-Bola, the Chicago cornetist, keyboardist, and composer summons the dread and excitement of the lesser-known Rio festival.

albums.title: American Football (LP3)
albums.label: Polyvinyl
albums.description: The dazzling third album from the stalwarts of Midwestern emo does away with the band’s self-mythology and takes bleary, bold steps toward a new dawn.

albums.title: The Devil You Know
albums.label: Suicide Squeeze
albums.description: The punk trio’s unfussy production and precise vocal harmonies are a testament to their well-earned longevity.

albums.title: Bubble Universe!
albums.label: Hausu Mountain
albums.description: A new project from the Chicago vaporwave maven eases off the aggression of her Fire-Toolz alias, finding new inspiration in the clash of new age, smooth jazz, prog rock, and video-game soundtracks.

albums.title: Crazy But It’s True
albums.label: Alamo
albums.description: The Atlanta rapper’s new project stumbles around in search of a hit and comes very close to finding one.

albums.title: GloToven
albums.label: RBC
albums.description: It isn’t really in Keef’s nature to be sentimental, but even Zaytoven has a way of getting to the hardest rappers.

albums.title: Plastic Anniversary
albums.label: Thrill Jockey
albums.description: Recorded using only plastic material, the concept of the latest Matmos album is undergirded by the compositional integrity, the quality of the sound, and the sickeningly beautiful idea of it all.

albums.title: Make a Wilderness
albums.label: Music From Memory
albums.description: Jonny Nash draws on the otherworldly sounds of the Baschet brothers’ experimental instruments to sculpt a gently haphazard ambient mirage.

albums.title: Komachi
albums.label: Métron Records
albums.description: Blending modern techniques with deep reverence for history, producer Meitei sets out to recapture a “lost Japanese mood.”

albums.title: ATAXIA
albums.label: Planet Mu
albums.description: The UK producer’s debut album fashions a distinctive aesthetic out of asymmetrical machine beats and dabs of electronic melody, balancing academic concerns with rave-tested thrills.

albums.title: High Anxiety
albums.label: Thrill Jockey
albums.description: The Chicago noise-rock/thrash/punk/metal/etc. trio continue to hate you, your band, and most other things.

albums.title: Lux Prima
albums.label: BMG
albums.description: Karen O and Danger Mouse have concocted a lush, vivid world on their dreamy and poignant collaboration.

albums.title: Trust in the Lifeforce of the Deep Mystery
albums.label: UMG
