albums.description: The cosmically minded group featuring rising jazz saxophonist Shabaka Hutchings dances to the apocalypse and pleads for humanity.

albums.title: Rapture EP
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: The young Jamaican singer shows off her versatility on her debut EP, slipping between rapid-fire ragga grit and conscious reggae styles, and maintaining an unwavering focus on memorable melodic hooks.

albums.title: Let There Be Eve...Ruff Ryders’ First Lady
albums.label: Interscope
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Eve’s 1999 debut, a hard-bodied and self-determined showcase.

albums.title: Groove Denied
albums.label: Matador
albums.description: The indie-rock icon fires up his laptop and lays down a set of quasi-electronic jams that owe more to late-1970s post-punk than to the Berlin nightlife that supposedly inspired the record.

albums.title: Cry 4 Help EP
albums.label: Change Minds
albums.description: The L.A. singer and rapper’s intimate EP confronts trauma and healing in smooth, unflinching songs.

albums.title: Downer Edn
albums.label: Goner
albums.description: The Sydney punks comb through society’s sludge on a deadpan collection of mosh pit anthems and glistening new wave synthesizers.

albums.title: Many Any
albums.label: 1432 R
albums.description: The D.C. dance-music vet and Future Times honcho drops a freeform set of free-spirited club tracks that show off his keen beatmaking abilities.

albums.title: Panorama
albums.label: Epitaph
albums.description: On their Epitaph debut, the Grand Rapids post-hardcore band ruminates on the small stuff—death, grief, life, love.

albums.title: Psychodrama
albums.label: Neighbourhood
albums.description: On his debut album, the talented South London rapper Dave explores family and identity with the unguarded catharsis of a therapy session.

albums.title: PUNK
albums.label: Burger
albums.description: The Japanese quartet devote their second album to enthusiastic, maximalist pop with a bluntly feminist message.

albums.title: Sucker Punch
albums.label: Island
albums.description: On her debut, the Norwegian pop phenom offers a patina of fresh-faced authenticity and not much else.

albums.title: Egowerk
albums.label: Saddle Creek
albums.description: More than two decades in, the Omaha electro-rock band finds new reasons to stay angry and keep dancing.

albums.title: EXPORT
albums.label: Jolly Discs
albums.description: The UK duo’s ambitious second album has an alluring and unclassifiable sound. Rarely has a hybrid of new wave and experimental electronic music led to such an introspective place.

albums.title: PURGE
albums.label: PTP
albums.description: The tempestuous debut by producer and vocalist Felicia Chen is an emotionally tense album that whips between violent outcries and quiet pockets of respite

albums.title: Knife + Heart (Original Soundtrack)
albums.label: Mute
albums.description: On his third outing composing music for film, Anthony Gonzalez breaks from his own soundtracking habits with a welcome sense of playfulness.

albums.title: The Transitory Poems
albums.label: ECM
albums.description: Two celebrated jazz pianists bring contrasting, complementary approaches to a set of improvised pieces that pay tribute to Cecil Taylor, Geri Allen, and other titans of the instrument.

albums.title: I Don’t Know How to Be Happy
albums.label: Sweat Equity
albums.description: The industrial noise-punk duo Deli Girls’ I Don’t Know How to Be Happy is a vengeance document built on industrial mutant rage.

albums.title: On Time Out of Time
albums.label: Temporary Residence
albums.description: The ambient composer turns his attention to the skies, sourcing an epic, heart-stirring sound from gravitational waves emanated by two massive black holes that collided 1.3 billion years ago.

albums.title: Still on My Mind
albums.label: BMG
albums.description: The UK goddess of lite pop still sounds serene, unbothered, and preternaturally confident.

albums.title: Death Race for Love
albums.label: Grade A
albums.description: Over 72 minutes, the emo-rap star explores drugs, heartbreak, and the drugs that lead to heartbreak.

albums.title: Toothsayer EP
albums.label: Six Shooter
albums.description: On a five-song EP accompanying the British National Maritime Museum’s “Polar Worlds” exhibit, the Inuk experimental musician joins landscape, culture, and resistance.

albums.title: Dead Man Original Soundtrack
albums.label: Vapor
albums.description: A vinyl reissue of the atmospheric guitar score for Jim Jarmusch’s 1995 film reveals a spare and intuitive performance unlike anything else Neil Young has recorded.

albums.title: Everything Not Saved Will Be Lost Part 1
albums.label: Warner Bros.
albums.description: The UK rockers summon all their crowd-pleasing, arena-sized ambition on the first half of a double album but lack the panache to really pull it off.

albums.title: Hyperion
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: The second album by the French producer Gesaffelstein brings in big pop collaborators like Haim and Pharrell.

albums.title: Sky Blue
albums.label: Fat Possum
albums.description: A posthumous 1973 solo album from the Texas singer-songwriter, released the week he would’ve turned 75, displays his careful sense of craft across a set of covers, favorites, and unheard songs.

albums.title: Beware of the Dogs
albums.label: Secretly Canadian
albums.description: The Australian singer-songwriter’s debut album brings her captivating voice and keen eye to songs that demolish expectations. Fierce, funny, and unsettling, her music is empathetic to the core.

albums.title: Nick Waterhouse
albums.label: Innovative Leisure
albums.description: The Southern California rocker cobbles together a pastiche of 1950s rockabilly, 1960s pop, and old-school soul. At its best, it’s a shot of pure joy, but it never quite transcends its inspirations.

albums.title: Dusty Notes
albums.label: Megaforce
albums.description: Meat Puppets’ 15th album mirrors the Kirkwood brothers’ ethos: earthy and out of time, casual and familiar, and wholly at ease with itself.

albums.title: If I Could Only Remember My Name
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit David Crosby’s solo debut, a foggy dream of psychedelic folk-rock.

albums.title: Girl
albums.label: Sony
albums.description: On her second album, the country-pop singer remains a powerhouse talent who can sing the hell of out every middle-of-the-road style going.

albums.title: archipelago
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: Having traded K-pop’s regimented model for an experimental sound merging modular synthesis with vocal manipuation, the Tokyo-based Yeohee Kim finds a new degree of artistic freedom.

albums.title: The Same but by Different Means
albums.label: Anti-
albums.description: The home-recording savant stitches together micro-epics into a sprawling expanse that feels both intimate and grand.

albums.title: Inferno
albums.label: Tapete
albums.description: 13 years after the death of his Go-Betweens partner Grant McLennan, Forster offers reflections with a spring in his step.

albums.title: SASAMI
albums.label: Domino
albums.description: Sasami Ashworth’s debut union of synthesizer decay and guitar reverb that embodies shoegaze’s supernatural ability to conjure sadness from the void.

albums.title: This Is How You Smile
albums.label: Rvng Intl.
albums.description: Roberto Carlos Lange’s sixth and best album as Helado Negro deepens and expands upon the imagistic nature of his lyrics and cosmic synth-folk. It is a sublime, masterful piece of music.

albums.title: Posthumous Humiliation
albums.label: Profound Lore
albums.description: On their second album, this proudly gratuitous Philadelphia quartet dives headlong into extreme gore and extreme sonics, making a real-life mess of death.

albums.title: I Also Want to Die in New Orleans
albums.label: Caldo Verde
albums.description: Mark Kozelek’s latest 90-minute dispatch frames his unedited ramblings as a kind of... free jazz?

albums.title: Baby On Baby
albums.label: Interscope
albums.description: The irreverent and charismatic Charlotte rapper's Interscope debut is just as wild as his mixtapes.

albums.title: Sofia Kourtesis EP
albums.label: Studio Barnhus
albums.description: The Peruvian-born, Berlin-based musician’s debut EP is the kind of house music that skirts convention and renounces rote functionality without ever forgetting that its purpose is to make people move.

albums.title: Westkust
albums.label: Run for Cover
albums.description: On their first LP following another bout of lineup changes, this Gothenburg band pushes against shoegaze confinement with songs meant to feel good.

albums.title: GREY Area
albums.label: Age 101
albums.description: The third album from the 25-year-old UK fire-spitter is a wickedly assured, highly entertaining, coming-of-age marvel.

albums.title: M for Empathy
albums.label: Double Double Whammy
albums.description: The Texas songwriter examines empathy in a series of probing and gemlike miniatures.

albums.title: 1UP
albums.label: Cinematic
albums.description: The Auto-Tune crooner catches everyone’s attention and promptly squanders it again.

albums.title: Fantasy & Facts
albums.label: AllPoints
albums.description: The UK singer weaves in and out of reality and make-believe on her debut album of lush, experimental R&B. It’s a transparent look into her swelling heart and wistful imagination.

albums.title: Wasteland, Baby!
albums.label: Rubyworks
albums.description: The man who took us to church tries to take us to the same church, again, 14 times, six years later.

albums.title: Rap or Go to the League
albums.label: Def Jam
albums.description: The Atlanta rapper rewrites the rulebook on winning on his most thoughtful album.

albums.title: When I Get Home
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: Solange’s fourth album is unhurried, ambient, and exploratory. Using everything from spiritual jazz to Gucci Mane, Solange conjures her hometown with stunning songcraft and production.

albums.title: American Love Call
albums.label: Dead Oceans
albums.description: If this Indiana soul band’s debut was the party, the strings come out for these songs about heartbreak and the hope in resilience.

albums.title: Girls
albums.label: Yung Baby Tate
albums.description: On her first full-length album, the versatile Atlanta artist explores the alternate identities of girls and women, finding solidarity in a cast of striking friends.

albums.title: SNAFU
albums.label: Get Better
albums.description: Six years after their scrappy debut, the pop-punk band Potty Mouth return with an arena-sized follow up that sounds like a major-label effort without all the compromises.

albums.title: Weezer (The Black Album)
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: Weezer reflects on their own capricious history, using a blunt force the likes of which they’ve never deployed before.

albums.title: White Stuff
albums.label: Fat Possum
albums.description: Perhaps their reunion is already doomed, but for the first time in almost two decades, this haywire tandem goes wild with their singularly subversive rock’n’roll.

albums.title: Death Becomes Her
albums.label: Hyperdub
albums.description: On her full-length debut, the provocative producer also raps, smartly using her voice as a tool in her quest to dislodge gender binaries and power hierarchies.

albums.title: Good at Falling
albums.label: Dirty Hit
albums.description: On her debut album, the British singer-songwriter Amber Bain lets go of her self-consciousness and, with some help from the 1975, makes the transformation from hesitant outsider to unlikely pop star.

albums.title: Walking Wounded
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the intersection of pop and trip-hop and love and memory in a stellar record from 1996.

albums.title: This Land
albums.label: Warner Bros.
albums.description: Leaning into both his songwriting and his studio experimentation, the Texas guitarist proves his eagerness to move beyond the confines of modern blues.

albums.title: Eminent Domain
albums.label: L.I.E.S.
albums.description: Showcasing the darker, noisier side of Ron Morelli’s industrial-electronics label, this collection creates a cohesive whole out of jagged contrasts.

albums.title: Pretty Face
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: The 22-year-old Queens rapper offers a tape of thoughtful and weighty heartbreak hymns that slowly reveal more of his layered personality.

albums.title: BTTB (20th Anniversary Edition)
albums.label: Kab America Inc.
albums.description: This restrained collection of solo piano instrumentals evokes Satie, but the often-overlooked experimental touches presage Sakamoto’s subsequent work.

albums.title: A Long Red Hot Los Angeles Summer Night
albums.label: Nature Sounds
albums.description: Evoking the golden age of LA hip-hop with rapid-fire rhymes, vivid set pieces, and sample-centric beats, the rapper finally offers a proper follow-up to an ill-fated opus.

albums.title: Tasmania
albums.label: Interscope
albums.description: The eighth album from the Australian psych-rockers is their most melodically realized of their career. The strains of pop offer a lovely imprint of a band in a constant state of flux.

albums.title: placeholder
albums.label: Saddle Creek
albums.description: Anxiety swirls through these songs about non-normative relationships, the unease countered by a bucolic mix of pleasing melodies, soft guitars, and gentle vocals.

albums.title: All My Relations
albums.label: Daptone
albums.description: The Dap-Kings saxophonist assembles a sizeable, percussion-heavy ensemble on a set that draws inspiration from a search for his ancestral past.

albums.title: Gangster Music Vol. 1
albums.label: All City
albums.description: A hip-hop head’s presumptive fantasy, this compilation by the Gangster Doodles illustrator gathers loosies from cult favorites and a few new artists.

albums.title: Harverd Dropout
albums.label: Warner Bros.
albums.description: Having abandoned his lo-fi roots in the South Florida rap scene, Lil Pump has become a caricature of himself. His second album is sometimes fun but mostly unnecessary.

albums.title: Europa EP
albums.label: Mad Decent
albums.description: Despite trending toward pop in recent years, the globetrotting producer turns to European and African rappers to help him find new inspiration—or at least try.

albums.title: Big Bad...
albums.label: Island
albums.description: The London rapper’s fifth album reinforces his dominance of the UK scene and marks his increasing cachet in international waters, but the decision to sing might be the wrong kind of risk-taking.

albums.title: Swervvvvv.5
albums.label: Union IV
albums.description: On her supposedly final mixtape before she issues her full-length debut, the “urban jazz” rapper and singer adds intrigue with bits of her backstory and elliptical flourishes.

albums.title: Crushing
albums.label: Polyvinyl
albums.description: On an album that mines failed relationships for self-discovery, the Australian singer-songwriter shows her talent at distilling complex situations into searing couplets.

albums.title: Second Language
albums.label: BANA
albums.description: The second album from the experimental Korean rap/production duo really starts to come together. They find a catchy, powerful zone to serve up their invective.

albums.title: Drip or Drown 2
albums.label: Young Stoner Life
albums.description: The drowsy Atlanta rapper polishes his style and submits some of his best songs, but the same thing that makes Gunna dependable also makes him predictable.

albums.title: Father of 4
albums.label: Quality Control
albums.description: Though it’s undermined by its inertia and lack of focus, Offset’s solo debut offers glimpses of the rapper as a compelling storyteller and bluesman.

albums.title: Helium
albums.label: Sinderlyn
albums.description: The former Mac DeMarco guitarist shifts to tepid synths and limp beats on his fourth album, a pastiche of references beyond his reach.

albums.title: Sunshine 3
albums.label: Clone
albums.description: Using a bespoke tuning system, the Finish producer builds his songs inside an otherworldly ecosystem of sound using the pulse of electro, funk, and classic IDM. It is simply alluring.

albums.title: While We Wait
albums.label: TSNMI
albums.description: The Oakland R&B singer’s latest project is a shining example of both her emotional intelligence and her balmy, lucid songwriting.

albums.title: Fabric Presents Bonobo
albums.label: Fabric
albums.description: In the first installment of the London nightclub’s relaunched mix series, an artist best known for soulful, worldly downtempo tries his hand at upbeat house.

albums.title: Lung Bread for Daddy
albums.label: Moshi Moshi
albums.description: Beth Jeans Houghton’s second album as Du Blonde sorts through the messiest aspects of desire and revulsion with cathartic finesse, purging her past while leaving her strange, spiky magic intact.

albums.title: 808BB EP
albums.label: Ilian Tape
albums.description: Following last year’s thrilling Compro, the Ilian Tape label’s breakbeat-techno renegade returns with a three-track EP of club cuts that cleverly flip dancefloor expectations.

albums.title: Silences
albums.label: Canvasback
albums.description: Even if the second album from this Nashville singer doesn’t sound like the blues, she embodies the spirit, squaring up to her demons without fear.

albums.title: Los Angeles
albums.label: Fat Possum
albums.description: A powerful, iconic document of West Coast punk is reissued, warts and all.

albums.title: MTV Unplugged in New York
albums.label: DGC
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Nirvana’s transcendent live acoustic album recorded in 1993.

albums.title: Modern Sounds in Country & Western Music Volumes 1 & 2
albums.label: The Ray Charles Foundation
albums.description: At last available digitally, these quietly revolutionary albums still break one of music’s deepest-held genre orthodoxies.

albums.title: Secrets of the Beehive / Brilliant Trees / Alchemy: An Index of Possibilities / Gone to Earth
albums.label: UMC
albums.description: After the breakup of Japan, this reluctant star retreated into a series of four albums—including his masterpiece—built on noir balladry, instrumental abstraction, and an abiding sense of distance.

albums.title: You Will Not Die
albums.label: BMG
albums.description: The strikingly intimate debut from the London-via-South Africa singer showcases an exciting new talent despite its occasionally lead-footed pacing and stilted theatrics.

albums.title: Serpent Power
albums.label: True Aether
albums.description: Completing the move from hard club music to phantom ambient music, the producer escapes pixel-pocked logic for something more like nature.

albums.title: Illegal Moves
albums.label: Trouble in Mind
albums.description: Calling back to the insurgent sociopolitical jazz from another era of national unrest, these ecstatic instrumentals are urgent and purposeful.

albums.title: Post Earth
albums.label: Wichita
albums.description: The LA quartet’s second album is more musically focused and emotionally unsettled, its once shaggy sound sculpted into post-punk precision.

albums.title: Love Is Love
albums.label: TSO
albums.description: On her second full-length album, the Baltimore rapper indulges in the time-honored queer tradition of plotting a great escape from it all.

albums.title: Steals
albums.label: Other People
albums.description: On his second album for Nicolas Jaar’s label, the Russian producer continues to move away from footwork, building a gloomy world that is strangely welcoming.

albums.title: Mazy Fly
albums.label: Sacred Bones
albums.description: Tia Cabral’s second album retains the great mysticism of her songwriting. The unsettling synth textures and soundscapes fly around her soulful voice, making something beautiful out of sheer terror.

albums.title: Kankyō Ongaku: Japanese Ambient, Environmental & New Age Music 1980-1990
albums.label: Light in the Attic
albums.description: Visible Cloaks’ Spencer Doran curates an appealingly cohesive compilation of Japanese ambient music that, while decades old, feels uncannily suited to contemporary listening habits.

albums.title: Freewave 3
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: The latest project from the 22-year-old Chicago rapper is dour and affecting, a dispatch from a young man able to diagnose his wounds but unable to repair them.

albums.title: Mujeres
albums.label: Tender Loving Empire
albums.description: During this whirlwind of dream pop, folk, and jubilant dance music rendered in Spanish and English, Luz Elena Mendoza steps forward as a singer and bandleader like never before.

albums.title: ALL
albums.label: Mute
albums.description: Best known for his music’s starring role in films like Amélie, the composer aims to become the auteur here—maybe a little too much.

albums.title: Volume One: Dilemmas of Identity
albums.label: Lower Floor
albums.description: On his first solo LP in six years, the noise architect lingers inside a series of haunted scenes, animated by the surreal sounds of homemade instruments.

albums.title: New Atlantis
albums.label: Ostgut Ton
albums.description: Berlin’s Phillip Sollmann strikes a balance between dancefloor techno and avant-garde experiments; his tracks slip into the cracks between common melody and rhythm.

albums.title: Hello Happiness
albums.label: A Diary
albums.description: Co-produced by UK dance mainstay Switch, this comeback album largely ignores all the qualities that made the Queen of Funk a legend in the first place.

albums.title: Crush on Me
albums.label: Father/Daughter
albums.description: Kelsie Hogue’s debut album is likely to be among the year’s most extra albums, but behind its excitable homage to Britney and “TRL” lies an even more intriguing spin on ’90s alternative.

albums.title: Head Above Water
albums.label: BMG
albums.description: Though an interesting showcase of her powerful and newfound voice, the Canadian pop star’s comeback too often lapses into the rote, the stale, or the uninspired.

albums.title: An Attempt to Draw Aside the Veil
albums.label: Sacred Bones
albums.description: On their first album in seven years, the experimental guitarist and lutist craft surprisingly accessible and candid instrumentals from esoteric topics.

albums.title: Cherushii & Maria Minerva
albums.label: 100% Silk
albums.description: Chelsea Faith Dolan perished in Oakland’s Ghost Ship fire in 2016; this EP of left-field dance music made with her 100% Silk labelmate Maria Minerva is a moving testament to her talents and legacy.

albums.title: Another Kind of Revolution
albums.label: Thrill Jockey
albums.description: On her Thrill Jockey debut, this Basque multi-instrumentalist ties together political and personal revolutions with atmospheric and even cinematic ballads.

albums.title: TNT
albums.label: Thrill Jockey
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the wondrous alchemy of performance and technology found on Tortoise’s third record.

albums.title: Powder in Space
albums.label: Beats in Space
albums.description: On her first official mix album, the Tokyo DJ unveils an intricate, inspired playing style whose value system differs from the typical dancefloor mix.

albums.title: Elder Mantis
albums.label: Leaving
albums.description: On the sort of record that would have once sparked a minor bidding war between Stones Throw and Ninja Tune, hip-hop, IDM, and ambient music drift into a waking dream.

albums.title: The Language of Injury
albums.label: Holy Roar
albums.description: The debut from the UK melodic hardcore band shows their passion for experimentation in a genre where that is desperately welcome.

albums.title: Cast
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: Leaving behind the singer-songwriterly stylings of his previous project, Coldair, Tobiasz Biliński taps the pristine sonics of 1980s sophisti-pop, but it’s often too bloodless for its own good.

albums.title: Solitude
albums.label: Cosmo Rhythmatic
albums.description: Now a duo, Kevin Martin and Roger Robinson strip away all the excess and most of the reggae, yielding a desolate snapshot of heartbreak framed in stark, largely beatless drones.

albums.title: Ladytron
albums.label: !K7
albums.description: A dystopian band for dystopian times, Ladytron return with an angry, pitiless, evil-sounding record whose nihilism presents them as sirens of the apocalypse.

albums.title: In a Galaxy
albums.label: PIAS
albums.description: On her second album, the Dutch-Zimbabwean musician feeds off the energy of a move from Amsterdam to Peckham, England, turning the minutiae of daily life into bold, 1980s-inspired synth pop.

albums.title: Let’s Try the After Vol. 1 EP
albums.label: Arts & Crafts
albums.description: A pleasant palate-cleanser after the nourishing Hug of Thunder, the Canadian collective’s latest EP tackles familiar modes in capable fashion, while offering moments of life-affirming beauty.

albums.title: Rosa Parks: Pure Love. An Oratorio of Seven Songs
albums.label: TUM Records
albums.description: The jazz trumpeter’s meditation on the legacy of civil rights and the heroism of Rosa Parks is formally inventive and emotionally gripping.

albums.title: After its own death / Walking in a spiral towards the house
albums.label: Yellowelectric
albums.description: The new project from Grouper’s Liz Harris contains some of her most beguiling work. Spread across two long, contrasting ambient compositions, her music remains in an enigmatic class of her own.

albums.title: Fyah
albums.label: Gearbox
albums.description: A player in Shabaka Hutchings’ Sons of Kemet and a key figure in London’s vital jazz scene, Cross brings new energy to the tuba, an instrument long neglected in jazz and hits offshoots.

albums.title: Living Tomb
albums.label: 20 Buck Spin
albums.description: On their debut album, this Portland quartet demonstrates their old school death metal bona fides, even when they’re more interested in evolution and atmosphere.

albums.title: Bad Influence
albums.label: Roc Nation
albums.description: A producer with a knack for matching any rapper’s flow and a rapper at his best when embracing his regional flair are, turns out, good influences.

albums.title: Zandoli EP
albums.label: DEEWEE
albums.description: The Belgian-Caribbean musician’s breakout EP, co-produced by Soulwax, channels Guadeloupean influences into striking, playful electro pop with a sly sense of humor.

albums.title: Girl With Basket of Fruit
albums.label: Polyvinyl
albums.description: The duo’s latest speeds between fragmented beats and mournful balladry but rarely makes an impression beyond its sound and fury.

albums.label: Jet Life
albums.description: The ostensible sequel to How Fly offers a few fleeting glimpses of the easygoing, unruffled, and effortlessly cool rap produced by the duo 10 years ago.

albums.title: Main Pop Girl 2019
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: The wonderful second album from James Brooks’ project uses breakbeats, samples, and beautiful rave-pop motifs to tell stories about the bruising power of memory.

albums.title: Empire EP
albums.label: Shelter Press
albums.description: Following last year’s mesmerizing Stadium, this three-track EP is as spacious and richly textured as experimental percussion gets.

albums.title: What It Is
albums.label: Dualtone
albums.description: After a solemn post-divorce album, the Nashville-via-Texas songwriter works his endearing wit back into songs about loving someone new and abhorring social trends.

albums.title: Buoys
albums.label: Domino
albums.description: Noah Lennox finds solace in solitude on his sixth solo album as Panda Bear, stripping the instrumentation down to just a handful of sounds to create an unusually unified listen.

albums.title: Gangway for Navy
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: Built on loud, low-bit-rate samples, the New York rapper uses a relaxed, almost deadpan flow to nestle deep in his own consciousness, drawing you in close to his words.

albums.title: thank u, next
albums.label: Republic
albums.description: Released five months after the catharsis of Sweetener, these songs of affirmation feel lighter, freer, and more fun, carried effortlessly by Grande’s undeniable voice.

albums.title: VOL. 4 :: SLAVES OF FEAR
albums.label: Loma Vista
albums.description: The Los Angeles band used to make lithe, multifaceted songs that wrapped daring pop melodies in bristling noise; now, they seem content to complain into a murky hybrid of trip-hop and metal.

albums.title: AJ Tracey
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: The debut from grime’s rising star is a mixed bag but still peppered with hits, inviting elements of dancehall, pop, trap, and garage to the same house party.

albums.title: A Different Forest
albums.label: Sony Classical
albums.description: With more straightforward performances and compositions, the album has its flat spots, but it hints that Bertelmann might have as much to say as his piano does.

albums.title: A Prince Among Thieves
albums.label: Tommy Boy
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit an ambitious, righteous piece of hip-hop storytelling from 1999.

albums.title: Olympic Girls
albums.label: Ba Da Bing!
albums.description: After an extended search for inspiration, the New Zealand singer/songwriter uses color and newly adventurous song structures to explore definitions and limits of freedom.

albums.title: Tip of the Sphere
albums.label: Anti-
albums.description: On his ninth album, the reserved bandleader incorporates more classic rock references than usual, but they’re the frames for subtleties and surprises within.

albums.title: Severance
albums.label: Central Processing Unit
albums.description: On their second album, the Irish duo Mikron—brothers Michael and Ciaran Corcoran—make promising strides toward defining their own patch of techno turf.

albums.title: Unseen Worlds
albums.label: Unseen Worlds
albums.description: Reissued at last by the label that borrows its name, the second album from the computer music innovator is less predictable, with dark moods rising to a captivating surface.

albums.title: Quiet Signs
albums.label: Mexican Summer
albums.description: The Los Angeles folk musician’s third album is her best yet—a collection of hushed reveries that unspool like daydreams.

albums.title: Live in London
albums.label: Anti-
albums.description: Ten years after her last live record, Live in London feels like a valedictory statement.

albums.title: Pursuit of Momentary Happiness
albums.label: Third Man
albums.description: On their second album, this unruly British trio make the rare garage rock-informed record that aims for the upper reaches of Royal Albert Hall.

albums.title: Bobbie Gentry’s The Delta Sweete Revisited
albums.label: Bella Union
albums.description: A half-century after the release of Bobbie Gentry’s imaginative second album, the art-rock band revisits it as if in a daze but with the help of over a dozen brilliant singers.

albums.title: Oh Boy
albums.label: Female Fantasy
albums.description: In 2010, no band seemed to be having more fun with scrappy garage rock than this one. On their first album in nine years, they forget to replace that spark with anything else.

albums.title: The Oracle
albums.label: International Anthem
albums.description: The debut from the Chicago-based composer and clarinetist serves as a vibrant, spiritual, free-jazz document of black life as it stands today.

albums.title: True North
albums.label: Paradise of Bachelors
albums.description: On his second album produced by Steve Gunn, the underground folk icon sings about age and regret with authority and grace.

albums.title: Astronoid
albums.label: Blood
albums.description: On their second album, these metallurgists again find an awesome intersection of black metal pummel and shoegaze luster—then remain there, in its thrall.

albums.title: Electric Lady Sessions
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: The version of the band that toured behind 2017’s American Dream gathers in the legendary New York studio, giving old songs new life and additional oomph.

albums.title: Big Dreez
albums.label: Interscope
albums.description: After a quiet few years following her 2016 debut, the Chicago rapper returns sounding self-assured, wrapping her sharp flow in lush yet punchy beats.

albums.title: Sunshine Rock
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: After a stretch of dark, searching records, the former Hüsker Dü and Sugar leader uses the familiar power trio configuration to find a little peace.

albums.title: Drift Code
albums.label: Domino
albums.description: Former Talk Talk bassist Paul Webb finally steps to the microphone on his first album in 16 years, a meticulously arranged wonder steeped in English folk and proggy vibes.

albums.title: Music Inspired by the Film Roma
albums.label: Sony
albums.description: The curious, sometimes effective, sometimes bizarre music collected here features contributions from Beck, El-P, Patti Smith, DJ Shadow, Billie Eilish, and more.

albums.title: Emergency Raps Vol. 4
albums.label: Mutant Academy
albums.description: When emcee Fly Anakin and producer Tuamie connect inside a sound infatuated with the hip-hop of the past, it becomes a launch pad to new life.

albums.title: DJ-Kicks
albums.label: !K7
albums.description: The British house producer’s contribution to the longstanding series offers a broad cross-section of his tastes, mostly letting his selections, and not his mixing, do the heavy lifting.

albums.title: Stuffed & Ready
albums.label: Secretly Canadian
albums.description: Leading her thorny rock trio, Clementine Creevy keeps her themes broad and her anger specific as she reflects this moment’s feelings and fatigue.

albums.title: Pure Imagination, No Country
albums.label: Yeggs
albums.description: With a group behind him that recalls the electronic jazz splatter of ’90s New York, Dave Harrington’s guitar work becomes a psychedelic, soft-hued quest for transcendence.

albums.title: Gallipoli
albums.label: 4AD
albums.description: Zach Condon reunites with his old Farfisa on his fifth album, but otherwise he remains cozily ensconced in his twee wheelhouse.

albums.title: On the Other Ocean
albums.label: Lovely
albums.description: Over 40 years after its initial release, the composer’s pioneering work pairing computers with live players feels not only prescient but also refreshingly optimistic.

albums.title: Careful
albums.label: Nude Club
albums.description: A decade after minimal wave seemed to reach its peak, the Massachusetts duo proves the style’s continued vitality.

albums.title: This Is Not the End
albums.label: By The Time It Gets Dark
albums.description: On their debut LP, the Norwegian trio emboldens their customary celebration rock by adding emphatic stretches of post-rock and power-pop.

albums.title: Journey in Satchidananda
albums.label: ABC
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit a marvel of spiritual jazz, an album overflowing with transcendence, harmony, and grief.

albums.title: Internationally Unknown
albums.label: Hellcat
albums.description: The fashionable UK punk-rap frontman has been made into an icon, but his second album is too often a pale and rote imitation of rebellion.

albums.title: Michael O’Shea
albums.label: Allchival
albums.description: Originally released on the UK post-punk group Wire’s label in 1982, this long-lost one-off spotlights a singular busker who made magical music out of a stringed wooden door.

albums.title: Tatizo Pesa
albums.label: Nyege Nyege Tapes
albums.description: Jay Mitta adds an incredible amount of detail to the frenetic and kinetic sound of singeli, a blisteringly quick style of dance music from Dar Es Salaam, Tanzania.

albums.title: Mystery Hour
albums.label: Bella Union
albums.description: This baroque pop record is pleasant and roomy, but peer inside to find a fragmented portrait of heartbreak shared by the band’s cofounders.

albums.title: Comp x Comp
albums.label: Comatonse
albums.description: As the Tokyo experimental musician’s work is finally made available digitally, this compilation offers an introduction to the artist’s critical perspective on capitalism, gender norms, trans identity, and more.

albums.title: Scenery
albums.label: ATO
albums.description: The New York singer-songwriter’s third album maps life’s changes to sleek, vibrant R&B that’s packed with 1980s soundtrack flourishes and big moments; it’s the perfect frame for her extraordinary voice.

albums.title: Hueco Mundo
albums.label: NUXSENSE
albums.description: The solo debut from one of the Dublin rap group NUXSENSE’s core emcees, backed by ghostly beats from producer Sivv, represents the clearest iteration of the group’s aesthetic yet.

albums.title: What Chaos is Imaginary
albums.label: Anti-
albums.description: Weaving in and out of concrete, direct, indie-rock songwriting and meditative, impressionistic dream pop, Girlpool’s third album features their most expansive and surreal songs to date.

albums.title: Bartier Bounty
albums.label: Asylum
albums.description: Already an all-time-great shit talker, the Detroit rapper reaffirms his reputation as a fun-loving rapper who repurposes familiar topics in new forms.

albums.title: Almost Free
albums.label: Mom & Pop
albums.description: A little Gary Glitter, a little Kid Rock, even a little Smash Mouth—the third album from these former California party kids holds nothing back.

albums.title: Everything’s for Sale
albums.label: Shady
albums.description: The Compton rapper’s debut is smart, technically dazzling, and thoroughly sullen.

albums.title: D A Y S
albums.label: Northern Spy
albums.description: Perhaps familiar from her time in Okkervil River, the multi-instrumentalist builds fascinating webs of sound around skeletal songs on her solo debut.

albums.title: Isa
albums.label: Posh Isolation
albums.description: The sixth album from Loke Rahbek’s experimental industrial project is his most cohesive to date, dissecting pop for parts and refiguring melodic elements into something truly other.

albums.title: Signals Into Space
albums.label: Les Disques du Crépuscule
albums.description: After 30 years, the London duo sounds more refined than ever, though their mix of ethereal jazz, ambient electronics, and mechanized drums has rarely been harder to define.

albums.title: Epitaph
albums.label: Bokeh Versions
albums.description: On what is billed as his proper debut LP after several years’ worth of cassette releases, the Greek producer fashions a wide-ranging attempt to move beyond his dub influences.

albums.title: Goes West
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: The solo guitarist’s fourth album is soft and subtle, approaching the strains of pop while still basking in the solitude of Americana.

albums.title: Nectar
albums.label: YEAR0001
albums.description: The lo-fi, art rock project from Yung Lean is every bit as dazed as his rap music, while otherwise sounding almost nothing like it.

albums.title: La Maison de la Mort/Minimal Cuts EP
albums.label: Berceuse Heroique
albums.description: The Russian producer better known as Buttechno applies his gonzo sonics to psychoactive ambient miniatures and joyfully off-kilter club tracks.

albums.title: Nighttime Birds and Morning Stars
albums.label: Thrill Jockey
albums.description: After first gaining attention for representational acoustic beauties, the guitarist digs deeper into abstraction, until the physical trappings of her instrument largely melt away.

albums.title: All the Young Droogs
albums.label: Cherry Red
albums.description: Subtitled ”60 Juvenile Delinquent Wrecks, Rock’N’Glam (And a Flavour of Bubblegum) From the ’70s,” this collection makes a fine argument for glam as punk-before-punk and speaks to the herd mentality of rock‘s heyday.

albums.title: La Onda de Juan Pablo
albums.label: Captured Tracks
albums.description: On his first album sung entirely in Spanish, the Uruguayan-American singer-songwriter finds poetry in small moments, with low-key craftsmanship that matches his songs’ quotidian subject matter.

albums.title: King of the Dudes EP
albums.label: Mom & Pop
albums.description: Though still a bit shaky and cloying, the New York band strikes a good chord with a power-pop sound and starts to carve out a space of their own.

albums.title: new breed
albums.label: Local Action
albums.description: Moving in a more traditional R&B direction, new breed is a richly detailed, self-confident, yet somewhat uneven album that attempts to weave together disparate elements of Richard’s personality.

albums.title: Dry As a Bone/Rehab Doll
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: Now reissued in expanded editions, the first official Sub Pop release—and its full-length follow-up—deserve more than historical footnote status.

albums.title: Highway Hypnosis
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: On her third album, the magnetic D.C. multi-instrumentalist pushes from post-punk toward a new clutch of electronic influences, seemingly sorting them as she goes.

albums.title: Private Parts
albums.label: Lovely
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit a surreal, transcendental work by a giant of the American avant-garde.

albums.title: We All Shine
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: A true child of SoundCloud, the small-town Florida rapper trades some of his storytelling skills for enhanced fidelity on this Kanye West-assisted project.

albums.title: Black Axis/The Tribe
albums.label: Southern Lord
albums.description: The start of an extended reissues series, these two albums find the essential trio of the aggressive German guitarist fighting through darkness to find any light.

albums.title: Better Oblivion Community Center
albums.label: Dead Oceans
albums.description: Phoebe Bridgers and Conor Oberst team up for a tight-knit folk-rock album about alienation, solitude, and our potential to better ourselves against bad odds.

albums.title: The Unseen in Between
albums.label: Matador
albums.description: Though he rose to early acclaim as a fingerstyle guitarist, the singer/songwriter is steadily developing into a poignant lyricist, now chronicling the places and people he hopes to understand.

albums.title: Oliver Appropriate
albums.label: Dine Alone
albums.description: In what is billed as the emo band’s farewell album, Max Bemis concocts a tangled rock opera about a burnt-out singer grappling with his rage and his sexuality.

albums.title: In the Living Room
albums.label: Seal Mountain
albums.description: Crisp and shiny as a compact disc, these 10 songs position the North Carolina upstarts as late-1990s alt-connoisseurs, unashamed of and unapologetic about their enthusiasms.

albums.title: Power Chords
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: Pledging allegiance to fuzz, this power-pop barrage squares off against heartache, disappointment, and sleepless nights—and survives.

albums.title: Future Hndrxx Presents: The WIZRD
albums.label: Epic
albums.description: While there’s plenty of his melancholic, drug-induced staples, what you won’t find here is the Atlanta rapper stretching or surprising himself.

albums.title: Musical Prophet: The Expanded 1963 New York Studio Sessions
albums.label: Resonance
albums.description: Made months before he cut his masterpiece and almost exactly a year before he died, these newly excavated recordings show the exploratory vigor and versatility of the jazz revolutionary.

albums.title: direct line to My Creator
albums.label: The Vanguarde Craft and Creative
albums.description: The remarkable EP from the New York-based artist is a one-of-a-kind debut, filled with small details, warm soul, and great emotional depth.

albums.title: Tomb
albums.label: Asthmatic Kitty
albums.description: The Los Angeles singer-songwriter’s third album, his most polished to date, covers the full spectrum of brokenheartedness.

albums.title: Rat’s Spit
albums.label: Underwater Peoples
albums.description: On his first album since joining Real Estate, the hesitant singer and lavish sound artist at last puts those elements on equal footing with his songwriting.

albums.title: Phoenix
albums.label: Polyvinyl
albums.description: Assuming his old handle for the first time in 15 years, David Bazan digs into his desert childhood to make amends with the people he hurt—especially himself.

albums.title: Outer Peace
albums.label: Carpark
albums.description: Chaz Bear delivers a smartly crafted, comfortably mid-fi album of grooves and melancholy—one of his best albums in years.

albums.title: Assume Form
albums.label: Polydor
albums.description: There’s a suffocating seriousness that runs through the singer and producer’s fourth album, one that bogs down genuine moments of levity and love.

albums.title: Heard It in a Past Life
albums.label: Capitol
albums.description: Three years after an encounter with Pharrell turned her into a viral phenomenon, the accidental star finally delivers her debut album, but her talents are eclipsed by overproduction.

albums.title: The Favourite (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)
albums.label: Decca
albums.description: A dizzying mix of Baroque, religious, mid-century, and contemporary classical music, this soundtrack captures its film’s tempestuous relationship with power and feelings.

albums.title: Love Hates What You Become
albums.label: Mute
albums.description: On their second album, Ebony Hoorn and WU LYF’s Ellery Roberts sell a mix of motivation and despair with sheer bombast.

albums.title: Tracy Chapman
albums.label: Elektra
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit a folk classic that came to the world stage with a perspective crystallized in society’s margins.

albums.title: The Sensual World
albums.label: EMI
albums.description: Never did Kate Bush sound more grounded, more in control of her songwriting than on her sixth album from 1989, featuring stories that play out like intimate vignettes rather than fantastical fairy tales.

albums.title: The Dreaming
albums.label: EMI
albums.description: In 1982, Kate Bush’s daring and dense fourth album marked her transformation into a fearless experimental artist who was legibly, audibly very queer, and very obviously in love with pop music.

albums.title: The Red Shoes
albums.label: EMI
albums.description: An outlier in Kate Bush’s catalog, her seventh album from 1993 finds an effortless perfectionist pushing very hard to locate her next great idea.

albums.title: The Kick Inside
albums.label: EMI
albums.description: Released when she was just 19, and including songs begun four years earlier, Bush’s landmark debut is playful, experimental, and defiant: the sound of a young woman getting what she wants.

albums.title: Hectic Shakes EP
albums.label: Alter
albums.description: The German producer tests the balance of bleak ambience and diamond-tipped breakbeats on an introspective EP that remains true to his own idiosyncratic style.

albums.title: Nūr EP
albums.label: AGAINST GIANTS
albums.description: The debut EP from the Sudan-born, Twin Cities-based singer, poet, and activist reveals an artist with a warm, sophisticated sound and captivating presence on the mic.

albums.title: Remind Me Tomorrow
albums.label: ‎Jagjaguwar‎
albums.description: On her fifth album, Sharon Van Etten conjures tempests and explores their subsequent calms. It is the peak of her songwriting and her most atmospheric, emotionally piercing album to date.

albums.title: Scholars
albums.label: Brassland
albums.description: On their first album in six years, the experimental pop duo (mostly) puts down their namesake instruments to fold more electronic elements into their potent songs.

albums.title: About the Light
albums.label: Double Six
albums.description: The infamous Beta Band frontman could have lingered in the shadow of his cult-figure fandom; instead, on his fourth solo album, he sings directly about the long process of growing up.

albums.title: Why Hasn’t Everything Already Disappeared?
albums.label: 4AD
albums.description: Though the band is now squarely in its pop era, the nostalgia that laced its early records has morphed into a timely, fatalistic vision of the future and national decay.

albums.title: Malibu Ken
albums.label: Rhymesayers
albums.description: Teaming with the playful producer Tobacco, Aesop Rock has a joyous playdate with his overlooked senses of humor and storytelling.

albums.title: 13th Month
albums.label: Apocalipsis
albums.description: The Dominican producer pulls inspiration from a South Dakota Indian Reservation.

albums.title: Bird Box (Abridged) Original Score
albums.label: The Null Corporation
albums.description: The soundtrack institution of Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross return to their well of ominousness and employ an array of techniques to convey anxiety, impending danger, and discomfort.

albums.title: Untitled II
albums.label: a-ton
albums.description: On their second major outing for a label other than their own, the eternally enigmatic producer uses frantic EBM and lurid synths to cast a shadow as dark and deep as their reputation.

albums.title: Prehysteria
albums.label: Boogie Agency
albums.description: The New York band’s jangly indie pop is more ambitious than before, but their lyrics too often fail to move beyond low-stakes camp—hardly the radical liberation the band has hinted at delivering.

albums.title: AMITY
albums.label: Baby Gang
albums.description: The California-based producer, instrumental to the rise of emo-rap, offers a solid showcase of his talent that maps a constellation of strange and unforgettable artists.

albums.title: Tides: Music for Meditation and Yoga
albums.label: touchtheplants
albums.description: Music for yoga may be an ambient cliche, but the Los Angeles synthesizer musician largely avoids new-age pitfalls on this album of unabashedly functional background music.

albums.title: Spirit of Eden
albums.label: Parlophone
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the masterful, groundbreaking sound that laid the foundation for post-rock.

albums.title: DISRUPTION EP
albums.label: Club Chai
albums.description: The Bay Area producer’s debut project draws upon Armenian mythology to create an ambient-house-dabke hybrid in five shape-shifting tracks.

albums.title: first bloom
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: On spirited songs that shift eagerly among pop, hip-hop, rock, and soul, the voice of standout singer Wolf Weston emerges as a stirring new instrument.

albums.title: “…The Best Live Show of All Time” — NME EP
albums.label: Nonesuch
albums.description: Even given the tongue-in-cheek hyperbole of the title, this six-track live EP fails to live up the former Talking Heads frontman’s former heights.

albums.title: Lost Lovesongs / Lostsongs Vol. 2
albums.label: Planet Uterus
albums.description: On a pair of 30-minute SoundCloud streams, the former Giegling affiliate applies his windswept aesthetic to boom-bap, ambient, and jungle, to emotive—some would say maudlin—effect.

albums.title: Transportation EPs
albums.label: Telephone Explosion
albums.description: Perhaps familiar from being sampled by the Avalanches, this New York tween was an inspiring underground star in the early 1980s, a reputation confirmed by this archival collection.

albums.title: Roman Birds
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: Inspired by the eruption of Mount Vesuvius, this five-track ambient wonder finds the New York producer letting pulses and motifs overlap until the tracks resemble the inside of a lava lamp.

albums.title: Shadows of Death and Desire
albums.label: Hospital Productions
albums.description: On his second solo album, fueled by unspecified personal misfortune, the former Sandwell District member finds emotional resonance in the interface between techno and post-punk.

albums.title: Sick Boy
albums.label: Disruptor
albums.description: Trading away the dance-pop trifles of their hits for a faceless stylistic shuffle, the duo seems to be tiring of itself, too.

albums.title: Hoodie SZN
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: Despite the typical bloated-album problems like pacing issues and forced collaborations, A Boogie hardly ever loses his Bronx edge.

albums.title: V I S C 0 9
albums.label: V I S
albums.description: On a tape label with links to Hamburg’s Golden Pudel club, the German curator delivers a deep-diving, pitch-shifting DJ mix traversing Alice Coltrane, desert blues, and cacophonous synths and drums.

albums.title: Ménage à Trois: Sextape Vol. 1, 2, 3
albums.label: Radiokilla
albums.description: Totalling a bulky 40 songs, Terius Nash’s latest project is purposefully and hilariously indulgent, but his marathon session reveals an R&B luminary still working at the top of his game.

albums.title: Starter Home
albums.label: No Quarter
albums.description: Gracefully navigating the intersection of folk-rock and country, the gentle-voiced songwriter turns detailed images of domestic tranquility and promise into reflections on disappointment.

albums.title: Singles Going Steady
albums.label: IRS
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit a punk classic, a paragon of songwriting about the pain and joy of love.

albums.title: Happy New Year! We Wish You Happiness!
albums.label: трип
albums.description: The latest compilation from Nina Kraviz’s label explores the fringes of techno with a twisted grin.

albums.title: Nothing New in the West
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: The debut from the prodigious singer-songwriter is a fussy and affecting album of baroque art-rock that is crowded with ideas in the best way.

albums.title: War in My Pen
albums.label: 10k
albums.description: Of MIKE’s four projects last year, War in My Pen is the cleanest-sounding, but the New York rapper still prizes a faraway vibe that rewards close listening.

albums.title: Universalis
albums.label: Hammock
albums.description: This long-running Nashville duo captures the essence of their name with a low-slung, low-stakes sway, tracing a line between languid indie rock and experimental atmospheres.

albums.title: X 100PRE
albums.label: Rimas
albums.description: The expertly sequenced and always vibrant debut from the Puerto Rican rapper collects every fascinating side of Bad Bunny into one singular statement.

albums.title: Take 2 EP
albums.label: Because Music
albums.description: Though an accomplished actress, the French star fails to sell her cover of Kanye West’s “Runaway” on an EP that otherwise amounts to a deserved victory lap.

albums.title: I Am > I Was
albums.label: Slaughter Gang
albums.description: The second album from one of Atlanta’s most promising rappers recasts him as a star in waiting. He writes with grisly clarity and humor, and his songs here are sturdy, inventive, and sticky.

albums.title: Signs of Satanic Youth
albums.label: Emergency
albums.description: These Australians became radio mainstays at home after missing the grunge gold rush, but their debut EP remains a potent encapsulation of alternative rock in the early 1990s.

albums.title: Some Kind of Cadwallader
albums.label: Lauren
albums.description: The Pennsylvania emo stalwarts never found much fame in their own time, but a decade later, these reissues testify to their influence, idiosyncrasy, and proudly uncommercial spirit.

albums.title: A Day In The Life: Impressions Of Pepper
albums.label: Verve
albums.description: This version of Sgt Pepper’s treats the Beatles' originals like colorful clothes worn by today’s most electrifying jazz musicians, who give these old chestnuts a new body and vitality.

albums.title: Language
albums.label: BANA
albums.description: The debut from the young hip-hop duo is an antidote to mainstream South Korean rap and pop—personal, anti-capitalist screeds over experimental trap and techno hybrids.

albums.title: Foxwarren
albums.label: Anti-
albums.description: Songwriter Andy Shauf puts his solo success on hold for an atmospheric rock record with his friends—appropriate for these tunes about seeking solace in a lonely world.

albums.title: Opening Fire: 2008-2014
albums.label: Dark Operative
albums.description: This collection of early recordings from the Texas thrash powerhouse makes it clear that their influences and focus set them apart from the thrash revival they followed.

albums.title: Alienated
albums.label: Sister Polygon
albums.description: On their first release for the D.C. punk band Priests’ label, the duo finally let a little light into their rough-and-tumble rock songs, celebrating in spite of hardships.

albums.title: Vox Lux OST
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: If a soundtrack to a troubled movie that features half Sia songs and half Scott Walker compositions sounds at the very least interesting, rest assured, it is not.

albums.title: Temporary etc.
albums.label: NNA Tapes
albums.description: One of several recent drummers to combine electronic processing with instrumental chops, Booker Stardrum swings like a pendulum between chaos and order.

albums.title: Distancing
albums.label: Buzz
albums.description: The songwriting from Laura Hermiston on her latest indie-pop album is noisy but lucid, reflective of the sound and vision coming from Toronto’s Buzz Records.

albums.title: Lost Time Behind the Moon
albums.label: Scissor Tail
albums.description: After decades of wandering, the former Court & Spark and Hiss Golden Messenger member follows his wanderlust West again, where he puts down new roots for his soulful folk-rock sound.

albums.title: Chronicles II / Chronicles III
albums.label: a-ton
albums.description: At one point, Luke Slater’s atmospheric-techno guise sounded like the future of electronic music; a welcome new archive proves its soundscapes and grooves were prescient.

albums.title: Icarus Falls
albums.label: RCA
albums.description: Zayn’s reputation as a skillful interpreter of pop is tested on his second solo album, a tome of love songs with a concept that hinges on excess and its trickery.

albums.title: Penelope Two
albums.label: Houndstooth
albums.description: Summoning the great ghosts of vintage 4AD and Kranky, the Australian singer and producer makes inky dream pop that’s as heavy and welcoming as a weighted blanket.

albums.title: Sistahs
albums.label: Daydream Library Series
albums.description: The accomplished debut from the DIY UK post-punk trio is simmering with possibility and pure conviction.

albums.title: Trust Issues
albums.label: SOB X RBE
albums.description: SOB X RBE is already a compelling rap machine, a potential powerhouse in waiting. But this solo outing suggests that there’s plenty of life outside the group, too.

albums.title: Let Go
albums.label: Arista
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit a teenage fever dream, the mainstream pop-punk debut of Avril Lavigne.

albums.title: The Capitol Studio Sessions
albums.artist: Jeff Goldblum & The Mildred Snitzer Orchestra
albums.label: Decca
albums.description: Jeff Goldblum’s debut album, a live-in-the-studio ersatz nightclub affair, is a sincere, classy, and competent homage to the golden age of vocal jazz.

albums.title: Stokeley
albums.label: Victor Victor
albums.description: On his album debut, the South Florida rapper (and former XXXTentacion associate) employs a playful approach to celebrate style over substance.

albums.title: Skins
albums.label: Bad Vibes Forever
albums.description: Underneath it all, the posthumous album from the Florida rapper is woefully aimless and structurally unsound.

albums.title: A Million and One
albums.label: Rhyme & Reason
albums.description: In pursuit of sweaty deliverance, the acrobatic singer takes worries about police brutality, relationship woes, and embracing differences to the dance floor.

albums.title: Springsteen on Broadway
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: Even when Bruce sticks to the script in a playhouse, he can deliver a ranging and intimate performance full of the history and emotion befitting his long career.

albums.title: Live in Buenos Aires
albums.label: Parlophone
albums.description: Though it includes some of the band’s least memorable songs, their latest live album makes a strong case for Coldplay as one of the 21st century’s most enduring arena acts.

albums.title: Puff O’Gigio
albums.label: Bad Paintings
albums.description: On their fourth album together, Xiu Xiu and Larsen create a sense of cinematic whimsy anchored around a mythological creature who helps with household chores.

albums.title: The Chic Organization 1977-1979
albums.label: Rhino
albums.description: The latest in a long line of box sets and anthologies collects the pioneering disco duo’s core albums. Despite the songs’ deep familiarity, they still represent pop at its most triumphant and complex.

albums.title: MONOAkuma
albums.label: Room40
albums.description: Meant as an introduction to 40 years of a prolific noise icon, this live recording moves between grating analog and prickling digital modes with unmitigated force.

albums.title: DiCaprio 2
albums.label: Dreamville
albums.description: The East Atlanta rapper’s second album doesn't try to take on the world and is all the better for it, showing that J.I.D. has much more to offer than his formidable rapping chops.

albums.title: Evil Genius
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: Though it’s one of his most considered and carefully curated projects, Gucci plays it uncharacteristically safe for most of it.

albums.title: Sky Lake
albums.label: Tiny Engines
albums.description: Fleshing out its classic indie-rock sound with synths, Auto-Tune, and other hazy production touches, the North Carolina duo searches for dream-pop atmospheres in the muggy Florida landscape.

albums.title: Send Flowers
albums.label: Sophomore Lounge
albums.description: The Midwestern band’s fourth album cleans up their “punked-up country gunk,” giving more space to Ryan Davis’ incisive, deceptively offhand lyrics.

albums.title: Your Dog
albums.label: Father/Daughter
albums.description: After years of recording and quietly releasing beatific folk music, the Bay Area singer/songwriter flexes her voice and vision on pop songs of complicated feelings and private anxieties.

albums.title: Look
albums.label: New Deal
albums.description: The rising producer has made records with John Legend and Perfume Genius. On his new instrumental record, he expresses exquisite vulnerability at the intersection of ambient and modern classical.

albums.title: Manos
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: One of the first non-grunge bands on Sub Pop showed just how malleable underground pop could be; a quarter-century later, their debut remains a bracing, brazen showcase of rock minimalism.

albums.title: Paranoid
albums.label: Vertigo
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the dawn of metal, a document of dreary working-class blight and anti-war screeds.

albums.title: EP ONE
albums.label: Nomad
albums.description: On her debut EP, the Kazakh/British violinist, likely most familiar from work with Radiohead, creates teeming and imagistic environments with four strings and electronics.

albums.title: Hence
albums.label: Editions Mego
albums.description: On their third duo album, the two longtime accomplices balance free-improv flux with compositional rigor in a suite-like piece for guitar, electronics, and tabla.

albums.title: Pop Ambient 2019
albums.label: Kompakt
albums.description: Kompakt co-founder Wolfgang Voigt curates the latest in the label’s ambient series with a compilation of dark and moody tracks that reflect the best of what modern-day ambient has to offer.

albums.title: Throne
albums.label: Editions Mego
albums.description: Known for her improvisational aplomb, the pedal steel guitarist and singer returns with her second and most complex batch of composed songs, subversive and rich documents of love and lust.

albums.title: Utopia Teased
albums.label: Western Vinyl
albums.description: Recorded in the wake of the Ghost Ship fire and in a haze of psychedelics, these luminous pop songs articulate grief as a means of moving past it.

albums.title: The Pains of Growing
albums.label: Def Jam
albums.description: The pop singer hits a soft reset on her second album, which isn’t a revelation, but it has the tinge of a project made with love and devotion.

albums.title: Brace Up!
albums.label: Palilalia
albums.description: On their studio debut, these frenzied improvisers tap the ecstasy and explosiveness of their onstage chemistry while capturing their ideas and enthusiasms in vivid, glorious detail.

albums.title: Young HeartThrob
albums.label: Epic
albums.description: On her debut LP, the young Atlanta rapper and singer avoids guests and try-hard hits while embracing a voice that runs like water.

albums.title: Heavy Down Pour EP
albums.label: Misery Club
albums.description: The latest project from the alt-rap Misery Club member showcases his dynamic voice and features a grip of collaborators from Clams Casino to Alice Glass that often overshadow Zubin’s personality.

albums.title: Live at Third Man Records
albums.label: Third Man
albums.description: Recorded in Nashville, the spare set of songs taken from his last three solo albums is a minor but revealing statement from the graceful singer-songwriter.

albums.title: Breakfast
albums.label: Gloriette
albums.description: Borrowing the sample-crazed approach of the Avalanches, this unlikely California trio create winning tunes from a junkyard jumble of soft-rock keys and big breakbeats.

albums.title: Glastonbury 2000
albums.label: Parlophone
albums.description: The workmanlike renditions of hits he hadn’t played in years don’t rank among his best live takes, but there’s still a thrill in revisiting this curious point in the shape-shifting star’s career.

albums.title: From the Dirt
albums.label: Dirt Tech Reck
albums.description: The Detroit producer and Slum Village alum makes house music that’s true to his hometown’s diverse, deeply rooted legacy, with elements of R&B, funk, and soul informing its four-to-the-floor bounce.

albums.title: Merrie Land
albums.artist: The Good, the Bad & the Queen
albums.label: Studio 13
albums.description: On its first album in 11 years, the Damon Albarn-fronted supergroup tackles Brexit head on. In his “Anglo-Saxistentialist” reckoning, false nostalgia imperils a true vision of British identity.

albums.title: IIWII (It Is What It Is)
albums.label: Pro Era
albums.description: The Pro Era rapper finds the middle of the road on his latest project, chasing hot sounds in lieu of finding his own.

albums.title: Diplomatic Ties
albums.label: Set Life
albums.description: Dipset were always a theater of the absurd. On their first album in more than a decade, Cam’ron, Juelz Santana, and Jim Jones become a trio of almost no effort.

albums.title: Championships
albums.label: Maybach Music Group
albums.description: Despite being born of injustice, an air of victory hangs over Meek’s first full-length since he was released from prison. It captures an intensity that the Philadelphia rapper is known for and best at.

albums.title: Iron Maiden / Killers / The Number of the Beast / Piece Of Mind
albums.label: Parlophone
albums.description: Though at least two of Maiden’s first four albums are metal masterpieces, they showcase a band eagerly evolving while building a classic lineup in a breathless four-year span.

albums.title: Spencer Sings the Hits!
albums.label: In the Red
albums.description: For his first album under his own name, the ever-wild guitar renegade lampoons the posers and newbies while again rewiring rock’n’roll until the circuits almost short.

albums.title: Like Memory Foam
albums.label: Damnably
albums.description: On their second record, the Columbus, Ohio quartet play away the pain.

albums.title: DUMMY BOY
albums.label: ScumGang Records
albums.description: There’s nothing redeeming about Tekashi 6ix9ine’s DUMMY BOY, though he surely wishes there was.

albums.title: WARM
albums.label: dBpm
albums.description: On his first ever collection of original solo songs—a companion piece to his recent memoir—the Wilco leader uncovers himself like never before.

albums.title: Homework
albums.label: Virgin
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Daft Punk’s debut, the duo’s greatest illusion yet.

albums.title: Songs for Judy
albums.label: Shakey Pictures
albums.description: Collecting two-dozen highlights from 1976 solo sets, this candid document finds the singer sorting through old standards and almost-lost classics at a particularly restless moment.

albums.title: Tommy Genesis
albums.label: Downtown
albums.description: On her debut album, the playful Canadian rapper is bossed up, horny, or lonely as she searches for a sound to match her shrugged-off swagger.

albums.title: The Bela Session
albums.label: Leaving
albums.description: The original studio version of goth’s transcendent standard finally gets reissued alongside three songs that show just how quickly the band progressed.

albums.title: Ens
albums.label: Thrill Jockey
albums.description: After two astounding EPs last year, half of the droning duo Mountains returns with an intimate, affectionate album inspired by the birth of his child.

albums.title: Spoken By the Other EP
albums.label: XL
albums.description: The mischievous electronic producer teams up with the photographer on an album where the latter’s voice becomes the source material for unsettling tracks full of silence and space.

albums.title: Magnetic Memory
albums.label: Don Giovanni
albums.description: The Anti-Pop Consortium rapper and producer imagines the death of hip-hop as a means for exploring histories both personal and political: “To write like it’s the afterlife.”

albums.title: Some Rap Songs
albums.label: Tan Cressida
albums.description: With his latest record, the onetime teen prodigy reemerges as the face of a new sound and scene that blurs the line between avant-garde jazz and hip-hop.

albums.title: Anne
albums.label: Western Vinyl
albums.description: On his second solo album, the saxophonist and Destroyer collaborator grapples with intergenerational trauma by turning interviews with his mother into gorgeous and empathetic ambient music.

albums.title: The Dream My Bones Dream
albums.label: Drag City
albums.description: Again working with producer Jim O’Rourke, the Japanese singer/songwriter explores a peculiar family history in songs that pull her own musical past into the present.

albums.title: Look Now Look Again
albums.label: Polyvinyl
albums.description: A timely reissue of this prescient Midwest emo band’s back catalog—including their second and best album—shows how they transformed sadness into searching euphoria.

albums.title: “Ouch”
albums.label: Tin Angel
albums.description: The Vancouver singer-songwriter lays everything bare on his latest record.

albums.title: A Brief Inquiry Into Online Relationships
albums.label: Dirty Hit
albums.description: The British band’s outrageous and eclectic third album attests to the worth of putting in an honest effort in the face of near-constant gloom.

albums.title: Daily Routine
albums.label: Peder Mannerfelt Produktion
albums.description: On his most extreme and cohesive solo album yet, the Swedish producer and Fever Ray collaborator steers from the dancefloor while locating a sense of humor within techno.

albums.title: Creed II: The Album
albums.label: Eardruma
albums.description: Whereas the first Creed soundtrack reached for the rafters, the sequel is placeless and tame. Its only muse seems to be Mike WiLL’s contact list.

albums.title: G I R L C O D E
albums.label: Quality Control
albums.description: The Miami duo’s new album builds on the strengths of their recent mixtape with speaker-rattling songs about pleasure, power, and strong women unapologetically getting their own way.

albums.title: Terminal
albums.label: UIQ
albums.description: The Cairo electronic linchpin at last combines his kinetic production and hip-hop acumen in quick blasts that delightfully warp the words of some of Egypt’s best rappers.

albums.title: The Fuzz EP
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: Linnea Siggelkow downsized her city of choice, a move that inspired her to confront confusion and ambivalence in six dream-pop gems that carve out a welcome space of security.

albums.title: Moriyama EP
albums.label: Palto Flats
albums.description: The Japanese footwork producer largely steps away from the genre on this five-track EP, exploring an illusion of motion through a woozy sense of space and stillness.

albums.title: Fever Focus EP
albums.label: LuckyMe
albums.description: After last year’s Feel Infinite, the Canadian producer expands and refines his arsenal of club tools, folding touches of acid and ambient into tracks that build on his melodic sensibilities.

albums.title: Shugga Sextape Vol. 1
albums.label: UNO NYC
albums.description: The latest mixtape from this brilliantly over-the-top R&B singer finds him mixing spirituality with salaciousness while creating a heavily Auto-Tuned space somewhere between T-Pain and SOPHIE.

albums.title: Love in the Time of Lexapro EP
albums.label: Warp
albums.description: After the fantastical Age Of, Daniel Lopatin plays it relatively straight on this four-track EP, though reworks from Ryuichi Sakamoto and (Sandy) Alex G take his material in intriguing new directions.

albums.title: The Lillywhite Sessions
albums.label: Dead Oceans
albums.description: On what may seem like a readymade gag, the psych-folk favorite covers the lost Dave Matthews Band album in full. He convincingly connects his adolescent love to his adult explorations.

albums.title: Ghost Box (Expanded)
albums.label: Northern Spy
albums.description: After the Western soundscapes of their debut album took hold through Spotify, the New York quintet return with an expanded edition of their meditative, magnetic debut.

albums.title: Acrylic
albums.label: Hardcover
albums.description: On her second album, the mysterious Brooklyn rapper begins to pull back the mask with vivid reporting about the trials and triumphs of her home and the resilience of black womanhood.

albums.title: Moondance
albums.label: Warner Bros.
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Van Morrison’s 1970 classic.

albums.title: Ghost Forests
albums.label: Three Lobed
albums.description: On their debut collaboration, the acclaimed harpist and the Espers singer pull long songs and meditative moods taut by creating unexpected tangles.

albums.title: Wham! Bang! Pow! Let’s Rock Out!
albums.label: Alcopop!
albums.description: After a seven-year absence, a band whose quest for rock’n’roll fame always mixed a piss-take with genuine aspiration return in charmingly humbled fashion.

albums.title: Love & Work: The Lioness Sessions
albums.label: Secretly Canadian
albums.description: On this installment in a series of expanded reissues from the vaults of the late Jason Molina, love songs with raw nerves document a tender, transitional period in his career.

albums.title: Caution
albums.label: Epic
albums.description: On her 15th album, the R&B singer celebrates her ultimate-diva status by sticking to her core pop-soul aesthetic, despite collaborators like Poo Bear, Dev Hynes, and Skrillex.

albums.title: LillyAnna
albums.label: Whatever
albums.description: On her solo debut, the veteran songwriter turns from writing hits for Shawn Mendes and One Direction to establishing her own voice.

albums.title: Grapetooth
albums.label: Polyvinyl
albums.description: These synth-pop goofs attempt to translate the fun of their intoxicating stage show into their debut record, but they mostly make effortlessness seem insincere.

albums.title: Music Inspired by Illumination & Dr. Seuss’ The Grinch EP
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: Tyler, the Creator goes green.

albums.title: Delta
albums.label: Gentlemen of the Road
albums.description: Having shed the beardy affect and folksy shuffle, the band could now slip mostly unnoticed between Imagine Dragons and twenty one pilots, but their newly palatable sound could really use more quirks.

albums.title: Sinner EP
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: The young rapper’s typically erratic nature is missing from his latest EP. Instead, he is just hurried and sluggish.

albums.title: Superstition
albums.label: Prosthetic
albums.description: These belligerent North Carolinians epitomize the crossover vitriol of metal and punk in 2018 and help signal the crucially political personality of their label.

albums.title: Lover Chanting EP
albums.label: Ninja Tune
albums.description: On their first-ever EP, the Swedish dance-pop band again aim for escapism while failing to realize that the format offers a chance for exactly that.

albums.title: Shiny and Oh So Bright, Vol. 1 / LP: No Past. No Future. No Sun.
albums.label: Napalm
albums.description: The legends of ’90s alt-rock have reunited only to bring this puzzling, indecisive husk of an album into the world.

albums.title: Negative Capability
albums.label: Panta Rei
albums.description: At the age of 71, the British singer who helped define rock-star redemption shares gorgeous and vulnerable self-portraits, shaped by an ace backing band that sometimes includes Nick Cave.

albums.title: 2 Minute Drills EP
albums.label: Play Runners Association
albums.description: The rising Oakland rapper and the Connecticut-raised beatmaker team up for a short and ridiculously fun tape about football, talking shit, pimping, and more football.

albums.title: Hellboy
albums.label: self-released
