albums.description: With Youth Lagoon in the rear-view, Trevor Powers remains a sure-handed sculptor of sound. His voice here surges to the fore, newly exposed and digitally treated.

albums.title: Future Me Hates Me
albums.label: Carpark
albums.description: The debut from Auckland indie rockers is just really impressive—hook-filled songs filled with energy and attitude, written with depth and played masterfully.

albums.title: Slimeball 3
albums.label: Paradise East
albums.description: At his best—as on this third installment of his Slimeball series—Nudy can distill the influence of Atlanta’s integral artists into his a world of his own.

albums.title: At Weddings
albums.label: Saddle Creek
albums.description: Sarah Beth Tomberlin’s debut album traces the hole left by the loss of her faith, filling it in with wave-like acoustic phrases and a sharp-eyed attention to everyday details.

albums.title: The Diet
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: The former Smith Westerns member’s second album represents a return to his core strengths: crystalline, cosmically ornate melodies and wryly clear-eyed lyrics.

albums.title: Suffuse
albums.label: Ba Da Bing Records
albums.description: After tentative vocal experiments on 2016’s R M H Q, the New Zealand guitarist crafts an entire album around guest singers, all women, in which he progressively blurs the traces of his own handiwork.

albums.title: Be the Cowboy
albums.label: Dead Oceans
albums.description: The fifth album from the singular songwriter is her greatest to date. From the music to her emotions, Mitski has the power to make the complex seem dazzlingly clear.

albums.title: Tangerine Reef
albums.label: Domino
albums.description: Composed by Avey Tare, Geologist, and Deakin, AnCo’s second audiovisual album reckons abstractly with the environmental devastation and the potentially horrifying consequences yet to come.

albums.title: Time
albums.label: Brainfeeder
albums.description: Drummer Louis Cole’s sidelong blend of hard funk and soft pop—aided by guest spots from Thundercat and Brad Mehldau—remains delightfully sly and off-kilter.

albums.title: Flintlock
albums.label: Treasure Chest Entertainment
albums.description: Given a leg up by Roc Marciano, the veteran rapper returns with his own take on classic, streetwise East Coast rap: tales of nefarious business delivered in painstaking, and often chilling, detail.

albums.title: forever & ever
albums.label: SALES Universe
albums.description: On their second record, the Orlando duo create a world of cozy, minimalist pop.

albums.title: Heart Head West
albums.label: Downtown
albums.description: The actress’ full-length debut is firm in its influences but lacking in variety.

albums.title: Life’s a Trip
albums.label: 10K Projects
albums.description: Chasing hits and fighting against his own strengths prevent Trippie Redd’s debut album from having a seismic impact.

albums.title: Nostrum Grocers
albums.label: Ruby Yacht
albums.description: Having evolved from his early days as art rap’s cocky philosopher in chief, milo displays a newfound confidence alongside Elucid, a grittier and more seasoned lyricist.

albums.title: The Voice of Love
albums.label: Sacred Bones
albums.description: The reissue of Julee Cruise’s second album, featuring David Lynch and Angelo Badalamenti, follows the singer on her dizzying dream-pop trajectory, where love and loss are flip sides of the same coin.

albums.title: Being Woke Ain’t Fun
albums.label: New Deal Collectives
albums.description: The Chicago rapper is something of an outcast in his hometown’s hip-hop scene, delivering slick punchlines over boom-bap beats. His third project in four months is his best, but he’s got room to grow.

albums.title: Bell House
albums.label: Polyvinyl
albums.description: Bubblegum surf-pop meets Midwestern earnestness on the Kansas City quintet’s sweet, funny, but sometimes inscrutable sophomore album.

albums.title: Queen
albums.label: Young Money Entertainment
albums.description: On her most rap-oriented release yet, Nicki jettisons all the industry madness, drowns out the noise, and creates rap the way she believes it should sound.

albums.title: RAM 7: August 1791
albums.label: Willibelle Publishing & Sales
albums.description: With history and folklore as its backdrop, the Haitian band moves further away from Western styles to focus on Creole tradition and West African roots.

albums.title: Locations, Processed
albums.label: Moog Records
albums.description: The veteran field-recording artist turns his microphones on New York City in the attempt to capture something essential lurking within the ephemeral.

albums.title: Body
albums.label: Northern Spy
albums.description: The Necks’ 20th album is as laser-focused on repetition as ever. But for the first time, the trio indulges its rock’n’roll instincts, resulting in one of the most powerful albums in the band’s catalog.

albums.title: Nearer My God
albums.label: Triple Crown
albums.description: The St. Louis band’s third album is big, beautiful, and audacious, an artful leap toward creating the new sound of rafter-shaking indie rock.

albums.title: Loyalty Over Love
albums.label: Sick Wid It
albums.description: The latest project from the Sacramento by way of Mobile rapper is a rich portrait of loneliness, suspicion, and weariness, showcasing his eye for observation and a knack for self-examination.

albums.title: Earl
albums.label: OFWGKTA
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit Earl Sweatshirt’s debut mixtape, the keystone to Odd Future’s success.

albums.title: Born Again in the Voltage
albums.label: Important Records
albums.description: After the complex programming of last year’s Patterns of Consciousness, the Berlin-based composer explores new realms with her modular synthesizer, incorporating cello, voice, and doom-laden drones.

albums.title: Bandwagonesque / Thirteen / Grand Prix / Songs from Northern Britain / Howdy!
albums.label: Sony Legacy
albums.description: These vinyl reissues of the Scottish power-pop luminaries’ outstanding Creation Records output showcase a band whose music captures the feeling of living with the music you love.

albums.title: What Another Man Spills
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: On this sparkling reissue of an early career highlight, the act that billed itself as “the most fucked-up country band in Nashville” revels in the ecstasy of influence.

albums.title: Late 20s
albums.label: YOU.KNOW.I.GOT.IT Entertainment
albums.description: On the Berkeley rapper’s second album, he struggles with depression in stark, evocative terms, confirming his stature as one of the most intensely cathartic narrators out there.

albums.title: Coup de Grace
albums.label: Virgin
albums.description: The louche UK singer returns with an album that thrusts ahead quickly and painlessly but leaves you itching to shower off its overpowering cologne the second it’s over.

albums.title: Devotion
albums.label: Domino
albums.description: Produced by Mica Levi, Tirzah’s debut is a compelling vision of what imperfect pop music can be—joyful in both sound and feeling precisely because both seem so out-of-step and asymmetrical.

albums.title: Jake Shears
albums.label: Freida Jean Records
albums.description: The Scissor Sisters frontman’s solo debut could’ve been a disaster: A pop star moseys down to New Orleans to find “real music.” But if you’re not a stickler for authenticity, it’s actually irresistible.

albums.title: Dia del Asesinato
albums.label: Soul Assassins
albums.description: The veteran producer and Cypress Hill alum reconnects with his New York roots on a fun, if not terribly challenging, revivalist romp surrounded by outer-borough icons and a few hungry upstarts.

albums.title: Lithium Zion
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: The Melbourne quartet’s fifth album doesn’t counteract any Sonic Youth comparisons, but it does conjure an alternate history where the rock formalism of Goo and Dirty became the band’s defining sound.

albums.title: Live at Third Man Records ||| Nashville & Cass Corridor
albums.label: Third Man
albums.description: Released through Third Man’s record club, Jack White’s 3xLP live set takes some of his knotty, obtuse songs from this year’s Boarding House Reach and lets them breathe on stage.

albums.title: Dissolvi
albums.label: Ghostly
albums.description: No longer content to deconstruct the droning sounds of his former band, the Emeralds alum gives Kompakt-style minimal techno a try.

albums.title: Emergency Raps, Vol. 3
albums.label: Mutant Academy
albums.description: The Virginia producer lays out chopped loops for the surrealistic rapper Koncept Jack$on, whose narrow-eyed presence plays off the rest of the Mutant Academy crew.

albums.title: 4Milli
albums.label: OVO Sound
albums.description: Across 25 torturous minutes, the Toronto rapper doesn’t make a single lasting impression as a performer, storyteller, or craftsman. He’ll do well on OVO.

albums.title: Vicious Circles EP
albums.label: Planet Mu
albums.description: In their latest joint release, Kanye producer Sinjin Hawke and Jlin collaborator Zora Jones combine human voices and digital processing to manifest a seamless fusion of flesh and code.

albums.title: Survive the Summer EP
albums.label: Island
albums.description: On the embattled rapper’s latest EP, Iggy Azalea knows what a good rap song sounds like in the abstract but is simply incapable of making one.

albums.title: Someday Everything Will Be Fine
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: The North Carolina trio’s fifth record show a softer side, but some moments yearn for their trademark snarkiness.

albums.title: Genericana
albums.label: Western Vinyl
albums.description: Despite its title, Joseph O’Connell’s second release for Western Vinyl is his most distinctive release to date, an elegant study of life’s circularity set against a backdrop of slowcore folk and woozy rock.

albums.title: Paradise: The Sound of Ivor Raymonde
albums.label: Bella Union
albums.description: The composer behind Dusty Springfield’s “I Only Want to Be With You” also worked with David Bowie, the Walker Brothers, and Ian Dury. A new compilation reveals how he helped shape 1960s British pop.

albums.title: Astroworld
albums.label: Epic
albums.description: Travis Scott’s third album is inarguably his strongest to date. His skill as a curator helps sculpt a sticky, humid, psychedelic world with dazzling production and odd pleasures at every turn.

albums.title: The Nature of Imitation
albums.label: Brainfeeder
albums.description: On his second solo album, Austrian producer and Flying Lotus associate Oliver Johnson puts his own eclectic spin on FlyLo’s brand of over-caffeinated astral jazz and hiccuping robo-breaks.

albums.title: Stay Dangerous
albums.label: Def Jam
albums.description: Filled with numbing vulgarity, warmed-over nostalgia, and actual nursery rhymes, YG’s third studio album is a mindless step backward.

albums.title: Baby Grand
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: After three albums packed with peach-sweet melodies, a move to the West Coast inspires one of indie rock’s most underrated songwriters to supercharge his sound and upgrade his showmanship.

albums.title: Ba Suba, Ak Jamm EP
albums.label: Grand Closing
albums.description: The Brooklyn rapper has a reputation for emulating Earl Sweatshirt’s brutal atmospherics and determined flow, but what sets him apart is the emotional precision he brings to his debut EP.

albums.title: Amici
albums.label: Upset the Rhythm
albums.description: The Melbourne post-punk band makes a messy life feel easier to untangle, writing songs with an appealing simplicity, buoyancy, and emotional openness.

albums.title: Faith
albums.label: Epic
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit the liminal sex-pop of George Michael’s 1987 debut album.

albums.title: There’s Always Glimmer
albums.label: Orindal
albums.description: The Chicago-based songwriter sees singing about personal experiences as an act of violence, but her debut LP translates that dark view into 34 minutes of surprisingly serene, perceptive storytelling.

albums.title: At WAR With Myself Too
albums.label: Grind Hard
albums.description: A decade into the East Nashville rapper’s latest incarnation, he delves into the dark corners of his mind on an album that’s dense, prickly, and full of jarring personal details.

albums.title: Manhunter Original Motion Picture Music
albums.label: Waxwork
albums.description: Michael Mann’s 1986 film was a critical and commercial flop, but its soundtrack has proved a major inspiration for the music supervision on projects like Drive and “Stranger Things.”

albums.title: Channel Tres EP
albums.label: Godmode
albums.description: Channel Tres barely avoided the EDM world. And thank god for that. He turns in a debut EP of dark and deep hip-house with tons of promise.

albums.title: Qualm
albums.label: Ninja Tune
albums.description: The Hamburg musician’s second album is a spartan mix of techno, acid, EBM, and coldwave. Even at her most damaged, Helena Hauff’s take on noise is nothing short of opulent.

albums.title: Swimming
albums.label: Warner Bros.
albums.description: On his wounded fifth album, Mac Miller sings deftly about heartbreak and his mental state, capturing his resignation without turning sadness into a performative spectacle.

albums.title: At Your Leisure
albums.label: Topshelf
albums.description: The Chicago-based band sounds more consistent—but also more risk-averse—than ever on a guitar-driven album that’s as peaceful and unchallenging as its title suggests.

albums.title: Sleep Like It’s Winter
albums.label: Newhere
albums.description: Jim O’Rourke doesn’t much care for ambient music, so it makes sense that his first ambient album picks apart the genre and scrutinizes its attempts to produce truly structureless music.

albums.title: Oli Gumm
albums.label: трип
albums.description: The five tracks here are among the most satisfying productions the Icelandic musician has released, a mix of comic, deranged, and weirdly sensual moods.

albums.title: Repeat/Metal/Made Available/Live 80-81
albums.label: Light in the Attic
albums.description: A set of reissues of the British experimental trio’s non-album work, including a Peel sessions EP, live LP, and posthumous anthology, reveals the group’s restless, radical openness.

albums.title: Book of Life
albums.label: Erased Tapes
albums.description: On his first solo album since his 2016 collaboration with Jan Jelinek, the experimental vibraphonist blurs the edges of his instrument in compositions both abstract and warmly sentimental.

albums.title: Nova
albums.label: Wedidit
albums.description: Henry Steinway’s second full-length largely abandons the cool-kid stylistic tics of his debut for something bigger, brighter, and wholly anonymous.

albums.title: Bringing the Backline
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: If Bristol-based songwriter Ellis Jones’ witty yet melancholy final album as Trust Fund has an overarching theme, it’s how deeply disenchanted he feels with making music.

albums.title: Swervo
albums.label: Machine Entertainment Group
albums.description: The Chicago rapper’s latest project as his alter-ego named Swervo is all velocity. He delivers some of his starkest verses like a steamroller, almost completely desensitized.

albums.title: Head in the Clouds
albums.label: 88rising
albums.description: For this 88rising showcase, Joji, Rich Brian, AUGUST 08, and the rest of the label all act like promising pop stars but are often overshadowed by the outside talent they bring along.

albums.title: Change the Station / Mind Made Up
albums.label: Mute
albums.description: Two reissues from the Manchester veterans track the progress of their post-punk/disco fusions into the 1990s and 2000s—an uneven path, but their freewheeling energy still charms.

albums.title: Teatime Dub Encounters EP
albums.label: Caroline International
albums.description: On their collaborative EP, the UK electronic duo provides a lush and polished bed of sound for Iggy Pop to grouse about the state of the world.

albums.title: Fine
albums.label: Dais
albums.description: On his third and final album as SONOIO, Alessandro Cortini of Nine Inch Nails combines the brooding intensity of Trent Reznor’s band with arena-rock melodies in the vein of U2 and Depeche Mode.

albums.title: Ares
albums.label: Pina
albums.description: The reggaeton stalwart and Latin trap pioneer embraces contemporary pop and hip-hop sounds on an uneven album that is at its most interesting when it verges into soul, salsa, and other novel styles.

albums.title: Amazon to LeFrak EP
albums.label: Phantom Limb
albums.description: The debut EP from Cibo Matto veteran Miho Hatori builds on her former band’s experimental pop aesthetic while dialing down their quirky tendencies and moving into more mature subject matter.

albums.title: Bag of Holding
albums.label: NNA Tapes
albums.description: Singer-songwriter Paco Cathcart taps into mysticism on his newest release as the Cradle, something fantastical, folky, and intensely imaginative.

albums.title: A Heart From Your Shadow
albums.label: Mondoj
albums.description: Mixed by Jim O’Rourke, the duo’s debut is a progression of left turns and interruptions—drone blasts, electronic spasms, lyrical cello—whose unpredictability mimics the rhythms of city life.

albums.title: Silk Canvas
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: The debut album from the Nigerian-American sisters in VanJess is a captivating fusion of 1990s R&B with contemporary electronic touches; its defining feature is the sisters’ uncanny synchronicity.

albums.title: I Don’t Want: The Gold Fire Sessions
albums.label: Downtown
albums.description: The singer’s latest mixtape is soulful, summery, and without borders. Thanks in part to the production of Mixpak’s Dre Skull, Santigold commits to a careful interpolation of the dancehall sound.

albums.title: Poison
albums.label: MCA
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit a 1990 R&B blockbuster that bridged the gap between new jack swing and hip-hop soul.

albums.title: Daniel Aged
albums.label: Quality Time
albums.description: One half of the brother act Inc. makes his solo debut with a satisfying collection of ambient-funk instrumentals that sound easy without being facile and chill without ever becoming soporific.

albums.title: Kill the Lights
albums.label: Slumberland
albums.description: The master of the micro-song goes power pop on an ambitious release whose songs slide along the spectrum from sadness to madness, capturing Molina’s grief over a lost love.

albums.title: Family Portrait
albums.label: Brainfeeder
albums.description: On his debut album, the UK producer attempts to shake the shackles of “lo-fi house” in search of a more nuanced understanding of dance-music nostalgia, but he can’t quite escape the shadow of his influences.

albums.title: Opal
albums.label: Requiem Pour Un Twister
albums.description: Lionel Williams’ fourth album brings new melodic clarity to his kaleidoscopic variations on soft-focus psych pop, pushing his songs into the realm of pure, escapist pleasure.

albums.title: The Station EP
albums.label: Warp
albums.description: Daniel Lopatin’s latest release is less a conceptual follow-up to last month’s Age Of than a gift to hardcore fans who relish even his odds and ends.

albums.title: Best to Ever Do It
albums.label: SODMG
albums.description: Soulja Boy just isn’t able to capitalize on his recent goodwill with some worthwhile new music.

albums.title: The Morning Star
albums.label: Three Lobed
albums.description: No longer content to play music tethered to the past, the Virginia guitarist uses field recordings and unsettling ambient experiments to remake his virtuosic folk compositions for the present.

albums.title: TA13OO
albums.label: Loma Vista
albums.description: The South Florida rapper carves out his own lane within the genre known as SoundCloud rap, displaying considerable versatility as he channels the pain and confusion of youth.

albums.title: Rolling Papers 2
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: The latest album from Wiz is a bloated and expensive version of the rap he’s always made but without that signature effortlessness.

albums.title: Porter 2 Grape EP
albums.label: EMPIRE
albums.description: On the first record to appear since 03 Greedo’s incarceration, the L.A. rapper teams up with Vallejo’s Nef the Pharaoh on a breezy five-track EP that makes the most of their respective strengths.

albums.title: Almost
albums.label: Joyful Noise
albums.description: Featuring production assistance from Yoni Wolf of WHY?, the Cincinnati quartet’s second album uses bright surfaces to obscure sinister intentions, clothing dark songs in indie-pop innocence.

albums.title: Sacracorpa
albums.label: Trouble in Mind
albums.description: The final installment in a trilogy of albums by Chicago experimentalist Whitney Johnson gets its motifs from nature and its emotional immediacy from the musician’s recent medical emergency.

albums.title: Collected Acknowledgements
albums.label: Stucco
albums.description: The Olympia punks’ second album presents a chiming, inventive take on post-punk that's shot through with sly humor, madcap time signatures, and wild abandon.

albums.title: Be Yourself EP
albums.label: Tay Bennett Entertainment
albums.description: On his latest project, the Chicago MC deftly explores self-affirmation and paper-chasing without really finding the tension between the two.

albums.title: Here From Where We Are
albums.label: Houndstooth
albums.description: Eight years after releasing his first UK bass single, London’s Arthur Cayzer offers a debut LP of ambient music whose invocation of canonical tropes plays like a love letter to the resurgent genre.

albums.title: Marlowe
albums.label: Mello Music Group
albums.description: On their first collaborative album, Seattle producer L’Orange and North Carolina rapper Solemn Brigham craft spirited, old-school rap that owes a hefty debt to Madvillain.

albums.title: Hive Mind
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: The fourth album from the R&B collective is a peak example of their combined powers. It simplifies their sound with soft-focus blues, plush arrangements, and deep-in-the-ground grooves.

albums.title: Demur EP
albums.label: Flumo
albums.description: Cleveland producer Warren Harris pushes the deep house sound into rhythmical challenges and brilliantly gothic alcoves with the apparent nonchalance of someone barely breaking a sweat.

albums.title: The Order of Change
albums.label: Music From Memory
albums.description: Amsterdam label Music From Memory continues its revival of late-20th-century Mediterranean sounds with this collection of works by Spanish multi-instrumentalist Suso Sáiz's eclectic ’80s new age trio.

albums.title: Harlan & Alondra
albums.label: RCA
albums.description: The debut from versatile Compton rapper offers a perspective that is close enough to suffer turbulence but removed enough to avoid succumbing to it.

albums.title: Third
albums.label: No Quarter
albums.description: The guitarist’s latest album features almost nothing but the sweet sounds of his instrument. You’ll know within its opening notes whether this music is for you—and if it is, you’ll feel instantly at home.

albums.title: Tru
albums.label: Exploding in Sound
albums.description: On their first album in half a decade, Steve Hartlett and his reunited band of fuzz-rockers turn up both the overdrive and the emotion, fortifying tender songs with muscular squall.

albums.title: Cosmo’s Factory
albums.label: Fantasy
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore Creedence Clearwater Revival’s improbable stardom with 1970’s Cosmo’s Factory.

albums.title: New Lows
albums.label: Fool's Gold
albums.description: The debut album from the Queens crew is fiery and kinetic, mining the history of New York rap without coming up with much of anything new.

albums.title: Forever
albums.label: Mixpak
albums.description: Popcaan’s second album is full of faith, joy, and the wealth of his international pop celebrity, but falters when it comes to his idea of romance.

albums.title: Yolk in the Fur
albums.label: Tiny Engines
albums.description: Following a debut steeped in generational aimlessness, the Brooklyn band’s second album thrives on a combination of rock extroversion and frontman John Ross’ hard-won and tenuous new optimism.

albums.title: Joy
albums.label: Drag City
albums.description: Ty Segall and Tim Presley lock into a psychedelic hive mind again for an exciting, wildly varied album made to be combed through and prodded.

albums.title: Devouring Radiant Light
albums.label: Prosthetic
albums.description: The Ohio party animals scale back the turnt-up thrash of their past in favor of nuanced black metal—without losing their feral edge—on their first full-length with vocalist Adam Clemans.

albums.title: Feel My Pain EP
albums.label: SOB X RBE
albums.description: Post-breakout solo releases are supposed to be this-is-my-time proclamations, but the SOB x RBE member’s project feels engineered to bring out his pathos.

albums.title: Single Rider
albums.label: Hardly Art
albums.description: Carissa’s Wierd alum makes her first foray into crowd-pleasing synth pop in an intriguing collaboration with Seattle-based producer SYML.

albums.title: Homotopy to Marie
albums.label: Rotorelief
albums.description: Decades after its release, the industrial innovators’ newly reissued masterpiece sounds as terrifying as ever—and claims its place in history as a bridge between generations of avant-garde art.

albums.title: Filo Loves the Acid
albums.label: Tresor
albums.description: It’s possible that nobody needs another 303 workout, but the Italian producer’s latest album proves that a programmer of his caliber can still wring some ecstasy from the machine.

albums.title: Don’t Mess With Cupid, ‘Cause Cupid Ain’t Stupid
albums.label: трип
albums.description: A compilation from Nina Kraviz’ трип label connects the dots between leftfield techno, acid, and breakneck hardcore, forging an adventurous style evocative of warehouse raves in deepest Siberia.

albums.title: The Roxy July 7, 1978
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: At turns explosive and intimate, the three-hour-plus show performed at a small club in West Hollywood is a legendary document of how Bruce and the E Street Band could transform their songs on stage.

albums.title: Sculptor
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: On their third record, the indie-folk duo celebrate choices but settle on none.

albums.title: Disambiguation
albums.label: Drawing Room Records
albums.description: On her debut album as Cruel Diagonals, the Oakland experimental musician Megan Mitchell turns samples sourced from ethnomusicological archives into ambient music that’s both expressive and empathetic.

albums.title: Le Renard Bleu EP
albums.label: !K7
albums.description: On her first new release in almost 20 years, Japanese composer Midori Takada joins London-based musician Lafawndah on a short but fascinating multimedia project with mythical overtones.

albums.title: Raw Silk Uncut Wood
albums.label: Latency
albums.description: Laurel Halo’s most ambient—and most linear—record to date swims in mysterious electro-acoustic textures; it marks a departure from her usual mode of thorny, cerebral electronic composition.

albums.title: 鬼島 Ghost Island EP
albums.label: Danse Noire
albums.description: Taiwanese artist Pon blends traditional mythology and instruments with electronic beats and cacophonous samples on a release inspired by life in—and the urge to escape from—her home city of Taipei.

albums.title: Still Run
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: The alt-R&B duo’s second album remains preoccupied with breakups, but these stories of separation and loss are rendered so dispassionately, it’s hard to feel invested in their outcomes.

albums.title: Power
albums.label: Tri Angle
albums.description: The debut from the Berlin-based producer explores at the idea of power in the world and within themself, tiptoeing the line between exuberance and terror.

albums.title: Lamp Lit Prose
albums.label: Domino
albums.description: Dave Longstreth is on a madcap quest for personal and political salvation on his latest album, reviving a more hopeful, chipper kind of songwriting of his past.

albums.title: Heart 2 Say
albums.label: Different
albums.description: Singer Rosita Bonita and producer Prinz George prove R&B can still be crazy, sexy, cool on a mixtape that favors the uptempo ’90s grooves of Timbaland, New Edition, and especially TLC.

albums.title: Fink
albums.label: Double Double Whammy
albums.description: Evolving from the lo-fi sound of his home recordings, the New York singer-songwriter significantly steps up his studio chops, but his songs’ emotional register often remains frustratingly oblique.

albums.title: 400 Degreez
albums.label: Cash Money
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore the rise of Cash Money on Juvenile’s 1998 classic 400 Degreez.

albums.title: Closer Apart
albums.label: Hyperdub
albums.description: The mostly solid debut album from the South African producer Okzharp and vocalist Manthe Ribane foregoes their earlier sound for something slower and more ponderous.

albums.title: Trouble Anyway
albums.label: Scissor Tail
albums.description: Philadelphia singer-songwriter Rosali Middleman constructs verdant, contemplative rock songs whose soft exteriors conceal a steely core of cool observations about heartache and vulnerability.

albums.title: Death Lust
albums.label: Captured Tracks
albums.description: The proudly suburban Ontario band’s first album uses styles as different as indie pop, shoegaze, and post-hardcore to dramatize frontman Brandon Williams’ journey from despair to rage to resilience.

albums.title: DJ-Kicks
albums.label: !K7
albums.description: DJ Seinfeld’s entry to the long-running mix series is a competent mix of ambient and deep house for the fledgling selector.

albums.title: Sundays
albums.label: Company Records
albums.description: San Francisco musician Hannah Van Loon marries the dreamlike eeriness of the weekend’s final hours with the heaviness of shoegaze on a debut album co-written and produced by Toro Y Moi’s Chaz Bear.

albums.title: Dissidentova
albums.label: AGF Producktion
albums.description: The German experimental musician Antye Greie pays tribute to 16 Russian dissidents, putting cut-up vocals, electronic sound, and collective practice in the service of feminist revolution.

albums.title: The Switch
albums.label: Matador
albums.description: On their most purposeful record to date, Kim Gordon and Bill Nace conjure a complete sonic ecosystem where they control the weather.

albums.title: Ordinary Corrupt Human Love
albums.label: Anti-
albums.description: The most extreme thing about Deafheaven’s remarkable fourth album is how subdued it sounds. It suggests devastation without placing you at the center of it.

albums.title: Supreme Blientele
albums.label: Griselda
albums.description: The ascendent Buffalo rapper combines ’90s boom-bap and a love of wrestling for his latest, which features Anderson .Paak, Busta Rhymes, and more

albums.title: Adepta
albums.label: Fade to Mind
albums.description: Every second of Brooklyn-based DJ and producer Brian Friedberg’s debut album is a cacophony, with sounds that range from Bible-verse vocal samples to foghorns to the tinkling of shattered glass.

albums.title: The Choice
albums.label: Young Turks
albums.description: On a bonus album originally hidden inside gatefold copies of his opus Heaven and Earth, the saxophonist explores his mellower side without breaking any significantly new ground.

albums.title: Pale Lemon
albums.label: Ghost Ramp
albums.description: As recently as last year, So Stressed were a ferocious post-hardcore trio. Now, inspired by the contentment love brings, they make blithe, breezy, and unapologetically melodic pop music.

albums.title: Wandelaar
albums.label: Queeste
albums.description: The debut release on Dutch label Queeste is everything you could wish for in an ambient soundtrack to humid midsummer nights, its melodies as graceful as a swallow’s arc.

albums.title: Vol. 5
albums.label: Yung Bans
albums.description: On his latest project, the Atlanta rapper struggles to break the mold while searching for vulnerability with middling results.

albums.title: Byen
albums.label: Smalltown Supersound
albums.description: After abandoning leftfield disco for a more eclectic brand of weirdness a decade ago, the producer revisits the space disco sounds that made him one of Norway’s original house innovators.

albums.title: BEASTMODE 2
albums.label: Epic
albums.description: The newly vulnerable Future and the hyper-expressive Zaytoven offer up a sequel that doesn’t just reprise the original’s magic but improves on it.

albums.title: Legends of the Summer EP
albums.label: Maybach Music Group
albums.description: The Philadelphia rapper’s first project out of prison is a quick and powerful Meek sampler: the bustling street anthem, the croon-assisted sex jam, the tortured flashback.

albums.title: Valley of Search
albums.label: Valley of Search
albums.description: A 1974 recording from a largely forgotten downtown artist loft space captures some fierce players putting their talents toward a questing, incandescent strain of jazz.

albums.title: Dude, the Obscure
albums.label: Normaltown Records
albums.description: The former Dead Confederate frontman surveys his tangled personal history and uncertain future on a Southern glam rock album that is the highlight of a frustrating career.

albums.title: LP
albums.label: Spectrum Spools
albums.description: Ren Schofield continues to straddle noise and techno on his fourth album, pushing his ramshackle rave music to its breaking point.

albums.title: Uniform Distortion
albums.label: ATO
albums.description: Information overload and its discontents inspire a guitar-heavy solo album that sounds more like a classic My Morning Jacket record than anything James’ band has released in the past 15 years.

albums.title: Ignis EP
albums.label: Cosmo Rhythmatic
albums.description: On the second album to result from a three-year collaboration between late electronic pioneer Mika Vainio and French composer Franck Vigroux, the most striking moments are also the most elemental.

albums.title: I’ll Tell You What!
albums.label: Planet Mu
albums.description: On his first album of all new material, the Chicago footwork pioneer pushes at the outline of the genre, playing with convention and keeping listeners thrillingly off balance.

albums.title: Divine Weight
albums.label: NON Worldwide
albums.description: In what is essentially a radical remix project, the artist formerly known as Dirty Beaches refines his own imperfect saxophone recordings into something radiant and pure.

albums.title: Miss America
albums.label: Virgin
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore the ecstatic songs on Mary Margaret O’Hara’s cult hit Miss America.

albums.title: Plight & Premonition / Flux & Mutability
albums.label: Gronland
albums.description: A double reissue of late-1980s albums by the Can co-founder and the synth-pop savant finds them laying the groundwork for years of ambient music that would follow.

albums.title: How Many Times Have You Driven By EP
albums.label: Luminelle
albums.description: On her first official release, the 17-year-old songwriting prodigy offers six slickly produced electronic dream pop tracks whose streaks of misery feel discernibly teenage.

albums.title: Palo Santo
albums.label: Polydor
albums.description: The British trio moves beyond the tropical-house Top 40 of their debut on a theatrical, diverse sophomore album that finds frontman Olly Alexander blurring the boundaries between sacred and profane.

albums.title: Bardo for Pablo
albums.label: Stroom
albums.description: On the second part of a planned trilogy of archival anthologies, a long-forgotten Belgian group from the early 1990s emerges as standard-bearers of globe-trotting ambient and psychedelic techno.

albums.title: Electronic Music From the Eighties and Nineties
albums.label: Unseen Worlds
albums.description: A second volume of the Los Angeles composer’s archival work highlights pieces that attempted to bridge academic research with emotional accessibility, with mixed results.

albums.title: God Level
albums.label: Alamo
albums.description: The Los Angeles rapper’s final album before his 20-year sentence is anxious, forlorn, and self-assured—the violence simmers just below its cool and breezy surface.

albums.title: The Graduation
albums.label: Broyal
albums.description: The debut from the amazing, helium-huffing Atlanta rapper features production from Brodinski and a grip of other European producers that makes it a standout among the city’s rising stars.

albums.title: Seastones
albums.label: Round
albums.description: An expanded new mix of an overlooked, misunderstood 1975 electronic “biomusic” opus—featuring mysterious contributions from Jerry Garcia, David Crosby, Phil Lesh, and others—finally gives the record its due.

albums.title: High as Hope
albums.label: Republic
albums.description: Another relatively stripped-down album featuring the titanic voice of Florence Welch is troubled by its overwhelmingly beige production.

albums.title: I’m All Ears
albums.label: Transgressive
albums.description: The second album from the UK duo is future-pop at its best: kaleidoscopic production and incisive lyrics that swirl into marvelous, breathtaking songs.

albums.title: Topdown Dialectic
albums.label: Peak Oil
albums.description: The anonymous artist’s rustling, swirling ambient techno is as immediate and enveloping as anything leftfield electronic music has produced this year.

albums.title: Sixth House
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: In the 1990s, the Georgia underdogs influenced a generation of indie rockers with their theatrical, reverb-soaked anthems. Nearly two decades later, their first reunion album is more than a throwback.

albums.title: Desolation
albums.label: 20 Buck Spin
albums.description: The Denver doom metal band’s third album is streamlined, expansive, and melodically sharp.

albums.title: Intra
albums.label: Boomkat Editions
albums.description: Mark Fell enlists Portugal’s Drumming Grupo de Percussão to perform captivating computer-generated rhythms on the sixxen, a little-known invention of Iannis Xenakis.

albums.title: All the Things That I Did and All the Things That I Didn’t Do
albums.label: Anti-
albums.description: After years of making somber, traditionalist folk on dueling acoustic guitars, Kenneth Pattengale and Joey Ryan expand their palette on the duo’s most engaging and diverse record to date.

albums.title: Scorpion
albums.label: Young Money Entertainment
albums.description: Drake’s fifth proper studio album is richly produced, studded with gems, and grapples with his fatherhood in a way that casts his arrested development into sharp relief.

albums.title: Incesticide
albums.label: DGC
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore the radical underbelly of Nirvana’s 1992 compilation Incesticide.

albums.title: Both Directions at Once: The Lost Album
albums.label: Impulse!
albums.description: The newly discovered, unreleased album from 1963 featuring the “classic quartet” finds the jazz giant thrillingly caught between shoring up and surging forth.

albums.title: Errorzone
albums.label: Closed Casket Activities
albums.description: Yesterday’s Active Rock playlist gets ransacked and reconfigured on the debut full-length from a Boston hardcore quintet whose influences range from Converge to Korn.

albums.title: Hello It’s Me
albums.label: Arrowhawk
albums.description: The comedian, actor, musician, and professional personality recounts a miserable breakup with disarming sincerity and grim humor on a solo debut steeped in rock history.

albums.title: Sink Ya Teeth
albums.label: Hey Buffalo
albums.description: Maria Uzor and Gemma Cullingford channel ESG, Liquid Liquid, and New Order but surpass mere genre mimicry on a debut album that captures the feeling as well as the sounds of classic dance music.

albums.title: The Now Now
albums.label: Parlophone
albums.description: The allure of isolation defines Damon Albarn’s latest project. With only a few guests on the album, he writes simple, mostly upbeat songs with words of exhaustion.

albums.title: Passwords
albums.label: HUB
albums.description: On their sixth album, the Los Angeles rockers attempt to reach across the political spectrum, but their noble intentions clash with cloying lyrics and worn-out arrangements.

albums.title: Zebra
albums.label: Mexican Summer
albums.description: With a large group of collaborators, Alexis Georgopoulos has crafted a pulsing, eclectic, wonderfully breezy album of ethereal psychedelia.

albums.title: Joytime II
albums.label: Marshmello
albums.description: On his second album, the quasi-anonymous DJ in a stylized marshmallow mask proves the perfect figurehead for a commercial EDM scene running on fumes.

albums.title: Freddie
albums.label: ESGN
albums.description: Freddie feels like a pure and reckless purge from Gibbs, a collection that finds him at his wildest and most essential.

albums.title: Renaissance Man
albums.label: Lex
albums.description: The Bronx rapper’s second album in two months has the intimacy of voicemails to a close friend and the warmth of Lil B in his most generous BasedGod form.

albums.title: Year of the Snitch
albums.label: Third Worlds
albums.description: The prolific noise rap project drills down on their sonic signature and remains politically agnostic and persistently agitated.

albums.title: Love Junction
albums.label: Friends of Friends
albums.description: The past decade of British club music looms large on Lorenzo Calpini’s breezy debut album, which enlists a global cast of guest vocalists to broaden the Rome-based producer’s sound.

albums.title: Come to Canada You Will Like It
albums.label: Verdicchio
albums.description: On an album meant to strike “a balance between rural and city living,” the Canadian producer evokes rural idyll in dozy deep house, but the mood too often verges on soporific.

albums.title: Hawaiki Tapes
albums.label: Umor Rex
albums.description: Recorded on the humble Korg Volca FM during a vacation on the Big Island of Hawaii, this atmospheric, unobtrusive album lives somewhere between landscape sketch and spiritual sojourn.

albums.title: Wet Will Always Dry
albums.label: TERNESC
albums.description: The UK techno titan’s debut album is a display of his sound-design prowess—as well as a reminder that even the heaviest techno needn’t shy from the pleasures of weirdo pop.

albums.title: Best Kids
albums.label: Amazon Music
albums.description: Bethany Cosentino and Bobb Bruno recapture the dizzy exuberance that drew audiences to their early singles—but trade the weed for ice cream—on their first foray into kids’ music.

albums.title: K.T.S.E.
albums.label: G.O.O.D. Music
albums.description: Teyana Taylor and her tremendous voice are so deft at performing modernist soul with the genre’s forebears as her backdrop, and her album features some of the best Old Kanye beats heard this year.

albums.title: 200% Galcher
albums.label: Lustwerk Music
albums.description: Five years after his breakthrough mixtape, the former upstart has become a veteran. On his second album in eight months, the rough edges give way to the assured pleasures of an expert in his zone.

albums.title: Lord of Lords
albums.label: Superior Viaduct
albums.description: Alice Coltrane’s newly reissued Lord of Lords capped off a trio of richly orchestral albums in the early ’70s. It is a slow-building, cosmic, unnerving throbbing organism of sound.

albums.title: International Artist
albums.label: Highbridge
albums.description: The latest project from the Bronx rapper enlists musicians from across the globe for an attempted cross-cultural exchange of Afrobeat, dancehall, and reggaeton to mixed effect.

albums.title: Simple Answers
albums.label: Last Things
albums.description: The Psalm Zero frontman and Zs alum reckons with the rise of fascism—and his internal struggle against its insidious appeal—on a debut solo album of unusually confrontational modern classical music.

albums.title: Heaven’s Only Wishful EP
albums.label: Don’t Guess
albums.description: Toronto musician Seth Nyquist’s versatile voice soars on every track of an inviting debut that spans a surprising array of genres and techniques.

albums.title: Dies Iræ Xerox
albums.label: Dial
albums.description: The Rhode Island native’s second album of noisy, downbeat techno is a cocoon ringed with razor wire—the kind of music that’s perfect for headphones and subway journeys when you’re in a foul mood.

albums.title: Kazuashita
albums.label: 4AD
albums.description: On their first album in seven years, the New York fusionists tap into a welter of global styles; the result is soft-edged and idyllic, yet hides a subtle political undercurrent.

albums.title: для FOR
albums.label: Rvng Intl.
albums.description: The Russian electronic musician Kate NV’s sonic portrait of her native Moscow is surreal, otherworldly, and playfully inscrutable.

albums.title: To Record Only Water for Ten Days
albums.label: Warner Bros.
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore the haunting and beautiful 2001 solo album from the Red Hot Chili Peppers’ John Frusciante.

albums.title: Redemption
albums.label: Top Dawg
albums.description: After a life-threatening motorcycle accident, Jay Rock returns with his strongest album yet, a collection of rap songs that highlight his struggle and journey.

albums.title: Bad Witch
albums.label: The Null Corporation
albums.description: Trent Reznor’s third EP-length NIN release in the last two years is the best of the lot, with a raw and rough sound that feels both unfinished and alive.

albums.title: Post Traumatic
albums.label: Warner Bros.
albums.description: On his debut solo album, the Linkin Park rapper and producer mourns the death of his bandmate Chester Bennington but never translates that grief into candid lyrics or inspired songwriting.

albums.title: Babelsberg
albums.label: Rough Trade
albums.description: The Super Furry Animals frontman has always been political, but he’s never sounded as spiteful as he does on this satirical portrait of the United States in 2018.

albums.title: Heaven and Earth
albums.label: Young Turks
albums.description: The latest from the saxophonist and bandleader is a multi-genre feast of musical ideas, his most sweeping and complete statement yet.

albums.label: Cash Money
albums.description: The 24-year-old Cash Money singer upcycles ’90s R&B hits on an album of charmingly naughty sex jams—but his referential style is more than just a schtick.

albums.title: June
albums.label: Thrill Jockey
albums.description: In the 37-minute piece that comprises his first solo album since 2005, the Mountains multi-instrumentalist ditches the distractions of the attention economy to luxuriate in a stream of consciousness.

albums.title: Lower East Suite Part Three
albums.label: Big Dada
albums.description: The finale of the New York jazz ensemble’s Lower East Suite trilogy marks a shift in tone and finds the band newly focused.

albums.title: Moodie EP
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: The multi-talented Floridian musician flaunts his 2000s indie and emo influences on a debut EP of perky pop that chronicles a post-breakup transformation.

albums.title: Déjàvu
albums.label: Matty Unlimited
albums.description: A breakdown that led BADBADNOTGOOD keyboardist Matty Tavares to move in with his parents also resulted in this breezy, psychedelic soft-rock album recorded with sought-after sample maker Frank Dukes.

albums.title: Nasty
albums.label: Sugar Trap
albums.description: The ferocious 21-year-old shapeshifter comes through with one of the hardest rap records of the year.

albums.title: Call the Comet
albums.label: New Voodoo
albums.description: The former Smiths guitarist absorbs the political shocks of 2016 on a characteristically polished album that imagines life in an alternate universe that values kindness, curiosity, and intelligence.

albums.title: Sorpresa Familia
albums.label: Captured Tracks
albums.description: Label woes finally resolved, the Catalonian quartet gets its frustrations off its chest on its third album, showcasing a newfound maturity of songcraft without sacrificing youthful energy.

albums.title: Nothing Is Still
albums.label: Ninja Tune
albums.description: After two albums of jazzy, humid club cuts, the British producer moves beyond the dancefloor with a stunning concept record about his grandparents that incorporates ambient and modern classical music.

albums.title: Bon Voyage
albums.label: Fat Possum
albums.description: Six years and one nearly fatal accident after her promising debut, French singer-songwriter Melody Prochet celebrates her recovery with an album of gleefully overstuffed psych-pop.

albums.title: Nasir
albums.label: Mass Appeal
albums.description: No longer able to summon his mythical sense of storytelling, Nas sounds lost on his 11th studio album. Kanye’s production doesn’t help, either.

albums.title: Liberation
albums.label: RCA
albums.description: The pop survivor shows off her powerhouse voice, dabbles in try-hard slang, and takes tentative steps toward creative rebirth on her first album since 2012.

albums.title: Ecstatic Arrow
albums.label: Fire
albums.description: On their third album of avant-garde synth pop, Alice Merida Richards and Sam Pillay eschew protest language and the depressing status quo to conjure a vision of feminist utopia.

albums.title: Cloud Corner
albums.label: Thrill Jockey
albums.description: On her Thrill Jockey debut, the solo guitarist creates truly borderless music, fusing the diverse global traditions she favors without drawing too much attention to the act of juxtaposition.

albums.title: Collagically Speaking
albums.label: Blue Note
albums.description: Jazz pianist Robert Glasper assembles an all-star cast in search of a sound that might reflect the tenor of the times; the meditative results are shaded by politics without wallowing in it.

albums.title: Everything Is Love
albums.label: S.C. Enterprises
albums.description: The Carters round out a trilogy of confrontational albums about their marriage with something lighter but no less resonant. It is a celebration of resilient black love and proud black extravagance.

albums.title: Home Boy, Sister Out
albums.label: Wewantsounds
albums.description: This long-forgotten 1985 album is far from the legendary jazz trumpeter’s best work, but look past its awkwardness and dated sonics, and a certain charm reveals itself.

albums.title: Make My Bed EP
albums.label: Zelig Records
albums.description: On a debut EP that occupies a space between the cathartic stadium pop of fun. and the vulnerability of Lorde, the young singer-producer offers the kind of love songs generations of queer kids craved.

albums.title: Head Over Heels
albums.label: Big Beat
albums.description: On their bona fide all-stars album, everyone from DRAM to Amber Mark to The-Dream cannot save the electronic duo from their tastelessness.

albums.title: New Bodies
albums.label: Temporary Residence
albums.description: The Australian instrumentalists have always used their breathtaking technical dexterity to craft songs that feel like little worlds. Their fourth album fills those spaces with emotion.

albums.title: Super Fly
albums.label: Curtom
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore the political soul of Curtis Mayfield’s 1972 album Super Fly.

albums.title: The Graduate (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)
albums.label: Sony Legacy
albums.description: Featuring Simon & Garfunkel’s studious folk and the easy listening of Dave Grusin, a new vinyl reissue attests that what makes a fascinating artifact does not always make for an especially good listen.

albums.title: Stranger Fruit
albums.label: MVKA Music
albums.description: Manuel Gagneux’s latest provocative mix of black metal and Southern folk and gospel music is an absurd union that provides moments of vitality and stark political statements about race in America.

albums.title: Come Tomorrow
albums.label: RCA
albums.description: The long-running jam band’s ninth album centers on hard-earned optimism but smooths out much of what makes Dave Matthews’ music engaging.

albums.title: Hereditary (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)
albums.label: Milan
albums.description: The saxophonist’s soundtrack to the unsettling horror movie feeds off his darkest impulses as a composer, amplifying and mirroring the trauma and fear on the screen.

albums.title: Consolation EP
albums.label: Domino
albums.description: The four-song EP from the Michigan post-punk band features Kelley Deal of the Breeders and some of the most pointed and impactful songwriting of their career.

albums.title: Devotion
albums.label: Chapter
albums.description: The Australian folk-turned-pop singer revisits her eccentric, romantically unfulfilled teen years on an album that reaches for the coming-of-age immediacy of artists like Lorde and Taylor Swift.

albums.title: OIL OF EVERY PEARL’s UN-INSIDES
albums.label: Transgressive
albums.description: The experimental music of SOPHIE relaxes into new forms on her debut album. It is sprawling and beautiful, while still keeping the disorienting, latex-pop feel of her fascinating production technique.

albums.title: Hope Downs
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: The “120 Minutes” revivalists trade manic exuberance for panicked agitation on a debut album that applies their infectious brand of motorik jangle rock to lovelorn ruminations and geopolitical laments.

albums.title: Showtime EP
albums.label: XL
albums.description: On his first release for the iconic British label XL, the Swedish deep house trickster leans into his pop proclivities and heavy-lidded Lothario persona.

albums.title: Mental Wounds Not Healing
albums.label: Sacred Bones
albums.description: Extreme-metal titans and prolific collaborators the Body team with New York-based industrial duo Uniform on a brutally satisfying—and surprisingly melodic—joint album.

albums.title: Remain in Light
albums.label: Kravenworks
albums.description: Inspired by its Afrobeat underpinnings, the Beninese singer tackles an album-length cover of the Talking Heads’ 1980 landmark, in the process unearthing hidden rhythmic and emotional nuances.

albums.title: The Midnight Hour
albums.label: Linear Labs
albums.description: The two rap-and-soul fusionists aim for a retro aesthetic imbued with the intimacy of a basement club; the results are reminiscent of their Harlem Renaissance-inspired Luke Cage soundtrack.

albums.title: soil
albums.label: Secretly Canadian
albums.description: Taking full advantage of his voluminous, one-of-a-kind voice, experimental pop artist serpentwithfeet offers complex visions of queer love on his debut album.

albums.title: IRISIRI
albums.label: Pan
albums.description: On her third album, the Queens experimental musician explores the way women’s voices can challenge the norms of taste and decorum and push past the boundaries of accepted musical language.

albums.title: Bruce Wayne
albums.label: 300 Entertainment
albums.description: The 28-minute EP continues Fetty Wap’s steady decline from promising trap balladeer to one-dimensional chant rapper.

albums.title: No Shame
albums.label: Warner Bros.
albums.description: Pilloried in the press for her every misfortune, Lily Allen scrutinizes her public persona on an album that dilutes staggering sincerity with uninspired beats.

albums.title: so sad so sexy
albums.label: RCA
albums.description: With festival-ready hooks and trap-inspired production, Lykke Li delivers another record about an unraveling romance and the fraught sexuality of its final moments with diminishing returns.

albums.title: Lost & Found
albums.label: FAMM
albums.description: The precocious 20-year-old singer fuses R&B, soul, and trip-hop on a debut album that documents her ongoing quest to discover who she is and how she fits into a troubled world.

albums.title: Constant Image
albums.label: Domino
albums.description: As D.C. punks with ties to Priests, Fugazi, and Comet Ping Pong, Flasher are expected to have something to say about politics in 2018—but their debut album would have felt just as timely 30 years ago.

albums.title: Roach Goin’ Down
albums.label: Wharf Cat
albums.description: The offbeat New York trio’s wicked sense of humor shines on an album of punchy, peculiar songs that register as pleasant and uncomfortable at once.

albums.title: Whack World
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: The surreal, audiovisual album from the Philadelphia artist is only 15 minutes long, but it is overflowing with hooks and a powerful sense of imagination.

albums.title: Kids See Ghosts
albums.label: G.O.O.D. Music
albums.description: The psychic bond between Kanye and Kid Cudi yields a spacious and melancholy album about brokenness—thoughts are fragmented, relationships are ended, and societal ties are cut.

albums.title: Insula
albums.label: Hyperdub
albums.description: Still a child during grime’s original heyday, the Edinburgh producer approaches the genre with a collagist’s appreciation for layering, juxtaposition, and hyper-referentiality.

albums.title: Childqueen
albums.label: Fat Possum
albums.description: The psych-soul singer summons the confidence and exuberance of childhood on an immersive sophomore album.

albums.title: Shannon in Nashville
albums.label: Easy Eye Sound
albums.description: The gale-force frontwoman of Shannon and the Clams collaborates with producer Dan Auerbach on a sparkling debut solo album that sounds like Roy Orbison lost in the Brill Building.

albums.title: The Band
albums.label: Capitol
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore the collectivism of the Band’s 1969 self-titled album.

albums.title: An ASMR Album
albums.label: Nice Life
albums.description: The extremely online 25-year-old comedian’s foray into a more traditional comedy format makes for an imposing and uneven listen, even for the most logged-on.

albums.title: 3rd Ward Bounce EP
albums.label: Asylum
albums.description: The bounce queen’s latest EP marks her return to the unctuous, mechanized mother tongue of New Orleans.

albums.title: Kicker EP
albums.label: Polyvinyl
albums.description: After nearly 20 years of playing against their strengths, the Get Up Kids jump on the “adult emo” bandwagon and recapture the punk immediacy of their late-’90s heyday.

albums.title: Lightlessness Is Nothing New
albums.label: Barsuk
albums.description: After a six-year hiatus, the Chicago math-rock-turned-pop-rock act returns with a deceptively upbeat album inspired by the death of singer-guitarist Dave Davison’s father.

albums.title: Listening to Pictures (Pentimento Volume One)
albums.label: Ndeya
albums.description: On his first album in nine years, the Los Angeles trumpeter-composer sounds like he’s remixing himself, taking apart his past 40 years of work and reassembling it for the present moment.

albums.title: Our Raw Heart
albums.label: Relapse
albums.description: The long-running Oregon doom metal trio opens its third act with a sensuous, aggressive, and jubilant album inspired by singer-guitarist Mike Scheidt's recent brush with death.

albums.title: Lush
albums.label: Matador
albums.description: Snail Mail’s striking debut album is emotionally wise, musically clear, and encompasses the once and future sound of indie rock.

albums.title: Both
albums.label: Heavy Body
albums.description: King Krule collaborator Kaya Wilkins escapes music-industry servitude and speaks truth on her own terms in a frank, often melancholy bedroom-pop debut leavened by diaristic sarcasm.

albums.title: LUMP
albums.label: Dead Oceans
albums.description: On their first collaborative album, Laura Marling and Tunng’s Mike Lindsay wrap prickly observations about lifestyle consumerism in bales of gorgeous melody and grumbling dissonance.

albums.title: Stereo EP
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: The Indiana singer-songwriter brings his seductive falsetto and clever production touches to a short, sweet debut EP of bedroom pop and throwback soul.

albums.title: Strata EP
albums.label: Once In A Blue Moon
albums.description: Named after an architectural icon looming over South East London, the rapper’s six-track EP offers a detailed account of life at the building’s base.

albums.title: Prequelle
albums.label: Loma Vista
albums.description: Unmasked in 2017 as Ghost’s mastermind, Tobias Forge trades in his papal regalia for a new persona on a darkly comic album that is lots of fun despite its flaws.

albums.title: The Future and the Past
albums.label: ATO
albums.description: The singer-songwriter follows up her gloriously baroque debut with an album that uses deep grooves, politicized self-portraiture, and an eye for everyday cruelty to reckon with life in the Trump era.

albums.title: Still EP
albums.label: Rhymes of an Hour
albums.description: The dream-pop legends breathe new life into old songs on a slight, unsurprising, but reliably lovely EP of dreamy desert blues.

albums.title: Streams of Thought, Vol. 1
albums.label: Human Re Sources
albums.description: After 30 years fronting the Roots, Black Thought has finally put out his first solo EP. It is rigorous but rarely hermetic, a small testament to his sustained excellence.

albums.title: You, Forever
albums.label: Saddle Creek
albums.description: Celestial Shore singer-guitarist Sam Owens puts his own actions and desires under a microscope on a gentle, sunny, yet boldly honest solo album.

albums.title: Patina Echoes
albums.label: Timedance
albums.description: Released by UK bass scion Batu, this survey of cutting-edge club music is less a collection of voices than a shared statement of purpose, full of thrilling rhythms and textures.

albums.title: Winning Star Champion
albums.label: Barsuk
albums.description: Seattle indie scene veteran Matt Batey contrasts bouncy power-pop with lyrics about anxiety and failure on his cathartic solo debut for Barsuk.

albums.title: Sacrifices
albums.label: Lex
albums.description: Returning to his best-known alias, the veteran hip-hop deconstructionist scales back his approach, but Sacrifices can feel slight, with songs that too often fade into the background.

albums.title: Assimilation
albums.label: Where to Now?
albums.description: Fresh off a thrilling collaboration with Joy Orbison, the British saxophonist teams with Mica Levi, Rupert Clervaux, and others on an audacious solo album that feels like another team effort.

albums.title: Hell-On
albums.label: Anti-
albums.description: On her self-produced seventh solo LP, Neko Case brings on a bunch of collaborators for a dense album that searches for connection amid human cruelty and chaos.

albums.title: ye
albums.label: G.O.O.D. Music
albums.description: Kanye West’s stint in Wyoming created an album born from chaos for chaos’ sake. Though it can be somewhat fascinating, it is undoubtedly a low point in his career.

albums.title: The Long Sleep
albums.label: Sacred Bones
albums.description: The experimental songwriter abandons the conceptual rigor of her recent albums, collaborating with a handful of jazz musicians on a loose, ambiguous EP where repetition induces a state of déjà vu.

albums.title: Wildness
albums.label: Polydor
albums.description: On his band's first album in seven years, Gary Lightbody aims for clarity, connection, and personal resonance but lapses into the pomp and incoherence that have plagued Snow Patrol for a decade.

albums.title: Deeper
albums.label: Fire Talk
albums.description: The Chicago quartet’s debut is well-oiled and worn-in indie rock, played with the precision and confidence typically expected from a band much further along in its career.

albums.title: Live Through This
albums.label: City Slang
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore the righteous anger of Hole’s 1994 album Live Through This.

albums.title: Return of the Frog Queen
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: The Sunny Day Real Estate leader's 1996 solo debut is often viewed through the prism of his Christian rebirth. Sub Pop's reissue reveals how its orchestral grandeur helped shape indie rock's future.

albums.title: Age Of
albums.label: Warp
albums.description: The tenth album from Daniel Lopatin is his most collaborative and accessible solo project to date, yet still full of unexpected chaos and songs that can suddenly dissolve and disarm.

albums.title: Lush Life
albums.label: Mysteries of Trade
albums.description: The Toronto duo follows up an eight-year-old debut EP with an album that gestures toward various eras of dancehall and traverses a range of emotion.

albums.title: Dream House
albums.label: Innervisions
albums.description: The Berlin tech-house duo’s debut album purports to expand its palette, but an impressive list of collaborators can’t keep the music from lapsing into middle-of-the-road anonymity.

albums.title: Skulls Example
albums.label: Orindal
albums.description: Katy Davidson’s indie-folk project returns on an album that mines philosophical poetry from moments when ancient natural wonders meet modern technology.

albums.title: Cruel Practice
albums.label: NUXXE
albums.description: On her debut EP, South East London singer and DJ Blane Muise combines venomous lyricism with tar-boiling industrial beats to inhabit a fierce, sexual, pathologically impatient, and deeply cathartic alter ego.

albums.title: Goodbye & Good Riddance
albums.label: Grade A
albums.description: Juice WRLD’s emo-rap debut is an adolescent breakup record that is equal parts endearing and grating.

albums.title: God’s Favorite Customer
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: Josh Tillman is still self-absorbed. But his fourth full-length as Father John Misty exhibits a new sense of empathy and vulnerability while losing none of his wit.

albums.title: Cave Vaults of the Moon
albums.label: Séance Centre
albums.description: The Taos composer’s 1987 accompaniment to a sculpture exhibition with a sci-fi bent makes for a synth-heavy adventure in new age that’s by turns eerie and playful.

albums.title: V.
albums.label: Thrill Jockey
albums.description: The dyed-in-the-wool psych-rock band returns with some of their most accessible songs to date, full of fuzz-pedal jams that capture moments of fleeting happiness in dark days.

albums.title: Diary 001 EP
albums.label: Fader
albums.description: The lo-fi pop singer’s first label release is an EP whose careful songwriting and intriguingly flat vocals should quiet naysayers who dismissed her as a one-hit fluke.

albums.title: Vibras
albums.label: Universal Music Latino
albums.description: The reggaetonero’s latest sets him up for even more global success. Its infectious vibe is draped in dancehall with a dash of trap production and nods to salsa, bachata, and Afrobeat.

albums.title: Shawn Mendes
albums.label: Island
albums.description: On his third album, the former Vine star grows into a persona that’s playful, gently libidinous, and safely menace-free, but his music too often falls on the wrong side of beige.

albums.title: Love Is Dead
albums.label: Glassnote
albums.description: With help from some outside producers, Chvrches’ try to launch themselves into the mainstream. The result is an uncomplicated, unsurprising collection of steely synth pop.

albums.title: cc EP
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: After last year’s Tommy EP, the South London electronic musician turns her abstracted sound collages to more pointedly cathartic ends: complex music that brims with conflicting emotions.

albums.title: Medicaid Fraud Dogg
albums.label: C Kunspyruhzy
albums.description: On their first album in 38 years, George Clinton and his impressive band channel the Parliament of old for something decidedly modern. It’s delightfully raunchy but also surprisingly tenderhearted.

albums.title: Tracyanne & Danny
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: Five years after Camera Obscura’s last album, Tracyanne Campbell returns with a new musical partner and a more mannered, slightly cautious sound, but her voice is as singular as ever.

albums.title: Sink EP
albums.label: Stones Throw
albums.description: The genre-defying violinist levels up as a songwriter on an EP of experimental pop and R&B. It explodes conventional musical logic with disarming ease.

albums.title: Paz & Amor EP
albums.label: Príncipe Discos
albums.description: The Lisbon producer’s solo debut takes the spiky, polyrhythmic sound of Portuguese batida and bends it toward a sleek dancefloor sensibility, making for Príncipe’s most accessible release yet.

albums.title: Midnight Marker
albums.label: Beats in Space
albums.description: On Shy Layers’ second album, his chill-but-adventurous aesthetic snaps into clearer focus. Highlife, funk, Ethio-jazz, and more all swirl together in every measure of music.

albums.title: Testing
albums.label: RCA
albums.description: On his third studio album, Rocky is more experimental and personal. But for music that relies on the New York rapper’s artful intuitions, it’s unfortunate his intuitions are often very basic.

albums.title: Black Soap
albums.label: Lex
albums.description: The 19-year-old rapper’s latest project is a quest of self-discovery that serves as a reminder of the power and dexterity New York’s new vanguard of artists.

albums.title: Only Built 4 Cuban Linx
albums.label: Loud
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore Raekwon’s game-changing 1995 debut Only Built 4 Cuban Linx.

albums.title: Uptown Festival / Disco Gardens / Big Fun
albums.label: Robinsongs
albums.description: The first three records from the R&B group that came out of “Soul Train” show their evolution from a schmaltzy cash-grab to a bona fide bringer of disco joy.

albums.title: Big Wave More Fire
albums.label: Loma Vista
albums.description: The LA-based electronic duo that gave Kanye’s The Life of Pablo its gospel-house sheen embraces pop on an album featuring guest vocals by Amber Mark, Khalid, and The-Dream.

albums.title: Sugar & Spice EP
albums.label: Double Double Whammy
albums.description: On her well-formed debut EP, Harriette Pilbeam's version of dream pop is more pop than dream.

albums.title: Puff LP: In the air without a shape
albums.label: Arts & Crafts
albums.description: Pop and R&B melodies meet shambling, C86-style song structures on the eclectic Toronto band’s first album since 2011.

albums.title: Themes for Television
albums.label: Italians Do It Better
albums.description: The surprise release collects unheard material originally meant for “Twin Peaks: The Return”; though slighter than this year’s Digital Rain EP, it might be Jewel’s strongest soundtrack work yet.

albums.title: The Return
albums.label: Black Focus
albums.description: Following the dissolution of the jazz-funk duo Yussef Kamaal, the London keyboardist returns with an urbane, dynamic album that’s deeply rooted in the city’s rhythms.

albums.title: (((echo chamber)))
albums.label: Mello Music Group
albums.description: On his first album in nearly a decade, the absurdist rapper uses his enormous vocabulary to riff on race, class, and becoming a parent—but he still hasn’t outgrown of fart jokes.

albums.title: Daytona
albums.label: G.O.O.D. Music
albums.description: Produced entirely by Kanye West, the spare and serrated solo album from Pusha-T is a near-airtight exercise in flair and focus.

albums.title: Perfume EP
albums.label: Drag City
albums.description: Cory Hanson and his SoCal cohorts continue their transformation from manic garage rockers to shape-shifting innovators on an EP as eclectic as White Light/White Heat.

albums.title: Double Dream of Spring
albums.label: 4AD
albums.description: This limited, tour-only cassette feels spontaneous yet brimming with ideas. It sounds somewhere between ghostly demos and a lo-fi avant-garde ambient composition.

albums.title: Steamroom 40
albums.label: steamroom
albums.description: The 40th installment of the prolific producer and composer’s Steamroom series is a highlight, one long, meditative piece of synth overtones, slowly rising arpeggios, and pure drift.

albums.title: Light of Mine
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: The carefree California rapper’s debut is an exceedingly joyous and self-aware slice of pop rap.

albums.title: Love Yourself 轉 ‘Tear’
albums.label: BigHit Entertainment
albums.description: The latest album from the masters of the K-pop formula is a slick, loosely thematic album about love and loss, with a stronger emphasis on rapping than ever before.

albums.title: Reckless
albums.label: XO
albums.description: The Toronto rapper’s debut is a long shot at cementing his legacy that is plagued by indecision and self-doubt.

albums.title: Harder Than Ever
albums.label: Quality Control
albums.description: Lil Baby’s official debut is technically impressive: polished, efficient, but also kind of nondescript.

albums.title: Deeper Woods
albums.label: Thrill Jockey
albums.description: On her third solo album, North Carolina guitarist Sarah Louise Henson steps beyond her vivid acoustic work and into a realm of glowing studio experimentation and layered vocals.

albums.title: Luminosity Device
albums.label: Dynamic Tension
albums.description: Inspired by the Tibetan Book of the Dead, the Birmingham techno producer puts a fresh spin on his pummeling club tracks; the album is equally suited for dancefloor abandon and spiritual searching.

albums.title: Angels of Death
albums.label: Paradise of Bachelors
albums.description: The Toronto singer’s album is a country and gospel-infused meditation on death and mourning that flickers between the broadly universal and the devastatingly personal.

albums.title: Tell Me How You Really Feel
albums.label: Mom & Pop
albums.description: Courtney Barnett’s second album is smaller, more introverted than her debut. It’s tentative but with a purpose, songs about what it means to not have—or need—the right words for everything.

albums.title: Yesterday’s Tomorrows
albums.label: Wolf
albums.description: On his third album, Berlin producer Sebastian Genz switches up his dreamy house sound with forays into drum ‘n’ bass and boom-bap hip-hop but can’t shake his nostalgia addiction.

albums.title: Deafman Glance
albums.label: Dead Oceans
albums.description: After several albums of traditional, jazzy folk-rock, the Chicago-based singer-songwriter finds a more instinctive voice.

albums.title: Wax Chattels
albums.label: Captured Tracks
albums.description: Billing itself as a “guitarless guitar band,” the New Zealand noise-rock trio endeavors to make bass, keyboard, and two-piece drum kit sound as loud as possible.

albums.title: Happy Ending
albums.label: Etruscan Gold
albums.description: Wax Idols complete their transformation from sardonic post-punks to theatrical goth-rock storytellers on an album that dares to take pleasure in confronting death.

albums.title: Saved
albums.label: Trans
albums.description: Now, Now trade guitar rock and raw nerves for slick, left-of-center pop on a deceptively upbeat comeback album whose intense lyrics and unsettling sounds stay true to the duo’s emo roots.

albums.title: Wide Awake!
albums.label: Rough Trade
albums.description: On their fourth album, Parquet Courts enlist Danger Mouse to produce an album of joyfully absurd, danceable rock music. It is straightforward but alien, simple but endlessly referential.

albums.title: Spirit in the Dark
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we explore Aretha Franklin’s immensely personal 1970 album Spirit in the Dark.

albums.title: Buck Meek
albums.label: Keeled Scales
albums.description: The debut solo album from the Big Thief guitarist has a quiet and mischevious spirit, with a focus put on his nimble playing and Texas twang.

albums.title: Cannonball!
albums.label: 88rising
albums.description: The Kyoto-born, Chicago-based multi-instrumentalist uses his nonchalant flow and the sharp instincts he acquired playing saxophone as a kid to craft a dynamic, introspective jazz-rap debut.

albums.title: The Album Collection Vol. 2, 1987-1996
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: The seven albums after Bruce Springsteen’s commercial peak tell a story of lost faith and self-doubt. It’s a darker, messier portrait that still includes one of his essential records.

albums.title: Everything Matters But No One Is Listening
albums.label: Polyvinyl
albums.description: Inspired by his love for Stephin Merritt, James Alex serves up chamber-pop covers of his own earnest punk songs on the first album from this Beach Slang spin-off band.

albums.title: Hundreds of Days
albums.label: Ghostly International
albums.description: The harp innovator experiments with an arsenal of new instruments—including her voice—on an album of ambient music as complex and meditative as the work of Pauline Oliveros.

albums.title: Violet Psalms
albums.label: Paper Bag
albums.description: On what the band has said is its final album, Frog Eyes sound galvanized by the prospect of bowing out, resulting in their strongest record in years.

albums.title: Rausch
albums.label: Kompakt
albums.description: Wolfgang Voigt’s investigations of German heritage turn ominous on an imposing, hour-long ambient album whose title translates as “frenzy”; it feels closely keyed to the current political state.

albums.title: Letters of Irrelevance
albums.label: EMPIRE
albums.description: Following his bandmates Syd, Matt Martians, and Steve Lacy, the bassist of L.A.’s the internet steps up with his solo debut. He’s not yet a natural leader, but his musicianship is self-evident.

albums.title: Sparkle Hard
albums.label: Matador
