albums.label: Matador
albums.description: The second album from Tennessee songwriter Julien Baker wrestles with self-worth, rejection, and God. Centering on her voice, guitar, and piano, Baker begins to sound defiant.

albums.title: The Best of Both Worlds
albums.label: Classic Music Company
albums.description: A glorious vision of house music’s inclusive, utopian potential unfolds on this DJ and producer’s first full-length album.

albums.title: Ogilala
albums.label: BMG
albums.description: In his latest reinvention, the Smashing Pumpkins frontman hires Rick Rubin to deliver a prestige comeback album in the producer’s usual stripped-down and soul-baring mode—but Corgan is no Johnny Cash.

albums.title: Listen Without Prejudice Vol. 1
albums.label: Sony
albums.description: On a new four-disc reissue of George Michael’s mostly acoustic, bossa nova-inflected LP from 1990, the pleasures of the flesh co-exist with a deepening spiritual malaise.

albums.title: Pacific Daydream
albums.label: Crush
albums.description: On their 11th album, Rivers Cuomo and co. aim for a hook-filled tribute to California guitar pop but the production gloss suffocates any personality these songs could have had.

albums.title: It’s Alright Between Us as It Is
albums.label: Smalltown Supersound
albums.description: The Norwegian producer Hans-Peter Lindstrøm’s latest solo full-length feels breezily noncommittal. Each experiment—including a spoken word piece by Jenny Hval—dissolves into the next.

albums.title: Tokyo Flashback
albums.label: Black Editions
albums.description: A new reissue of this influential 1991 Japanese psych compilation—with gems from Ghost, Keiji Haino and others—is a revelatory listen.

albums.title: CCFX EP
albums.label: DFA
albums.description: CCFX is the filmic dream pop collaboration of Mary Jane Dunphe (Vexx, CC Dust) and members of Olympia band Trans FX. Their EP for DFA Records is brought to life by Dunphe’s visceral, magnetic vocals.

albums.title: Any Other Way
albums.label: Numero Group
albums.description: A new box set documents the riveting story of Toronto soul singer and transgender music pioneer Jackie Shane. Hers are songs laced with pain but emboldened by a remarkable sense of self-possession.

albums.title: Going Grey
albums.label: Fueled by Ramen
albums.description: The New Jersey-based indie-rock underdogs, more popular than ever before, embrace synths on their sixth studio album.

albums.title: Death Revenge
albums.label: Relapse
albums.description: The goregrind crew’s sixth album, based on a 19th-century Scottish killing spree, is the metal equivalent of a bingeable British TV period piece.

albums.title: Losing
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: Singer-guitarist Alicia Bognanno sounds tensed and ready to strike on the Nashville-based grunge torchbearers’ second album (and first for Sub Pop).

albums.title: Super Slimey
albums.label: Epic
albums.description: This surprise-released collaboration sees the Atlanta rappers finally finding common ground, though neither is in peak form. Super Slimey forgoes explosiveness and poignancy for streamlined action.

albums.title: Musik
albums.label: Secretly Canadian
albums.description: On a new collection of recordings stowed away since the 1980s, the iconic color photographer extends his knack for defamiliarizing the mundane to synthesizers and pop standards.

albums.title: Glasshouse
albums.label: Island
albums.description: On her third album, the English singer/songwriter vividly captures a love both intimate and powerful.

albums.title: Thawing Dawn
albums.label: Dull Tools
albums.description: The debut solo LP from Andrew Savage of Parquet Courts finds him singing more intimately about love in quieter, more rustic settings. In its own peculiar way, it speaks to our current condition.

albums.title: III
albums.label: Run for Cover
albums.description: Soaring Swedish indie rockers Makthaverskan deliver anthems of heartache that anyone could love on their third album.

albums.title: Anthology: Movie Themes 1974-1998
albums.label: Sacred Bones
albums.description: New recordings of the horror auteur’s iconic film themes, from Halloween to Assault on Precinct 13 and beyond, highlight his influential approach to music.

albums.title: The Queen Is Dead
albums.label: Warner Bros.
albums.description: Newly reissued as a boxed set, the Smiths’ 1986 masterpiece still stands as an enduring testament to England in the ’80s, the complex relationship between performer and fan, and the ecstasy of emptiness.

albums.title: The Saga Continues
albums.label: Entertainment One
albums.description: Thanks to Martin Shkreli, Wu-Tang is worth millions again. But is their new album even worth your time?

albums.title: Beginning to Fall in Line Before Me, So Decorously, the Nature of All That Must Be Transformed
albums.label: W.25TH
albums.description: A new live album from the avant-garde power trio led by Japanese noise icon Keiji Haino is a demented joy, best experienced at high volumes.

albums.title: Sis-boom-bah!
albums.label: Dekmantel
albums.description: The Israeli-Dutch techno duo’s fifth album is an intriguing left turn, leading them far from the dancefloor and well into serene, spacey new age territory.

albums.title: Ruler Rebel / Diaspora / The Emancipation Procrastination
albums.label: Ropeadope
albums.description: On the three albums that compose The Centennial Trilogy, the New Orleans horn player and composer pays tribute to the American jazz tradition by tapping into the legacy of fusion.

albums.title: Humble Beast
albums.label: Machine Entertainment Group
albums.description: The Chicago rapper has earned his role as a leader of rap. His latest album recalls the best records of the ’00s graced with a singular kind of songwriting that sounds inarguably like the present.

albums.title: In the City / This Is the Modern World / The Polydor Demos: February 1977 / Live 1977 + John Peel Sessions
albums.label: UME
albums.description: Their career was just beginning, but the Jam were already the hardest-working band in U.K. punk. A new box set revisits their breakthrough year.

albums.title: ken
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: Elegant and perverse, Dan Bejar’s latest album slinks around in the shadows like he did on Kaputt, synthy, sleazy, and newly paranoid. He remains one of the most evocative songwriters of his generation.

albums.title: Reaching for Indigo
albums.label: Drag City
albums.description: Haley Fohr’s latest and best record of experimental folk folds in some of the simpler songwriting of her countrified Jackie Lynn project.

albums.title: As You Please
albums.label: Run for Cover
albums.description: The Ohio rock band’s bleak, heavy, and ambitious third LP is a subtle signal that they’re a band their fans can grow up with rather than out of.

albums.title: The Con X: Covers
albums.label: Warner Bros.
albums.description: Tegan and Sara are celebrating the 10th anniversary of their vanguard fifth album with a compilation of covers from Hayley Williams, Chvrches, Bleachers, Grimes, Kelly Lee Owens, and more.

albums.title: Mr. Davis
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: Seventeen months since his release from prison, Gucci Mane delivers one of his most consistent and accessible releases in years, and a prime showcase for his renewed charisma.

albums.title: D.K. / S.K. EP
albums.label: Melody As Truth
albums.description: The first collaboration from increasingly-mellow producers Diego Herrera (aka Suzanne Kraft) and Dang-Khoa Chau wades into sedate territory that’s tentative but promising.

albums.title: Ain’t Too Long
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: On his third mixtape this year, the young Baton Rouge rapper continues to upend the fear and survivalism that he carries with him.

albums.title: Body Consonance
albums.label: Hands in the Dark
albums.description: In a departure from the spatial concerns of his site-specific pieces, the composer’s new album explores the physicality of sound itself.

albums.title: Morning After
albums.label: OVO Sound
albums.description: The second album from the OVO R&B duo wades into the thick fog of heartbreak but stays grounded by the delicate and powerful voice of Daniel Daley and the shadowy, cinematic beats of Ninteen85.

albums.title: Wamp 2 Dem
albums.label: Island
albums.description: With top-shelf beats and assists from A-list contributors, the South London rapper’s new mixtape aims to show American listeners that there’s more to British rap than grime and cameos on Drake singles.

albums.title: Lune Rouge
albums.label: Young Art
albums.description: The Los Angeles electronic musician rebounds from a rare brain disease—and the temporary loss of her ability to speak and hear music—by confidently streamlining her pop impulses.

albums.title: Rose
albums.label: Ninja Tune
albums.description: For her debut album, now reissued on vinyl by Ninja Tune, Abra draws on the cynicism of darkwave and its brooding hues, while making room for brighter beats, quicker tempos, and lyrical vulnerability.

albums.title: Colors
albums.label: Fonograf
albums.description: Beck’s 13th album is his most overtly pop record, one filled with sunshine and sadness, but feels connected to little more than a good idea.

albums.title: There Is No Love in Fluorescent Light
albums.label: Last Gang
albums.description: The Montreal indie band Stars have stretched hushed electro-pop into scrambling arena rock for nearly 20 years. They sound revived and more emotionally mature on their eighth album.

albums.title: Murderburgers
albums.label: Khannibalism
albums.description: The once wildly unhinged psych-rock maverick grows into adulthood, though his backing band brings some much-needed weirdness to the proceedings.

albums.title: A Love Letter to You 2
albums.label: Capitol
albums.description: Ohio rapper Trippie Redd’s second mixtape this year is all hooks, all emotion, but features poorly designed songs that lack the spark of his previous mixtape.

albums.title: The Magic City / My Brother the Wind Vol. 1
albums.label: Cosmic Myth
albums.description: Sun Ra manifested an ecstatic vision of jazz that is still being unpacked and realized a half-century on. A pair of new reissues highlight two defining albums in his oeuvre.

albums.title: Masseduction
albums.label: Loma Vista
albums.description: Annie Clark’s fifth album as St. Vincent isn’t a pop album so much as a deeply, admittedly personal communique with a pop veneer. The songs tear into the feeling of leaving and having been left alone.

albums.title: Wrong Way Up
albums.label: Opal
albums.description: Brian Eno and John Cale’s 1990 collaboration is an album of contention, contrasts, cycles, and pop songs so layered and euphoric it is one of the best albums either artist has ever made.

albums.title: For Paris
albums.label: Novel Sound
albums.description: Though weighted with a complicated backstory, Vincent’s latest album contains some of the most organic and sincere techno to come out this year.

albums.title: Exit Entrance
albums.label: DFA
albums.description: Japan’s Kouhei Matsunaga, aka NHK yx koyxen, takes a scientific approach to experimental electronic music. His new album is a dynamic work of maze-like rhythms, trapdoors, and serenity.

albums.title: Eros in Arabia
albums.label: Freedom to Spend
albums.description: On his 1981 debut album, the composer and percussionist channels the Fourth World spirit of his collaborator Jon Hassell, to spellbinding effect.

albums.title: Offering
albums.label: Sinderlyn
albums.description: On the third album from the bedroom-pop duo, Madeline Follin and Brian Oblivion turn their faces toward the sun with songs fuller and brighter than ever before.

albums.title: Nothing Valley
albums.label: Wax Nine
albums.description: On their debut album, the quartet applies noise-rock chops and jazz-versed drumming to a wild set of songs with a gastrointestinal fixation.

albums.title: The OOZ
albums.label: True Panther
albums.description: The producer born Archy Marshall crafted The OOZ to be alien and timeless. It is the richest and most immersive album the London singer-songwriter has made yet, under any name.

albums.title: Shaneera EP
albums.label: Hyperdub
albums.description: Producer Fatima Al Qadiri adapts the “evil extreme femme alter ego” of Shaneera for her new EP on the Hyperdub label, which is packed with melody, drama, and joy.

albums.title: Wide Open
albums.label: Kanine
albums.description: The new LP from Toronto’s Weaves features more refined production than their 2016 debut. It highlights frontwoman Jasmyn Burke’s lyrics about personal experiences that parlay into universal struggle.

albums.title: Tenderness
albums.label: Arbutus
albums.description: Raphaelle Standell and Alexander Kerby’s third album draws upon classic house and disco in its examination of the pitfalls of love in the digital era.

albums.title: Lil Pump
albums.label: Tha Lights Global
albums.description: Lil Pump’s debut is loud, hyper, and catchy. There isn’t a moment where the 17-year-old rapper, seemingly born in some viral think tank, doesn’t sound completely, endearingly stoked.

albums.title: Pinewood Smile
albums.label: Cooking Vinyl
albums.description: The Darkness have never sounded more dated, or more like unsuccessful comedy rock, than on their depressing new album.

albums.title: Lotta Sea Lice
albums.label: Matador
albums.description: The collaborative LP from Kurt Vile and Courtney Barnett feels like an overheard discussion between two existential misfits. They sing songs about writing songs, covering each other in the process.

albums.title: DEADSTAR
albums.label: Alamo
albums.description: On his debut album, the 20-year-old Florida rapper offers a dead-eyed approximation of the SoundCloud rap zeitgeist; it’s an album full of undirected transgressions, less thrilling than numbing.

albums.title: Cry Cry Cry
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: Wolf Parade have cleaned up further on their streamlined new record, making for solid throwback indie rock.

albums.title: Three Futures
albums.label: 4AD
albums.description: The new album from singer-songwriter Mackenzie Scott is her most ambitious work by an order of magnitude. It’s an electric-electronic hybrid that is lush, physical, and full of contradictions.

albums.title: Heaven Upside Down
albums.label: Loma Vista
albums.description: On his 10th album, Marilyn Manson embraces the tropes that made him a menace and a rock star and a stalwart of goth. This is his turf, and rather than expand it, he seeks to defend it.

albums.title: Damn the Torpedoes
albums.label: Backstreet
albums.description: Damn the Torpedos is the peak of Tom Petty’s songwriting with the Heartbreakers. Slick, big, and immutably classic, the album is a front-to-back feat of production and songwriting.

albums.title: Wildflowers
albums.label: Warner Bros.
albums.description: When he was 44 years old, Tom Petty released his second and greatest solo album. It is a crucial entry to his catalog, one whose songwriting is elegantly spare, personal, and intuitive.

albums.title: Full Moon Fever
albums.label: MCA
albums.description: On his debut solo album, Tom Petty’s economical, thoughtful songwriting gelled with Jeff Lynne’s restrained production. They crafted a laid-back sound but kept the tension of heartland rock‘n’roll.

albums.title: Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers
albums.label: Shelter
albums.description: Despite featuring two of the band’s most enduring hits, Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers’ debut is best remembered as a sketchpad for ideas that came together later.

albums.title: Belief System
albums.label: Houndstooth
albums.description: Amplifying the scope of his rave-nostalgia project, Paul Woolford expands his ambitions but loses sight of the spontaneity that made the music so thrilling in the first place.

albums.title: Fatherland
albums.label: BMG
albums.description: On his third solo album, the former Bloc Party frontman unexpectedly trades electronic trappings for a folksy, fingerpicked inner-soul audit.

albums.title: The Weather Station
albums.label: Paradise of Bachelors
albums.description: Toronto songwriter Tamara Lindeman self-produced her bold fourth LP. From front-to-back, this is the first Weather Station album that sounds as fleshed-out and powerful as the world it contains.

albums.title: I Love You Like a Brother
albums.label: Dead Oceans
albums.description: On her giddy rush of a debut, Australia’s Alex Lahey offers a remarkably focused set of sing-along choruses, punk-pop dynamics, and casually witty observations about relationships.

albums.title: For Sale: Live at Maxwell’s 1986
albums.label: Rhino
albums.description: This oft-bootlegged, now greatly enhanced 29-song recording finds the Replacements on the brink of a crucial turning point—like a final college bender before entering the working world.

albums.title: The Carnival
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: Riding the wave of success from the Fugees’ The Score, Wyclef Jean’s 1997 solo debut is a 74-minute party, as advertised. It’s a proud transcultural product that broadcasted an eclectic future.

albums.title: Dreams and Daggers
albums.label: Mack Avenue
albums.description: The young jazz singer’s live double album showcases the gravitas, humor, and modernity she brings both to classic standards and her own compositions.

albums.title: U Feel Anything?
albums.label: Planet Mu
albums.description: In her abraded experimental club music, Berlin producer Ziúr favors a skeletal sound that still confidently occupies a maximal amount of space. It suggests that agitation can produce beauty.

albums.title: Red Burns
albums.label: Grand Closing
albums.description: Standing on the Corner is the collaboration of two jazz-inclined oddballs from New York City. Their dazzling, invigorating Red Burns project is a freeform response to recent world events.

albums.title: Electric Circus
albums.label: Vinyl Me Please
albums.description: Newly reissued on vinyl, Common’s 2002 album is a massive group effort: Prince, Erykah Badu, Pharrell, Jill Scott, and many more built a sound that helped change the limits of rap, soul, and R&B.

albums.title: Take Me Apart
albums.label: Warp
albums.description: Kelela’s debut album is technically stunning and emotionally realized. It lives in a new, outré, rhythmic pop galaxy that honors but outpaces its peers.

albums.title: Josie and the Pussycats—Music from the Motion Picture
albums.label: Mondo
albums.description: The first reissue of the 2001 film’s soundtrack proves the last legacy of three Archie comics characters.

albums.title: Eternal Recurrence
albums.label: Anticon
albums.description: Angel Deradoorian zooms in on the heady, spiritual undercurrent of her past work for the new age Eternal Recurrence, which is hushed, meditative, and bathed in amber glow.

albums.title: The Kid
albums.label: Western Vinyl
albums.description: On her most accessible album yet, Kaitlyn Aurelia Smith draws out the organic qualities of her Buchla 100 modular synth. But The Kid sparks a bodily pleasure alongside her music’s cerebral delights.

albums.title: Trip
albums.label: Def Jam
albums.description: Written during a period of grief, Jhené Aiko’s 22-track LP turns her methods of survival—enlightenment, drugs, music itself—into an epic concept album. Some of Aiko’s most honest writing occurs here.

albums.title: The Bigger Artist
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: The New York rapper’s promising debut showcases a 21-year-old who’s still finding his own lane between sensitivity and swagger.

albums.title: Multi-task
albums.label: Trouble in Mind
albums.description: The wiry Atlanta, Ga. rock trio Omni sells its nervous energy as a logical way of dealing with the world. Where other bands might smooth things out, Omni finds angles and sharp turns.

albums.title: As You Were
albums.label: Warner Bros.
albums.description: The debut solo album from the 45-year-old, would-be rock’n’roll savior fails to match the charm of his cantankerous public persona.

albums.title: Neō Wax Bloom
albums.label: Brainfeeder
albums.description: The new album from Irish producer Iglooghost presents an alien landscape with only rare bits of human comfort. Even at its most elegant, it unfurls like a sensory attack.

albums.title: Tell Me You Love Me
albums.label: Island
albums.description: On her sixth album, Demi Lovato finds a consistently compelling space: flinty, flirty R&B that’s just as thrilling hushed as it is at full blast.

albums.title: Ash
albums.label: XL
albums.description: On their second album, the French-Cuban twins Lisa-Kaindé and Naomi Díaz make gorgeous, genre-agnostic meditations on resilience and mindful resistance.

albums.title: Dream Theory in Malaya: Fourth World Volume Two
albums.label: Glitterbeat
albums.description: Trumpeter and composer Jon Hassell follows his own dream logic on this 1981 LP, which synthesized his hybrid of jazz and minimalism, ambient and exotica, ancient ethnic music and glitchy electronics.

albums.title: Decreation
albums.label: 20 Buck Spin
albums.description: Under the influence of French philosopher Simone Weil, the Oakland quartet Acephalix offer the immediate hook of classic death metal on their third full-length.

albums.title: Hiss Spun
albums.label: Sargent House
albums.description: Chelsea Wolfe dives headfirst into sludge metal and creates a unique space where sweetness can be heavy and contact is always uncomfortable.

albums.title: New Energy
albums.label: Text
albums.description: Kieran Hebden’s pursuit of new sounds has found him digging into his own catalog. New Energy is a wide-ranging album that connects the warmth of his early work to his latest club experiments.

albums.title: Dark Bliss
albums.label: White Material
albums.description: The debut album from the Cleveland-raised, New York-based producer is a dreamy, hypnotic style of hip-house. It’s a low-key album that keeps its pleasures close to its chest.

albums.title: Relatives in Descent
albums.label: Domino
albums.description: The fourth album from the literary Detroit rock band Protomartyr is sinuous and allusive, dense and at times dizzying. It contains a constant sense of unease about the world and its future.

albums.title: Visions of a Life
albums.label: RCA
albums.description: Wolf Alice proudly carry the banner for Britrock on their second album, a holy site where dead metaphors and teen clichés can spring magically back to life.

albums.title: Always Foreign
albums.artist: The World Is a Beautiful Place & I Am No Longer Afraid to Die
albums.label: Epitaph
albums.description: On their vital, bristling third LP, the band is at their most concise and vitriolic. Their songwriting suggests the world is an increasingly terrible place and we should all be scared to death.

albums.title: Tommy EP
albums.label: Hyperdub
albums.description: On her exhilarating Hyperdub debut, the London electronic musician slathers on processed vocals in thick, inky layers, breaking feverishly free of the rhythmic grid.

albums.title: If Blue Could Be Happiness
albums.label: Double Double Whammy
albums.description: The second full-length from New York folk-pop trio Florist distills their sound to its essence. It finds beauty in simplicity and strength in fragility, full of songs that are quietly commanding.

albums.title: He’s the DJ, I’m the Rapper
albums.artist: DJ Jazzy Jeff & The Fresh Prince
albums.label: Jive
albums.description: The duo’s 1988 goofy but undeniably catchy double-album mixed hip-hop bona fides with an effervescent MC. It would win over Middle America and score the first-ever Grammy for a rap album.

albums.title: DJ-Kicks
albums.label: !K7
albums.description: Tapping Detroit techno, IDM, and boom-bap hip-hop, Lone’s horizontally inclined DJ-Kicks mix uses expert selection and programming to highlight his own distinctive musical sensibility.

albums.title: Vilseledd
albums.label: Party Smasher Inc.
albums.description: Sweden’s God Mother blend black metal, d-beat, grind, math rock, and more, contorting tradition rather than kowtowing to it. Their hellish new album offers occasional glimpses of greatness.

albums.title: VTM
albums.label: VTM
albums.description: The offbeat Chicago rapper’s knowing, laconic vocal style fits into the spare beats on his latest mixtape. It is deceptively cool and unpredictable.

albums.title: Now
albums.label: Mercury Nashville
albums.description: Shania Twain’s fifth studio album and first in 15 years feels courageous. Her songs are modern and pleasant but the specter of her life’s temporary collapse hangs over its best tracks.

albums.title: Younger Now
albums.label: RCA
albums.description: Bland production and weak songwriting hamstring the personalized nature of Younger Now, making it merely a suggestion of the kind of artist Miley Cyrus could be.

albums.title: Paradise
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: After producing for Joey Purp and Vic Mensa and singing on Chance the Rapper’s “All Night,” Chicago’s Kevin Rhomberg steps up with his breezy debut album. It crystallizes his peculiar pop appeal.

albums.title: La Confusion
albums.label: Because Music
albums.description: The long-married Malian duo confronts the country’s upheavals with an album of shimmering Afro-pop that urges hope and offers uplift.

albums.title: The Centre Cannot Hold
albums.label: Mute
albums.description: Recording in Chicago with Steve Albini at the controls, Ben Frost unleashes volleys of brutalizing electronic sound as an allegory for the grim state of the world.

albums.title: Harmony of Difference EP
albums.label: Young Turks
albums.description: Even on this shorter EP, saxophonist and composer Kamasi Washington displays a tireless ambition with his compositions, performance, and spiritual approach.

albums.title: By Any Means 2
albums.label: Bread Winners’ Association
albums.description: The Baton Rouge rapper is still a fearsome MC in his prime. His latest mixtape cuts the distance between his singsongy, hook-driven punches and his cold, levelheaded lessons.

albums.title: Experimental Music
albums.label: Radical Elite
albums.description: The sixth album from Ian Svenonius’ rock group Chain and the Gang could be his sharpest set of ironic arguments yet. Svenonius’ hot-wired backing band whips his clever tunes into tornados.

albums.title: L’Rain
albums.label: Astro Nautico
albums.description: Brooklyn experimentalist Taja Cheek adopted the stage name L’Rain in 2014, and her debut is a beautiful, untidy conduit of her grieving. The album’s unconventional structures lend it a pastoral feel.

albums.title: V
albums.label: Caroline
albums.description: On their fifth album, the Horrors retool their formula for retro-leaning, riff-laden arena rock in an attempt to reconnect with the “unsettling” spirit of their garage-rock roots.

albums.title: Plum
albums.label: Drag City
albums.description: The new album from Cory Hanson’s band Wand is its most focused, finessed, and best record to date. It contains an audacious refinement that transcends the group’s beginnings in the garage-rock scene.

albums.title: Roll With the Punches
albums.label: Exile
albums.description: Van Morrison’s 37th album is a thorough exploration of the blues. It’s crisp, precise, and reveals his ability to inhabit classic songs while paying respect to their form.

albums.title: Aromanticism
albums.label: Jagjaguwar
albums.description: The debut album from Moses Sumney is a soulful, cosmic embrace of aloneness. His deep blue songwriting examines the blasé cruelty that defines intimacy in our swipe-left era.

albums.title: Sun Gong / Bring on the Sun
albums.label: All Saints
albums.description: On his latest set of releases, the new age composer Laraaji delivers divine works full of drifting ambience. He offers sage advice and highlights the transformative power of ancient gong tones.

albums.title: Young Martha EP
albums.label: YSL
albums.description: The first collaborative EP from Young Thug and the producer Carnage is an intriguing proposition, and it’s dazzling at times. But it seems to scratch the surface of their potential chemistry.

albums.title: Gemini
albums.label: Bendo
albums.description: The new album from Macklemore—his first without collaborator Ryan Lewis since 2006—is a light listen with a couple of good moments and some innocuous clunkers, plus features from Lil Yachty and Offset.

albums.title: Thrice Woven
albums.label: Artemisia
albums.description: On the follow-up to 2014’s electronic departure, Celestite, the Olympia band stumble in the attempt to find their way back to classic black metal.

albums.title: Cold Dark Place EP
albums.label: Reprise
albums.description: The new Mastodon EP is an eclectic, psychedelic journey that sees guitarist/vocalist Brent Hinds picking up a Sho-Bud 13-string pedal steel guitar. His mastery of the instrument is quickly clear.

albums.title: Living Water
albums.label: Woodsist
albums.description: L.A. singer-songwriter Shannon Lay’s new album is a work of plainspoken mysticism that goes to the small, bright truth of things, showcasing her unusual songwriting and quietly commanding voice.

albums.title: The Spirit of Memphis (1962-1976)
albums.label: Stax
albums.description: Covering his prime years as Stax Records’ ace in the hole, this four-disc set presents Hayes as a complex, compelling bandleader, producer, and songwriter who reshaped the dimensions of soul.

albums.title: Dulce Compañia
albums.label: Incienso
albums.description: On his full-length debut, the versatile Queens producer Brian Piñeyro adopts his serpentine alias to make the most of the dembow riddim’s slippery extremes.

albums.title: Fabriclive 94
albums.label: Fabric
albums.description: The debut commercial mix CD from UK producer Harry Agius, aka Midland, transcends the typical function of a DJ mix. It’s one of the year’s best, with potential to resonate beyond dance-music diehards.

albums.title: Elastica
albums.label: Deceptive
albums.description: With its pithy, searing songs about sex, groupies, and ennui, the self-titled 1995 debut from Elastica captured the whirlwind of the early-’90s Britpop explosion.

albums.title: Stranger in the Alps
albums.label: Dead Oceans
albums.description: L.A. singer-songwriter Phoebe Bridgers’ debut LP is a collection of songs about intimacy, documenting how our relationships affect the way we view ourselves and interact with others.

albums.title: Experiencing the Deposit of Faith
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: This self-released compilation from Yves Tumor is more atmospheric than last year’s excellent Serpent Music. Its 12 sketches account for some of the prettiest songs Tumor has made.

albums.title: Their Satanic Majesties Request
albums.label: ABKCO
albums.description: Reissued for its 50th anniversary, Satanic Majesties remains a singular entry in the Stones’ catalog. It is the strange result of a bizarre set of personal, professional, and cultural circumstances.

albums.title: Strange Peace
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: The Toronto-based trio Metz have incorporated harmony into their heavy sound on their third full-length. They shift away from all-out abrasion, adding color to their eruptions.

albums.title: I’m a Harmony
albums.label: Omnivore
albums.description: Like her 2014 comeback record, the new album from psych-folk artist Linda Perhacs features collaborations with Julia Holter and electronic touches, expanding the borders of her sound.

albums.label: Light in the Attic
albums.description: A new anthology of the oft-overlooked 1990s indie rockers zeroes in on what they did best: gentle jangle, tumbleweed drift, and hazy harmonies that display profound comfort in quietude.

albums.title: Music for the Age of Miracles
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: On the first full album in seven years from the softly psychedelic British band, they’ve left something behind in the quest to recapture the essence of the Clientele.

albums.title: Wonderful Wonderful
albums.label: Island
albums.description: With the Killers, greatness and ridiculousness go hand in hand. Their fifth album contains only a little of both.

albums.title: You.Know.I.Got.It (The Album)
albums.label: YOU.KNOW.I.GOT.IT Entertainment
albums.description: Recorded over two years, the up-and-coming Berkeley rapper’s debut is intensely passionate and artfully subtle. Few rappers can say so much with so little.

albums.title: Hallelujah Anyhow
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: Hiss Golden Messenger’s bittersweet, new LP is full of fluttery soul-grooves, borrowing from various regional folk and blues traditions. It speaks to what it means to be a compassionate citizen today.

albums.title: Brand New Abyss
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: The duo of Khaela Maricich and Melissa Dyne venture into modular synthesis for the latest the Blow album. The change is not entirely positive, but it glimmers with some promising moments.

albums.title: Luciferian Towers
albums.label: Constellation
albums.description: The sound of Godspeed’s radical fury takes a sideline on their impeccably composed sixth album. It contains their most melodic and powerfully positive-sounding music to date.

albums.title: Haiku From Zero
albums.label: Astralwerks
albums.description: The Australian band’s reverence for reference is part of their allure and their fifth album sticks to the tried-and-true pop formulas of the past.

albums.title: ununiform
albums.label: !K7
albums.description: On his 13th studio album, Tricky translates newfound contentment into songs that fail to live up to the risk-taking example of his early work.

albums.title: Electric Trim
albums.label: Mute
albums.description: Lee Ranaldo’s latest album is his finest post-Sonic Youth solo effort, featuring collaborations with Sharon Van Etten, Nels Cline, Kid Millions, and lyrics co-written with novelist Jonathan Lethem.

albums.title: Light Information
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: The sixth proper album from Calgary-based multimedia auteur Chad VanGaalen is one of his finer efforts, demonstrating his uncanny knack for off-kilter songcraft.

albums.title: Brick Body Kids Still Daydream
albums.label: Mello Music Group
albums.description: Armed with a caustic wit and a poetic eye, Open Mike Eagle builds a small, quiet monument to a housing project in Chicago across a diverse and singular piece of contemporary hip-hop.

albums.title: Mourn
albums.label: Wedidit
albums.description: Teen R&B oddball Corbin Smidzik (fka Spooky Black) has refocused his energy. Working with Weeknd collaborator Doc McKinney, he hones his vocal talent, even going for some black metal-inspired screams.

albums.title: Son of a Lady EP
albums.label: Tendril Tales
albums.description: The former Mazzy Star frontwoman presents three gentle tracks where her mature, reserved delivery gets tangled in threads of childlike whimsy.

albums.title: Prophets of Rage
albums.label: Concord Music Group
albums.description: The power once held by Rage Against the Machine, Public Enemy, and Cypress Hill is spread far too thin and feels far too dated to sustain the momentum of the supergroup’s debut LP.

albums.title: Concrete and Gold
albums.label: Roswell
albums.description: Nine albums in and Dave Grohl knows how to keep the machine running. Concrete and Gold is reliable, relatable, and powerful with just barely enough new ideas to keep things interesting.

albums.title: Buy Muy Drugs
albums.label: Ether Jung
albums.description: The collaborative concept album from rapper Denmark Vessey and producer Azarias mixes Afro-Brazilian rhythms, grime, and bass to imagine a dystopian world in which desperation is the new normal.

albums.title: Parallels
albums.label: Innovative Leisure
albums.description: The new album from L.A. producer Jason Chung, aka Nosaj Thing, is more open-ended than usual, bringing collaborators like Zuri Marley, Blonde Redhead’s Kazu Makino, and Steve Spacek into the fray.

albums.title: Existence Problem EP
albums.label: Pelican Fly
albums.description: The 21-year-old Norwegian producer’s debut EP is driven by whimsy and promises a fresh spin on the Pelican Fly sound.

albums.title: White Pony
albums.label: Maverick
albums.description: While living on houseboats in Sausalito, California, Deftones broke away from nu-metal and recorded the melodic highlight of their career, a moody album born of sex, Sade, and cocaine.

albums.title: Event Horizon
albums.label: Be With
albums.description: Power pop band the Necessaries are best remembered for counting Arthur Russell and Modern Lovers’ Ernie Brooks as members. But there’s more to the story, as their newly reissued 1982 LP shows.

albums.title: Half-Light
albums.label: Nonesuch
albums.description: The intimate, elliptical solo debut from producer and former Vampire Weekender gorgeously traces the stories and sounds of his past.

albums.title: Discussions
albums.label: Wide Hive
albums.description: Five decades since co-founding the Art Ensemble of Chicago, the pioneering saxophonist offers innovative fusions of composition and improvisation on a rare album for large ensemble.

albums.title: The Aviary
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: Swedish pop duo Galantis are gleeful vocal manipulators who have written for the likes of Britney Spears and Icona Pop. On their new LP, their maximalism takes on the halting sounds of tropical house.

albums.title: Akira (Symphonic Suite)
albums.label: Milan
albums.description: The new vinyl reissue from Milan Records highlights the “sonic architecture” of Dr. Shoji Yamashiro’s intense and immersive suite of music.

albums.title: Souvenirs
albums.label: Plume
albums.description: On her third LP, Seattle’s Shenandoah Davis turns breakups into pitch-perfect chamber pop, propelled by wise lyrics and her striking, classically-trained voice.

albums.title: Wide Open
albums.label: BMG
albums.description: The erstwhile Doobie Brothers leader and Steely Dan associate’s first album in 20 years is more of an urbane R&B labor of love than an attempt to capitalize on his resurgent popularity.

albums.title: Blue Velvet (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)
albums.label: Fire
albums.description: The iconic soundtrack marks the beginning of Angelo Badalamenti’s 30-plus-year creative partnership with David Lynch; torn between terror and ecstasy, it is as full of mystery as his films.

albums.title: Dedicated to Bobby Jameson
albums.label: Mexican Summer
albums.description: Refining the gonzo pop-collages of his previous work, Ariel Pink crafts an immersive, intimate record, marked by solitude.

albums.title: Communicating
albums.label: OWSLA
albums.description: Carving out an intensely introspective space in the overlap between electronic and acoustic sounds, the Los Angeles trio’s third album traffics in melancholy and occasionally ecstatic moods.

albums.title: Ardor
albums.label: Southern Lord
albums.description: Channeling squalls of feedback and waves of downtuned guitars, Montreal’s BIG|BRAVE represent the raw unconscious turned up as loud as their amps will go.

albums.title: Deer Tick Vol. 1 / Deer Tick Vol. 2
albums.label: Partisan
albums.description: On their latest release, which is two whole albums long, Deer Tick offer an acoustic set and an electric one. The discs both contain a more settled outlook from bandleader John McCauley than usual.

albums.title: Running Back Mastermix
albums.label: Running Back
albums.description: The New York DJ Tony Humphries mixes an impeccably smooth course through disco-inflected house from Germany’s Running Back label.

albums.title: The Gradual Progression
albums.label: Rvng Intl.
albums.description: Greg Fox’s second solo album is spiritually ecstatic. The once and future metal drummer finds new clarity in electronic, ambient, and even New Age sounds.

albums.title: Native Invader
albums.label: Decca
albums.description: The 15th album from one of pop’s most inventive composers as a braid of political, maternal, and celestial statements. Amos’ intricately arranged songs are passionate and despairingly poetic.

albums.title: CCCLX
albums.label: LuckyMe
albums.description: The debut LP from Montreal producer Lunice (one-half of TNGHT) is intended as the score for a speculative theater piece, but the music alone comes off garish and retrograde.

albums.title: Hippopotamus
albums.label: BMG
albums.description: On the first proper Sparks album in nearly a decade, the Mael brothers let existential anxiety into their bouncy music more overtly than usual.

albums.title: A Moment Apart
albums.label: Counter
albums.description: The electronic duo Odesza are at the center of the current movement in stadium-filling ”chill” music. Their latest is full of billowing vocal harmonies, seismic rumble, and turbo-charged trap beats.

albums.title: 1992 Deluxe
albums.label: Rough Trade
albums.description: On her newly reissued and expanded 2016 mixtape, Destiny Frasqueri—aka Princess Nokia—raps with granular detail about mysticism, childhood, and her native New York City.

albums.title: In Search of Lost Time
albums.label: You've Changed
albums.description: Defiantly queer, proudly Canadian, and righteously stoned, Ontario’s Partner infuse their bubble-grunge indie-rock riffs with a slyly subversive spirit.

albums.title: Hitchhiker
albums.label: Reprise
albums.description: Recorded over one night in 1976, Hitchhiker is an acoustic snapshot of Neil Young’s creative process, captured at a time when he was crafting music strong enough to last his whole career.

albums.title: MAKANDA at the End of Space, the Beginning of Time
albums.label: Bonsound
albums.description: Uniting musicians from Kinshasa, Montreal, and Seattle, Pierre Kwenders’ second album, produced by Shabazz Palaces’ Tendai Maraire, is a wildly inventive, globe-spanning triumph.

albums.title: The Hanged Man
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: On his first album in seven years, Ted Leo faces down private and public upheaval, as personal tragedy and political calamity fuel the most expansive, emotionally devastating music of his career.

albums.title: Love What Survives
albums.label: Warp
albums.description: Mount Kimbie harness their command of detail—plus star turns from King Krule and James Blake—on a rhythm-driven album that feels less like electronic music and more like the work of a full band.

albums.title: Thx
albums.label: Double Double Whammy
albums.description: The second album from Texas songwriter Hannah Read—the creative force at the heart of Lomelda—is alternately quiet and erupting, with immediately arresting melodies that long for closeness and wonder.

albums.title: Outrage! Is Now
albums.label: Warner Bros.
albums.description: The Toronto dance-punk duo’s new album sees them embracing maturity, bringing in more reflection, more funk, more production finesse, and—crucially—more hooks.

albums.title: Red
albums.label: Island
albums.description: Red stands as one of classic rock’s heaviest albums and also one of its most meticulous. With its dark, meditative sheen, it laid the groundwork for Robert Fripp’s more atmospheric work to come.

albums.title: Forced Witness
albums.label: Secretly Canadian
albums.description: The art-sleaze of Alex Cameron’s second album transcends its surface-level smarm to become a biting piece of commentary. Thankfully, the songs are as effortlessly catchy as they are eminently creepy.

albums.title: Out of All This Blue
albums.label: BMG
albums.description: Mike Scott takes his long-running Irish/Scottish folk rock band the Waterboys into new terrain on his latest LP—incorporating four-four disco stomp, a heavy dose of hip-hop, and romantic love.

albums.title: How Did I Find Myself Here?
albums.label: Anti-
albums.description: On their first album in nearly 30 years, the Paisley Underground group reintroduce some of what made their 1982 debut—atmospheric rock music veering between noise and subtlety—so compelling.

albums.title: Mountain Moves
albums.label: Joyful Noise
albums.description: Mountain Moves is one of Deerhoof’s widest-ranging and most melodic sets, with hints of chamber music, hip-hop, and avant-garde jazz, plus more legible lyrics than usual. It’s a purposeful mosaic.

albums.title: Fifth Harmony
albums.label: Epic
albums.description: Now down to a quartet, the group’s latest album falls short of the kind of stellar pop songwriting they once possessed.

albums.title: Sleep Well Beast
albums.label: 4AD
albums.description: The band’s seventh album adds more chaos to their stately drama. It is full of abandon and quiet contemplation, as Matt Berninger sings not about how to enjoy life, but how to simply endure it.

albums.title: I Can’t Stand It Here on Quiet Nights: Singles 1981-82
albums.label: Silent Street
albums.description: Like many of their early ’80s UK peers, Maximum Joy mixed punk, funk, disco, and reggae. This new set captures a band carving its own place with two of music’s most powerful tools: muscle and joy.

albums.title: Ariadna
albums.label: 2MR
albums.description: Working with classic hardware synths, the Russian musician makes dark, dreamlike techno infused with her ethereal vocals.

albums.title: Antisocialites
albums.label: Polyvinyl
albums.description: The second album from the Toronto indie pop band is nothing but thoroughly accomplished songs. Alvvays have sharpened their focus without losing sight of themselves.

albums.title: Death Valley Oasis
albums.label: Anticon
albums.description: The producer and guitarist D33J has long been an integral behind-the-scenes member of L.A. beat collective WEDIDIT. His immersive debut full-length contains the surreal lushness its title suggests.

albums.title: The Echo of Pleasure
albums.artist: The Pains of Being Pure at Heart
albums.label: Painbow
albums.description: Full of gleaming exteriors, the latest album from the Pains of Being Pure at Heart is essentially a solo outing from frontman Kip Berman, who was on the brink of fatherhood when he wrote it.

albums.title: Okovi
albums.label: Sacred Bones
albums.description: Okovi showcases the searing, fully-formed music of Nika Danilova, an album of close personal experiences rendered into urgent goth-pop songs as emotional as they are necessary.

albums.title: Saturation II
albums.label: EMPIRE
albums.description: On their second album in as many months, the Los Angeles rap crew stay sleek and cool, but offer more appealing bouts of aggression and swagger.

albums.title: Poor David’s Almanack
albums.label: Acony
albums.description: David Rawlings finds news ways of inhabiting old folk music alongside his longtime musical partner Gillian Welch. There’s a crisp intimacy to his new solo effort, but also a self-awareness.

albums.title: The Source
albums.label: Blue Note
albums.description: On this hybrid album of jazz and Afrobeat, long-time Fela Kuti drummer Tony Allen makes the complex sound effortless. Rarely has percussive innovation sounded this downright satisfying.

albums.title: Twin Peaks (Music From the Limited Event Series)
albums.label: Rhino
albums.description: The hallucinatory performances at the Roadhouse in Twin Peaks: The Return are collected on a new soundtrack, celebrating a triumph of musical programming, mood, and David Lynch’s strange reality.

albums.title: Omnion
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: Andy Butler’s fourth album as Hercules and Love Affair delivers the subtle genre pivot that was so needed to reinvigorate their standing as the elder gatekeepers of club music history.

albums.title: Superchunk
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: It’s a blast to remember how versatile Superchunk are on their newly-reissued 1990 debut. It features all the embryonic styles of their power-pop-punk at once, with awkward, utterly alive exuberance.

albums.title: Every Country’s Sun
albums.label: Temporary Residence
albums.description: With David Fridmann producing, the latest Mogwai album contains the same bratty conviction that defined their greatest records, like there’s something truly at stake.

albums.title: Popeye: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack
albums.label: Varese Saraband
albums.description: Newly reissued to include the storied demo sessions, Harry Nilsson’s soundtrack to Robert Altman’s 1980 film is a mind-meld of two artists, a mournful little under-appreciated classic.

albums.title: Country Grammar
albums.label: Universal Records
albums.description: Nelly’s 2000 debut brought the life and sound of St. Louis to the world. It’s a syntactical maze of local culture that doubles as a flier for the greatest party you could ever imagine.

albums.title: Urban Hymns
albums.label: Virgin
albums.description: The Verve’s blockbuster third album—newly reissued in a five-disc expanded edition—has come to be seen as the swan song for Britpop’s cultural hegemony. But in 1997, it felt like a step forward.

albums.title: Toy
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: The fourth album from Austin, Tx.’s A Giant Dog fuses the gaudy delivery of 1970s rock and the pillars of modern punk. Its songs offer lyrics about sex without typical depictions of love.

albums.title: The Pacific Visions of Martin Glass
albums.label: Kit
albums.description: The electronic artist Martin Glass makes lounge music informed by exotica, emulating 1970s nippon pop, neo-classical, and ambient. Most of the sounds here are charming and innocuous.

albums.title: Dixieland
albums.label: Flesh and Bone
albums.description: Playing remarkably tuneful pop-rock at sludgy tempos, the Flint, Mich. trio Greet Death benefit from isolation. Their debut album is full of bludgeoning tones and diamond-cut production.

albums.title: we think we alone EP
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: On his new EP, the 21-year-old Queens singer presents a series of heart-rending song sketches inspired by loss.

albums.title: American Dream
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: The rebirth of LCD Soundsystem is marked by an extraordinary album obsessed with endings: of friendships, of love, of heroes, of a certain type of geeky fandom, and of the American dream itself.

albums.title: Trash Generator
albums.label: Sargent House
albums.description: On Trash Generator, the Sacramento trio Tera Melos builds on its prodigious mix of post-hardcore and prog, reining-in the chops in service of catchy, harmonically rich songs.

albums.title: Holiday Destination
albums.description: The third album from the UK singer-songwriter is unerringly compassionate. Her brooding post-punk is an unsettling backdrop for songs about the refugee crisis, Islamophobia, and poisonous politicians.

albums.title: Cozy Tapes Vol. 2: Too Cozy
albums.label: RCA
albums.description: A$AP Mob’s latest group effort features RZA, Frank Ocean, Chief Keef, Quavo and more, but the Mob’s energy and skill are consistently eclipsed by that of their guests.

albums.title: Results
albums.label: SFE
albums.description: The newly reissued 1989 collaboration between Liza Minelli and the Pet Shop Boys is a fascinating, addled mix of show tunes, strings, and 808s that coalesces in a mood of chic Upper East Side regret.

albums.title: Sketches of Brunswick East
albums.label: Flightless
albums.description: On their third full-length of 2017 alone, the Melbourne psych-rock band are surprisingly agile, incorporating soul, jazz, North African overtones, and pastoral English folk.

albums.label: EMPIRE
albums.description: The Florida rapper’s debut album is muted and mired with pain, trauma, and controversy. The reasons it is difficult to listen to can overshadow the need to listen to it.

albums.title: No Mountains in Manhattan
albums.label: XL
albums.description: Wiki’s new album is an acidic and vivid manifestation of his city, at times surreal and too real, with contributions from Earl Sweatshirt, Kaytranada, Ghostface Killah, and more.

albums.title: Bicep
albums.label: Ninja Tune
albums.description: On their debut album, the Irish duo Bicep—founders of the blog-turned-party and label Feel My Bicep—offer a lean and consciously paced survey of UK dance sounds with hints of psychedelia.

albums.title: Rainbow Edition
albums.label: Big Dada
albums.description: The first LP from Hype Williams in six years is ostensibly helmed not by its founders—Dean Blunt & Inga Copeland—but by a duo called Slaughter & Silvermane. It’s full of sludgy 808s and cheap synths.

albums.title: Luv Is Rage 2
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: Uzi’s latest project comes very close to delivering on the chaotic, sublime promise of “XO Tour Llif3.” It’s the Philly rapper’s  most musically developed work to date.

albums.title: A Man Called Destruction
albums.label: Omnivore
albums.description: In the mid-1990s, Alex Chilton entered a Memphis studio to track a collection of deep R&B and pop covers. The results were fascinating and frustrating in equal measure.

albums.title: Afrobeat Hot Hits: New Urban Dance Grooves From Africa
albums.label: Shanachie
albums.description: A new compilation of this hybrid Nigerian dance music—popularized in the U.S. by the likes of Drake and Diplo—shows that with Afrobeats, there’s much more than one dance.

albums.title: Blue Chips 7000
albums.label: Vice
albums.description: Action Bronson’s second studio album is also the third installment of his Blue Chips mixtape series. It’s full of bare raps and funky beats, of unadorned samples and dopey swaggering.

albums.title: Project Baby 2
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: On the Florida rapper’s latest project, he’s less measured than he’s been in the past. The moments of transparency are overshadowed by disingenuous storytelling and colorless punch lines.

albums.title: TFCF
albums.label: Mute
albums.description: Now working solo, Liars’ Angus Andrew looks back on the dissolution of his group with a strange, often contradictory album conceived in self-imposed isolation.

albums.title: Villains
albums.label: Matador
albums.description: With production flourishes from Mark Ronson, Josh Homme leads the band's most accessible album in decades. It’s equal parts disco inferno and devil-may-care experimentation.

albums.title: Beaucoup Fish
albums.label: UMC
albums.description: Originally released in 1999, Underworld's newly reissued rave-inspired fifth LP is often thrilling, but is mainly a fascinating snapshot of the UK group at a moment of ambivalence.

albums.title: Paranoia
albums.label: Def Jam
albums.description: The Harlem rapper’s latest project merges mainstream and underground rap flows while combating the perils of newfound success.

albums.title: Gypsy Woman
albums.label: Fania
albums.description: Singer, songwriter, pianist, and bandleader Joe Bataan took boogaloo to its peak with Gypsy Woman, combining soul, mambo, and traditional Latin tunes and became a mainstay for the famous Fania label.

albums.title: Brown Sugar
albums.label: Virgin
albums.description: D’Angelo’s debut was a sudden shock to ’90s R&B. The deluxe, expanded version of Brown Sugar reveals the extent to which it was grown folks music made by a 21-year-old genius.

albums.title: Freudian
albums.label: Golden Child
albums.description: On his debut album, Toronto R&B singer Daniel Caesar looks to gospel for a roadmap to the complexities of romantic love.

albums.title: Electro-Soma I + II
albums.label: Warp
albums.description: In the early ’90s, B12 were the best example of Detroit’s influence on IDM, and the reissue of Electro-Soma alongside a new compilation is a fearsomely beautiful work of electronic head music.

albums.title: Invitation
albums.label: Kill Rock Stars
albums.description: Sleater-Kinney’s Corin Tucker and R.E.M. guitarist Peter Buck team up for a crisp, allusive record that taps into their gnarled indie rock and punk roots.

albums.title: Good Nature
albums.label: Run for Cover
albums.description: The last album from Virginia-born band Turnover found a sweet spot between pop-punk and dream pop, but their influences are more sedate and smooth this time.

albums.title: Aytche
albums.label: Western Vinyl
albums.description: The debut album from saxophonist Joseph Shabason, best known for his work with Destroyer, shows a new side of his instrument. He uses electronics to create a kind of ambient jazz.

albums.title: Exile in the Outer Ring
albums.label: City Slang
albums.description: Erika M. Anderson’s third solo album is a surreal and powerful story about political alienation. Her character-driven songs of noise, folk, and pop music thrum with rage and fear.

albums.title: A Deeper Understanding
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: The obsessive studio work of Adam Granduciel creates a hermetic experience like no other. A Deeper Understanding is his most layered and meticulous album, a twilight world in which to lose yourself.

albums.title: So Numb
albums.label: Profound Lore
albums.description: Brooklyn trio Sannhet is an instrumental powerhouse. On So Numb, they shake loose of their black metal and post-rock roots, making heavy music with their own beautiful language.

albums.title: Black Ken
albums.label: BasedWorld
albums.description: Years of online myth-making have culminated with Lil B’s masterpiece Black Ken, 27 tracks of deep funk and hyphy that finally defines the mercurial Based God.

albums.title: Far From Over
albums.label: ECM
albums.description: Following last year’s duo album with trumpeter Wadada Leo Smith, pianist Vijay Iyer debuts a powerhouse sextet lineup to tackle some of his strongest, most varied writing yet.

albums.title: Beast Epic
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: Sam Beam brings Iron & Wine full circle on his sixth album, using the warm acoustic instrumentation of his early work and some of the most moving singing of his career.

albums.title: Science Fiction
albums.label: Procrastinate! Music Traitors
albums.description: Brand New’s fifth album stands as a monument to their gradual evolution. It is a wise and vulnerable conclusion for a rock band who were crucial in shaping a scene, a sound, and many emotions.

albums.title: S/T
albums.label: Polyvinyl
albums.description: The new LP from revived emo band Rainer Maria presents a slower, heavier, and more methodical version of the group. It’s a reunion album that stacks up well against their most cherished work.

albums.title: Orc
albums.label: Castle Face
albums.description: With their latest full-length, and a minor name change, John Dwyer’s garage-punk band continues to travel further toward rock’s outer limits.

albums.title: Take Flight
albums.label: I/AM/ME
albums.description: The first major release in three years from British DJ and producer Maya Jane Coles—once sampled by Nicki Minaj—is a moody two-hour collection that highlights her weaknesses.

albums.title: The Water We Drink
albums.label: Posh Isolation
albums.description: The Danish trio’s daring album takes a fluid approach to arrangement and song structure, balancing their industrial, noisier tendencies by engaging with the broader realm of pop music.

albums.title: Tropical Drums of Deutschland
albums.label: Music For Dreams
albums.description: The Salon des Amateurs resident DJ combs his collection of exotica to produce a compilation of globe-trotting ambient and drum-driven dancefloor cuts.

albums.title: Alice Glass EP
albums.label: Loma Vista
albums.description: On her first solo EP since leaving Crystal Castles, Alice Glass clears more room for her voice and words, softening the jagged edges that had characterized her previous work.

albums.title: Ripe & Majestic
albums.label: Rad Cult
albums.description: For his latest Tobacco collection, Tom Fec of Black Moth Super Rainbow compiles 24 tracks spanning 2007 to present. They testify to his proficiency as an arranger of queasy electronic psychedelia.

albums.title: Terra Incognita
albums.label: Emotional Rescue
albums.description: Drawing from two long-out-of-print compilations from the mid 1980s, this abridged reissue documents experiments in fusion—mixing post-punk, electronic, and fourth world—that sound both as strange and as relevant as ever.

albums.title: 1 Up Top Ahk
albums.label: Mozzy
albums.description: The prolific Sacramento rapper’s latest has that bass and funk-heavy production but is deeply haunted by death. It unfolds like the diary of a man haunted by a past he’s trying to outrun.

albums.title: Still Striving
albums.label: RCA
albums.description: Though he’s still got style on the mic, Ferg’s latest is a regression into the gleeful ignorance that colored his earlier work.

albums.title: Time Well
albums.label: Relapse
albums.description: Though longer and mellower, Cloakroom’s second album still has an anxious, open-ended feel. They take the appealing parts of a masculine pose without being wholly trapped by them.

albums.title: Songs From the Big Chair
albums.label: Mercury
albums.description: Tears for Fears’ second album is the one sound of pop-rock in the ’80s. Its personal psychology, meticulous compositions, and world-sized choruses evoked the loss of control in an overwhelming era.

albums.title: Link Wray
albums.label: Future Days
albums.description: In 1971, Link Wray reinvented himself and made one of the greatest roots rock albums ever, full of fuzz blasts, gnarled folk, and backwoods gospel. Rock’n’roll doesn’t get leaner or more primal.

albums.title: Warmth
albums.label: R & S
albums.description: On their first album in four years, Brooklyn’s Blondes hone in on more overt dancefloor energies while maintaining the dreamy introspection that is their signature.

albums.title: Policies of Power EP
albums.label: Lucky Number
albums.description: Samantha Urbani’s debut is alt-pop with style and nuance. She coats her sound with some retro ’80s accessories, but her real emotions remain grounded in the present.

albums.title: Althaea
albums.label: Double Six
albums.description: The London duo incorporate more varied and esoteric sounds to create an album of fun but flawed 1980s-inspired sophisti-pop.

albums.title: A Fever Dream
albums.label: RCA
albums.description: The Manchester band are attuned to the absurdity of our times. The hyperactive synthpop of their fourth LP is full of surreal vignettes evoking our increasingly nightmarish world.

albums.title: Living EP
albums.label: No World
albums.description: While fitting comfortably into their discography of slinky slow jams, Living finds the Los Angeles R&B duo unsure of how to connect to the vital essence of the genre.

albums.title: Across the Multiverse
albums.label: Carpark
albums.description: Like a crooner in outer space, Dent May makes glum sounds that sound happy, with old-fashioned panache. But the production of his latest collection is dense and muddled.

albums.title: Painted Ruins
albums.label: RCA
albums.description: The intricate compositions on the band’s fifth album are bound tighter than ever, evoking distant images and emotions that continually shift in and out of focus.

albums.title: b.
albums.label: Fool's Gold
albums.description: Brittany Bosco’s latest project elevates smooth R&B and Afrofuturism from off the streets of Atlanta with an emotional, bop-heavy set of songs.

albums.title: Come Over When You’re Sober (Part One)
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: On his debut album, the alternately waggish and sincere Lil Peep is bona fide rocker warping the edges of rap.

albums.title: Candy-O / Panorama
albums.label: Rhino
albums.description: Expanded reissues of the Cars’ second and third albums capture the group running like a well-oiled machine, both refining and expanding upon their tightly wound new wave.

albums.title: Pool Party
albums.label: EYRST
albums.description: The Portland party rapper’s debut album is darker and more introspective than his past work, with features from the Last Artful, Dodgr, Michael Christmas, and Blossom.

albums.title: Like a Prayer
albums.label: Sire
albums.description: Madonna’s spectacular fourth album revealed just how grand, artistic, and personal a pop star could be at the very height of her fame.

albums.title: Madonna
albums.label: Warner Bros.
albums.description: The driving force of Madonna’s debut remains its palpable physicality, born out of New York dance clubs, a new pop mandate to move your body in ways both public and private.

albums.title: Bedtime Stories
albums.label: Maverick
albums.description: Released in 1994, the warm and mellow sound of Madonna’s sixth album has its seductive charms, but of all her work, it remains a curious non-event in the pop star‘s wildly eventful career.

albums.title: Ray of Light
albums.label: Warner Bros.
albums.description: Channeling acid electronica, Kabbalah, and motherhood, Madonna’s 1998 reinvention stripped away the controversy of her past and became one of her most unexpectedly successful albums.

albums.title: AI YoungBoy
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: The teenage Baton Rouge rapper’s latest mixtape an intense and emotional collection about finding new power in freedom. His versatility and charisma are shaping a style that’s all his own.

albums.title: Verisimilitude
albums.label: Pi
albums.description: If the jazz and experimental drummer’s work in other bands often suggests an irrepressible mania, the goal with this trio seems to be delicate chaos.

albums.title: Safely Nobody’s
albums.label: Exploding in Sound
albums.description: As Tall Friend, the singer-songwriter Charlie Pfaff makes bare-bones indie rock that processes trauma and recovery. Their modest debut cloaks its hurt in warmth.

albums.title: Anthology Resource Vol. 1 △△
albums.label: Sacred Bones
albums.description: A collection of soundtrack cues from the third season of “Twin Peaks,” Anthology Resource Vol. 1 is most effective when it remains in the background, tugging at the edges of your subconscious.

albums.title: Last Chance
albums.label: Infinite Best
albums.description: House of Feelings make euphoric New York house music packed with modern anxieties. Their promising debut EP is intricate and elegant, featuring guest vocals from Shamir, Meredith Graves, and GABI.

albums.title: Bushwick (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)
albums.label: Lakeshore
albums.description: Much like his rhymes, Aesop Rock’s score for the action thriller Bushwick is packed with captivating detail; it’s an excellent fit for the film’s unrelenting intensity.

albums.title: Elastic
albums.label: Winspear
albums.description: The lo-fi bedroom pop that defined Indiana singer-songwriter Amy Oelsner’s early career grows much larger on her latest album. She uses new instrumentation to express old feelings of anger, longing, and fear.

albums.title: Good Time (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)
albums.label: Warp
albums.description: Daniel Lopatin accentuates the Safdie Brothers’ character studies with his hyper-real music. Instead of pursuing moments of trance-like calm or humor, here he metes out anxiety measure by measure.

albums.title: Tidal
albums.label: Sony
albums.description: Rare is a debut so fully formed and overflowing with music and emotion. Tidal grapples eloquently with loneliness, retribution, and the oceanic ups and downs of being young and being a woman.

albums.label: RCA
albums.description: A$AP Twelvyy’s long-awaited solo debut wears its love for New York City proudly but is plagued with inconsistencies.

albums.title: The Fickle Finger of Fate/A Walk With Love & Death
albums.label: Joyful Noise
albums.description: After over three decades of drumming in the Melvins, Dale Crover has released a muffled, scattershot solo album. It comes on the heels of a new record from the Melvins themselves.

albums.title: Popular Manipulations
albums.label: Fat Possum
albums.description: On their third full-length, Pennsylvania rock band the Districts dives headfirst into the earnest indie rock of the mid-2000s, displaying a new emotional depth.

albums.title: Boy in a Well
albums.label: Bloodshot
albums.description: With Tommy Stinson producing, Denver trio the Yawpers mix a high-brow literary streak with messy rock’n’roll on their third album. They cherrypick from punk, rockabilly, and the blues in the process.

albums.title: Rainbow
albums.label: RCA
albums.description: Kesha’s musical career has been defined by her work with Dr. Luke. On her third album, she begins something new and promising.

albums.title: How Do You Spell Heaven
albums.label: GBV
albums.description: On Guided by Voices’ latest, Robert Pollard sounds reenergized by a sobering sense of lucidity. Some of these songs rank among the most intimate and earthbound in the band’s bottomless canon.

albums.title: Onism
albums.label: Astro Nautico
albums.description: Working within a fairly heavy philosophical framework, New York’s Photay has made some of his most captivating electronic music yet, with nimble house and disco rhythms and real emotional weight.

albums.title: Bright Phoebus
albums.label: Domino
albums.description: Once considered too weird for the folk crowd and too pastoral for the rock crowd, this obscure 1972 masterpiece gets a long-overdue reissue—a testament to its creators’ faith, perseverance, and genius.

albums.title: Shitty Hits
albums.label: Ba Da Bing!
albums.description: The second album from the Maryland singer-songwriter is sharp and beguiling, carried by Katie Von Schleicher’s innate and economic pop instincts.

albums.title: who told you to think?​?​!​!​?​!​?​!​?​!
albums.label: Ruby Yacht
albums.description: milo is a sharp-tongued rapper whose wordplay rewards close listening. On his third and best LP, the Maine emcee carries the flag for the underground rap scene that birthed him.

albums.title: Cage Tropical
albums.label: Slumberland
albums.description: With subtle tweaks to her sound, Frankie Rose shows that her glossy, new wave style can be a way of cutting through the murk to find clarity.

albums.title: Tessellatum
albums.label: Bedroom Community
albums.description: Composed by Donnacha Dennehy and performed on viola by Nadia Sirota and viol de gamba by Liam Byrne, Tessellatum is an impressive, sweeping work whose 15 pieces seem to just peel off one another.

albums.title: S’WOMEN
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: Stas offers a sharp solo debut doused heartbreak, identity, and the familiar production touches of her former futurist rap and R&B duo THEESatisfaction.

albums.title: Cost of Living
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: On their latest LP, produced by Fugazi’s Guy Picciotto, Downtown Boys present their thundering political punk with a richer sound. Singer Victoria Ruiz presses deep into the poetics of confrontation.

albums.title: Yellow
albums.label: Captured Tracks
albums.description: Olympia punk trio Naomi Punk’s third album is a 75-minute, 25-track study in repetition. They’ve become more interested in deconstructing their songs than writing them.

albums.title: Soul of a Nation — Afro-Centric Visions in the Age of Black Power: Underground Jazz, Street Funk, & the Roots of Rap 1968-79
albums.label: Soul Jazz
albums.description: Soul Jazz Records’ companion to the Tate Modern’s exhibition of black art from the 1960s traces pivotal developments in funk, soul, jazz, and spoken word that still resonate through popular music today.

albums.title: Hamtramck ’16
albums.label: Arbutus
albums.description: Moon King’s Daniel Benjamin moves from shoegaze to disco on his latest release, but his version of the genre sounds too flat and tinny to survive on the dance floor.

albums.title: Fried Shallots EP
albums.label: Drag City
albums.description: The brief odds and sods charity EP from Ty Segall brings both the eternal comfort of his garage rock and the joy of something new and mellow.

albums.title: The Golden Mile EP
albums.label: Tag Out
albums.description: Inspired by Brooklyn’s current electronic scene and ’80s acid house, the New York trio applies a sophisticated sheen to analog-driven electro-pop.

albums.title: Boy Who Cried Wolf
albums.label: Alamo
albums.description: The Palm Beach rapper shows turn-up promise on his latest, but much of this project feels like it’s coasting on autopilot.

albums.title: 50,000,000 Elvis Fans Can’t Be Wrong
albums.label: Western Vinyl
albums.description: On this re-release of her 2014 cassette, the Austin-based songwriter Caroline Sallee offers homespun solo recordings that draw on C86, bossa nova, and soothing folk music.

albums.title: A Black Mile to the Surface
albums.label: Loma Vista
albums.description: Manchester Orchestra’s new album is their most confounding and thrilling work yet, with the most grandiose narrative concepts, production, and arrangements of their career.

albums.title: Refresher EP
albums.label: Planet Mu
albums.description: Moving away from the abstracted electronica of earlier releases, the Scottish producer embraces streamlined rhythms and a newfound sense of clarity.

albums.title: Dark Matter
albums.label: Nonesuch
albums.description: Dark Matter is Randy Newman’s first album of new songs in nine years and his smart mix of cynicism and sentiment is fully intact.

albums.title: Good Morning Spider
albums.label: Parlophone
albums.description: Mark Linkous’ second album as Sparklehorse shines an old light on impossible things. He found the purity of pop music and then lacerated it with the quirks and imperfections he cherished.

albums.title: Late Night Tales
albums.label: Night Time Stories Ltd.
albums.description: With their entry in the long-running mix series Late Night Tales, the Canadian band BADBADNOTGOOD offer an eclectic, uncompromising, and delightful “soundtrack for reflection and meditation.”

albums.title: Dead Cross
albums.label: Ipecac
albums.description: Though led by a fiery performance from Mike Patton, this Slayer/Retox/the Locust supergroup doesn’t shed much new light on the players involved.

albums.title: Collection
albums.label: Fat Possum
albums.description: The songwriter Sophie Allison has built a following with her Bandcamp bedroom recordings, but on this new record, she upgrades to a full band, giving her mournful songs a little extra drive.

albums.title: Sacred Horror in Design
albums.label: Opal Tapes
albums.description: The producer Sote makes mind-melting electronic music at the center of a vital scene in Tehran. On his latest record, he applies his customary digital processing to traditional Persian instruments.

albums.title: Call It Love
albums.label: Jagjaguwar
albums.description: Briana Marela’s third album of effervescent synth pop is her punchiest effort yet, full of songs that portray the anxiety of falling in and out of love.

albums.title: Nervous System EP
albums.label: Republic
albums.description: After penning hits for Selena Gomez and Hailee Steinfeld, Julia Michaels brings her chart-topping songwriter chops to her solo career. The songs are refreshingly unique but their impact is varied.

albums.title: Content
albums.label: Hollywood
albums.description: The second album from the synth-pop group finds them getting anxious about their own ambition, a feeling that doesn't always gracefully adapt to the dance floor.

albums.title: Threshold of Faith EP
albums.label: Mute
albums.description: Assisted by Steve Albini, the Australian-born, Iceland-based electronic musician summons a gargantuan, apocalyptic din—one that is occasionally tripped up by its own bombast.

albums.title: Contempt
albums.label: Gilead Media
albums.description: On their second album, the abrasive New York band Couch Slut draw on hardcore, grindcore, and metal while offering unflinching lyrics about violence and terror.

albums.title: Verse
albums.label: Topshelf
albums.description: The second LP from People Like You is a fusion of jazz musicianship, emo spirit, and indie-pop tunefulness. It’s a mix so coherent that even the ugly parts are beautiful in their precision.

albums.title: Here Come the Warm Jets / Taking Tiger Mountain (By Strategy) / Before and After Science
albums.label: Virgin EMI
albums.description: Brian Eno’s run of rock albums in the ’70s was an unprecedented achievement in music built on aleatory synth settings, fiery guitar work, subconscious lyrics, and of course, Oblique Strategies.

albums.title: Tchornobog
albums.label: Fallen Empire
albums.description: On the ambitious new album from Ukrainian metal prodigy Markov Soroka, songs boil in their own misery. His dismal riffs and atmospheres bubble over until there’s nothing left but smoke.

albums.title: Perfect Timing
albums.label: Boominati Worldwide
albums.description: After signing to the Weeknd’s label XO, Toronto rapper-producer Navraj Goraya is releasing a full-length collaboration with Atlanta producer Metro Boomin. He sounds as lyrically hollow as ever.

albums.title: fantasii
albums.label: Halcyon Veil
albums.description: Positioning their alter ego Mhysa as a queer black underground pop star for the cyber resistance, the multimedia artist E. Jane constructs an elaborate alternate universe out of experimental club rhythms.

albums.title: Golden
albums.label: Sony
albums.description: The Bronx-born pop star expands his musical empire on Golden. But for the all the album’s myriad sounds, its roots are firmly planted in bachata, the sounds of the campo.

albums.title: The Elements
albums.label: Concord Music Group
albums.description: Alice Coltrane teamed with Joe Henderson for this 1973 jazz classic, an album where each member’s playing is in service of a single, cosmic statement of music.

albums.title: What Do You Think About the Car?
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: The 18-year-old UK singer-songwriter Declan McKenna has been called a voice of his generation. His major label debut is scattershot, though it includes a Rostam-helmed standout.

albums.title: Sounds from the Other Side
albums.label: Starboy
albums.description: Emerging as a pop star from Nigeria’s Afrobeats scene, WizKid’s stateside debut is a potent crossover album that blends pop, R&B, dancehall and features Drake, Trey Songz, Ty Dolla $ign and more.

albums.title: La Torre Ibiza — Volumen Dos
albums.label: Hostel La Torre
albums.description: Two veteran selectors propose an ideal soundtrack for sunset on Ibiza, drawing from Japanese electro-pop, soundtrack classics, and recent productions with a Balearic mindset.

albums.title: Good for You
albums.label: CLBN
albums.description: The Portland rapper’s debut album balances playful verses and cheerful wit with more revealing moments of introspection.

albums.title: Ceilings
albums.label: Styles Upon Styles
albums.description: Stepping out from her futuristic soul duo with Sene, Denitia’s electro-pop Ceilings is her most fully formed solo effort so far.

albums.title: Lack
albums.label: Pan
albums.description: Using voice and synthesizer, the Shanghai-born, Berlin-based artist channels operatic tropes and controlled explosions of noise into visceral and cathartic forms.

albums.title: The Autobiography
albums.label: Roc Nation
albums.description: The Chicago rapper’s first milestone is a careful step in his legacy-building business. It's an obvious turn inward, but Vic also digs his heels into his political ground.

albums.title: The Outsiders EP
albums.label: Magicwire
albums.description: With the crackling sounds of “lo-fi house” achieving autoplay ubiquity in the dance music corners of YouTube, one of the micro-genre’s progenitors runs up against the style’s limits.

albums.title: American Water
albums.label: Drag City
albums.description: In 1998, David Berman approached perfection. Absorbed in metaphor, ennui, and isolation, the loping music of American Water didn’t seem like it was trying to be art. It just was.
