albums.title: Sudan Archives
albums.label: Stones Throw
albums.description: The Los Angeles-based singer and violinist blends avant-garde experimentalism with the swagger-drenched posturing of club rap, ’90s R&B grooves, and biting introspection.

albums.title: Riding the Thin Line EP
albums.label: Anotherday
albums.description: A fundamental EP from the Detroit techno titan gets reissued 18 years after its release; aimed squarely at the dancefloor, its three cuts are by turns gooey, steely, and strange.

albums.title: Patterns for Resonant Space
albums.label: Youngbloods
albums.description: This avant-garde trio use piano, samples, and carefully skewered tapes to conjure an evocative sense of place. They drift to exquisite effect.

albums.title: New Facts Emerge
albums.label: Cherry Red
albums.description: Mark E. Smith’s meaty, swollen approach to garage rock may bristle fans of his early work, but the album’s little touches and turns makes this more than an average release for a legacy band.

albums.title: Greenspan and Taraval EP
albums.label: Geej
albums.description: Jeremy Greenspan and Ryan Smith’s hardware experiment EP is fundamentally a dance album, but the intelligent tracks skew more subtle and heady than their solo work.

albums.title: Everything Now
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: The Montreal band’s fifth album finds them in musical and lyrical stasis. The pale, joyless songs don’t transcend their social critique, they succumb to it.

albums.title: Rotations
albums.label: Thrill Jockey
albums.description: The Portland duo Golden Retriever have created their own musical language using bass clarinet and a modular synth rig. Rotations expands their sound, adding 10 classical musicians to the mix.

albums.title: Hate Songs EP
albums.label: LuckyMe
albums.description: Stepping away from his habitual trap beats and claustrophobic atmospheres, the New Orleans producer goes in search of wide-open vistas and melancholy maximalism.

albums.title: LoveJoys
albums.label: Small Press
albums.description: The second album from Seattle soul-rock quintet Pickwick finds the band with a renewed sense of harmony. But some songs make you wonder if it would have benefitted from more discord.

albums.title: Habit EP
albums.label: Sister Polygon
albums.description: The newly reissued six-song EP from the Maryland indie-pop band wallows in uncertainty and transition—but their songwriting makes it feel both adolescent and eternal.

albums.title: Strange Days
albums.label: Numbers
albums.description: This new release from Italian producer Lory D compiles and digitizes five recent EPs, previously only available on vinyl. It’s a behemoth document of organic, shapeshifting techno.

albums.title: Wins and Losses
albums.label: Maybach Music Group
albums.description: After freeing himself from the feuds and narrative that dragged him down, Meek Mill’s third studio album is a comeback by any measure, honest and gripping.

albums.title: Índia
albums.label: Mr. Bongo
albums.description: With 1973’s Índia, the samba singer Gal Costa cemented her status as one of Brazil’s biggest and most defiant stars, collaborating with Caetano Veloso and Gilberto Gil in the process.

albums.title: Add Violence EP
albums.label: The Null Corporation
albums.description: Nine Inch Nails’ second EP in a year is as perplexing and immediate as their first. Trent Reznor has lost none of his power to discomfit and intimidate.

albums.title: Hip Mobility
albums.label: Butterscotch
albums.description: Constructed around archival NASA recordings, the latest from Wilco’s Mikael Jorgensen’s features meticulous, pop-molded instrumentals that feel just a little incomplete without a vocal narrative.

albums.title: Moonshine Freeze
albums.label: Rough Trade
albums.description: With her new record as This Is the Kit, singer-songwriter Kate Stables offers a collection of sparse folk that takes on the mysteries of mortality with a wizened sigh.

albums.title: Eucalyptus
albums.label: Domino
albums.description: Dave Porter’s latest album as Avey Tare is ambitious and inspiring. His painful, deeply personal, and intimate songs never are in constant search for new sounds and emotions.

albums.title: Lust for Life
albums.label: Interscope
albums.description: The fourth full-length from Lana Del Rey is sincere, sublime and beautiful. As personal as it is impressionistic, Lust for Life is the emergence of a great American storyteller.

albums.title: Bedouine
albums.label: Spacebomb
albums.description: The soulful debut from Syrian-born Azniv Korkejian showcases the depth of her songwriting and uses Spacebomb’s retro sound to create an exquisite, subtle, and wide-eyed collection of songs.

albums.title: Pariah
albums.label: Objects Limited
albums.description: Twenty years into her career, after a hiatus of more than a decade, the Chicago footwork producer finally releases her debut album, taking apart her hometown’s club genres and recombining them in captivatingly original ways.

albums.title: Sacred Hearts Club
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: Mark Foster enlists more beat-filled haze for his third album, a tuneful but confounding modern pop event that lands somewhere between the Beach Boys and Just Blaze.

albums.title: Sunday Songs
albums.label: First Terrace
albums.description: The composer Peter Broderick assembles a 35-strong choir of professional and amateur singers, and the results are like a secular church service: rough around the edges, punctuated with laughter, and joyous.

albums.title: Fabriclive 93
albums.label: Fabric
albums.description: In his first Fabric mix under his Daphni alias, Caribou’s Dan Snaith zigzags his way through an eclectic set of edits and original productions.

albums.title: Full Flower
albums.label: Topshelf
albums.description: The Baltimore band’s full-length debut uses slowcore not just as a variant of indie rock, but also a framework to make real-deal pop songs that make boredom sound utterly desirable.

albums.title: Dots and Loops
albums.label: Duophonic
albums.description: Stereolab’s masterpiece fused analog with digital, past with future, Marxism with the commercial magic of music through a pristine record that defined an age of “recombinant pop.”

albums.title: Leave Home
albums.label: Rhino
albums.description: This 40th anniversary three-disc reissue of the second Ramones album is littered with alternate mixes, all attempting to achieve a precise balance of muscle and effervescence.

albums.title: Pagan Day / Allegory and Self
albums.label: Sacred Bones
albums.description: With post-Throbbing Gristle outfit Psychic TV, Genesis P-Orridge bent together the opposing poles of psychedelia and industrial music. Two new reissues show the extremities of their early catalog.

albums.title: Square One
albums.label: Smalltown Supersound
albums.description: The Scandinavian disco luminaries join for an album that draws on space rock, dub, leftfield disco, and post-punk, made more for the mind than the dancefloor.

albums.title: Lo Tom
albums.label: Barsuk
albums.description: For his latest LP, Pedro the Lion’s David Bazan formed a new band and returned to straight-ahead guitar rock. It’s got some of his most aerodynamic songs in over a decade, but suffers from redundancy.

albums.title: Dead Saints Chronicles
albums.label: Marionette
albums.description: The German electronic musician explores deep, fluid percussive grooves in the same vein as his work with the late drummer Jaki Liebezeit.

albums.title: Raskit
albums.label: Dirtee Stank
albums.description: With the grime revival in full swing, one of the genre’s elder statesmen returns with an album that’s torn between his UK roots and his affinity for American hip-hop.

albums.title: Flower Boy
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: On Tyler’s sincere and most accomplished album, he gets to the essence of what he's been chiseling at: the angst of a missed connection, the pain of unrequited love, and navigating youthful ennui.

albums.title: Several Shades of the Same Color
albums.label: Spectral Sound
albums.description: The Brooklyn producer Max Ravitz makes homespun techno with lush pads, errant noise, and intricate rhythms. His latest LP offers variations on the sound made with a limited palette.

albums.title: Mellow Waves
albums.label: Rostrum
albums.description: Returning to his long-running solo act, the Japanese producer Keigo Oyamada aims for the glowing emotional core of his playful, retro-futuristic aesthetic.

albums.title: One Night Only
albums.label: RCA
albums.description: On his major label debut, the once-scrappy Boston rapper Cousin Stizz flaunts his wealth as well as his ear for distinctive, minimalist production.

albums.title: Sounds of Crenshaw, Vol. 1
albums.label: Ropeadope
albums.description: After handling production for Kendrick Lamar, Terrace Martin’s work as a bandleader comes into focus with quiet storm, R&B, and deep grooves that show the composer and instrumentalist making strides.

albums.title: Solid Rain
albums.label: Semiotext(e)
albums.description: The eclectic new album from L.A. indie outfit Holy Shit is also the first musical offering from Semiotext(e), the publishing house run in part by I Love Dick author Chris Kraus.

albums.title: Jean​-​Jacques Perrey et son Ondioline
albums.label: Forgotten Futures
albums.description: In a collection of unreleased and rarely heard recordings, the French electronic music pioneer displays his mastery of an early proto-synthesizer.

albums.title: Blast Off Through the Wicker
albums.label: Western Vinyl
albums.description: Here We Go Magic frontman Luke Temple’s new project is his most cohesive yet. As Art Feynman, he emerges as a cool purveyor of dub-kraut.

albums.title: EP #260
albums.label: Sacred Bones
albums.description: With his band SQÜRL, the legendary filmmaker Jim Jarmusch makes drone-oriented music that’s more about texture than motion. Their latest EP is uniquely physical.

albums.title: Jungle Rules
albums.label: Bad Boy / Epic
albums.description: With features from Future, Quavo, Young Thug, and T.I., French Montana returns newly motivated with his sophomore album, which acts as a funnel for everyone’s strongest qualities but his own.

albums.title: Infinity Ultra
albums.label: Planet Mu
albums.description: With songs that travel great distances between the poles of ambient and noise music, Claude Speeed’s latest is a mercurial set, capturing with great skill a kind of restless, sourceless anxiety.

albums.title: Mura Masa
albums.label: Anchor Point
albums.description: Alex Crossan’s debut album is a love letter to multicultural London that’s informed by the 21-year-old musician’s insular upbringing and abetted by a number of high-profile guests.

albums.title: Soft Sounds From Another Planet
albums.label: Dead Oceans
albums.description: Inspired by the cosmos, Japanese Breakfast’s Michelle Zauner addresses life on Earth. Her voice shines over melancholic arrangements, evoking Pacific Northwest indie rock as much as shoegaze.

albums.title: Deep Marble Sunrise
albums.label: Wharf Cat
albums.description: Featuring members of Merchandise, the Ukiah Drag, and Uniform, these psych jams evoke a prog-inflected, Madchester-soaked record. They are unafraid to throw in any sound just to watch it whirl around.

albums.title: Kaleidoscope EP
albums.label: Parlophone
albums.description: Held up by two good-to-great songs, the lightweight EP is Coldplay’s first release in years that feels more like a clearing of the throat than a new, distinct statement.

albums.title: Raft
albums.label: Room40
albums.description: A long way from his 1970s folk-rock roots, the veteran guitarist travels far beyond the limits of genre, fusing pedal steel with ambient glitches and piercing insect sounds.

albums.title: God First
albums.label: Island
albums.description: Bombay Bicycle Club frontman Jack Steadman taps Charles Bradley, De La Soul, Horace Andy, and more for a crate-digging, sampledelic record that feels safe compared to the risks he took with his band.

albums.title: Sodium
albums.label: Jagjaguwar
albums.description: Led by drummer and lead singer Kylee Kimbrough, the noise-punk outfit Dasher deliver a murderous mix of garage-rock grime, fuzz-punk overdrive, and black-metal-schooled howls.

albums.title: The Album
albums.label: Apollo
albums.description: On his deeply expressive debut album, the electronic artist SW. refuses to adhere to any one style, covering atmospheric drum ‘n’ bass, deep house, lush techno-jazz, peak-time floor-fillers, and more.

albums.title: Appetite for Destruction
albums.label: Geffen
albums.description: The debut from Guns N' Roses was a watershed moment in '80s rock that chronicled every vice of Los Angeles led by the lye-voiced Axl Rose and a legendary, switchblade-sharp band.

albums.title: Need to Feel Your Love
albums.label: Wilsuns RC
albums.description: On their debut LP, Sheer Mag keep biting at the forbidden fruit of 1970s hard rock. They dance the line between proto-metal and power pop on songs about romantic obsession and societal oppression.

albums.title: Howling, for the Nightmare Shall Consume
albums.label: Relapse
albums.description: Modern hardcore legends offered definitive proof of their staying power as our apocalyptic poet laureates on their latest, a demonic and harsh concept album about Armageddon.

albums.title: Fly / Approximately Infinite Universe / Feeling the Space
albums.label: Chimera
albums.description: On three albums released from 1971 to 1973, Yoko Ono subverted pop forms and widened her vision, which at once grew more accessible and more explicitly feminist.

albums.title: Quazarz: Born on a Gangster Star / Quazarz vs. The Jealous Machines
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: Ishmael Butler’s free-form hip-hop project continues to defy convention with a pair of companion albums that view contemporary America as though it were a strange and hostile planet.

albums.title: The Mountain Has Fallen EP
albums.label: Mass Appeal
albums.description: In a follow-up EP to last year’s The Mountain Will Fall, Shadow bucks expectations and finds inspiration in unlikely collabs with Nas and Danny Brown.

albums.title: Dear
albums.label: Sargent House
albums.description: On Dear, the Japanese trio Boris hone in on their most essential quality—the ability to wrest subtlety from thick layers of distortion and amplifier volume.

albums.title: Out in the Storm
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: Katie Crutchfield’s fourth album features sharp, gorgeous songwriting. The polished production and urgent performances ensure her fiery exorcisms about the end of a relationship are deeply felt.

albums.title: Lifetime of Love
albums.label: Geographic North
albums.description: Using samples from thrift store LPs and dollar bins, Deerhunter drummer Moses John Archuleta crafted a diffuse solo effort where sweet melodies gleam from beneath grimy noise.

albums.title: Plastic Cough
albums.label: Double Double Whammy
albums.description: Led by Alex Menne, the Seattle band comes out with a solid debut of anxious bubblegum grunge, though its many charms also become its few flaws.

albums.title: Issa Album
albums.label: Slaughter Gang
albums.description: The ambitious debut from 21 Savage features some of the best producers around, but the young rapper doesn't have the finesse to break out beyond his horror-film style.

albums.title: Ex Eye
albums.label: Relapse
albums.description: This new quartet, which features the sax playing of Colin Stetson and drumming of Greg Fox, turns the crossroads of metal and jazz into a righteous, ecstatic fusion.

albums.title: Nothing Is Quick in the Desert
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: Though fully charged with political fervor and booming metallic beats, Chuck D and Flavor Flav’s incomparable lack of subtlety make this another clumsy late-career outing.

albums.title: Bells for the South Side
albums.label: ECM
albums.description: Recorded live at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago, the avant-garde saxophonist offers two hours of uncompromising experimentalism that’s been developed and sharpened to an atomically-fine point.

albums.title: Boo Boo
albums.label: Carpark
albums.description: Toro Y Moi’s Chaz Bear sounds increasingly comfortable as a lead vocalist and personality on his most personal album to date, as a still-funky but more ambient side of his writing emerges.

albums.title: Chronology
albums.label: Virgin
albums.description: In a genre known for singles, Kingston’s Jamar McNaughton offers a complete collection of hits, a confident mix of conscious reggae, pop, hip-hop, and lovers rock.

albums.title: Nídia é Má, Nídia é Fudida
albums.label: Príncipe Discos
albums.description: With her own strain of batida music, the Portuguese-born, Bordeaux-bred producer Nídia offers a debut album of mind-bending complexity.

albums.title: Dribble EP
albums.label: Visions Fugitives
albums.description: The Catalan producer Sau Poler puts an elegantly Iberian slant on house music. His euphoric new EP may be inspired by soccer, but it’s made for dancing on beaches in summertime.

albums.title: Hug of Thunder
albums.label: Arts & Crafts
albums.description: On their first album in seven years, Broken Social Scene distill their sound to a vital essence. The band is focused and renewed, invigorated by the missionary spirit of their best work.

albums.title: Teething
albums.label: I Oh You
albums.description: Australian drummer Alex Knight’s dry, beautiful debut pushes beyond ’90s indie rock trappings and into rougher, textured, more interesting terrain.

albums.title: Like a Woman
albums.label: G.O.O.D. Music
albums.description: The G.O.O.D. Music signee sets out to explore desire and sexuality, but her downcast songs rarely venture much past mood lighting.

albums.title: White Halo
albums.label: Translation Loss
albums.description: With their latest album, the Japanese band Heaven in Her Arms prove there’s still life in post-metal. They take a textured attack, mixing guitar guitar shimmer and aggression.

albums.title: Metallica
albums.label: Elektra
albums.description: After years of wild thrash metal, Metallica simplified everything and became the biggest rock band in the world. The Black Album’s dark, muscular sound would permanently alter the course heavy music.

albums.title: Grateful
albums.label: Epic
albums.description: The Snapchat icon’s 10th album is ostensibly an ode to the joys of fatherhood, but its A-list features and slick surfaces are the polar opposite of warm and fuzzy.

albums.title: Anguilla Electrica
albums.label: Tresor
albums.description: The dub techno duo’s first new record since 1999 is a submerged wonder. Its stirring, bold elements steer the tracks into murky, unexpected places.

albums.title: Poiemusia La Nau Dels Argonautes
albums.label: Freedom to Spend
albums.description: Long sought after by collectors, the Spanish composer’s 1987 album of minimalism, period electronics, folk melodies, and chanted Catalan poetry is another gem in Freedom to Spend’s reissue series.

albums.title: Reject on Steroids
albums.label: Shady
albums.description: On his new mixtape, the Buffalo rapper Conway spits clearly enunciated, precisely worded bars, but it often feels like he’s holding something back.

albums.title: Woodstock
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: The Alaska psych-pop group have embraced modern-rock glitz and EDM bombast, while trying to write an album that speaks to the times. But their attempts at topicality are clumsy.

albums.title: Man of the World
albums.label: Glassnote
albums.description: The latest solo album from Vampire Weekend’s Chris Baio was inspired by Bowie, Brexit, Trump, and climate change, but his synth pop sound doesn’t match those high stakes.

albums.title: Funk Wav Bounces Vol. 1
albums.label: Sony
albums.description: Rebranding himself as a kind of everyman Mark Ronson, the EDM superstar steps out from behind the booth with an album of 1980s-inspired boogie.

albums.title: Something to Tell You
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: Haim’s glossy second album is slyly complex. The California sisters remain masters of rhythm and create spacious, hook-filled pop-rock full of heartbreak, longing, and betrayal.

albums.title: TLC
albums.label: 852 Musiq
albums.description: With the final TLC album, Chilli and T-Boz have crafted a conscious epilogue to their catalog and a love letter to their fans. It hits every style in their vast range and dignifies their career.

albums.title: B-Sides and Rarities
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: The collected footnotes from the Baltimore band's decade-long career plays almost as smoothly as a proper album, showing the meticulous  construction behind some of Beach House’s spells.

albums.title: Fabric 94
albums.label: Fabric
albums.description: The Berlin-based DJ’s first official mix in four years sounds new and vital even when steeped in retro sounds. Her encyclopedic taste and smooth, linear style of mixing defines the shape of the set.

albums.title: Wintres Woma
albums.label: Paradise of Bachelors
albums.description: On his debut solo album, the guitarist James Elkington—a sideman for Jeff Tweedy and Richard Thompson—reemerges with an elegant and assured collection of acoustic fingerpicking and smart songwriting.

albums.title: Instrumental Mixtape 4
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: The latest in Mike Volpe’s series of boutique beats and remixes shows the producer in a new light. It sounds top-shelf, produced and engineered with a meticulousness that puts the new kids to shame.

albums.title: GT Ultra
albums.label: DFA
albums.description: On their latest, this Brooklyn dance-noise quintet finds crazy colors while tearing loose from the axis.

albums.title: Ruinism
albums.label: Brainfeeder
albums.description: Stuart Howard’s third album veers off into the abstract, somewhere between a classical and post-electro mindset. Its many guests are never spotlit and yet its textures never lack a human soul.

albums.label: Roc Nation
albums.description: The most crafty and evasive MC lays bare his complicated life. This late-career gem is soulful and diamond-sharp, confronting the failings and legacy of Shawn Carter and America.

albums.title: Here, My Dear
albums.label: Tamla
albums.description: What was supposed to be a kiss-off alimony payment to his ex-wife shape-shifted into a towering ode to divorce. The maligned and complicated double-LP remains a candid soul confessional.

albums.title: The Underside of Power
albums.label: Matador
albums.description: Gospel, punk, and noise fuse together for Algiers’ ambitious and chaotic second album. The songs burn with anger and grief, but lack cohesion to get the message across.

albums.title: Psychic Drift
albums.label: The Flenser
albums.description: With heavy electronic textures, Brooklyn noise trio White Suns add a fresh wrinkle to their catalog on the vertiginous Psychic Drift.

albums.title: Bill Orcutt
albums.label: Palilalia
albums.description: The noise of Bill Orcutt’s acoustic guitar days is dialed back on his latest album. It features shimmering solo electric guitar that charts new sounds for one of music’s premiere abstractionists.

albums.title: 1967 - Sunshine Tomorrow
albums.label: Capitol
albums.description: A remarkable new set of 1967 recordings captures the Beach Boys as they grew into a more democratic band. They sound at once chaotic and relaxed, naive and sophisticated, pop-oriented and intimate.

albums.title: Ennanga Vision
albums.label: Soundway
albums.description: Electronic beats and dub effects put a heady, psychedelic spin on traditional Ugandan Royal Court music.

albums.title: Vulture
albums.label: Good Cheer
albums.description: With his scrappy indie rock project Turtlenecked, Harrison Smith pens witty lyrics that riff on social media and scene politics. But his second album is often insufferable.

albums.title: May God Bless Your Hustle
albums.label: 10k
albums.description: The new 18-year-old New York rapper carves a unique path of searing lyricism through back-alley soul-sampling beats. He examines his youth with an ancient coolness and preternatural technique.

albums.title: Moonlight (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack)
albums.label: Lakeshore
albums.description: For the ravishing Moonlight, Nicholas Britell composed a score that splits the difference between classical and codeine. It’s orchestral music, chopped and screwed. There’s beauty in its glacial pace.

albums.title: Mister Mellow
albums.label: Stones Throw
albums.description: The latest from chillwave pioneer Ernest Greene, aka Washed Out, is a visual album for Stones Throw Records. But it doesn’t say anything new about Washed Out.

albums.title: Cracked Actor (Live Los Angeles ’74)
albums.label: Parlophone
albums.description: This live album is culled from a show late in David’s Bowie’s 1974 tour. It’s heavy on material from Diamond Dogs and Aladdin Sane and finds a drug-addled Bowie in a moment of transition.

albums.title: Murder of the Universe
albums.label: ATO
albums.description: Australia’s King Gizzard have become one of indie rock’s most unlikely and glorious crossover stories of late. Their second album of 2017 pushes towards new levels of raucousness and ridiculousness.

albums.title: Which Way Iz West
albums.label: Year Round
albums.description: On his first album in 11 years, Compton rap veteran MC Eiht’s no-frills approach hasn’t changed one bit. Executive produced by DJ Premier, the record is a who’s who of 1990s rap.

albums.title: Colter Wall
albums.label: Young Mary's
albums.description: Colter Wall is one of country music’s most exciting young voices. His debut album is strange and stirring, rarely ever rising above a gentle rumble.

albums.title: Dust
albums.label: Hyperdub
albums.description: On her third album for Hyperdub, Laurel Halo continues to resist classification and deflect interpretation by treating the human voice like a synthetic material to be molded and shattered.

albums.title: Reflections - Mojave Desert
albums.label: Luaka Bop
albums.description: Sam Shepherd and his ensemble incorporate the vast, rocky landscape of the California desert into the very fabric of their ambient post-rock.

albums.title: Tropisch Verlangen
albums.label: Stroom
albums.description: This collection of new age, which gathers tracks from a series of tapes originally issued in the 1980s, shows how instrumental textures from around the globe met early electronics.

albums.title: Together at Last
albums.label: dBpm
albums.description: Armed only with his acoustic guitar, Wilco frontman Jeff Tweedy offers stripped-down versions of songs pulled from across his catalog, including songs originally cut with Loose Fur and Golden Smog.

albums.title: On the Echoing Green
albums.label: Mexican Summer
albums.description: The ambient noise artist Jefre Cantu-Ledesma moves towards shoegaze on his beautiful new record, which engenders a feeling of pure optimism.

albums.title: Precious Art
albums.label: SideOneDummy
albums.description: The West Virginia band Rozwell Kid play power pop with a potentially divisive sense of humor, but their latest album is full of pleasingly straightforward hooks.

albums.title: Hamburg Recordings 1967
albums.label: Third Man
albums.description: The sole LP from short-lived Hamburg garage band the Monks now ranks in the upper echelon of 1960s gems. This new set pulls together 15 minutes’ worth of odds and ends recorded during their final year.

albums.title: Fake Sugar
albums.label: Virgin
albums.description: The debut solo album from Beth Ditto finds the former Gossip singer reconnecting with her southern roots. Despite some thin lyrics and odd production choices, it has a few excellent moments.

albums.title: Purple Rain Deluxe — Expanded Edition
albums.label: Warner Bros.
albums.description: In 1984, Purple Rain turned Prince into a global superstar, and the 3xCD remaster of the canonical record adds an entire disc of previously unreleased music cut during the same period.

albums.title: Blight Upon Martyred Sentience
albums.label: Profound Lore
albums.description: Australia’s Impetuous Ritual take death metal to its outermost limits, with guitars that blossom and decay. On their latest, they progress by getting even more extreme.

albums.title: ...Of the Dark Light
albums.label: Nuclear Blast
albums.description: Long Island death metal stalwarts bring considerable technical aptitude to an album that works within the framework of their long-established sound.

albums.title: Rembo
albums.label: Don't Be Afraid
albums.description: In an album of studio recordings informed by her partly improvised live hardware sets, the UK-based techno musician balances dance-floor functionalism with wild idiosyncrasy.

albums.title: Tres Hombres
albums.label: London
albums.description: ZZ Top’s 1973 breakthrough was a masterful melding of  complementary styles, cramming Southern rock and blues boogie through the band’s own idiosyncratic filter.

albums.title: 13 Thirteen
albums.label: Erstwhile
albums.description: On this two-and-a-half hour, semi-improvised opus, the two guitarists and composers approach finely wrought detail and vast empty space in ways that can warp one's perception of time itself.

albums.title: SATURATION
albums.label: EMPIRE
albums.description: The Los Angeles rap collective espouses an all-caps message of self-love on a debut album split between effortless cool and empty platitudes.

albums.title: Not Two
albums.label: New Amsterdam
albums.description: Trumpeter Amir ElSaffar is after a trance-like state of ecstasy on the new release from his chamber orchestra group Rivers of Sound, which boasts some of contemporary jazz’s most powerful soloists.

albums.title: Iteration
albums.label: Ghostly International
albums.description: As Com Truise, the producer Seth Haley works within an especially constrained 1980s aesthetic. But he pushes himself towards a higher level of sophistication on his new LP.

albums.title: Smiley Face
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: The Sunny Day in Glasgow affiliate steps out with an album of unconventional indie pop that’s brimming with potential.

albums.title: Big Fish Theory
albums.label: Blacksmith
albums.description: On his second album, Vince Staples teams with producers like SOPHIE, Jimmy Edgar, and Flume on a collection of sleek club-rap bangers. But his eye for detail and observational skills remain intact.

albums.title: H.E.R. Vol. 2 EP
albums.label: RCA
albums.description: On the sultry new EP from anonymous R&B singer H.E.R., mystery lends itself to relatability.

albums.title: A Place I’ll Always Go
albums.label: Polyvinyl
albums.description: On her second album, Boston singer-songwriter Ellen Kempner constructs affecting narratives filled with grief and hope.

albums.title: Shadow Expert EP
albums.label: Carpark
albums.description: The serrated new EP from rawboned Philadelphia art rock band Palm is their best work to date, full of tensions that boil over and careen.

albums.title: So You Wannabe an Outlaw
albums.label: Warner Bros.
albums.description: Steve Earle’s excellent new album marks a much-welcomed return to country music. He sounds more energized and powerful than he has in years.

albums.title: OK Computer OKNOTOK 1997 2017
albums.label: XL
albums.description: Twenty years on, Radiohead revisit their 1997 masterpiece with a deluxe reissue. The bonus material includes familiar B-sides and a few previously unheard recordings that hint at an intriguing road not taken.

albums.title: AFTER...
albums.label: KingBrittArchives
albums.description: On the latest from his sci-fi-leaning project Fhloston Paradigm, the renowned Philadelphia producer King Britt shows a more vulnerable side, collaborating with Moor Mother, Nosaj Thing, and others.

albums.title: Subtle Vertigo
albums.label: International Feel
albums.description: The California producer’s second release is a chill, whimsical listen whose Balearic compositions are filled with jazzy guitar, vintage synths, and reveal themselves to be surprisingly complex.

albums.title: “Abysmal Thoughts”
albums.label: Anti-
albums.description: The Drums continue to perfect their 1980s-inspired indie pop formula on their latest album, while adding some dark humor to the mix.

albums.title: Chasing an Illusion
albums.label: Northern Spy
albums.description: Sorrowful lyrics against spirited playing create a magical crux on the experimental singer-songwriter’s latest, a powerfully maternal and spiritually yearning collection of dark folk music.

albums.title: City Music
albums.label: Dead Oceans
albums.description: Kevin Morby’s captivating fourth album feels spacious and intimate at once. It possesses an elegant, dusky atmosphere and Morby’s hopelessly optimistic songwriting is the best it has ever been.

albums.title: The Fifth State of Consciousness
albums.label: Two Flowers
albums.description: On their latest album, Peaking Lights’ dreamy mix of dub, new wave, and disco is emboldened by Indra Dunis’ simple, repetitive verses.

albums.title: Beautiful Thugger Girls
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: Everything about Young Thug remains inimitable. He steeps himself in smooth R&B guitars on his latest, distilling the chaos of young love and lust into vital, undeniable pop.

albums.title: Hudson
albums.label: Motéma
albums.description: The new ensemble from vanguard jazz drummer Jack DeJohnette has been called a supergroup. Their debut draws on the cultural legacy of Upstate New York, with takes on Dylan, Hendrix, and Joni Mitchell.

albums.title: OUÏ
albums.label: Because Music
albums.description: The Parisian pop experimentalist Camille sounds awed by language as a brilliant, living thing on her latest album. Inspired by the psychedelia of motherhood, she doubles down on her sharp playfulness.

albums.title: Witness
albums.label: ATO
albums.description: On his new album, the New Orleans-based Benjamin Booker makes retro music feel modern, reflecting on racism in America while drawing on blues, soul, and gospel.

albums.title: Weather Diaries
albums.label: Wichita
albums.description: Ride’s reunion album is the British group’s first since returning to stages in 2015. It’s promising but never quite satisfying, with modern production touches courtesy of DJ Erol Alkan.

albums.title: Boomiverse
albums.label: Epic
albums.description: Big Boi returns with a collection of shiny bangers unbothered with modern trends. With Killer Mike, Snoop Dogg, Organized Noize, everyone here sounds a little out of touch and just fantastic.

albums.title: House and Land
albums.label: Thrill Jockey
albums.description: House and Land is the new collaboration of Asheville guitarist Sarah Louise with fiddle player Sally Anne Morgan. The tension between new and old, between folk and avant-garde, is its driving force.

albums.title: The Writing’s on the Wall
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: Beyond its tabloid drama, the innovation of Destiny Child’s second album codified the sound of R&B at the turn of the millennium. It is stilletto-sharp, and laid the groundwork for Beyoncé's career.

albums.title: The Nashville Sound
albums.label: Southeastern
albums.description: His new album with the 400 Unit feels a little one-note, but Jason Isbell can still rouse with an anthem show off his gritty country and even breezy pop skills.

albums.title: Symbolic Use of Light
albums.label: Technicolour
albums.description: The Kansas-bred, New York-based DJ has been stripping techno to its essentials. Yet Emma Olson’s latest contains so much to admire, each track is a glimpse into something much larger.

albums.title: Can — The Singles
albums.label: Mute
albums.description: For a band whose legacy rests on the restless sprawls of their catalog, Can could also turn improvised uncut cloth into something stunningly concise. This new comp shows that lesser-known side of Can.

albums.title: Adiós
albums.label: UME
albums.description: The new record from 1960s hitmaker Glen Campbell is intended as his last. It’s a pleasant postscript, collecting covers of Bob Dylan and Willie Nelson, among others.

albums.title: Rose Colored Corner
albums.label: Light in the Attic
albums.description: Issued for the first time are the rhapsodic, intimate, melancholy tunes of Lynn Castle, the first lady barber of L.A. who recorded these demos with Lee Hazlewood and Jack Nitzsche in the late 1960s.

albums.title: Trouble Maker
albums.label: Epitaph
albums.description: Trouble Maker is about as good as a latter-day Rancid album gets. The Bay Area group examines contemporary political turmoil with a quick, scratchy sound that honors their punk past.

albums.title: Melodrama
albums.label: Republic
albums.description: Lorde captures emotions like none other. Her second album is a masterful study of being a young woman, a sleek and humid pop record full of grief and hedonism, crafted with the utmost care and wisdom.

albums.title: Pretty Girls Like Trap Music
albums.label: Def Jam
albums.description: Pretty Girls is the most fulfilling 2 Chainz album to date. He switches on a dime from dark to hilarious to laid back, cooly landing punches while lounging at the yacht club’s VIP section.

albums.title: In a Mood
albums.label: ATO
albums.description: The Austrailian singer Simon Okely’s latest is a collection of crooning seduction, pop songwriting, and lush production. The breezy spirit of Laurel Canyon hovers around the album in a powerful way.

albums.title: Crack-Up
albums.label: Nonesuch
albums.description: The band’s third album is their most complex and compelling to date. Robin Pecknold’s songwriting retreats inward while around him dense folk compositions rise and fall on a massive scale.

albums.title: Modern Species
albums.label: Firecracker
albums.description: Denmark’s DJ Sports makes experimental dance music with a hazy patina and a healthy appreciation for the 1990s. His new album is among the dreamiest, most heartfelt dance music this year.

albums.title: Thot Breaker
albums.label: RBC
albums.description: This long-awaited and revamped mixtape is Keef’s most accessible and incidentally romantic project in years, a bop-filled R&B gem that shows the Chicago rapper evolving in every direction naturally.

albums.title: City of No Reply
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: On her debut album, Coffman leaves behind the indie-prog of the Dirty Projectors for sunny kaleidoscopic pop that reveals how love and loss are tied inextricably to the music of our youth.

albums.title: Witness
albums.label: Capitol
albums.description: On her fourth album, the pop superstar’s stunning voice is stronger than ever. This is muted by the fact that words she sings are cringe-worthy and at times stupefying.

albums.title: Sugar at the Gate
albums.label: Arbutus
albums.description: With their third album, the Montréal band TOPS have sharpened their hooks and clarified their aesthetic. These slyly-produced soft rock tunes carry a plush atmosphere and vintage warmth.

albums.title: Selfless
albums.label: Constellation
albums.description: The first widely-released album from French-born, Montréal-based artist Joni Void is a found-sound project that reflects the anxiety of cities.

albums.title: S.A.N.D.A.S
albums.label: Warner Bros.
albums.description: Newly reissued with a more polished sound, the ATL rapper’s third mixtape finds the promising SahBabii on shaky ground trying to discover his voice.

albums.title: Peasant
albums.label: Weird World
albums.description: Newcastle singer-songwriter Richard Dawson twists his compositions into gruesome shapes at the exact moment you start to get comfortable—but Peasant contains his most accessible music to date.

albums.title: Planetarium
albums.label: 4AD
albums.description: The supergroup’s cosmic concerto features lush, lilting instrumentals unfurling from Stevens’ tightly-wound pop choruses, though its glut of sound and ideas becomes wearisome.

albums.title: Chuck
albums.label: Dualtone
albums.description: In his final years, Chuck Berry endeavored to make another record worthy of his rock’n’roll legacy. The resulting Chuck is a collection of new songs and covers that meditate on love and mortality.

albums.title: CTRL
albums.label: Top Dawg
albums.description: The long-awaited debut from the Jersey singer is a opulent, raw R&B album that constantly tests the borders of the genre. SZA’s deeply personal lens on modern romance gives these songs endless life.

albums.title: Lindsey Buckingham / Christine McVie
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: A Fleetwood Mac album in all but name, the two esteemed songwriters bring their signature tics and genius songwriting, though the rush wears thin as the album progresses.

albums.title: The Age of Anxiety
albums.label: 4AD
albums.description: The debut album from UK indie pop artist Hannah Rodgers, aka Pixx, is forlorn, agitated, and at times infectious. She sings critically of her doubt and discontent with our times.

albums.title: Too Many Winters
albums.label: Brutal Panda
albums.description: Featuring YOB bassist Aaron Riesberg, Too Many Winters is a welcome throwback, taking cues from ’80s power and doom metal in a way that is actually refreshing.

albums.title: Club Coil EP
albums.label: Mixpak
albums.description: The second EP from London producer Murlo is competent but bland. It feels like a document from dance music’s recent past, proof enough that the post-club sound is becoming stale.

albums.title: Very Necessary
albums.label: Next Plateau
albums.description: Salt-N-Pepa laid out their best music and bravest activism on Very Necessary, an album about love, agency, and take-no-shit femininity from the Queens rap trio.

albums.title: Platinum Tips + Ice Cream
albums.label: Drag City
albums.description: The duo’s first album in 17 years is a surprisingly practical gesture, a career-spanning live album that connects the accessible and impenetrable extremes of the Trux discography.

albums.title: Paradygm Shift
albums.label: Dekmantel
albums.description: With his latest full-length, techno pioneer Robert Hood returns to his true-form minimal techno—a style the producer is often credited with inventing.

albums.title: Towards Language
albums.label: Rune Grammofon
albums.description: The Norwegian trumpeter’s ninth album feels like an opaque and ambient jazz album you can walk right into. Truly, his instrument always seems on the verge of speaking.

albums.title: Home Counties
albums.label: Heavenly
albums.description: The unhurried new album from English indie pop trio Saint Etienne centers on a theme of geography. Across 19 tracks, the band offers a day-in-the-life snapshot of their native London commuter towns.

albums.title: Dubbing in the Backyard
albums.label: Pressure Sounds
albums.description: This newly-reissued 1982 dub reggae album carries historical heft as one of the last times three of the form’s titans would work together. There’s a halcyon sweetness to its 10 mellow grooves.

albums.title: I Can't Go Home
albums.label: EMPIRE
albums.description: The East New York rapper’s complicated relationship with wealth, poverty, and his neighborhood fuels his debut, an album about what happens when you leave home in search of fame and money.

albums.title: Capacity
albums.label: Saddle Creek
albums.description: Big Thief’s sophomore album beautifully excavates family history and trauma into a delicate, intricately built folk rock record, showcasing the gorgeous style of singer Adrianne Lenker.

albums.title: Smidley
albums.label: Triple Crown
albums.description: On his solo debut, the frontman of emo band Foxing offers a mix of bubble-grunge, jangly power-pop, and breezy balladry. It manages to be as heavy and compelling as his main group.

albums.title: Ti Amo
albums.label: Glassnote
albums.description: Phoenix are as decadent and beguiling as ever. Their sixth album is a romantic, glossy, soft-pop ode to sweet escapes and dance floors, though at times their pleasure-seeking falls flat.

albums.title: All of This
albums.label: Friends of Friends
albums.description: On her sophomore album, the London-born, Berlin-based singer lives in subdued reveries. She strikes a dynamic balance of harmony and discord, of aspirational pop and visceral experimentation.

albums.title: Cigarettes After Sex
albums.label: Partisan
albums.description: As Cigarettes After Sex, Greg Gonzalez writes modern love songs set to downbeat dream pop. Much like relationships themselves, the songs on his self-titled debut LP are full of contradictions.

albums.title: Ideas of Beginnings
albums.label: VDSQ
albums.description: On his latest release, the former Emeralds member presents a back-to-basics approach to his trancelike guitar playing. The result is an LP that feels as natural and refreshing as summer rain.

albums.title: Know No Better EP
albums.label: Mad Decent
albums.description: This brisk, summery, inarguably fun EP features Quavo, Travis Scott, and Jidenna gliding atop the trio’s tropical big-tent beats, which coincide with the all-too familiar riddims of Top 10 radio.

albums.title: Five Years of Loving Notes
albums.label: Antinote
albums.description: The French label Antinote has spent five years carving a niche in the electronic music landscape with a sonically and geographically diverse roster, which this compilation neatly surveys.

albums.title: Somersault
albums.label: Bayonet
albums.description: Somersault is a huge leap for Beach Fossils and includes some of Dustin Payseur’s most nuanced songs to date, with features from Slowdive’s Rachel Goswell and Cities Aviv.

albums.title: hopeless fountain kingdom
albums.label: Astralwerks
albums.description: The rising pop star's sophomore album goes for experimental radio hits that are full of anhedonic drama. It's ambitious and nuanced, though calculating in ways that dull its impact.

albums.title: Different Days
albums.label: BMG
albums.description: To mark their 30th anniversary, the Charlatans continue the unbroken streak of good-not-great albums they’ve released since 1997—this time with guests like Paul Weller and Johnny Marr.

albums.title: To Syria, With Love
albums.label: Mad Decent
albums.description: The latest from Syria’s Omar Souleyman comes via the Mad Decent label, making him labelmates with the likes of Major Lazer and Riff Raff. He works with producer Hasan Alo for a sleek, hypnotic sound.

albums.title: RELAXER
albums.label: Canvasback
albums.description: The third album from the British fuss-rockers features tastefully trimmed string arrangements, chamber woodwinds, and terminal boredom.

albums.title: I Used to Spend So Much Time Alone
albums.label: Hardly Art
albums.description: Between post-punk and shoegaze live Chastity Belt, whose latest album displays a new kind of aggressiveness and gravity. Their songs relay the psychological slog of trying really hard just to be OK.

albums.title: Best of Crime Rock
albums.label: In the Red
albums.description: This eight-year retrospective comprises robust and fierce re-recordings from the group’s decidedly lo-fi catalog, featuring the best of Ian Svenonius’ sneering rock ‘n’ roll anthems.

albums.title: Balsams
albums.label: VDSQ
albums.description: On this expressive and singular new album, Chuck Johnson gives his steel pedal guitar the starring role, and creates a kind of country post-rock. It feels like a universe unto itself.

albums.title: Fantasy Club
albums.label: Warner Music Japan
albums.description: Channelling Southern rap, house music, and lush orchestral pop, the third release from Yusuke Kawai as tofubeats is one of the best J-Pop releases of the year.

albums.title: Droptopwop
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: Metro Boomin pulls the best out of Gucci Mane on his fourth LP since he was released from federal prison. Together, they are sharp and unhinged.

albums.title: Vision
albums.label: Polyvinyl
albums.description: Into It. Over It’s Evan Weiss has a rock band for every occasion. When he’s looking to goof around, he turns to Pet Symmetry, and here they’ve made a record that feels like a sweet spot.

albums.title: Supreme Clientele
albums.label: Epic
albums.description: An unrivaled classic, Supreme Clientele marked a seismic rupture with rap tradition. It’s Tony Starks, invulnerable and silvery, casting stream-of-consciousness hexes from a general who survived hell.

albums.title: Horizonless
albums.label: Profound Lore
albums.description: With an emphasis on the sublime, the Nashville funeral doom band Loss have made one of the year’s most beautiful metal records.

albums.title: Ten Years Alive on the Infinite Plain
albums.label: Superior Viaduct
albums.description: This dynamic, captivating 1972 performance featuring Rhys Chatham and Laurie Spiegel is the most important shot in the arm to the composer and violinist’s legacy in over a decade.

albums.title: From the Heart, It’s a Start, a Work of Art
albums.label: DDS
albums.description: The mysterious Japanese producer Shinichi Atobe has recently revived his shimmering ambient techno project. This striking new album focuses squarely on dancefloor energies while amping up the emotion.

albums.title: Demolition 9
albums.label: Atlas Réalisations
albums.description: The dizzying new album from Suicide’s Martin Rev is 34 tracks long, and highlights his playful streak—an underdeveloped mix of noise, new age, bossa nova, rock’n’roll, and more.

albums.title: Insecurity Guard
albums.label: Giegling
albums.description: The electronic duo’s latest is a wonder, a record of ambient house grooves filled with hundreds of tiny, captivating details. It’s also a showcase for the unique allure of their German label Giegling.

albums.title: Still Bewitched
albums.label: Flying Nun
albums.description: In the 1980s, the women of Look Blue Go Purple helped define the Flying Nun label’s Dunedin sound, putting their own enchanted spin on gentle guitar pop. This new comp surveys their catalog.

albums.title: Gone Now
albums.label: RCA
albums.description: Jack Antonoff’s stately sophomore effort as Bleachers has all the affectations of an over-the-top pop masterpiece, with some soaring anthems. But it’s a largely uneven album.

albums.title: I’m Not Your Man
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: The London singer’s sophomore album is a bracing, darkly funny blend of folk and Britpop. Her tactile lyrics keep the songs melodically strong and full of surprises.

albums.title: Neva Left
albums.label: EMPIRE
albums.description: As Snoop cruises on into his Cool Uncle entrepreneur phase, the title of his very enjoyable 15th studio album, Neva Left, is, nevertheless, pretty accurate.

albums.title: Empirical House
albums.label: [a:rpia:r]
albums.description: The minimal techno legend brings his first solo album in five years: four long tracks aimed squarely at the dancefloor, perforated by needle-tipped hi-hats and sharp, serrated claps.

albums.title: Spots y Escupitajo
albums.label: The Vinyl Factory
albums.description: The beguiling new album from producer Elysia Crampton is a dizzying, hyper-conceptual collection of miniatures. It highlights a number of her hallmark sounds before pushing into strange new territory.

albums.title: Waiting on a Song
albums.label: Easy Eye Sound
albums.description: The Black Keys’ singer’s solo album bears little relation to his past efforts, yet nonetheless exudes his signature retro-soul fetishism. It’s casual in execution and intricate in construction.

albums.title: True to Self
albums.label: RCA
albums.description: Bryson Tiller’s sophomore album leans heavily on ’90s R&B samples. It sounds luxurious, but Tiller’s come-up narrative and good-guy pose are starting to lose their power.

albums.title: A Prayer for the Unemployed
albums.label: Escho
albums.description: The debut LP from this Copenhagen band arrives via the same label that introduced Iceage. But First Hate make bright pop music—yearning melodies, sparkling Euro trance keyboards, padding club beats.

albums.title: Capture
albums.description: Indiana’s Thunder Dreamer embrace their Midwest roots on Capture, mixing elements of emo, post-rock, and pop. It’s a summer album with thick atmosphere and a dusk that seems to last infinitely.

albums.title: Sufi La EP
albums.label: Customs
albums.description: Heems and Riz MC follow up last year’s politically charged Cashmere with an EP that shows off their range with a loose and playful energy.

albums.title: Black Laden Crown
albums.label: Nuclear Blast
albums.description: Black Laden Crown is Danzig’s strongest album in some time, because he’s mostly built it around his own limitations. His thunder has quelled, but his ear is sharpening again on these metal blues.

albums.title: Niggative Approach
albums.label: 12XU
albums.description: Cleveland’s one-man garage-rock industry Lamont Thomas has a wide vision of what is noise and punk, and if *Louder Space *was his hip-hop album, *Niggative Approach *is his funk excursion.

albums.title: MrLA
albums.label: 400 Summers
albums.description: RJ’s music comes from the heart of Los Angeles, and his latest for YG’s and DJ Mustard’s label bumps and snaps like summer in a way only West Coast artists can portray.

albums.title: Bookhead EP
albums.label: Lex
albums.description: Newly reprinted on vinyl, this collab between Jneiro Jarel and the elusive MC features remixes from Thom Yorke, Beck, and more. It remains one of the best releases to feature DOOM’s name this decade.

albums.title: Easter
albums.label: Arista
albums.description: Easter embraces and rebukes rock’n’roll. It’s a love letter and a break-up letter all in one, the album that brought Patti Smith fame, the rebirth of her career, and her most controversial song.

albums.title: Truth, Liberty & Soul - Live in NYC: The Complete 1982 NPR Jazz Alive! Recording
albums.label: Resonance
albums.description: There’s never been an electric bassist as deified as Jaco Pastorius, who had the swagger of a stadium rocker and the sophistication of a jazz artist. His 1982 Lincoln Center concert is newly released.

albums.title: And the Birds Flew Overhead
albums.label: Footfalls
albums.description: Captured by the ubiquitous NYC Taper, this 2016 live collaboration from harpist Mary Lattimore and keyboardist Elysse Thebner Miller is magic. Over two extended pieces, the duo is perfectly ascendant.

albums.title: Stone Garden
albums.label: Guruguru Brain
albums.description: In the clubs of Tokyo, psych-rockers Kikagaku Moyo have always let noise and chaos linger on the edges of their songs. Stone Garden, however, rejects familiar structure in favor of improvisation.

albums.title: Is This the Life We Really Want?
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: The Pink Floyd frontman teamed with producer Nigel Godrich for his new album. They don’t take many risks, but Roger Waters presents some of his most focused songs since the mid-’70s.

albums.title: Mulatu Of Ethiopia
albums.label: Strut
albums.description: This groundbreaking and newly-reissued 1972 album is an excellent introduction to Mulatu Astatke, the inventor and sole exemplar of Ethio-jazz.

albums.title: Voices Bloom
albums.label: Umor Rex
albums.description: The new album from electronic artist Phil Tortoroli earns the optimism of its title. There are dark themes, but his music is brighter than ever, cut with Maya Angelou and James Baldwin samples.

albums.title: Play What They Want
albums.label: Thrill Jockey
albums.description: Drummer John Colpitts (aka Kid Millions) taps Laurie Anderson, Yo La Tengo, and more for the group’s most accessible album yet—confounding melody and rhythm into something clear and grandiose.

albums.title: Teenage Emotions
albums.label: Capitol
albums.description: Yachty is our master of joy. His debut album is well-polished and full of pop-rap confections, but his polarizing style hardly captures the nuance suggested by the album’s cover and title.

albums.title: T-Wayne
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: This lost mixtape, which has been sitting around since 2009, features Lil Wayne rapping at his effortless peak and T-Pain straining to keep up.

albums.title: The Following Mountain
albums.label: Nonesuch
albums.description: The folk singer enlists an elite, dynamic group of players for an album deconstructed from a master jam session, naturally creating his most jazz-forward release to date.

albums.title: Dreamcar
albums.label: PLOF
albums.description: Dreamcar is a new supergroup featuring three-quarters of No Doubt with AFI frontman Davey Havok. This eponymous debut is a testament to the new wave crushes of their youth.

albums.title: Close but Not Quite EP
albums.label: XL
albums.description: This short EP is the proper solo debut from XL Recordings boss Richard Russell. Like all of his work, though, Russell is in the background, more an orchestrator than a frontman.

albums.title: Dr. Octagonecologyst
albums.label: Get on Down
albums.description: Kool Keith’s second act was inspiring, and it came from a relentless willingness to redefine himself. His newly-reissued collaboration with Dan the Automator was a rap album of unprecedented oddity.

albums.title: Ends With And / The Dirt of Luck / The Magic City / No Guitars
albums.label: Matador
albums.description: Mary Timony led Helium into the outer sci-fi reaches of ’90s alt-rock. Their new career-spanning box set captures their singular, influential style of punk mysticism and righteous shredding.

albums.title: Shake the Shudder
albums.label: Warp
albums.description: The new !!! album finds them working with a slew of guest singers, exploring twitchy R&B, queasy dub-disco, romantic house, and more. As ever, their dance music is both celebratory and unsentimental.

albums.title: You’re Welcome
albums.label: Ghost Ramp
albums.description: Filled as always with ridiculously catchy garage-pop hooks, Wavves’ sixth album is caught between exploring something new and rehashing something old.

albums.title: The King & I
albums.label: Rhino
albums.description: Though the project oozes affection for Biggie, it’s yet another gangly, recycled posthumous album of verses we’ve all heard before—a painful tour through rap’s emptiest vault.

albums.title: New Tab
albums.label: Pacific Rhythm
albums.description: On his deeply expressive new album, Canadian producer Dylan Khotin-Foote uses humble materials to broaden the outlines of ambient music and make them feel fresh again.

albums.title: Green Twins
albums.label: ATO
albums.description: Inspired by soul singers like Marvin Gaye and Curtis Mayfield, the D.C.-born singer puts a modern spin on classic concepts. His genre-bending debut operates at a fever pitch.

albums.title: Singles: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack-Deluxe Edition
albums.label: Sony
albums.description: The legendary document of grunge celebrates its 25th anniversary with a reissue dominated by Chris Cornell, revealing just how much he contributed to the film’s blend of Seattle reality and fiction.

albums.title: Rosewood Almanac
albums.label: Bella Union
albums.description: With pastoral folk roots, New York singer-songwriter Will Stratton has gotten more discreet in his approach. Not a single note sounds out of place here, meshing into a breathtaking whole.

albums.title: The Never End EP
albums.label: Apron
albums.description: The latest EP from quietly legendary Cleveland producer Warren Harris offers deep house music with a beating human heart.

albums.title: Rubbish of the Floodwaters EP
albums.label: Ostgut Ton
albums.description: Released on Berghain’s house label, Dominick Fernow’s latest is built around clubbier techno atmospheres, but its transitional nature recalls the spirit of his earlier cassette releases.

albums.title: Goths
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: John Darnielle's latest is a richly detailed collection of songs about the beautiful melancholy life of a goth, and the long journey between life in the dark and death in the light.

albums.title: From Night to Night
albums.label: All City
albums.description: The full-length from singer-songwriter David Kitt moves from moody nighttime flickers to jazz-rooted deep house with Kitt’s pop-focused voice front and center.

albums.title: Violent Femmes
albums.label: Slash
albums.description: They were a cult band from Wisconsin in the ’80s who hit it big in the ’90s with their self-titled debut of brash, devil-eyed songs that hummed with sex, violence, and perverted religiosity.

albums.title: Shine
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: Wale is buoyant on his latest LP, but remains fixated on the subjects that have long obsessed him: success, wealth, and the haters who are blocking his path to success and wealth.

albums.title: Agistri
albums.label: LM Dupli-Cation
albums.description: The solo debut from Heather Trost, formerly of A Hawk and a Hacksaw, recalls atmospheric pop à la Broadcast and Stereolab. Trost is accompanied by members of Neutral Milk Hotel, Deerhoof, and more.

albums.title: Nost
albums.label: Bpitch Control
albums.description: The BPitch Control label founder brings the intoxicating humidity of classic techno with a crackling texture reminiscent of 2 a.m. sets at Berghain that became their own balmy, utopian ecosystems.

albums.title: Missing Link EP
albums.label: Downtown
albums.description: Nick Murphy (fka Chet Faker) fires off in a new direction while trying to bridge a gap with his diverse new EP featuring Afrobeat, R&B, soul, and Kaytranada—sometimes all at once.

albums.title: United States of Horror
albums.label: Caroline
albums.description: Volatility is Ho99o9’s brand. The L.A.-based duo merge interests in old-school hardcore and hip-hop on their scorching debut album.

albums.title: Common Sense
albums.label: Black Butter
albums.description: The debut from the young East London rapper is a unique coming-of-age story that shapes the best of grime, Afrobeat, dancehall, and early ’00s hip-hop into a vibrant, wholly unique sound.

albums.title: DJ-Kicks
albums.label: !K7
albums.description: Michael Mayer’s technique as a DJ is impeccable, and his personality bursts from the decks. His latest mix CD gathers obscure house tracks and other oddities, reflecting his restless tastes.

albums.title: Rocket
albums.label: Domino
albums.description: The Philadelphia musician offers a meticulously filtered, distorted document of indie rock. Though it’s his most accessible album, his best traits remain obtuse storytelling and oddly-shaped songs.

albums.title: Life After Youth
albums.label: Saddle Creek
albums.description: After a seven year pause, Elizabeth Powell’s new album as Land of Talk still sounds like a direct line to her consciousness, full of unpredictable songwriting twists and poetically opaque lyrics.

albums.title: spin
albums.label: Black Cement
albums.description: The new album from Tigers Jaw is their major label debut, but it’s also the debut of a major label, as the first release on producer Will Yip’s new Atlantic imprint Black Cement.

albums.title: Black Origami
albums.label: Planet Mu
albums.description: The sophomore album from the brilliant producer turns the tools of footwork into an overwhelming piece of musical architecture, an epic treatise on where rhythm comes from and where it can go.

albums.title: É Grau EP
albums.label: True Panther
albums.description: The baile funk artist known as MC Bin Laden is becoming a real-deal pop star in his native Brazil. His first U.S. release collects his biggest hits from the last three years, and shows why.

albums.title: Passive Aggressive
albums.label: Melody As Truth
albums.description: This collaboration from Amsterdam’s Jonny Nash and Suzanne Kraft is a work of profound tranquility. In the right frame of mind, its meditative miniatures come springing vividly to life.

albums.title: Occult Architecture Vol. 2
albums.label: Sacred Bones
albums.description: The fifth album from the hypnotic Moon Duo is their breeziest to date. Its combination of sweetness and substance is blissed-out and pillowy, like soft-core shoegaze.

albums.title: I Can Feel the Night Around Me
albums.label: Western Vinyl
albums.description: Dave Hartley’s latest album is his most ambitious record yet, one that takes him out of his bedroom and places him out on the open road with deep shades of mysterious Laurel Canyon folk-rock.

albums.title: Stubborn Persistent Illusions
albums.label: Constellation
albums.description: The Toronto post-rock band returns with their first album in eight years. It’s the well-oiled sound of a band pushing the boundaries of a genre littered with tropes, without succumbing to any of them.

albums.title: Routines
albums.label: Fat Possum
albums.description: The lo-fi bedroom rock project from Indiana brings smooth guitar licks into clearer focus with their Fat Possum debut, a light and bright collection of weaving, winding psych-pop.

albums.title: Olden Goldies
albums.label: BUFU
albums.description: The debut album by Juan Zaballa, a Buenos Aires-via-Far Rockaway singer/songwriter gleefully indebted to the Ramones.

albums.title: Harry Styles
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: The One Direction member’s solo debut pays fine tribute to classic rock’n’roll and shows off his exceptional voice, if not his enigmatic persona.

albums.title: The Bob’s Burgers Music Album
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: Though there are tracks featuring Cyndi Lauper, the National, and St. Vincent, this exhaustive 112-song soundtrack is chiefly a profound testament to humanity’s endless fascination with butts.

albums.title: Stealing From Our Favorite Thieves / Sultans of Sentiment
albums.label: La Castanya
albums.description: The lines between post-hardcore, indie rock, and emo blurred on the two mid-’90s full-lengths from the Van Pelt, which are newly reissued.

albums.title: Endlings
albums.label: Sicksicksick
albums.description: Endlings is the collaboration of Deerhoof guitarist John Dieterich with the New Mexico-based composer and noise artist Raven Chacon. Their self-titled album embraces abstraction.

albums.title: After Laughter
albums.label: Fueled by Ramen
albums.description: After years of merrily keeping the Paramore lights on, Hayley Williams considers her life and lets go of her grin on her latest album, a fizzy yet despondent piece of ’80s pop-rock.

albums.title: Enjoy the Great Outdoors
albums.label: Run for Cover
albums.description: The Ohio songwriter Spencer Radcliffe enlisted a seven-piece band for his latest album. The musicians give his doomy themes a billowing energy like a cloud of smoke.

albums.title: PARADISO
albums.label: NON
albums.description: The debut album from the co-founder of NON is a noisy and unrelenting ride through the hell of this world, full of label associates who help define its gruesome electronic sound.

albums.title: Reasonable Doubt
albums.label: Roc-A-Fella
albums.description: There is nothing like the debut of Jay Z, a stroke of genius chronicling the life of a 26-year-old drug kingpin from the Marcy Houses with a love for craft unrivaled elsewhere in his work.

albums.title: Lovely Creatures: The Best of Nick Cave & The Bad Seeds 1984-2014
albums.label: Mute
albums.description: Compiled by Nick Cave and founding member Mick Harvey, the massive Bad Seeds retrospective paints a dark, awe-inspiring portrait of all the sex, drugs, love, and death that fill the band's catalogue.

albums.title: ISON
albums.label: Twisted Elegance
albums.description: On her debut album, the Iranian-born Netherlands-based singer and multidisciplinary artist Sevdaliza establishes herself as a provocateur with a sense of global mission.

albums.title: Black Populous
albums.label: Bootleg Tapes
albums.description: Composed on hardware and recorded straight to tape without edits or overdubs, Adrian Mojica creates visceral, dystopian techno that reflects the deep thrum of the city.

albums.title: A Little Light
albums.label: R&S
albums.description: The grime producer's latest LP play simmers down the tension to hint at more meditative things lurking below, trying to blend wild movement with more contemplative ambience.

albums.title: All the Beauty in This Whole Life
albums.label: Rhymesayers
albums.description: On his latest LP, the rapper Brother Ali rekindles his long-running collaboration with Atmosphere producer Ant. They’ve crafted a purposefully uplifting sound.

albums.title: Everybody
albums.label: Def Jam
albums.description: The Maryland rapper’s latest is an impossibly dense meditation on race, religion, identity, the cosmos, social media, you name it. It's executed with skill but is often tone deaf and heavy-handed.

albums.title: Powerplant
albums.label: Anti-
albums.description: Girlpool's sound gets bigger on their sophomore LP, but Cleo Tucker and Harmony Tividad’s voices still sit center stage in all their vulnerable glory.

albums.title: Morningside
albums.label: Flying Nun
albums.description: Auckland bedroom pop artist Amelia Murray is the latest signee to Flying Nun. She honors her label’s history of making effortless pop songs that are far less effortless than people think.

albums.title: The Imperfect Sea
albums.label: Erased Tapes
albums.description: Simon Jeffes’ Penguin Cafe Orchestra were charming and baffling in late ’70s UK music, mixing ambient, Balearic, drone, and more. Now Jeffes’ son is using the name with members of Gorillaz and Suede.

albums.title: Meeting of the Waters EP
albums.label: Domino
albums.description: Recorded along the Amazon River, the four-song EP features just Avey Tare and Geologist in a return to the hazy, patiently paced, and largely improvised records of their early days.

albums.title: Thin Black Duke
albums.label: Hydra Head
albums.description: Since 1989, Oxbow have been releasing some of the most eccentric heavy music albums ever. On Thin Black Duke, frontman Eugene S. Robinson wields his voice as a vehicle for disorder and transcendence.

albums.title: Pollinator
albums.label: BMG
albums.description: Featuring collaborations with Sia, Dev Hynes, Charli XCX and more, Blondie’s 11th album is a bit uneven but remains a showcase for Debbie Harry’s versatile, supremely grounded voice and style.

albums.title: White Knight
albums.label: Cleopatra
albums.description: Todd Rundgren’s new album seeks to represent him in a holistic light. It’s a genre-spanning collection that finds him pairing with artists new and old—Robyn, Trent Reznor, and Daryl Hall among them.

albums.title: World Spirituality Classics 1: The Ecstatic Music of Alice Coltrane Turiyasangitananda
albums.label: Luaka Bop
albums.description: In the ’80s and ’90s, Alice Coltrane recorded and released an exquisite catalog of ashram music. These devotionals tell a story of womanhood and spirituality through the lens of a peerless composer.

albums.title: Real High
albums.label: Gloriette
albums.description: Ramona Gonzalez digs back into the ’90s to find the right R&B moods for her latest album as Nite Jewel, her most focused work yet with many nods to new jack swing and Janet Jackson.

albums.title: Finding People EP
albums.label: Posh Isolation
albums.description: On his new EP, Danish electronic artist Loke Rahbek creates a landscape of yearning choral pads and dubby loneliness, nodding at themes of love and despair.

albums.title: Trumpeting Ecstasy
albums.label: Profound Lore
albums.description: The new album from crushers Full of Hell is an impressive show of stylistic transcendence—featuring a standout collaboration with art-pop auteur Nicole Dollanganger.

albums.title: Best Troubador
albums.label: Drag City
albums.description: Will Oldham’s double-album tribute to Merle Haggard is an intimate and considered collection that pays homage to a legend while showcasing the steady growth of Oldham’s voice and career.

albums.title: Halo
albums.label: Crammed Discs
albums.description: On her excellent new album, Juana Molina continues shedding formal pop structures to reveal more of her own artistic voice. Her occultish narrative is defined not by words, but by moods.

albums.title: in•ter a•li•a
albums.label: Rise
albums.description: On their first album in 17 years, the post-hardcore band comes exploding back with dutiful performances and familiarly obtuse lyrics, but the overall impact of their style has waned.

albums.title: Satan’s graffiti or God’s art?
albums.label: Vice
albums.description: The eighth Black Lips album finds the band with a new five-piece lineup. Weighing in at 18 tracks, it assumes the form of a concept album while making a complete mockery of the medium.

albums.title: Slowdive
albums.label: Dead Oceans
albums.description: The shoegaze legends return with their first album in 22 years, a precise and altogether gorgeous showcase of their peerless ability at production, mood, and songcraft.

albums.title: Mixtape IV
albums.label: Northern Spy
albums.description: For their latest “mixtape” release, Baltimore band Horse Lords honor composer Julius Eastman, covering his early 1970s disco-meets-minimalist piece “Stay On It.” The rapper Abdu Ali contributes.

albums.title: Joan Shelley
albums.label: No Quarter
albums.description: The fifth album from the Kentucky singer-songwriter is her most intimate record yet, bracing and dense, featuring subtle production touches from Jeff Tweedy.

albums.title: I
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: The debut album from R&B singer Niia, produced by Rhye’s Robin Hannibal, is a placid mix of trip-hop and sophisti-pop. It imparts lovelorn angst and sweet romanticism in equal measure.

albums.title: Dookie
albums.label: Reprise
albums.description: From its humble roots in the Bay Area punk scene to its massive hooks, Dookie has become one of the greatest teenage wasteland albums of any generation.

albums.title: Laughter
albums.label: Ba Da Bing!
albums.description: On her first major solo release in eight years, Jesy Fortino buries her voice—once her most recognized instrument—in dark, ambient chambers of synths.

albums.title: Compassion
albums.label: Ninja Tune
albums.description: The second full-length from UK electronic artist Forest Swords focuses more acutely on the music’s organic elements. It retains the uncanny qualities he’s known for, but with dashes of hope.

albums.title: Grey EP
albums.label: Closed Sessions
albums.description: On his latest standout EP, the young Midwestern rapper isn’t looking for his voice so much as finding out exactly what he can do with it.

albums.title: May 1977: Get Shown the Light
albums.label: Rhino
albums.description: Hailed often as the Dead’s best shows of their career, this massive box set showcases the band at their tightest and most accessible—it’s perfect for beginners and lifelong Deadheads alike.

albums.title: All Blue
albums.label: Priority
albums.description: While nodding to West Coast legends of the ’90s, G Perico steps into the spotlight on his debut, a searing and vivid album that details a world of his own.

albums.title: Blob on a Grid
albums.label: Haord
albums.description: The music of songwriter Brian Esser is at once hilarious and horrifying. His debut synth-pop album as Cabo Boing is an unrelenting collection of high-energy jokes.

albums.title: In Spades
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: Bolstered again by the louche and ravaged voice of singer Greg Dulli, the latest from the indie rock icons is delightfully stuffed with romance and rancor.

albums.title: No Shape
albums.label: Matador
albums.description: Mike Hadreas’ fourth record is pure decadence. It’s his most realized album yet, a tender and transcendental protest record of love and devotion.

albums.title: HOWSLA
albums.label: OWSLA
albums.description: The new comp from Skrillex’s label is their brash take on house music, a wide-ranging collection of misses with some hits in between.

albums.title: Early Recordings
albums.label: Tough Love
albums.description: This vinyl release compiles the germinal recordings of D.C. punks Priests, originally out on tape via their own Sister Polygon label. It shows the band’s sense of purpose was intact from the start.

albums.title: The Weather
albums.label: Marathon Artists
albums.description: Australian psych rockers Pond share members with Tame Impala, as well as a penchant for arena-sized 1970s rock. Their new album mixes bright synths, campy detours, and grim lyrics.

albums.title: This Old Dog
albums.label: Captured Tracks
albums.description: On his third album, the antics of Mac DeMarco are muted in favor of his impeccable songwriting, which shines through more than ever with warmth and precision.

albums.title: Grafts
albums.label: Boomkat Editions
albums.description: Grafts is the latest release from Montreal composer Kara-Lis Coverdale, whose work exists somewhere between computer music and Erik Satie.

albums.title: Carrie & Lowell Live
albums.label: Asthmatic Kitty
albums.description: Documenting the South Carolina stop of the Carrie & Lowell tour, this audiovisual album takes a record that thrived on simplicity and adorns it with glowsticks, but each track retains a subtle beauty.

albums.title: The Gag File
albums.label: Dais Records
albums.description: The work of noise musician Aaron Dilloway, formerly of Wolf Eyes, exudes a raw vulnerability and needling playfulness. His new album strikes a balance between dread and curiosity.

albums.label: Interscope
albums.description: The Norwegian producer, once at the nexus between pop and electronic music, offers many new collaborations but little in the way of new thrills on his latest album.

albums.title: All This I Do for Glory
albums.label: 52Hz
albums.description: On his latest solo album, the breathless saxophone playing of Colin Stetson locks into familiar, albeit vastly impressive and evocative forms.

albums.title: Volume 1
albums.label: Bella Union
albums.description: The self-described “poor man’s Traveling Wilburys” features members of Franz Ferdinand, Grandaddy, Band of Horses, Travis, and Midlake in an effort to collectively seize upon their best traits.

albums.title: Untitled
albums.label: Wharf Cat
albums.description: The short-lived New York band WALL recorded this debut LP before breaking up last year. Drawing on the sardonic din of post-punk and no wave, they paint a picture of the city in a time of uncertainty.

albums.title: I Love You, Go Away
albums.label: Disco Halal
albums.description: Tel Aviv’s Nadav Spiegel is one of the more promising producers to emerge from his city’s revived electronic scene. His new LP draws on post-punk, disco, kosmische, and more, but the lyrics fall flat.

albums.title: Strength of a Woman
albums.label: Capitol
albums.description: The R&B legend returns with a soulful, deeply personal album that luxuriates in the classic sounds of wronged-woman blues, featuring guest spots from Kanye West, DJ Khaled, and Kaytranada.

albums.title: Pussycat
albums.label: American Laundromat
albums.description: Juliana Hatfield’s new album is her angriest by a landslide. It’s packed with scathing vignettes about predatory men, particularly the one currently leading the free world.

albums.title: Gargoyle
albums.label: Heavenly
albums.description: On Mark Lanegan’s 10th solo album, his leather voice and slow-burning songwriting play up the pulp and noir that’s been with him his entire career.

albums.title: Sophia Kennedy
albums.label: Pampa
albums.description: On Sophia Kennedy’s bewitching debut LP, flickering electronic music mingles with scraps of Tin Pan Alley signage. It’s an unlikely release from DJ Koze and Marcus Fink’s dance-oriented Pampa Records.

albums.title: async
