albums.label: Milan
albums.description: The Japanese composer's first solo album after eight years and a battle with throat cancer is marvelous, using a bounty of textures, moods, and ambience from his esteemed four-decade-long career.

albums.title: In on the Kill Taker
albums.label: Dischord
albums.description: Fugazi's third album arrived in 1993 when the underground began seeping into the mainstream. The D.C. band stayed raw and visceral, growing their fanbase while keeping their famous DIY ethics intact.

albums.title: The Great Annihilator / Drainland
albums.label: Mute
albums.description: By 1995’s The Great Annihilator, Swans weren’t imitating pop music so much as swallowing its features to create something monstrous. This deluxe reissue also includes Michael Gira’s solo LP Drainland.

albums.title: What Mountain
albums.label: Halocline Trance
albums.description: The Toronto duo of Anna Mayberry and David Psutka take folk music as a starting point, but walk an unfamiliar path, warping the genre with a dose of future shock.

albums.title: God’s Problem Child
albums.label: Legacy
albums.description: Written partly over text messages with his co-writer Buddy Cannon, Willie Nelson’s latest album finds the cosmic joker contemplating mortality with endearing humor and touching honesty.

albums.title: Whatever Makes U Happy
albums.label: White Room
albums.description: The R&B singer JMSN is devoted to the sound of late 1990s neo soul, but on his new album, he lacks a unique approach to it.

albums.title: Snow
albums.label: Undertow
albums.description: Formed out of slowcore legends Bedhead, the New Year return with an album that is judiciously paced and artfully arranged, recorded with fine detail over the better part of the last decade.

albums.title: Shanghai
albums.label: Lakeshore
albums.description: David Grellier returns with a collection of filmic mood pieces that work well as a sound package but begs for some kind of visual accompaniment.

albums.title: Rock n Roll Consciousness
albums.label: Caroline
albums.description: Thurston Moore’s new solo LP evokes the hippie leanings that were always at the heart of Sonic Youth. With some of his most joyous lyrics to date, Moore uses outer aggression to achieve inner bliss.

albums.title: Humanz
albums.label: Parlophone
albums.description: Vince Staples, Danny Brown, Kelela, and Pusha T all star on the fifth album from Damon Albarn’s cartoon crew, another gloomy party playlist for the end of the world.

albums.title: Pleasure
albums.label: Interscope
albums.description: On Leslie Feist’s fifth album, sparks of rock’n’roll are balanced with simmering introspection across a collection of patient, lushly arranged songs.

albums.title: Digital-Dance
albums.label: 100% Electronica
albums.description: The cheesy new age sounds on this obscure album from 1988, discovered by a YouTube algorithm and recently reissued, have become a touchstone for producers because of their intense irony and nostalgia.

albums.title: Tinguely 1967 / Hétérozygote / Petite symphonie intuitive pour un paysage de printemps
albums.label: Editions Mego
albums.description: Two of the most famous pieces of musique concrète by French composer Luc Ferrari are reissued in all their aleatory and surrealist clamor.

albums.title: How I Creep
albums.label: Clan Destine
albums.description: Producer and DJ Collin Strange draws inspiration from Chicago acid house and New York hardcore in equal measure, but his new EP exists in its own moment.

albums.title: What Now
albums.label: Loma Vista
albums.description: The sophomore album from the electronic pop duo offers a biting, withering take on pop music, full of crisp humor while still finding real moments of tenderness.

albums.title: Significant Weather
albums.label: Lauren
albums.description: Brooklyn’s Real Life Buildings have become an indie supergroup of sorts, counting Vagabon’s Lætitia Tamko and Crying’s Elaiza Santos as members. Their new album carries a smart, raggedy charm.

albums.title: Tara Jane O’Neil
albums.label: Gnomonsong
albums.description: The singer-songwriter finally embraces that label on her ninth solo album, unspooling songs of unhurried beauty and great detail.

albums.title: Visuals
albums.label: Play It Again Sam
albums.description: The seventh album from Mew suggests the Danish alt-rock trio could say more with less. It’s a pop record with a light outer frosting of edginess.

albums.title: TOSS
albums.label: Polyvinyl
albums.description: Shugo Tokumaru’s songs barrel towards joyous cacophony at full tilt. On his latest LP, he expands his one-man chamber-pop sound with drum tracks from Deerhoof’s Greg Saunier.

albums.title: Midnight Moonlight EP
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: Chicago R&B singer Ravyn Lenae’s impressive new EP brims with quiet intensity, as her subtle falsetto glides over a blend of modern bounce, dream pop, and electro-soul.

albums.title: My Moment
albums.label: 300 Entertainment
albums.description: The debut mixtape from Detroit’s Tee Grizzley argues for him as a sober, sincere street rapper with the potential for some crossover success.

albums.title: Hammersmith Odeon, London ’75
albums.label: Legacy
albums.description: Reissued for Record Store Day, the live *Hammersmith Odeon, London ’75 *captures the combination of determination, ambition, and vulnerability that makes Bruce Springsteen’s early years so fascinating.

albums.title: Ledyanoy Album
albums.label: Gost Zvuk
albums.description: Released by the Russian label Gost Zvuk, producer Aleksei Nikitin offers a 16-track portrait of IDM, atmospheric sketches, and weightless techno inspired by six-month-long St. Petersburg winters.

albums.title: Love Is Love
albums.label: Woodsist
albums.description: Filled with warmth, horns, and many messages of love, Woods’ tenth album is a feel-good record for these rough times.

albums.title: Look at the Powerful People
albums.label: Grand Jury
albums.description: The dance-punk duo Formation made the most 2003 album of 2017, and it’s co-produced by house mastermind Leon Vynehall.

albums.title: Odd Hours
albums.label: Inflated
albums.description: On their third album, the New Orleans duo master their omnivorous style, which ranges from hectic noise rock to jangling ambience to arena riffage—sometimes within the span of a single song.

albums.title: Dissonance
albums.label: Bedroom Community
albums.description: Icelandic composer Valgeir Sigurðsson has worked with Björk, Damon Albarn, Sigur Rós, and many more. His new collection of long-form works feature emotional string arrangements in a digital setting.

albums.title: Dummy
albums.label: Go!Beat
albums.description: Portishead's 1994 debut is a masterwork of downbeat and desperation. They invented their own kind of virtuosity, one that encompassed musicianship, technology, and aura.

albums.title: Disciples of Blood
albums.label: Goner
albums.description: Hard punk from Florida doesn’t get much bloodier than this—22 minutes of loud, incredibly catchy songs that revel in mythological and contemporary scum and violence.

albums.title: Key
albums.label: Tompkins Square
albums.description: Originally released in 1971, this monumental work in experimental music is reissued for Record Store Day, preserving the debut of a visionary experimental singer and contemporary classical composer.

albums.title: Playboi Carti
albums.label: Interscope
albums.description: The young Atlanta rapper’s debut mixtape finds a cloudy and economical mood and stays there, but it’s Carti’s magnetic confidence that turns just enough into plenty.

albums.title: Back to the Basics
albums.label: Motown
albums.description: After a few years in limbo, the Atlanta rapper reestablishes himself as one of the genre’s most innovative stylists and its most heartfelt writers.

albums.title: Territory EP
albums.label: Animal 63
albums.description: French duo the Blaze are better known for their powerful short films, in which music—their slow, mournful take on house—allows for profound catharsis. But the tracks lack nuance without the visuals.

albums.title: Guppy
albums.label: Barsuk
albums.description: The New York band breathes life into the poppier side of ’90s indie rock, and their debut is both wry and sincere in its expression of the endless crap conveyor belt that is life and love as a girl.

albums.title: Narkopop
albums.label: Kompakt
albums.description: After 17 years, Wolfgang Voigt returns to his GAS moniker with a new album of unsettling and symphonic ambient music that has become deeper, richer, and more luxurious.

albums.title: Hotep
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: Dean Blunt’s latest semi-unofficial side project is his least inscrutable, featuring 20 minutes of low-key, free-flowing vignettes made largely with guitars, keys, and samples.

albums.title: Motor City
albums.label: Vintage Vibez Music Group
albums.description: This set of rare and unreleased Dilla instrumentals spans many of his styles, but the flat sequencing doesn’t do justice to his history of deeply focused vibe-building.

albums.title: Devout
albums.label: Planet Mu
albums.description: UK grime fixture Mr Mitch’s latest LP explores a pared-back sound. It feels polished and tactile, with themes of loyalty, accountability, and fatherhood.

albums.title: Hope
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: Recorded on a four-track over a weekend, Shamir's sophomore album is the definition of a departure, moving from effervescent pop into a bracing new lo-fi world.

albums.title: Bloodroot
albums.label: Telegraph Harp
albums.description: The composer and multi-instrumentalist Kelly Moran draws inspiration from John Cage’s “prepared piano,” extending the practice with electronic keyboards and melodic ingenuity.

albums.title: Belong
albums.label: Downtown
albums.description: The third album from studied Brooklyn chamber-pop ensemble San Fermin benefits from a sharper focus. But its lyrics signify depth and meaning without quite delivering.

albums.title: Belladonna of Sadness
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: The young American singer launches her career with a slinky, vintage album featuring production from Arctic Monkeys’ Alex Turner—though it sounds more like Turner side-project than a showcase debut.

albums.title: The Search for Everything
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: John Mayer suffers simultaneously from an excess of taste and an oblivious lack of it. It makes his seventh studio album neither sensitive nor scuzzy, just pleasantly bland.

albums.title: Taster
albums.label: Double Double Whammy
albums.description: The minimal Austin duo Hovvdy stack simple riffs in idiosyncratic ways. Their debut album rarely accelerates past a snail’s pace, but its interlocking pieces are deceptively complex.

albums.title: Americana
albums.label: Legacy
albums.description: The Kinks legend uses Americana to blaze a path through both America's rock’n’roll history and his own. Its back-to-basics energy and prosaic storytelling make it his best solo album in years.

albums.title: Big Day
albums.label: Father/Daughter
albums.description: Philadelphia’s Loose Tooth hopscotch between post-hardcore, midwestern emo, scuzz-rock, and slacker pop. On their eccentric new album, the only constant is stylistic inconsistency.

albums.title: DAMN.
albums.label: Top Dawg
albums.description: DAMN. is a widescreen masterpiece of rap, full of expensive beats, furious rhymes, and peerless storytelling about Kendrick’s destiny in America.

albums.title: Thelonious Monk: Les Liaisons Dangereuses 1960
albums.label: Sam Records
albums.description: In 1959, Thelonious Monk recorded selections from his songbook for the soundtrack to French director Roger Vadim’s film Les Liaisons Dangereuses. The lost tapes were never released until now.

albums.title: Cuidado Madame
albums.label: Northern Spy
albums.description: On the former DNA guitarist’s first album in 13 years, Arto Lindsay conjoins abstract noise and tropicália, clamor and glamour, into something unusually beautiful and distinctly his own.

albums.title: Light Sleep
albums.label: Mesh-Key
albums.description: The Japanese avant-garde vocalist Phew got her start in O.G. punk band Aunt Sally before collaborating with members of Can in the ’80s. Her latest set of analog bedroom productions recalls Suicide.

albums.title: Sonatra
albums.label: Cantaloupe
albums.description: Two versions of Michael Gordon's meticulously designed piano composition—one equal-tempered and one just intonation—played by Vicky Chow showcase the pair's crazed and brilliant obsession with rhythm.

albums.title: Electric Lines
albums.label: Domino
albums.description: The Hot Chip founding member’s first official solo full-length is a collection of charming odes to the history of dance music.

albums.title: Damaged
albums.label: SST
albums.description: Black Flag’s debut LP is a living document of hardcore, a mutable album of anger, empathy, and politics. Its raw power is still felt today, and its influence on the genre is incalculable.

albums.title: Miracle Steps (Music From the Fourth World 1983-2017)
albums.label: Optimo Music
albums.description: Devised by Optimo’s JD Twitch and NTS Radio’s Fergus Clark, this new compilation surveys the previously untenable “Fourth World” sound, from post-punk goofs to classical composers.

albums.title: Darling of the Afterglow
albums.label: Bella Union
albums.description: The Toronto-based composer and her wonderfully dynamic voice sail into poppier waters on her second album with huge, lush arrangements that have a tendency to weigh down the songs.

albums.title: Over the Edge
albums.label: Tankcrimes
albums.description: Oakland “stoner violence” trio Connoisseur’s entire debut LP is about the pleasures and politics of smoking weed. The band attempts to be dually comical and menacing, falling short in both capacities.

albums.title: Collected Pieces
albums.label: Ghostly International
albums.description: The latest set from harpist Mary Lattimore is like an audio scrapbook, collecting songs she recorded between 2011 and 2016. It contains a sense of time frozen into snapshots of memory.

albums.title: Ruff Hysteria
albums.label: Natural Sciences
albums.description: Swedish producer Armand Jakobsson, aka DJ Seinfeld, is an ostensible figurehead of the recent lo-fi house movement. His new EP tends towards warmth and melody even at its roughest.

albums.title: The Wild
albums.label: Ice H2O
albums.description: Raekwon’s reflective new solo LP is his first to feature zero Wu-Tang Clan members. Amid its casual braggadocio and nimble wordplay, The Wild surveys the Chef’s experience and legacy.

albums.title: Season High
albums.label: Loma Vista
albums.description: Despite the best efforts of Yukimi Nagano's dynamic voice, the Swedish band's fifth album of cautiously controlled, luxury mood music remains flat on the page.

albums.title: Queen Elizabitch
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: The amazingly explicit Chicago rapper has begun to embody the totality of her experience on record. Social issues, violence, and wild sex are all approached with the same fiery conviction.

albums.title: Bloodlust
albums.label: Century Media
albums.description: The seventh album from Ice-T’s heavy metal band sounds like a TED Talk set to a bracing thrashcore/groove metal soundtrack.

albums.title: Tremendous Sea of Love
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: Released for free on Twitter, the fourth Passion Pit album is a different kind of confessional for Michael Angelakos, who's rediscovering the joy of process rather than the satisfaction of product.

albums.title: Thunder of the Gods
albums.label: Modern Harmonic
albums.description: This new set of unheard songs is gripping and challenging, as to be expected from the the free jazz legend. Using oddball orchestrations, Sun Ra unfurls more complexities of the astral realm.

albums.title: Soundcheck
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: The hyped-up mixtape from the UK rap crew is without narrative and full of static posse cuts, but its production is terrific and it is a respectable capitalization on their rabid fanbase.

albums.title: Mista Thug Isolation
albums.label: Hundebiss
albums.description: Noise musician turned rapper Travis Miller made his mark as Lil Ugly Mane with *Mista Thug Isolation, *a weird and wonderful album that, five years after its release, still commands a cult status.

albums.title: AZD
albums.label: Ninja Tune
albums.description: Actress’ sixth LP reaches deep into both Darren Cunningham’s clubbiest and most avant-garde impulses, exploring language and Afrofuturism while maintaining a musicality that holds the listener close.

albums.title: Siberia
albums.label: Lisch
albums.description: The Swedish electronic artist Vanbot and two collaborators made this new album while journeying along the Trans-Siberian Railway—but they can’t quite sustain its immersive mood.

albums.title: LINES
albums.label: EMPIRE
albums.description: The debut album from the Canadian-born, St. Paul-based rapper stretches his stylings further than they’ve ever gone before. It’s an innovative study in individuality, as technical as it is passionate.

albums.title: Memories...Do Not Open
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: The debut album from the celebrity production duo is a somber departure from their EDM days—a lifeless, anodyne pop record that wallows in basic feelings of regret and narcissism.

albums.title: Arla II EP
albums.label: XL
albums.description: As Overmono, the UK techno duo of Tom and Ed Russell shift their focus away from club-friendly 4/4 kicks to tracks with looser architectures. Their second EP feels gutsy and modern.

albums.title: At What Cost
albums.label: Squaaash Club
albums.description: The D.C. rapper’s major label debut is made of loose, richly textured hip-hop that weaves a colorful tapestry from his city’s musical history featuring Wale, the Internet, and Kaytranada.

albums.title: August by Cake
albums.label: GBV
albums.description: Guided by Voice’s 24th studio album is a 32-track double-album that contains plenty of tiny details to savor. It is impressively low on filler from Robert Pollard.

albums.title: The Far Field
albums.label: 4AD
albums.description: Five albums in, Future Islands are beyond reinvention. Instead, they tap into the emotion that runs deep under their synth-pop, and the results are more cathartic and devastating than ever.

albums.title: Pleasure Suck
albums.label: Tiny Engines
albums.description: The Philadelphia band’s new record often veers towards an alluring ugliness. But when they let some light in and it hits just right, *Pleasure Suck *emanates a psych-folk warmth.

albums.title: Rules
albums.label: Full Psycho
albums.description: On her first solo album, Giant Drag singer Annie Hardy fills every song with palpable grief. It is a brave, angry, and mournful album that captures the manic energy of her musical past.

albums.title: All-Amerikkkan Bada$$
albums.label: Pro Era
albums.description: The New York rapper aims for political awareness on his latest, trading out his clever rhyme schemes for more clarity. Though varied and sometimes powerful, its themes feel undercooked.

albums.title: Nordic Flora Series Pt. 3: Gore-Tex City
albums.label: Northern Electronics
albums.description: Featuring Yung Lean and Chloe Wise, the Swedish producer’s dark and personal record imbues ambient and gothic techno with oversized feelings that find their reflection in endlessly overcast skies.

albums.title: Love Deluxe
albums.label: Epic
albums.description: Sade's 1992 album is a luxurious world of its own. Their most monolithic album is an ocean of quiet storm, R&B, and jazz-pop that surrounds Sade Adu's timeless expressions of desire and heartache.

albums.title: Whiteout Conditions
albums.label: Concord
albums.description: The New Pornographers’ seventh album is a peppy team effort, rich with new wave synths and closely blended harmonies. It’s their first LP without Dan Bejar, and lacks his stranger inklings.

albums.title: Short Passing Game
albums.label: Wah Wah Wino
albums.description: Irish producer Davy Kehoe’s latest is a strange and exhilarating vision of electronic music, drawing from adrenaline-fuelled krautrock, slathered in harmonica and dub delay.

albums.title: Adios
albums.label: Bloodshot
albums.description: Cory Branan’s latest set of countrified rock tunes may be his best to date. Branan sounds like he’s finally found the right balance between audacity and subtlety, between humor and heartbreak.

albums.title: Death Peak
albums.label: Warp
albums.description: As a mainstay of Warp Records, Clark returns with a more accessible, more human album that still reinforces his outré techno dreams and arpeggiated fantasies.

albums.title: Swear I’m Good at This
albums.label: Frenchkiss
albums.description: On their debut LP, the eager duo fumbles that which makes indie pop so meaningful. It becomes a lively collection of empty gestures.

albums.title: The World’s Best American Band
albums.label: Polyvinyl
albums.description: The Louisville band sell classic pop-rock almost perfectly. Their sophomore album is smart, well-polished, and cheeky—loaded with more riffs than you can fit into the trunk of a Camaro.

albums.title: FROM DEEWEE
albums.label: Play It Again Sam
albums.description: The Belgian electro-rock outfit Soulwax have aged gracefully. Over two decades on, they’ve finally found a coherent sound, layering robust synths, dusty live drums, and simple vocal melodies.

albums.title: Pure Comedy
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: Father John Misty is a consummate entertainer. On Pure Comedy, he questions the value of entertainment, capitalism, and everything else in a grueling odyssey through the psyche of Josh Tillman.

albums.title: Simultonality
albums.label: Eremite
albums.description: With his group Natural Information Society, Joshua Abrams crafts simple loops, primarily with a three-string African lute called the guimbri. Their fourth album takes on a Zen quality.

albums.title: Silver Haze
albums.label: Don Giovanni
albums.description: The new LP from Brooklyn’s Aye Nako introduces the songwriting of guitarist/singer Jade Payne. It presents two equal voices with their own takes on the queer black American experience.

albums.title: Triplicate
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: *Triplicate, *again, features Dylan singing tunes from the Great American Songbook. His voice is filled with character, though the cumulative impact of the 30-song set is somewhat dimmed.

albums.title: Cellular Automata
albums.label: Leisure System
albums.description: Gerald Donald—one-half of Detroit techno legends Drexciya—continues to dive deeper into his Dopplereffekt project, evoking a teeming futuristic landscape cruised over at low altitudes.

albums.title: Welcome to Paradise: Italian Dream House 1989-93
albums.label: Safe Trip
albums.description: In contrast with its American and British counterparts, the set positions Italian house as almost exclusively euphoric, a perfect sound to emanate from a land of chiseled Adonises and the Tuscan sun.

albums.title: Mystic 100’s
albums.label: Dom America
albums.description: Released with little fanfare, the new album from Olympia punks Milk Music is full of pure kinetic joy. It’s fueled by a tension between nihilistic fun and heady expansiveness.

albums.title: Arca
albums.label: XL
albums.description: The more Alejandro Ghersi gives of himself, the larger his music as Arca grows. His latest feels both intimate and expansive, a connection between his melodic past and a chaotic future.

albums.title: Corpus I
albums.label: Corpus
albums.description: New York punk trio Show Me the Body’s latest release is a scattered 17-track “collaborative mixtape” featuring guests such as Moor Mother, Mal Devisa, Cities Aviv, Dreamcrusher, and Princess Nokia.

albums.title: Mono No Aware
albums.label: Pan
albums.description: Mono No Aware collects new ambient music that reflects our present moment. Each piece of the 80-minute compilation has its own unique identity, yet together it feels like the work of one mind.

albums.title: Silver/Lead
albums.label: Pinkflag
albums.description: As the originators of UK post-punk enter their fifth decade, they write with a natural-born ease—uncomplicated music cruising under lyrics that question progress and our ability to move forward.

albums.title: Automaton
albums.label: Virgin EMI
albums.description: The British dance-funk group return with their first album in seven years, not so much cashing in on retro styles but leaning into it like they always did.

albums.title: Tribute to Ndiouga Dieng
albums.label: World Circuit
albums.description: Senegal’s legendary Orchestra Baobab return with their first record in a decade—a tribute to the group’s longtime member Ndiouga Dieng, who passed away late last year.

albums.title: Eternal Something
albums.label: Erased Tapes
albums.description: Daniel Brandt is the percussionist of Berlin’s Brandt Brauer Frick ensemble, which balances modern classical and dance music. His first solo album is better suited to isolated contemplation.

albums.title: The Awakening
albums.label: Be With
albums.description: Heralded by Miles Davis, sampled by both Nas and Gang Starr, the great pianist’s 1970 album is alive with a buoyancy and jubilance that went overlooked in its day.

albums.title: In the Same Room
albums.label: Domino Documents
albums.description: Featuring gorgeous, dynamic live studio recordings from her last two albums, In the Same Room is a showcase of Holter's imagination and her ability to reimagine.

albums.title: Emperor of Sand
albums.label: Reprise
albums.description: Full of melodic singing and zig-zagging riffs, the new Mastodon LP reins-in the Atlanta metal band’s technical abilities without watering them down—though it smooths out some of their angular edges.

albums.title: Let the Dancers Inherit the Party
albums.label: Golden Chariot
albums.description: British Sea Power evoke an eternal 1984, when bands bridged caustic post-punk and stadium-sized pop. Dismayed by the black cloud of post-Brexit Britain, they designed this album as a beacon of light.

albums.title: Liquid Liquid EP/ Successive Reflexes EP/ Optimo EP
albums.description: Their entire recorded output is less than an hour long, but it became the blueprint of wired, New York dance rock. Incomparable and otherworldly, Liquid Liquid were just in search of the “big beat.”

albums.title: Instrumentals
albums.label: Audika
albums.description: Newly remastered and reissued, Instrumentals is an ideal entry point into Russell’s pre-disco, magpie aesthetic. His early ideas as a downtown composer and cellist were both complex and joyful.

albums.title: Brood X
albums.label: In the Red
albums.description: Jon Spencer and his New York blues-punks return with their first new album in nearly two decades—a powerful showcase for singer Cristina Martinez and the fiery, apocalyptic buzz in her wake.

albums.title: Mental Illness
albums.label: Superego
albums.description: Mental Illness is Aimee Mann’s quintessential statement, tempering the discord of life with elegant chamber folk. Mann fills her songs with ordinary people struggling against operatic levels of pain.

albums.title: Rather You Than Me
albums.label: Epic
albums.description: The ninth Rick Ross album features tons of guests including Young Thug, Future, and Nas. As the Bawse enters his 40s, his bite has weakened, but he still owns his lane in luxury rap.

albums.title: Ransom 2
albums.label: Interscope
albums.description: His debut album—and sequel to a 2014 mixtape—is equal parts cash grab, roster exhibition, and résumé bulletin. But because it’s a Mike WiLL creation, it can’t help but thrill.

albums.title: Undertow
albums.label: Lower Floor
albums.description: *Undertow *finds Detroit noise trio Wolf Eyes a bit tamer than usual, as they apply a wrecking ball to the spacious frameworks of world music, ambient, and even reggae.

albums.title: Build Music
albums.artist: Janka Nabay and the Bubu Gang
albums.label: Luaka Bop
albums.description: Sierra Leone musician Janka Nabay returns with another collection of joyous bubu sounds. His greatest theme remains unchanged: how bubu music makes you dance.

albums.title: A Hairshirt of Purpose
albums.label: Exploding in Sound
albums.description: The sharp new LP from the Boston rockers avoids expectation without losing their asymmetrical songwriting style. It feels, in some sense, like their first true album.

albums.title: Silver Eye
albums.label: Mute
albums.description: On their first album in four years, Goldfrapp synthesize all their many sounds and modes to get at the core of their musical identity. They find a beautiful, poppy, platonic ideal.

albums.title: Contact
albums.label: Sacred Bones
albums.description: Each track of the new Pharmakon LP can be heard as a violent scuffle between mind and body. Even when her visceral noise achieves moments of transcendence, it still strikes you in the gut.

albums.title: Yaeji EP
albums.label: Godmode
albums.description: The New York and Seoul-based Kathy Yaeji Lee is one of the most fascinating vocalists to appear in house music of late. Her languid debut EP is full of elliptical earworms.

albums.title: Strike a Match
albums.label: Rock Action
albums.description: The debut of guitarist Rachel Aggs and drummer Eilidh Rogers is unconventionally well-formed. Their tightly-wound art punk unspools their anxiety and turns it into something worth celebrating.

albums.title: Sand
albums.label: Dais Records
albums.description: In the 40 years since the young Swedish composer's first proper release, the two-part, fifty-minute composition has become a cult minimalist classic. Its textures and humanity remain deeply absorbing.

albums.title: Step Brothers THREE
albums.label: EMPIRE
albums.description: Without sacrificing any of the technical virtuosity, the pair of Tennesseans have made THREE* *their most personal collection to date. They turn street voyeurism and psychic panic into a triumph.

albums.title: You Only Live 2wice
albums.label: ESGN
albums.description: Gibbs is in full command of his weathered voice and persona, and though its runtime may be short, You Only Live 2wice is a brief showcase of the Indiana rapper at his hardest and most haunting.

albums.title: The Ride
albums.label: Nelstar
albums.description: Nelly Furtado’s exuberant energy elevates her new album. Her flexibility is an asset as she attempts many styles—synth-rock, R&B, and piano balladry among them.

albums.title: Hands in Our Names
albums.label: Orindal
albums.description: On her first full-length, Karima Walker fuses structured folk songs with abstracted sound art to create an uncanny Americana.

albums.title: Star Stuff
albums.label: Company
albums.description: On this collaborative album, Toro Y Moi’s Chaz Bundick teams with twin-brother jazz duo the Mattson 2. The trio swings between lucidity and lunacy and back again.

albums.title: Flowers in the Dirt [Deluxe Edition]
albums.label: Capitol
albums.description: The reissue of his 1989 collaboration with Elvis Costello reveals the art underneath its schlocky gloss. It is also the rarest of things: a McCartney record where you can sense his need to be loved.

albums.title: Kelly Lee Owens
albums.label: Smalltown Supersound
albums.description: The Welsh singer and producer leaves her indie rock past behind and mixes dream pop and ambient techno on her immensely varied and fully-formed debut.

albums.title: It's a Myth
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: Using just a bass and a drum machine, Eva Moolchan's punk is bare and hypnotic. On her first record on Merge, she maintains her raw sound in the powerful space she built for herself.

albums.title: All the Way/At Saint Thomas the Apostle Harlem
albums.label: Intravenal Sound Operations
albums.description: Three and a half decades on, Diamanda Galás still talks about her singing as an act of violence. She shreds the American songbook on two new records, with a restrained version of her deadly approach.

albums.title: Sorcerer
albums.label: Mexican Summer
albums.description: On their 17th album, the White brothers discover where their symbiotic psych rock goes when it has more space, more range, and more fidelity.

albums.title: Number 1 Angel
albums.label: Asylum
albums.description: Produced by PC Music and affiliates, this collection from Charli XCX is presented as a “project” rather than an album or mixtape. It’s largely stolen by its guests, like Uffie and CupcakKe.

albums.title: Feel Infinite
albums.label: LuckyMe
albums.description: The French-Canadian DJ Philippe Aubin-Dionne debuts his long-overdue love letter to the dance floor.

albums.title: Bach: The Goldberg Variations
albums.label: CBS
albums.description: Two virtuosic performances of a Bach composition by the eccentric Canadian pianist brought Baroque music into the modern era. Together, they explore how art and taste evolve through time.

albums.title: Ripe Dreams, Pipe Dreams
albums.label: Anti-
albums.description: Tame Impala bassist Cameron Avery veers away from psych-rock with an album of throwback ballads, a modern twist on the tried and true songwriting of crooners from the ’40s and ’50s.

albums.title: Room 29
albums.label: Deutsche Grammophon
albums.description: For their droll, minimal collaboration, Jarvis Cocker and Chilly Gonzales turn their attention towards a famous hotel but end up with a more philosophical examination of these transient spaces.

albums.title: Where Are We Going?
albums.label: Honey Soundsystem
albums.description: The house producer Maya Bouldry-Morrison, aka Octo Octa, both describes and comforts anxiety. On this new LP, her candied synths and incandescent songs spiral towards infinity.

albums.title: II
albums.label: Flying Nun
albums.description: Vancouver’s the Courtneys capture the shambolic spirt of New Zealand bands like the Clean and write effortlessly catchy songs about heartache and longing.

albums.title: Heroes of the Second Story Walk Up
albums.label: Spring Break Tapes
albums.description: The new album from the ambient baritone guitar and turntable duo is the most fully formed and expressive to date. Its recurring themes and phosphorescent textures evoke an engaging kind of ambiguity.

albums.title: Year of the Snake
albums.label: Tankcrimes
albums.description: On the latest of the Toronto band's experimental zodiac EPs, Fucked Up continue to break and rebuild the definition of hardcore, venturing further out into realms of drone, ambient, and psychedelia.

albums.title: Heartless
albums.label: Profound Lore
albums.description: The deep cauldron of metal, prog, and doom influences have so far been a key to Pallbearer's greatness, but their third record fails to piece it all together. They have run up against their limits.

albums.title: A Crow Looked At Me
albums.label: P.W. Elverum & Sun
albums.description: Phil Elverum lost his wife—an artist and the mother of his child—to cancer. His new album is a meditation on her memory, but also on what it means to keep living.

albums.title: Watercolor
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: On his Sub Pop debut, Seattle rapper Porter Ray unspools wordy verses that delve into personal tragedy, including his brother’s murder.

albums.title: All That Is Solid Melts Into Air
albums.label: NNA Tapes
albums.description: The New York-based composer offers two experimental, evocative pieces featuring cello, viola, and double bass to uniquely recreate and interact with the spaces in which they were recorded.

albums.title: You're Not As _____ As You Think
albums.label: Triple Crown
albums.description: Sorority Noise know brutal honesty can be uncomfortable, but they employ it so well on their latest album, a rafter-reaching emo record about the raw stages of grief and loneliness.

albums.title: We All Want the Same Things
albums.label: Partisan
albums.description: No longer sounding like stripped-down Hold Steady songs, Finn's latest solo album is the accomplished work of a wise songwriter—mournful, musically layered, and full of empathy.

albums.title: Motore Immobile
albums.label: Stranded Rekords
albums.description: What is the difference between American and Italian minimalism? A preeminent example of the latter is this 1979 record, one of the most sumptuous, spiritual ambient albums of any era or provenance.

albums.title: Concrete Desert
albums.label: Ninja Tune
albums.description: This electronic collaboration pairs Dylan Carlson of pioneering drone metal band Earth with UK producer the Bug. It’s one man’s sprawling open space versus another’s sonic claustrophobia.

albums.title: More Life
albums.label: Cash Money
albums.description: Drake's course correction to VIEWS bursts with energy—more South African house, more grime, more Kanye. It's a long player made for luxuriating and a total immersion into Drake's world-pop lifestyle.

albums.title: The Night Land
albums.label: R&S
albums.description: Barcelona’s John Talabot and Stockholm’s Axel Boman work in tandem to bring house music off the floor and into the air with an invigorating and meditative mix of compositions.

albums.title: Find Me Finding You
albums.label: Drag City
albums.description: Like her former band Stereolab, Laetitia Sadier’s new solo album draws on sounds ranging from French yé-yé to krautrock, though its tone is earthier. It features a duet with Hot Chip’s Alexis Taylor.

albums.title: In Mind
albums.label: Domino
albums.description: Martin Courtney's songwriting adjusts to a revamped band lineup, while together they continue to perfect the singular, warm, and reliable Real Estate sound.

albums.title: Trickster
albums.label: Pi
albums.description: The jazz guitarist is more than able to lead both his band and the listener into far-off rhythmic and harmonic places, and crucially finds a way to bring everyone back, too.

albums.title: Samurai
albums.label: Tigersushi
albums.description: The eclectic new album from French DJ and producer Joakim is unified only in its consistent oddity. He avoids conventional song structures, drawing inspiration from new age, funk, and krautrock.

albums.title: Obituary
albums.label: Relapse
albums.description: Floridian death metal veterans Obituary remain a beacon of consistency. This self-titled record is their most energetic effort since reforming in 2003, and it proves their vitality.

albums.title: Damage and Joy
albums.label: ADA
albums.description: Nineteen years after their last album, the Jesus and Mary Chain pick up where they left off, offering their usual mix of feedback-spiked rockers and stoned ballads.

albums.title: Detroit House Guests
albums.label: Mute
albums.description: On their first album in four years, the married electro duo curate a highly collaborative record that is richer and stranger than anything they've done before. It's unusually electrifying.

albums.title: Ultramega OK
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: Originally released in 1988 on SST, Soundgarden’s full-length debut returns in expanded and remixed form on Sub Pop.

albums.title: Doris and the Daggers
albums.label: Domino
albums.description: His voice deeper and his aim truer, Pavement’s Scott Kannberg is at his most confident and mellow as he navigates middle age’s ups and downs.

albums.title: Wailing
albums.label: Jah Guidance
albums.description: As Jamaica stood at a political crossroads in 1980, the Wailing Souls worked with famed engineer Scientist on a magical blend of unearthly dub and traditional songcraft.

albums.title: Bonny Doon
albums.label: Salinas
albums.description: Detroit's Bonny Doon recline deep in the kind of alternative folk music that gives off its own warmth, wise enough to sit back with some guitars and watch the world crumble.

albums.title: Action Painting
albums.label: Numero Group
albums.description: The psychedelic mod band were only around for a few years, but as this Numero compilation overwhelmingly proves, they were as self-aware as the Move, as vicious as the Who, and as clever as the Kinks.

albums.title: Ron Trent Presents - Prescription: Word, Sound & Power
albums.label: Rush Hour
albums.description: Few have taken house music deeper than Ron Trent and his Prescription label, and this new comp gives a moody, silvery snapshot of the label’s mid-’90s heyday.

albums.title: Spirit
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: Spirit is Depeche Mode’s most pointedly topical album, but the synth giants still write universal, stadium-sized music. These songs make you feel like singing in response to today’s headlines.

albums.title: GRID
albums.label: NNA Tapes
albums.description: On this LP from New York noise-jazz trio GRID, saxophonist Matt Nelson—a collaborator on tUnE-yArDs’ w h o k i l l—puts his tones through pedals and electronics to thrilling effect.

albums.title: Offers
albums.label: Grand Jury
albums.description: Chicago's NE-HI come out of the basement for their second album, one that sees the band shaping their wiry garage rock sound for larger stages while still honing their musical personalities.

albums.title: Elektrac
albums.label: Warp
albums.description: Tom Jenkinson of Squarepusher gathers a live band to play fast-and-busy jazz fusion, including versions of some of his early classics. The chops are there, but the broader point is less clear.

albums.title: Paradise EP
albums.label: Secretly Canadian
albums.description: As a musical companion EP to 2016's HOPELESSNES, Anohni makes explicit the connections between gender and ecocide, and asks herself and her audience to recognize complicity and take action.

albums.title: All My Circles Run
albums.label: Students of Decay
albums.description: Ambient composer Sarah Davachi departs from her usual mix of instruments and electronics on an album that (mostly) focuses on the sound of single instruments.

albums.title: Cubafonía
albums.label: Brownswood
albums.description: As an initiate of santería, the Havana-born jazz singer is in tune with her religious and musical practices, as Cubafonía illuminates, pulling from genres within and adjacent to Cuban popular music.

albums.title: Packs
albums.label: Fat Beats
albums.description: Featuring Heems, Danny Brown, and Wiki, the young New York MC 's first official album feels like a graduation, with bars and beats that feel both fresh and lived-in.

albums.title: Hot Thoughts
albums.label: Matador
albums.description: Spoon stay in their well-earned lane but tweak the formula just enough on their ninth album, keeping their reliably great songwriting and adding new, electronic textures.

albums.title: Cascades
albums.label: Arts & Crafts
albums.description: Michael Silver of CFCF teams with pianist Jean-Michel Blais on a sometimes-gorgeous collection of ambient pieces.

albums.title: Opposites
albums.label: Northern Spy
albums.description: Brooklyn trio Parlor Walls subvert the dichotomy between rock and jazz. They approach aggression with an agility that’s rare no matter the style of music.

albums.title: Grava 4
albums.label: Clone Aqualung Series Holland
albums.description: With their unvarnished style, the music of Detroit electronic duo Drexciya was proudly DIY. On their newly reissued 2002 album, they turned their attention from the sea towards the cosmos.

albums.title: The Navigator
albums.label: ATO
albums.description: The band's sixth LP demands more seats at the table. It's a powerful folk concept album from a Nuyorican runaway who grew up obsessed with West Side Story before being liberated by Bikini Kill.

albums.title: Semper Femina
albums.label: More Alarming
albums.description: With Semper Femina, Laura Marling uses a broad study of femininity to explore complex relationships between women. The album is filled with beautiful observations on the psychology of friendship.

albums.title: Time’s Up/Spiral Scratch
albums.label: Domino
albums.description: The Buzzcocks' newly reissued demo Time's Up is an invaluable document of punk snarls and yelps. Likewise, the more polished Spiral* Scratch* was at least as important to punk as the Sex Pistols’ rise.

albums.title: Salutations
albums.label: Nonesuch
albums.description: For Salutations, Conor Oberst rearranged songs from 2016’s Ruminations with a full band and shuffled, expanded tracklist. It’s one of his most demanding albums, and also one of his least ambitious.

albums.title: Love Songs for the Streets
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: The Chicago rapper moves away from his recent commercially-minded exploits and embraces a more mature style of writing.

albums.title: Heartworms
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: Self-produced and recorded, Heartworms is the most hermetic LP James Mercer has released since 2001’s Oh, Inverted World. His gift for making fussy arrangements seem effortless remains unparalleled.

albums.title: Through the Looking Glass
albums.label: Palto Flats
albums.description: The Japanese composer Midori Takada's newly reissued album is an assimilation of musical modes from around the world. It belongs in the pantheon alongside Steve Reich's most notable works.

albums.title: Yours Conditionally
albums.label: Mutually Detrimental
albums.description: On their new album, the duo of Patrick Riley and Alaina Moore continue channeling the retro warmth of ’70s pop. But their lyrics can drip with sarcastic self-effacement, adding bite to their sound.

albums.title: Valley of Grace
albums.label: Backwoodz Studioz
albums.description: The underground New York rapper's noisy, corroded new mixtape is also uniquely attuned to melody and song structure. It's thoughtful, spiritual, and above all, ambitious.

albums.title: Children of Alice
albums.label: Warp
albums.description: The collaboration between members of Broadcast and Focus Group creates lovingly rendered ambiance born of library music and musique concrète, steeped in eeriness and sweetened with wonder.

albums.title: Monk’s Music
albums.label: Riverside
albums.description: Featuring John Coltrane, Art Blakey, and Coleman Hawkins, Monk's Music was the world's introduction to the pianist's most famous songs. It helped define the future of jazz and the mind of Monk.

albums.title: World Eater
albums.label: Sacred Bones
albums.description: Fuck Buttons’ Benjamin John Power shows his teeth on his new LP as Blanck Mass. *World Eater *is suitable for casual noise fans who have some curiosity for extreme music and a decent threshold for pain.

albums.title: Love In a Time of Madness
albums.label: Blue Note
albums.description: On his fourth album for the Blue Note label, James deftly underlines jazz's flexibility in relation to new pop trends, the way Louis Armstrong and Miles Davis did in the past.

albums.title: Rosebudd’s Revenge
albums.label: Marci Enterprises
albums.description: The fourth LP from the tireless, master technician from Long Island stays making the case for Marciano as a vicious, creative, and vastly underrated MC.

albums.title: Tango in the Night
albums.label: Rhino
albums.description: Tango in the Night is the final album the band would record as an infamous quintet. It's a pop and production masterpiece, yet remains this monolithic, lucrative idea of a Fleetwood Mac record.

albums.title: Everybody Works
albums.label: Polyvinyl
albums.description: Melina Duterte's careful, wise, and excellent album is the rare debut that expands the borders of a genre. It's not bedroom-pop because it sounds a certain way, but because it feels so intimate.

albums.title: The Thing OST
albums.label: Waxwork
albums.description: Waxwork Records goes all out with its deluxe vinyl reissue of Ennio Morricone’s minimal score to John Carpenter’s The Thing—a 1982 box-office stiff that has only this century become a horror classic.

albums.label: Asylum
albums.description: Ed Sheeran sells trite innocence by the pound. He uses bland wisdom and unimaginative music to ponder the basic good and bad in people around him, without once looking inward.

albums.title: Steve Lacy’s Demo
albums.label: Three Quarter
albums.description: Made mostly on an iPhone, the first project from 18-year-old producer Steve Lacy—also a member of the Internet—sparkles with classic Southern California funk and soul.

albums.title: The French Press
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: Working from an old, dog-eared indie rock blueprint, this Melbourne trio delight in redrafting the lines. The French Press shines just as bright as their last EP, but the songs cast darker shadows.

albums.title: Born Again
albums.label: Bad Boy
albums.description: The half-baked 1999 release Born Again reeks of a posthumous cash-grab. We look back on its place in the Biggie canon on the 20th anniversary of Christopher Wallace's death.

albums.title: Life After Death
albums.label: Bad Boy
albums.description: Today we commemorate the 20th anniversary of Christopher Wallace's death with a review of his 1997 sophomore album L**ife After Death, released 16 days after he was murdered.

albums.title: No Way Out
albums.label: Bad Boy
albums.description: Puff Daddy's luxurious 1997 debut plays as both a cautionary tale and an affront to mortality. We examine its history on the 20th anniversary of the death of Christopher Wallace.

albums.title: Ready to Die
albums.label: Bad Boy
albums.description: Today we commemorate the 20th anniversary of the death of Christopher Wallace with a review of his 1994 debut Ready to Die, an unparalleled piece of rap history.

albums.title: Atonement
albums.label: Nuclear Blast
albums.description: The new album from New York’s Immolation is a masterclass in death metal songwriting. It pairs a queasy feeling of gloom with melodies you can actually hum along to.

albums.title: Last Place
albums.label: 30th Century
albums.description: A decade after their last album, Grandaddy pick up where they left off, for better and for worse.

albums.title: Either/Or: Expanded Edition
albums.label: Kill Rock Stars
albums.description: The 20th anniversary remaster of Smith's final solo album before his major label debut highlights its inimitable sound and style: a magical, alchemical mix of intimacy and bombast.

albums.title: Moh Lhean
albums.label: Joyful Noise
albums.description: Yoni Wolf's prog-rap project is rejuvenated, and Moh Lhean is a bracing, clear-eyed album that still sounds uniquely like WHY?. It's the most strangely beautiful thing Wolf's made in years.

albums.title: Uyai
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: Led by singer Eno Williams, Uyai becomes a wildly diverse mix of global sounds whose focus this time has turned to themes of liberation, power, and beauty—specifically that of women.

albums.title: Erasmo Carlos E Os Tremendões / Carlos, ERASMO... / Sonhos E Memórias 1941-1972
albums.label: Light in the Attic
albums.description: The Brazilian songwriter Erasmo Carlos remains beloved at home, but he hasn’t been widely heard outside Latin America. These three early ’70s LPs have been given new life thanks to Light in the Attic.

albums.title: ENGLiSH TAPAS
albums.label: Rough Trade
albums.description: On their first full-length for Rough Trade, the clattering duo Sleaford Mods remain bards of a Great Britain that is not in fact great, but sloppy, self-important, and wholly lacking in taste.

albums.title: 50 Song Memoir
albums.label: Nonesuch
albums.description: On this 5-disc musical memoir, Stephin Merritt has penned a song for each of the first 50 years of his life. His writing suggests that our deepest wisdom can be located in our most personal thoughts.

albums.title: Sunrise EP
albums.label: Endotherm
albums.description: The young Swedish house producer DJ Seinfeld applies an opaque dose of irreverence atop every surface of his project. He makes effective club tracks, but his acts of appropriation are dubious.

albums.title: Impermanence
albums.label: Anti-
albums.description: The Antlers singer's proper solo debut* *is the result of physical, mental and emotional therapy—a zen-like journey of a man trying to re-enter his own life.

albums.title: It’s Dark and Hell Is Hot
albums.label: Def Jam
albums.description: The debut album from DMX is the Dante’s Inferno of rap. His infamous stage presence and aggression gave a voice to the voiceless in the streets of New York and overnight changed the course of hip-hop.

albums.title: Machine Response
albums.label: Deranged
albums.description: The latest from Toronto's self-professed hardcore purists animates eleven songs in a style that, what with its limited vocabulary, usually lends itself to sets of four or five.

albums.title: Outro Tempo: Electronic and Contemporary Music From Brazil, 1978-1992
albums.label: Music From Memory
albums.description: This ambitious compilation features wild blends of electronics, jazz fusion, new age drifts, new-fangled digital drum machines, and traditional Brazilian percussion placed into new, curious sounds.

albums.title: Planetary Prince
albums.label: Mack Avenue
albums.description: Cameron Graves, the pianist for Kamasi Washington and a founding member of the West Coast Get Down collective, makes his own searing mark with an enrapturing and assured solo album.

albums.title: The Tourist
albums.label: Undertow
albums.description: With renewed confidence, focus, and contentment, Alec Ounsworth delivers a consistently satisfying Clap Your Hands album, the best since their debut.

albums.title: Youngish American
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: The hapless solo debut from the Vampire Weekend drummer is excruciatingly self-reflexive.

albums.title: HNDRXX
albums.label: Epic
albums.description: Over a well-played hand of wistful, bright-eyed, and reflective beats, HNDRXX strikes a near-perfect balance between a man still licking his wounds and a man emerging from a long, dark night.

albums.title: Hopes of Failure
albums.label: Thrill Jockey
albums.description: The Iowa City doom trio’s latest streamlines their approach. It lacks the subtleties that distinguished their previous work.

albums.title: Buried Wish
albums.label: Northern Spy
albums.description: Scum-rock, psychedelia, and drones collide on the latest full-length from NYC’s PC Worship, but Buried Wish errs towards a more skeletal sound.

albums.title: Headnod Suite
albums.label: Stones Throw
albums.description: After laying out the template for Common's latest album, the drummer/producer offers up another hour-long selection of more than two dozen expertly-made beats that are just waiting to be rapped on.

albums.title: Man Vs. Sofa
albums.label: Tectonic
albums.description: Dub pioneer Adrian Sherwood reteams with dubstep pioneer Rob Ellis (aka Pinch) for a more refined and surprising album that falls just short of its desired concept.

albums.title: The Iceberg
albums.label: Mello Music Group
albums.description: The latest from the D.C. rapper is a focused beam of live-band and hip-hop soul that rattles loudly in our present political moment.

albums.title: Infinite Worlds
albums.label: Father/Daughter
albums.description: On her compact debut, Lætitia Tamko’s inimitable take on DIY indie rock feels victorious. She explores ideas of home, community, and sharing space with others who don’t necessarily see eye to eye.

albums.title: FORGET
albums.label: Polyvinyl
albums.description: The new Xiu Xiu LP consolidates several of the band’s strengths—mixing hooks, cacophony, and stellar production. Individual moments shine, but the album can lull you into a state of absentmindedness.

albums.title: Sick Scenes
albums.label: Wichita
albums.description: The British group’s sixth album is a love note to aging indie idealism and to those who’ve reveled in their careening pop-punk singalongs, scathing neuroses, and charmingly specific soccer references.

albums.title: Why Love Now
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: Co-produced with Lydia Lunch, the new Pissed Jeans LP is the sludge-punk band’s cleanest, most hi-fidelity album, and their deepest dive into the inglorious male psyche yet.

albums.title: Nightmare Logic
albums.label: Southern Lord
albums.description: Power Trip embody a platonic ideal of heavy metal escapism. With more focus on detail, the Dallas thrashers push their second LP over the edge, balancing modern intricacy and old-school aggression.

albums.title: Common as Light and Love Are Red Valleys of Blood
albums.label: Rough Trade
albums.description: Songwriter Mark Kozelek's 130-minute epic is indeed daring and self-reflective, but too often he prides long stretches of bitter humor and anger over the subtlety of his previous work.

albums.title: Gang Signs & Prayer
albums.label: #Merky
albums.description: The debut solo album from the breakout grime MC is a detailed portrait and full-throated riot, switching between clapping back at lesser rappers and serving up smoothed-out Quiet Stormzy.

albums.title: Book of Changes
albums.label: Thrill Jockey
albums.description: On his first Entrance LP in a decade, Guy Blakeslee’s songs are newly exposed and intimate, telling a story of love and loss with folk, pop, and echoes of Laurel Canyon.

albums.title: Burning the Threshold
albums.label: Drag City
albums.description: This new LP from psych-folk guitar hero Ben Chasny is his warmest, most accessible release yet. Its supporting cast of avant-rock all-stars includes Damon & Naomi, Ryley Walker, and Circuit Des Yeux.

albums.title: Skin Companion EP II
albums.label: Mom & Pop
albums.description: The Australian producer built his career on pop accessibility, but his latest EP—featuring Pusha T and Moses Sumney—lacks the spark to make his pop music memorable.

albums.title: Drunk
albums.label: Brainfeeder
albums.description: The third album from bassist/songwriter Thundercat is whimsical and somber, funny and meaningful, sometimes all at once. Drunk's oddball soul confronts the challenge of just trying to live life.

albums.title: The Closer You Get
albums.label: Beggars Banquet
albums.description: The overlooked Brit-rock stars reissue their sophomore album on its 17th anniversary. It’s easy to say underappreciated bands were ahead of their time, but Six by Seven were totally of their time.

albums.title: In Between
albums.label: Bar/None
albums.description: The new Feelies album is both mellow and intense in ways only the New Jersey band can pull off. With the increased use of acoustic guitar, it feels like a spiritual sequel to 1986’s The Good Earth.

albums.title: Rap Album Two
albums.label: The Order Label
albums.description: Finally full of purpose, rapper Jonwayne navigates his own downward spiral, seeking the answer to his most important question: What do you do when rap is both your living and a fuel for your vices?

albums.title: Weezer (Blue Album)
albums.label: DGC
albums.description: Weezer’s 1994 debut, filled with geeky humor, dense cultural references, and positively gargantuan hooks, took alt-rock in a striking new direction.

albums.title: Windy City
albums.label: Capitol
albums.description: Her first solo record since 1999 is mildly ambitious and sounds spectacular, but Windy City is not a great showcase of Allison Krauss' crossover sound.

albums.title: Tears in the Club
albums.label: Fade to Mind
albums.description: Ezra Rubin’s debut LP is an earnest and subdued attempt at making his soulful, ominous, post-club productions agreeable to a general audience.

albums.title: Chalice Hymnal
albums.label: Temporary Residence
albums.description: On the follow-up to 2011’s Deep Politics, the Portland post-rock trio have subtly expanded their approach, building moods of somber reflection, energized optimism, and cathartic release.

albums.title: Flying Microtonal Banana
albums.label: ATO
albums.description: On this sprawling new album, the Australian psych-rock band hoists its freak flag a few inches higher up the pole. It flutters in a more gentle breeze.

albums.title: Dirty Projectors
albums.label: Domino
albums.description: In what is ostensibly a solo record with a few high-profile collaborations, Dave Longstreth masterfully peels away layer after layer of heartbreak across a strange, dizzying pop album.

albums.title: Wild Pink
albums.label: Tiny Engines
albums.description: Mixing mid-fi ’90s influences with elements of slowcore, the Brooklyn trio Wild Pink evoke early Death Cab as they calmly process the chaos of the city around them.

albums.title: Oz Waves: Compiled by Steele Bonus
albums.label: Efficient Space
albums.description: A new comp of charming, peculiar, and strangely timeless Australian DIY music released mostly on cassette-zines in the ‘80s amid the macho pub rock sound of the decade.

albums.title: Crystal Fairy
albums.label: Ipecac
albums.description: Crystal Fairy pits together At the Drive In’s Omar Rodríguez-López, Le Butcherettes’ Teri Gender Bender, and Melvins members Buzz Osborne and Dale Crover. Their sounds prove strikingly complementary.

albums.title: Freedom Highway
albums.label: Nonesuch
albums.description: Rhiannon Giddens emerges as a peerless and powerful voice in roots music on her second solo album, a record that traces the power of African-American song from 200 years ago to today.

albums.title: Saturday Night
albums.label: Jagjaguwar
albums.description: On this unsettled solo album, Ought frontman Tim Darcy slowly dismantles the confessional crooner archetype, transforming himself from singer-songwriter to sound sculptor.

albums.title: Hard Love
albums.label: Dead Oceans
albums.description: The latest Strand of Oaks album has a sunnier outlook and a hedonistic streak, evoking Creation Records bands like Primal Scream and Oasis. But it never really adds up to a bold statement.

albums.title: FUTURE
albums.label: Epic
albums.description: The first of two albums released within seven days of each other, FUTURE is an ambitious Future exhibition, but replicating his brightest moments is often a hit or miss proposition.

albums.title: Her Too EP
albums.label: Top Dawg
albums.description: The Top Dawg label’s latest signee is Inglewood-bred crooner Sir Darryl Farris, aka SiR. His latest EP embraces restraint and subtlety—a pure, 18-minute jolt of traditionalist R&B.

albums.title: Life Will See You Now
albums.label: Secretly Canadian
albums.description: On his fourth album, Jens Lekman opens up in new ways. He narrates the vulnerability of others, works with a producer, and crafts pop songs that absorb disco, calypso, and samba to soften their ache.

albums.title: II
albums.label: Kompakt
albums.description: Danilo Plessow and Marcus Worgull's second full-length ambient project strips away percussion and focuses on the soul and timbre of classic analog synthesizers.

albums.title: The Chief
albums.label: Epic
albums.description: A versatile dandy, Jidenna tries on many different musical styles with his debut album—but all that changing quickly grows tiresome.

albums.title: Occult Architecture Vol. 1
albums.label: Sacred Bones
albums.description: The latest LP from Moon Duo builds on their psychedelic formula—corroded guitars, kraut rhythms, steely grit—and allows them to indulge their most sinister tendencies.

albums.title: Fabric 92
albums.label: Fabric
albums.description: The London DJ born Joseph Richmond Seaton crafts a set that channels Fabric’s late-hours ambience, when things get weird and wooly.

albums.title: No Home of the Mind
albums.label: 4AD
albums.description: On his third proper Bing & Ruth album, and first for 4AD, David Moore’s electroacoustic minimalism carries its strongest emotional tug. It’s his earthiest and most distinctive record yet.

albums.title: Field of Love
albums.label: Arbutus
albums.description: With her second album as Mozart’s Sister, Montreal’s Caila Thompson-Hannant uses aggressively bubbly synth-pop and unhinged vocals to explore the peculiarities of love.

albums.title: An Act of Love
albums.label: Kranky
albums.description: The minimal dub-techno landscapes that Jacob Long makes as Earthen Sea carry a sense of refinement and grace. Each element of his Kranky debut is radiant.

albums.title: Araya EP
albums.label: Dekmantel
albums.description: Fatima Yamaha’s 2004 song “What's a Girl to Do?” made him a cult favorite. Here, on his second release since then, the Dutch producer offers future directions but none as captivating as his start.

albums.title: Reassemblage
albums.label: Rvng Intl.
albums.description: Visible Cloaks’ hard-to-classify ambient music is a fascinating mix of organic and synthetic, past and future.

albums.title: Plata O Plomo
albums.label: EMPIRE
albums.description: Fat Joe and Remy Ma had their biggest hit together in 2004 before last year’s comeback “All the Way Up.” On this collaborative LP, their hard styles are too similar to make for a compelling dynamic.

albums.title: AS TRUTH
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: Electronic music at the moment may not get more gurgling than Amnesia Scanner. The European duo keeps pushing the outer limits of noise and techno further on this excellent new collage of songs.

albums.title: Trans
albums.label: Geffen
albums.description: Neil Young’s polarizing 1982 album, influenced by new wave and heavy on the Vocoder, has long divided fans and critics. But beneath its cold exterior is a record with a lot of heart.

albums.title: Soul Sick
albums.label: Vanguard
albums.description: On her latest LP, Sallie Ford distills her retro rock sound and introduces a confessional lyrical approach. Soul Sick lands somewhere between between a ’50s sock hop and last call in a rockabilly bar.

albums.title: A Pink Sunset For No One
albums.label: Fire
albums.description: This is Sarah Lipstate’s biggest record as Noveller yet. Mixing genres to create her epic version of noise, what it loses in detail it makes up for in grandiosity.

albums.title: Unfold
albums.label: Ideologic Organ
albums.description: Australian improv trio the Necks have condensed their approach on this new double LP for Stephen O’Malley’s label. The experience feels like a ceaseless fever dream.

albums.title: Elwan
albums.label: Epitaph
albums.description: On their latest set, Mali’s Tinariwen ensemble mix Western African styles, feverish group workouts, and world-weary lyrics, collaborating with Kurt Vile and Mark Lanegan in the process.

albums.title: The Painters EP
albums.label: Domino
albums.description: After 2016’s loopy Painting With, Animal Collective return with a companion EP.

albums.title: Alice
albums.label: In the Red
albums.description: Chad Ubovich is already a proven guitar hero, having played in Fuzz and with Mikal Cronin. His second Meatbodies album is a mellower, full-band effort with more psychedelic textures than before.

albums.title: Created in the Image of Suffering
albums.label: Relapse
albums.description: On King Woman’s debut LP, band mastermind Kristina Esfandiari finds her own path to redemption in doom—and it’s enough to inspire new believers outside of metal circles.

albums.title: Selectors 002
albums.label: Dekmantel
albums.description: Amsterdam DJ Young Marco Sterk mixes Buchla experiments with Nintendo-derived dance in his ambitious new mix.

albums.title: Heba
albums.label: Bella Union
albums.description: On their full-length debut, the Danish dream pop group take a quantum leap forward, with a richer and more eclectic sound.

albums.title: Accelerator
albums.label: R&S
albums.description: Following their collaboration on last year’s Atrocity Exhibition, the Accelerator 12” finds Danny Brown and producer Paul White coloring even more brazenly outside of hip-hop’s lines.

albums.title: Daylight Ghosts
albums.label: ECM
albums.description: Jazz piano shredder Craig Taborn is a compositional force on his new quartet album. From the LP’s grand design to its smallest quirks, Taborn and his bandmates make the music gently rage.

albums.title: Now That the Light Is Fading
albums.label: Capitol
albums.description: Following the viral success of her Pharrell-approved hit “Alaska,” this young singer-songwriter searches for an original sound on her major label debut EP.

albums.title: Wildly Idle (Humble Before the Void)
albums.label: Woodsist
albums.description: The debut album by Hand Habits—aka Albany D.I.Y. stalwart Meg Duffy—is a joyous, open-ended study in vulnerability.

albums.title: Being You Is Great, I Wish I Could Be You More Often
albums.label: Mello Music Group
albums.description: Prolific Detroit rapper-producer Quelle Chris offers up his most compelling bout of existential voyaging to date, ultimately catching more than just his own reflection in the mirror.

albums.title: Undying Color
albums.label: Paradise of Bachelors
albums.description: A solo artist gathers some pals for a trippy trip through the droney side of the avant-garde. Good for island meditations and pretending to be weightless.

albums.title: Prisoner
albums.label: Blue Note
albums.description: Ryan Adams’ new album is being positioned as one of his classic breakup records. In terms of its sound, at least, it's a winner.

albums.title: Drip Mental
albums.label: Hausu Mountain
albums.description: As Fire-Toolz, the Chicago experimentalist Angel Marcloid creates an abrasive sonic world: Mundane internet ephemera swirls around in a boiling industrial centrifuge, powered by her fearsome growl.

albums.title: Terrible Human Beings
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: The Orwells recognize the need for a space where the ground rules of Weezer’s “In the Garage” still have merit, where knucklehead behavior is allowed and encouraged, so long as no one gets hurt.

albums.title: Studio One Rocksteady 2: The Soul of Young Jamaica
albums.label: Soul Jazz
albums.description: Drawn from the deep catalog of Jamaica’s legendary Studio One, every song on this new compilation is a bonafide classic, underscoring the connection between spacious rocksteady music and U.S. soul.

albums.title: DROGAS Light
albums.label: 1st and 15th
albums.description: By embracing the detuned bass and dope boy cool of state-of-the-art trap, Lupe Fiasco delivers his most subversive album yet.

albums.title: Africa Airways Three: The Afro-Psych Excursion 1972-1984
albums.label: Africa Seven
albums.description: After two volumes of heavy, straight-up motherland funk, DJ/label curator John Bryan culled Africa Airways 3 from only the sleekest and fastest-burning cuts from mid-’70s West Africa.

albums.title: Memories Are Now
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: Jesca Hoop’s fourth album Memories Are Now sounds like her most complete and refined statement yet, a boisterously declarative album that’s urgent and at times seditious.

albums.title: Celebrate Ornette
albums.label: Song X
albums.description: This new archival set documents an all-star tribute to Ornette Coleman held in 2014—at which the saxophonist gave his last public performance—as well as recordings from his 2015 funeral.

albums.title: Lifestyles of the Laptop Café
albums.label: Warp
albums.description: The only record by Drexciya’s James Stinson as the Other People Place is prescient in imagining our current connected-yet-disconnected state.

albums.title: Bad Timing
albums.label: Drag City
albums.description: Jim O’Rourke’s 1997 album Bad Timing turns his obsessions with Americana into a tangle of deep reverence and exuberant skepticism.

albums.title: Messes
albums.label: Urinal Cake
albums.description: Detroit indie rocker Stef Chura's lowlit, burnished debut Messes showcases her way with setting a twilit mood and her magnetic, mutable voice.

albums.title: It's Good to Be Differ-Ent
albums.label: Don't Be Afraid
albums.description: On It’s Good To Be Differ-Ent, Detroit's Differ-Ent (aka DJ Bone) doubles down on his hometown’s techno legacy, delivering a triple LP that acts as a sort of manifesto.

albums.title: Auto-Reverse
albums.label: Clone Classic Cuts
albums.description: In the late ’90s, two art students in Detroit formed the heavily Kraftwerk-inspired electro/techno group Le Car. This new compilation from Clone Records surveys their curio of a catalog.

albums.title: Blue
albums.label: Fat Possum
albums.description: The Danish rock band Communions offer a familiar sound—vaguely Strokes-y, ’80s-inspired pop rock—but they do it well.

albums.title: Uptown
albums.label: Flenser
albums.description: Trevor de Brauw is the guitarist for the stalwart instrumental rock band Pelican. His solo debut collects six open-ended, marvelously textured guitar instrumentals written during the last decade.

albums.title: Bye Bye Berta
albums.label: Wharf Cat
albums.description: The sound of trio Palberta evokes the post-punk era’s great experimentalists, with overloaded glee and delirious energy. The 20-song *Bye Bye Berta *is their first attempt at doing so longform.

albums.title: Snowdonia
albums.label: Joyful Noise
albums.description: After the death of guitarist Thomas Fekete last year, Surfer Blood return with an album shadowed by grief. Paradoxically, it’s their sunniest and loosest record in years.

albums.title: Obsidian Arc
albums.label: Eisenwald
albums.description: With his new band Pillorian, former Agalloch vocalist/guitarist John Haughm dives more heavily into his former group’s black and dark metal roots. Their furious first album is slightly underwhelming.

albums.title: Little Fictions
albums.label: Polydor
albums.description: Elbow's latest deepens their formula—rich, sweeping rock songs about melancholy and love—with a dreamy sense of loss and time passing.

albums.title: Borders
albums.label: Thrill Jockey
albums.description: The Bristol-based electronic duo Emptyset are in a class by themselves when it comes to excavating brutality out of silence.

albums.title: I Decided.
albums.label: Def Jam
albums.description: I Decided. attempts to bury Big Sean’s wide mean streak and present the 28-year-old in a mature light.

albums.title: The Drum Chord Theory
albums.label: AWAL
albums.description: Matt Martians is the founding member and a driving force behind the band the Internet. His new solo record is full of slack, indolent funk.

albums.title: Fin
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: Syd, the charismatic songwriter and performer at the center of R&B group the Internet, sounds more comfortable and focused than ever on her slinky, confident solo debut.

albums.title: Themes for Dying Earth
albums.label: Flora
albums.description: Responding to harsh realities, Jamison Isaak uses softsynths, guitar amps, and his sensitive way with melody to craft an idyllic space.

albums.title: Life & Livin’ It
albums.label: City Slang
albums.description: The work of London-born, Sudanese artist Ahmed Gallab, aka Sinkane, blends styles including sub-Saharan pop, shoegaze, and afro-rock. More than ever, his new album has the feel of a democratic band.

albums.title: Perishable Tactics
albums.label: Dial
albums.description: Carsten Jost, co-founder of Hamburg's Dial Records, returns with his first proper LP in over a decade. The result is hypnotic, torn between cool remove and encroaching dread.

albums.title: After the Party
albums.label: Epitaph
albums.description: The Menzingers join the “post-30 punk” club, alongside Beach Slang and Japandroids. The first chorus asks “Where we gonna go now that our 20s are over?” and the LP proceeds from there.

albums.title: Backlash
albums.label: Ingrooves
albums.description: Black Joe Lewis trawls the familiar intersection of blues, soul, funk, and garage rock, but he's got a few enlivening strategies to make the old formula feel fresh.

albums.title: Piano Song
albums.label: Thirsty Ear
albums.description: With at least 50 albums over three decades, the jazz pianist Matthew Shipp has honed an inherently diverse and exploratory style. He says Piano Song will be his final recording.

albums.title: Microclimate
albums.label: Volcanic Field
albums.description: On his third full-length as Porcelain Raft, Mauro Remiddi continues to put out sumptuous dreampop that's easy to mistake as style over substance.

albums.title: Phobiza "Noite" Vol. 2
albums.label: Mood Hut
albums.description: On the new EP from Canadian producer Phoebé Guillemot, she presents tracks as travelogues and postcards from strange realms, suggestive of old Ethnic Folkways Library records.

albums.title: T2 Trainspotting: The Original Motion Picture Soundtrack
albums.label: Polydor
albums.description: CHOOSE LIFE. (Again.)

albums.title: The Yunahon Mixtape
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: Jade Lilitri, frontman for Long Island pop/punk outfit Oso Oso, assembles an album-length tribute to ‘00s indie rock and emo, one style and song at a time.

albums.title: Not Even Happiness
albums.label: Ba Da Bing!
albums.description: Singer-songwriter Julie Byrne’s* *new album has the lucidity and tactility of a healing crystal. Not unlike Phil Elverum, she paints sublime, awestruck moments when simple things become overwhelming.

albums.title: Funeral Doom Spiritual
albums.label: Negrogothic
albums.description: In this gripping song cycle, the vocalist-pianist M. Lamar pairs with Liturgy’s Hunter Hunt-Hendrix to explore the tradition of African-American spirituals, mixing ideas from folk, opera, and metal.

albums.title: The Universe and Me
albums.label: Burger
albums.description: Former GBV partner and Robert Pollard creative foil Tobin Sprout offers his reliable blend of lo-fi. At his best, he still proves that simplicity doesn’t equate to half-assery.

albums.title: Happy Together
albums.label: Nicey
albums.description: Mega Bog is the malleable rock band masterminded by multi-instrumentalist Erin Birgy. Happy Together flits through a sound that is familiar and far-out, transforming the mundane into jazzy wonderlands.

albums.title: Homogenic
albums.label: Elektra
albums.description: Homogenic embraced all of Björk’s most provocative contradictions. The main theme is the wish to rush headlong into a life lived to the fullest—an unbridled yearning for the sublime.

albums.title: Bone Music
albums.label: EYRST
albums.description: On this collaborative album with producer Neill Von Tally, Portland via Los Angeles rapper/singer The Last Artful, Dodgr displays her gifts for melody and realism.

albums.title: New Gen
albums.label: XL
albums.description: This 17-track compilation on XL Recordings offers a snapshot of the new generation of London’s rappers, singers, and dancehall kings.

albums.title: Fake Famous
albums.label: Mozzy
albums.description: The hard-bitten and prolific Sacramento rapper Mozzy shifts slightly to accessibility on his first album of 2017. YG, Jadakiss, and G-Eazy are featured.

albums.title: Crossover Ministry
albums.label: Relapse
albums.description: The third full-length from Richmond thrash metal crew Iron Reagan—featuring members of Municipal Waste, Darkest Hour, and Cannabis Corpse—is a compact vehicle for nihilistic escapism.

albums.title: Land of Look Behind
albums.label: Palace of Lights
albums.description: In the ’80s underground, the Pacific Northwest artist Kerry Leimer never fit into any one category or scene. His soundtrack for the 1982 documentary Land of Look Behind could be called ambient reggae.

albums.title: Tourist in This Town
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: Allison Crutchfield’s debut solo LP jettisons punky guitars for pirouetting synths, vast open spaces, and lyrics that explore haunted memories and still-fresh heartache.

albums.title: Process
albums.label: Young Turks
albums.description: After singing with Solange, Drake, Kanye, and Frank, Sampha releases his debut LP. It’s a remarkable, meditative work, as he processes grief and navigates self-discovery.

albums.title: Fresh Air
