albums.label: EMPIRE
albums.description: On a new shared EP, '90s G-funk legend DJ Quik and Problem, a rapper a generation younger, find a breezy, lazy rhythm together.

albums.title: Some Other Time: the Lost Session from the Black Forest
albums.label: Resonance
albums.description: Some Other Time is a newly unearthed Bill Evans studio album, initially recorded in 1968 in Germany but not released until this month. It still sounds fresh and alive almost 50 years later.

albums.title: Waltzed in from the Rumbling
albums.label: Secret City
albums.description: Plants and Animals may not have made their most original album with Waltzed in from the Rumbling, but they have definitely made their most beautiful one.

albums.title: Lost Themes II
albums.label: Sacred Bones
albums.description: The legendary filmmaker and soundtrack composer John Carpenter began releasing standalone albums last year with Lost Themes. The followup is a reminder that the man was not known for sequels.

albums.title: It Kindly Stopped for Me
albums.label: Topshelf
albums.description: Sorority Noise's hushed, brief EP is a four-song cycle about grief and loss, narrated from the perspectives of both the departed and those left behind.

albums.title: Konono N°1 Meets Batida
albums.label: Crammed Discs
albums.description: The Congolese ensemble pairs with the Angolan-born producer Batida, and their best moments resemble a Ferris wheel spinning off its moorings, letting grooves careen and rumble as they might.

albums.title: The Future of Death
albums.label: Party Smasher Inc.
albums.description: The Brooklyn quartet Primitive Weapons blend the all-out assault of hardcore with dexterity and melody, striking a balance of brains, brawn, and heart.

albums.title: Blood Visions
albums.label: Fat Possum
albums.description: Jay Reatard was the kingpin of Memphis garage rock, and his best and most powerful full-length work—the record that made him a standalone rock star—was his first solo album.

albums.title: Please Be Honest
albums.label: Rockathon
albums.description: On the 23rd album to bear the Guided By Voices name, the ageless and indefatigable Robert Pollard wrote every track and played every instrument himself.

albums.title: Yoyogi Park
albums.label: Mule Musiq
albums.description: A wonderful, dreamy record of techno music that invites you to float freely in the time between late night and early morning. A perfect soundtrack for getting lost.

albums.title: Tower of Meaning
albums.label: Audika
albums.description: The minimalist classical Tower of Meaning is the greatest outlier in Arthur Russell's recorded catalogue: the most uncharacteristic one-off project in a career that is full of them.

albums.title: Phases
albums.label: Manifesto
albums.description: Cellars is the synth-pop project of Allene Norton. Her second album, produced by Ariel Pink, sounds zapped straight from the sepia-toned dance floor of a long-forgotten high school prom.

albums.title: Music of Morocco: Recorded by Paul Bowles, 1959
albums.label: Dust-to-Digital
albums.description: This 4-disc box set, curated by legendary Beat Generation composer and writer Paul Bowles, offers an eye-opening and immersive introduction to Moroccan music.

albums.title: BIS: 001-020
albums.label: Beats in Space
albums.description: BIS: 001-020 collects a track from each release on Tim Sweeney's Beats in Space label, making for a  groovy, lightly psychedelic compilation that might sound best at a deck party, or the beach.

albums.title: The Diary
albums.label: Mass Appeal
albums.description: Just like any diamond unearthed after many years, J Dilla's long-lost solo album The Diary is flawed, but still precious.

albums.title: Flutes, Echoes, It's All Happening!
albums.label: Leaving
albums.description: Carlos Niño's music charts an invisible continent where hippy jazz meets new age music and underground hip-hop meets airy, Laurel Canyon-style folk.

albums.title: 印象III : なんとなく、パブロ (Imagining “The Life of Pablo”)
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: Toyomu is a Kyoto-based producer who assembled his own version of Kanye West's The Life of Pablo from online sources like Genius and WhoSampled when he couldn't stream it.

albums.title: Become Alive
albums.label: Other People
albums.description: Before he became Nicolas Jaar’s foil in the electro-noir duo Darkside, guitarist Dave Harrington was immersed in the jazz world. Become Alive finds him circling back to his improv roots.

albums.title: A Sailor's Guide to Earth
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: Progressive country's lead tastemaker changes his path again. A Sailor's Guide to Earth finds Sturgill Simpson weirder and more adventurous than ever, forging a bold new way forward.

albums.title: Blind Spot EP
albums.label: Edamame
albums.description: Given all the recent shoegaze reunions—My Bloody Valentine, Slowdive—it makes sense Lush would make a comeback. Rather than simply embark on a nostalgia tour, Lush recorded this 4-song EP.

albums.title: Missed Calls
albums.label: Bad Habit
albums.description: Tunji Ige, a 20-year-old Philadelphian son of Nigerian parents, makes appealingly low-stakes rap that accomplishes a lot with a little.

albums.title: Welcome the Worms
albums.label: Dead Oceans
albums.description: L.A.-based quartet Bleached carve out a new identity on their latest, fast-forwaring past '60s revivalism into jagged and precise '70s rock edge.

albums.title: Sleep Cycle
albums.label: My Animal Home
albums.description: Josh "Deakin" Dibb's  Sleep Cycle is a short album but a substantial one, a deeply personal work that takes us inside the mind of Animal Collective’s most mysterious member.

albums.title: Don't Look Down
albums.label: Mello Music Group
albums.description: After a seven-year absence from rap, Mr. Lif returns with a sharp technical marvel of an album, and a meditation on all that’s brought him here.

albums.title: Love Letter for Fire
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: This slow-burning collaborative album from Jesca Hoop and Iron & Wine's Sam Beam recalls healing summer storms more than destructive blazes.

albums.title: YYY EP
albums.label: Arjunamusic
albums.description: YYY is a collaboration between the minimalist techno of Tyler Friedman and the improvised jazz drumming of Samuel Rohrer, split across two long, flowing tracks.

albums.title: Singing Saw
albums.label: Dead Oceans
albums.description: Kevin Morby (Woods, Babies) recalls singer/songwriters of the '60s and '70s in his solo work, particularly Bob Dylan and Leonard Cohen, and Singing Saw is his strongest album.

albums.title: Crab Day
albums.label: Drag City
albums.description: On her fourth album, the Welsh singer Cate Le Bon establishes a strange, almost Dadaist lyrical scheme to make sense of some unnamed life rupture that's left her gasping.

albums.title: Sorrow - A Reimagining of Gorecki's 3rd Symphony
albums.label: 52Hz
albums.description: Avant-garde saxophonist Colin Stetson's reimagining of the famous symphony by the Polish composer Henryk Gorecki comes close to something by Explosions in the Sky or Godspeed You! Black Emperor.

albums.title: Layers
albums.label: Bad Half Entertainment
albums.description: Royce 5’9” has done his most visible rapping as a plus-one. Trying to move beyond that supporting role, he loads his sixth solo album with big-time producers, skits, and careful introspection.

albums.title: Controlling Body
albums.label: Peder Mannerfelt Produktion
albums.description: The Swedish electronic musician Peder Mannerfelt, who has  produced groups like Fever Ray and Blonde Redhead, evokes a gothic energy in his own music. In his hands, electronic music's habitual futurism looks a lot more like horror.

albums.title: Fever Dream
albums.label: Caroline
albums.description: Ben Watt's third solo album finds the Everything But the Girl co-founder continuing to explore his reignited love for live instrumentation.

albums.title: Plays the Music of Twin Peaks
albums.label: Polyvinyl / Bella Union
albums.description: Xiu Xiu's tribute to the music of Twin Peaks is one of their most haunting and beautiful LPs in years.

albums.title: The Hope Six Demolition Project
albums.label: Island
albums.description: On a fascinating and flawed new album, PJ Harvey yokes the siren-like catchiness of her last great America-influenced album, Stories From the City… to the swamp-tarnished filth of her classic first three records.

albums.title: Year of the Rabbit
albums.label: Double Double Whammy
albums.description: Following on the heels of last year's O.K., the indie-pop outfit Eskimeaux releases a sweet little gem of an EP, fraught with indecision and insecurity.

albums.title: Commitment to Complications
albums.label: Dais Records
albums.description: Commitment to Complications strikes the ideal balance between the visceral nature of the  innovative L.A. hardcore group Youth Code's demo and the polish in their work since then.

albums.title: Outer Heaven
albums.label: Carpark
albums.description: The ferocious noise-punk quartet Greys redirects indie rock's inward gaze back out into the wider world.

albums.title: Everybody's Heart Is Broken Now
albums.label: Interscope
albums.description: Niki and the Dove's Malin Dahlström has one of the most fantastic voices in pop, and on their new LP she whirls herself into a frenzy to nip malignant growths like heartache and hate in the bud.

albums.title: Nat Love
albums.label: Closed Sessions
albums.description: On his new LP, Nat Love, rapper/singer/producer Kweku Collins offers intimate, hip-hop-informed bohemian rhapsodies.

albums.title: Kill 'Em All/Ride the Lightning
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: In a monumental one-two punch, Metallica set the blueprint for thrash metal and then gave the genre its worldview with its first two records—reissued in deluxe sets that feature alternate mixes, demos, and live shows.

albums.title: Ology
albums.label: Mind of a Genius
albums.description: Singer/songwriter Gallant's weightless voice channels ’80s and ’90s R&B, channeling the feeling of those eras without taking too much from them. On Ology, he’s coming to grips with all the struggle he’s endured, assessing himself through a mix of candor and ambiguity.

albums.title: Standards
albums.label: Triple Crown
albums.description: Standards is Evan Weiss’ first Into It. Over It. album since he's turned 30. Often the eleoquent spokesperson for the emo revival, on Standards he banks on subtlety—as good a way as any to distinguish yourself in a scene defined by overstatement.

albums.title: EARS
albums.label: Western Vinyl
albums.description: EARS, the rich and rewarding new album from composer Kaitlyn Aurelia Smith, is hard-to-pin-down music for the spaces in-between. In her hands, acoustic instruments sound like electronic ones, synthetic sounds reference nature, and human voices sound like the creation of machines.

albums.title: Gore
albums.label: Warner Bros.
albums.description: Gore is easily Deftones’ most engaging record since White Pony, filled with carefully crafted hooks disguised as bridges and transition. As with all of their best music, it sounds like the brutal, beautiful result of the band being passionate enough to rip each other’s heads off.

albums.title: Psychic Lovers
albums.label: Captured Tracks
albums.description: Singer/songwriter and producer Anders Rhedin is a former member of Choir of Young Believers, has written pop songs for Kid Cudi and Josh Groban, and has toured with Mac DeMarco under the Dinner alias. On his Captured Tracks debut, he offers a darkly deadpan take on ’80s synth-pop like the Simple Minds or Psychedelic Furs.

albums.title: Junk
albums.label: Mute
albums.description: The new M83 album almost makes you wonder: How much can you mine vintage sounds without them finally falling apart?

albums.title: Afterlife
albums.label: Teklife
albums.description: Afterlife compiles fifteen of DJ Rashad's previously unreleased collaborations. They match the mood and fervor you want from a Rashad track quite often, but it is hard to ignore their skeletal and fragmentary nature.

albums.title: More Issues Than Vogue
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: Now best known as a reality star from "Love & Hip Hop," K. Michelle proves on her new release she's more than just two dimensional. More Issues Than Vogue is contemporary R&B at its best.

albums.title: Azel
albums.label: Partisan
albums.description: Produced by Dirty Projectors leader Dave Longstreth, the virtuosic Saharan guitarist Bombino’s latest album features a sublime iteration of desert blues that’s both authentic and ambitious.

albums.title: Painting of a Panic Attack
albums.label: Canvasback / Atlantic
albums.description: Formed in 2003, Frightened Rabbit established their reputation with ramshackle anthems of heartbreak and hangovers. With the National's Aaron Dessner behind the boards, their newest is more a sensible repositioning than a reinvention.

albums.title: Atomic
albums.label: Rock Action
albums.description: Mogwai's latest full-length is technically a soundtrack, featuring reworked material from their musical contributions to a BBC 4 documentary on the atomic age.

albums.title: Djungelns Lag/Mors Mors/Kom Tillsammans
albums.label: Anthology Recordings
albums.description: The music of ’70s Swedish group Träd, Gräs och Stenar (Trees, Grass, and Stones) emerged from a chemical reaction between two basic elements: rock'n'roll and Terry Riley.

albums.title: Velvet Portraits
albums.label: Ropeadope
albums.description: Multi-instrumentalist Terrace Martin was a binding agent for Kendrick Lamar's last two releases; Velvet Portraits pulls in R&B and G-funk while paying homage to his native L.A.

albums.title: Lost Time
albums.label: Hardly Art
albums.description: Tacocat's third album loses some of the brightness that helped make their pointed cultural critiques sound so impossibly fun.

albums.title: Human Performance
albums.label: Rough Trade
albums.description: Parquet Courts' third album is a bracing snapshot of a band on a roll. Their music is not explicitly political, but Parquet Courts are definitely a thinking band, and a critical one.

albums.title: Love Streams
albums.label: 4AD
albums.description: Love Streams marks a subtle shift in Tim Hecker's habitual style, a pivot away from his hazy trademark.

albums.title: Interview 2016
albums.label: Third Worlds
albums.description: Interview 2016, another strange between-album release from Death Grips, is an intense instrumental EP that showcases the production chops of Zach Hill and Andy Morin.

albums.title: Further / Chorus
albums.label: Drag City
albums.description: Bristol's Flying Saucer Attack were a murky and beloved cult band that mixed shoegaze guitars with the drifting throb of krautrock to create extreme feelings of isolation and alienation. These albums, now reissued on vinyl by Drag City, find them at the moment in the mid-'90s when their sound hit its stride.

albums.title: City Sun Eater in the River of Light
albums.label: Woodsist
albums.description: After eight albums of solid if predictable psych-folk, Woods shake up their pastoral sound a bit, introducing notes of reggae and African jazz.

albums.title: Twenty88
albums.label: Def Jam
albums.description: Twenty88 is the chosen name of the duo of rapper Big Sean and R&B singer Jhené Aiko. As a pair, they complement each other well, and the battle-of-the-sexes theme manages to work on the strength of their chemistry.

albums.title: Halfaxa
albums.label: Artbus Records
albums.description: Claire Boucher's early experimentations were a far cry from the music she makes today. Halfaxa, 15 ethereal tracks in which her vocals approached pure glossolalia, is Grimes at her most mystical.

albums.title: I AKA I
albums.label: Ninja Tune
albums.description: Tehran-via-London artist Ashkan Kooshanejad works by breaking down samples into unrecognizable blips of sound, and then layering them up into thickets of melody and rhythm.

albums.title: Are You Serious
albums.label: Loma Vista
albums.description: Andrew Bird's latest release is his third album of pop originals since getting married and having a son, and a happy domesticity informs it.

albums.title: It's the Big Joyous Celebration
albums.label: Run for Cover
albums.description: Teen Suicide is the old band of Sam Ray, whose other projects include Ricky Eat Acid and Julia Brown. He resurrected the band for a 26-track blowout of an album that is constantly absorbing and equal parts astonishing and frustrating.

albums.title: Old Locks and Irregular Verbs
albums.label: Pi Recordings
albums.description: The veteran avant-garde jazz saxophonist and composer Henry Threadgill collaborates with pianist Jason Moran on his latest. The project offers plenty of room for twisty, adventurous solos, while also feeling like a tight 47 minutes.

albums.title: Amen & Goodbye
albums.label: Mute
albums.description: Yeasayer's latest is an ambitious psychedelic quasi-concept record that is refreshingly (sometimes bizarrely) out-of-step with current trends, occasionally baffling, but mostly unsuccessful.

albums.title: Patch the Sky
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: Bob Mould is at his best when he’s articulating anger at a high volume. His newest solo album, Patch the Sky, succeeds largely because these furious songs sound as if they're hardwired to raw nerves.

albums.title: Pussy's Dead
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: Autolux's third album is produced by Boots, and features a performance that permanently places Carla Azar amongst the pantheon of great American rock drummers.

albums.title: Everything You've Come to Expect
albums.label: Domino
albums.description: The long-awaited second album from the Last Shadow Puppets  is a lavish California confection, with strings by Owen Pallett. Like Zayn Malik's Mind of Mine, it makes very clear that frontmen Alex Turner and Miles Kane are sexy men with sexy lives having lots of sexy sex with their sexy girlfriends.

albums.title: Sept. 5th
albums.label: Warner Bros.
albums.description: On their debut album, the elusive R&B act signed to Drake's OVO Sound treats sex not as a social transaction but a serious act—something that can make you see things that aren't there, that can be a balm for life's rough edges, that can show you the worth of looking beyond yourself.

albums.title: All Empires Fall
albums.label: Relapse
albums.description: The Brooklyn metal band Tombs have shifted their lineup repeatedly while maintaining an eerie consistency—the group hasn’t released a bad record. Their new EP is capable of making you think of Unsane, Darkthrone, and Bauhaus in the same song.

albums.title: Rojus
albums.label: Running Back
albums.description: The British house producer Leon Vynehall's new album continues in the vein of 2014's mini-LP Music for the Uninvited, but it boasts a bigger sound in almost every way, with more layers, bolder basslines, and harder-edged drums.

albums.title: Super
albums.label: x2
albums.description: The Pet Shop Boys have persisted long enough that their return to club music feels calmly liberated, without any grasping for pop hits. On their latest, Super, they recall their own past with trademark arch wit.

albums.title: The Follower
albums.label: Kompakt
albums.description: The Field's Axel Willner is among electronic music's most doggedly consistent musicians.  Virtually all of his songs are built atop techno's steady pulse, but they share ambient music's domestic utility: If Satie's "furniture music" was meant to decorate rooms, the Field's music is the room.

albums.title: Silicon Tare EP
albums.label: Ghostly International
albums.description: L.A. producer  Seth Haley remains devoted to spacey slow-funk synth excursions with a whiff of ’80s nostalgia.

albums.title: The Rebellion Sessions
albums.label: Computer Ugly
albums.description: Veteran rapper/producer Black Milk teams up with D.C.-based live band Nat Turner for his latest release, a raw and unhindered affair that brings to mind organic hip-hop experimenters like Dilla and A Tribe Called Quest.

albums.title: Eric Bachmann
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: The Archers of Loaf frontman's first new album in five years finds Bachmann getting a tighter grip on who he is as a human and as an artist, and more deeply appreciating his past and the influences that got him to this point.

albums.title: Next Thing
albums.label: Bayonet
albums.description: Frankie Cosmos is the low-key indie pop project of Greta Kline. Her greatest talent is her ability to transform short songs into experiences that resemble hours of impressionistic conversation.

albums.title: N/A
albums.label: On-U Sound
albums.description: The Japanese avant-rock trio pair on their latest release with famous dub producer Adrian Sherwood, whose mixing-desk manipulations blow the trio's sound wide open.

albums.title: Fleeting
albums.label: Thrill Jockey
albums.description: For the last decade, Glenn Jones has taken a craftsperson's approach to the guitar and the banjo, issuing a sterling but rarely surprising string of records that find him telling stories and sharing vulnerabilities sans bells or whistles, his voice or his band. Fleeting, his latest, feels familiar, comfortable, welcome.

albums.title: IV
albums.label: Jagjaguwar
albums.description: The fourth album from Vancouver hard rock band Black Mountain rolls everything up the band has ever done—the heavy riffs, the prog ambitions, and the pop smarts—into an alternate-universe version of classic-rock history.

albums.title: Slay-Z
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: Slay-Z, Azealia Banks' latest EP, features production from the likes of Kaytranada and collaborations with Rick Ross and Nina Sky. It is not as hard-hitting as her debut Broke With Expensive Taste, but it still shimmers with her undeniable skill and personality.

albums.title: Three Men and a Baby
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: Mike and the Melvins is an unearthed collaboration from 1999 between the Melvins and godheadSilo bassist and vocalist Mike Kunka. The overall sensation it gives is of a bunch of guys engaging in playful, sophomoric misanthropy.

albums.title: Changes
albums.label: Daptone
albums.description: The 67-year-old soul singer's third album on Daptone feels like his most straightforward and best to date.

albums.title: Volume, Contrast, Brilliance... Unreleased & Rare Vol. 2
albums.label: Tapete
albums.description: The Monochrome Set arose from the late '70s British punk scene, and their records helped inspire the Smiths. They have a remarkably low profile in the U.S., but this collection of delightful demos, a sequel to a first batch in the '80s, highlights their dry whimsy and melodic ingenuity.

albums.title: Slime Season 3
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: The final installment of Young Thug's Slime Season trilogy is a lean, 8-track offering without filler that moves rather seamlessly. It also feels like the end of a holding pattern, hopefully leading to Thug's long-rumored official debut.

albums.title: Living Life Golden
albums.label: Record Company TEN
albums.description: The new album from Ellinor Olovsdotter, the Swedish one-woman outfit known as Elliphant, finds a happy middle ground that ditches the more hard-edged dancehall sound present on her early EPs for a sun-flecked, light reggae tone. Featuring guest spots from Azealia Banks, Twin Shadow, Skrillex, and others.

albums.title: Weezer (White Album)
albums.label: Crush
albums.description: Weezer's fourth self-titled record, trumpeted as a return to form just like 2014's Everything Will Be All Right in the End, is also their first concept album since Pinkerton.

albums.title: Empire Builder
albums.label: Barsuk
albums.description: Working with Neko Case drummer Dan Hunt, violinist Peter Broderick, and Death Cab for Cutie guitarist Dave Depper, singer/songwriter Laura Gibson sounds newly invigorated, resulting in her best record to date.

albums.title: A Mineral Love
albums.label: Warp
albums.description: Bibio's collage and pastiche-based music is hard to pin down, but his latest beams with a relaxed joyfulness that is refreshing after a spate of more laborious records.

albums.title: Psychopomp
albums.label: Yellow K
albums.description: Michelle Zauner is the guitarist and singer for the underrated Philadelphia indie rock band Little Big League. After her mother was diagnosed with cancer, she returned home to Oregon; while she was there, she revamped songs from her previous lo-fi releases under the name Japanese Breakfast.

albums.title: Venis
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: On his new nine-song EP Venis, the Drake-cosigned Toronto singer Ramriddlz displays all the poise of a nerdy kid brother learning how not to speak to women, one spectacular embarrassment at a time.

albums.title: Mind of Mine
albums.label: RCA
albums.description: Lacking compelling hooks, a unifying mood, or a clear narrative, former One Direction member Zayn's debut Mind of Mine is a definitive step away from One Direction towards nowhere in particular.

albums.title: III (Moderat)
albums.label: Mute
albums.description: Apparat and Modeselektor's third album as Moderat absorbs a dark spectrum of postminimal electronic music—James Blake, Burial, The xx, Four Tet—and reflects it into spare, crystal-clear electronic soul.

albums.title: The Terminator OST
albums.label: Milan
albums.description: The 1984 film The Terminator's vision of humanity crushed by a malign artificial intelligence was backed up by a Brad Fiedel score that not just dramatized but echoed that sense of a machine army in the ascendant. This remastered reissue is lavishly presented across two slabs of 180g red-and-blue spattered vinyl.

albums.title: Wuthering Drum
albums.label: Felte
albums.description: Despite a crowded field, Public Memory's Robert Toher mostly succeeds in creating a dark electronic landscape that is his own—and slightly claustrophobic at that.

albums.title: Dame Fortune
albums.label: RJ's Electrical Connections
albums.description: Much like the producer’s former offerings, Dame Fortune tries to be everything all at once, making for a good listen with occasional lapses.

albums.title: Genesis
albums.label: Odd Future
albums.description: The underrated Odd Future member Domo Genesis' debut is the culmination of his years of consistency, the result of existing on the fringes of his friends’ fame and trying to earn his keep.

albums.title: The Wilderness
albums.label: Temporary Residence
albums.description: Explosions in the Sky's sixth album,  their best since 2003's The Earth is Not a Cold Dead Place, is a quietly masterful, emotionally rich work.

albums.title: 3 Compositions (EEMHM) 2011/Trillium J: The Non-Unconfessionables No. 380/Quintet (Tristano) 2014
albums.label: Firehouse 12
albums.description: The legendary modern jazz composer and multi-instrumentalist Anthony Braxton has released more than one hundred albums in his career. For those looking for an entry point, he recently released several box sets highlighting his charming, insightful approach to the avant-garde.

albums.title: Kouen Kyoudai
albums.label: Editions Mego
albums.description: A collaboration between noise icon Masami Akita—aka Merzbow—and drummer/pianist Eiko Ishibashi, Kouen Kyoudai is long on pretentious theory but short on fresh musical ideas.

albums.title: Genius of Time
albums.label: EMI
albums.description: The twenty-two tracks on this definitive best-of compilation capture the slippery, pliant, ecstatic sound that defined Larry Levan as a producer, DJ and high priest for a club night deemed "Saturday Mass" by its attendees.

albums.title: BBF Hosted by DJ Escrow
albums.label: Hyperdub
albums.description: Babyfather is the name of the latest project by the elusive British musician Dean Blunt. It is a painfully raw, emotionally generous, politically charged, intensely intelligent, sometimes unlistenable album.

albums.title: Scenes 2012-2015
albums.label: Lustwerk Music
albums.description: This project's generic-sounding alias obscures the fact that it is a collaboration between Alvin Aronson and Galcher Lustwerk. Their combined sensibilities yield a sumptuous techno LP. These are not so much songs as spatial fields: You enter and walk around, admiring the ingenious architecture.

albums.title: Slow Forever
albums.label: Profound Lore
albums.description: After replacing their lead singer, the reborn metal duo Cobalt make their best-ever record, as accessible as it is aggressive, with magnetic hooks, shout-along mantras, and sparkling riffs.

albums.title: A Good Night in the Ghetto
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: Kamaiyah’s debut mixtape lightly recalls the rap and R&B of the ’90s, but her approachable and assured presence is all her own.

albums.title: I'm a Piece of Shit
albums.label: Awful
albums.description: Father's I'm A Piece of Shit finds the Awful Records head trying to forswear his debauched lifestyle, reckoning with the morning after way too many morning afters.

albums.title: Midwest Farmer's Daughter
albums.label: Third Man
albums.description: Margo Price is a country singer signed to Jack White's Third Man Records. On her highly buzzed debut, she emerges as a woman struggling to reclaim her story from the Nashville machine and reset it in old-school honky-tonk tunes.

albums.title: We Disappear
albums.label: Saddle Creek
albums.description: After two albums that struggled with the growing divide between the serious band they seemingly longed to be and the bubblegum punk band listeners want them to be, The Thermals strike the right balance on We Disappear, an album that manages to satisfy both camps.

albums.title: AS EP
albums.label: Young Turks
albums.description: The Berlin duo Amnesia Scanner make electronic music that feels both organic and alienatingly futuristic.  Even at its most mordant, AS somehow remains accessible and exciting, uncomfortable music you can dance to.

albums.title: Crucial EP
albums.label: Ghostly
albums.description: Crucial marks the debut solo release from Bryndon Cook, a guitarist who's toured with Solange, Dev Hynes, Chairlift and Kindness. He's a student of pop history and a skilled musician, though not yet a great songwriter.

albums.title: Thug Talk
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: After a scary bout with cancer, Boosie Badazz has a new lease on life and is releasing new music at a steady clip. Thug Talk is another hard memorandum on the turmoil of gangsta life.

albums.title: Vroom Vroom EP
albums.label: Vroom Vroom Recordings
albums.description: Produced entirely by PC Music's Sophie, Charli XCX's Vroom Vroom EP is pointedly uncommercial and abrasive.

albums.title: Aa
albums.label: LuckyMe
albums.description: After surviving his runaway viral hit "Harlem Shake," Baauer returns with a full-length on which appearances by Future, Pusha T, M.I.A. and others function like power-ups, allowing the album to ratchet up in excitement.

albums.title: A Cosmic Rhythm With Each Stroke
albums.label: ECM
albums.description: Trumpeter Wadada Leo Smith crafts a late-career highlight with pianist Vijay Iyer. Cosmic Rhythm is a frequently gorgeous, sometimes-roiling set that plays to both musicians' strengths.

albums.title: Hitch
albums.label: Caroline
albums.description: Fire still comes easy to the Joy Formidable, but Hitch is the first time they've seemed at a loss for how to use it.

albums.title: Drink More Water 6
albums.label: Warner Bros.
albums.description: iLoveMakonnen's latest falls uncertainly somewhere between mixtape and album, flipping between his established styles. All of the Makonnen sounds are here, but they are a little thinner, and more grating.

albums.title: Grapefruit
albums.label: Moshi Moshi
albums.description: Grapefruit is by turns astounding, accomplished and difficult to digest, an album shouldering ambitions so big that you fear that at any point it might give way at the knees.

albums.title: Good Grief
albums.label: Mom & Pop
albums.description: The Brooklyn band Lucius has been a stylish presence on the tour and festival circuit for the past few years. The quintet's sophomore album sounds like everything at once but nothing in particular.

albums.title: One Day You Will Ache Like I Ache
albums.label: Neurot
albums.description: Bearing a title culled from one of Courtney Love's most famously vindictive proclamations, One Day You Will Ache Like I Ache is a document of the overwhelming power of depression.

albums.title: Trekkie Trax the Best 2012 - 2015
albums.label: Trekkie Trax
albums.description: This collection compiles some of the EDM-oriented netlabel's finest cuts, and serves as a great introduction to one of Japan’s best outfits bubbling up from the Internet.

albums.title: Talk Tight
albums.label: Ivy League
albums.description: This Melbourne band alternates the pop literacy of the Go-Betweens and the rambunctious energy of the Easybeats with the roaring punk propulsion of Royal Headache.

albums.title: Gensho
albums.label: Relapse
albums.description: The latest collaboration between the heavy psych-rock mavens and the master of noise music consists of two separate CDs meant to be played simultaneously.

albums.title: Hella Personal Film Festival
albums.label: Mello Music Group
albums.description: The rapper's collaborative album with British producer Paul White finds them both in fine form, with Eagle's peculiar sense of storytelling fitting perfectly with White's ’70s-inspired beats.

albums.title: This Is What the Truth Feels Like
albums.label: Interscope
albums.description: Gwen Stefani's first solo album in a decade finds her keeping up with new pop sounds while writing from a new perspective: the quintessential divorcee, fresh off a messy split.

albums.title: Wolves of Want
albums.label: Slumberland
albums.description: On the punky indie-pop band's sharp sophomore album, singer/songwriter Ben Potrykus casts himself as an unlikable blowhard, and gets away with it in part because Bent Shapes' music is so inherently likable.

albums.title: Up to Anything
albums.label: Chapter Music
albums.description: The Goon Sax are a teenage indie-pop group from Brisbane. The best moments on their debut are as clever as they are sad, a dynamic frontman Louis Forster perhaps inherited from his father Robert Forster, one-half of the songwriting duo behind The Go-Betweens.

albums.title: Compassion
albums.label: Sacred Bones
albums.description: Lust For Youth have spent the last six years refining lo-fi darkwave into club-ready synth-pop. Compassion is the end product of that evolution, a once rough stone polished into a lustrous crystal.

albums.title: The Great Destroyer
albums.label: Relapse
albums.description: On their third full-length in 10 years, Swedish grindcore outfit Gadget sustain a blistering pace, while their lyrics implicitly critique the sociopolitical mores of their home country.

albums.title: Epic Jammers and Fortunate Little Ditties
albums.label: Drag City
albums.description: Epic Jammers and Fortunate Little Ditties is a jam session—an improvisational democracy where everyone has equal footing—between Bonnie "Prince" Billy and Bitchin Bajas.

albums.title: The Rarity of Experience
albums.artist: Chris Forsyth and the Solar Motel Band
albums.label: No Quarter
albums.description: Solar Motel Band leader Chris Forsyth strikes a near-perfect balance between ’70s rock tradition and present-day experimentation with his signature guitar tone.

albums.title: Full Circle
albums.label: Matador
albums.description: London's HÆLOS bring to mind a host of ’90s influences, from trip-hop to shoegaze, but they are able to channel the best parts of those early bands in a way that reflects the present moment.

albums.title: Chaosmosis
albums.label: First International
albums.description: At a time when the remaining bands of their vintage are locked into the album-retrospective tour circuit or releasing pro-forma records, Primal Scream’s 11th full-length sees them keeping pace with 21st-century pop, recruiting guests like Sky Ferreira and Haim.

albums.title: Lil Boat
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: This Atlanta rapper with a cult hit under his belt ("1 Night") brings to mind iLoveMakonnen. He inhabits a post-regionalist rap universe, a space defined by digital platforms rather than geography.

albums.title: Wayfaring Strangers: Cosmic American Music
albums.label: Numero Group
albums.description: The latest edition of Numero Group’s Wayfaring Strangers compilation series highlights forgotten artists who played a strain of country music in the early ’70s that mixed psychedelic rock with rootsy twanging.

albums.title: You and I
albums.label: Columbia
albums.description: It’s hard to amass much of a vault off one album and tour cycle, and perhaps inevitably, a good 80% of You and I, the latest posthumous release bearing Jeff Buckley's name, consists of covers, many already released.

albums.title: Only Life/Time For A Witness
albums.label: Bar/None
albums.description: These reissues from the Feelies train a new lens on the band's late middle period, when they honed their caffeinated energy, settling gracefully into their signature sound.

albums.title: For A Reason
albums.label: Light in the Attic
albums.description: After the breakup of the art-rock band This Heat, guitarist/vocalist Charles Bullen released a solo album as Lifetones in 1983. Now reissued, it remains a strange amalgam of post-punk’s desolation set to dub reggae’s sunny lilt.

albums.title: Sign of the Cross Every Mile to the Border
albums.label: Halocline Trance
albums.description: Toronto's David Psutka records as Egyptrixx, who helped define the atmospheric sound of London's Night Slugs label. His project Ceramic TL is a radical break: The beats are gone and the melodies have run dry. It's all atmosphere, heady as huffing aerosol.

albums.title: 3001: A Laced Odyssey
albums.label: Glorious Dead
albums.description: The Brooklyn rap group Flatbush Zombies deliver an off-kilter take on '90s touchstones like Gravediggaz and the Flatlinerz with a touch of ODB. Their debut LP is a deep dive into psychotropia—the highs and lows—with paranoia and invincibility trading places with suicidal thoughts.

albums.title: The Sentence
albums.label: Styles Upon Styles
albums.description: Composer Zach Cooper's debut album blends acoustic instruments, synthesizers and electronic effects into a shifting whole that's part chamber music, part post-rock, and part musique concrète.

albums.title: Bothic
albums.label: Bruiser Brigade
albums.description: The 21-year-old Detroit rapper ZeelooperZ is a member of Danny Brown's Bruiser Brigade. On his latest album, he tries to push the boundaries of conventional rapping.

albums.title: Barbara Barbara, we face a shining future
albums.label: Astralwerks
albums.description: On the first proper Underworld record in half a decade, the duo of Karl Hyde and Rick Smith continue to place matters of the heart at the center of their best songs.

albums.title: Horse Jumper of Love
albums.label: Disposable America
albums.description: Boston's Horse Jumper of Love are a self-proclaimed "slow rock" trio whose combination of wan croons, melancholic strumming, and ramshackle production place their music in Microphones territory.

albums.title: No One Deserves Happiness
albums.label: Thrill Jockey
albums.description: The Portland experimental metal outfit have made their simplest record yet, one that is less sprawling than their earlier releases and scarier for its concision.

albums.title: III EP
albums.label: Static Shock
albums.description: Sheer Mag's music stuffs hip-shaking hooks and burly riffs within impeccably structured pop songs, wrapped in lyrics both open-hearted and openly political. They’re the Jackson 5 raised to play punk rock, with an F-5 tornado for a singer.

albums.title: The Last Panthers
albums.label: Warp
albums.description: Chris Clark, a.k.a. Clark, composed the score for a moody British TV serial called The Last Panthers. Here, he shapes this incidental music into a flowing 48-minute suite that conjures almost as much of a story as the show itself.

albums.title: Mercy EP
albums.label: Sad Cactus
albums.description: Fake Boyfriend's debut EP Mercy merges post-punk with the poppier indie-rock stylings associated with acts like Waxatachee and Girlpool, full of thrashing guitar blasts and churning bass.

albums.title: Trotro
albums.label: Awesome Tapes From Africa
albums.description: DJ Katapila is a Ghanaian DJ who has become known for his marathon sets. His own production borrows as much from early Chicago house and Detroit techno as from Ga dance music, and boasts a remarkable sense of humor.

albums.title: Transition
albums.label: Erased Tapes
albums.description: Saxophonist Daniel Thorne and his Immix Ensemble stretch the boundaries of contemporary classical music and avant-garde composition. Each movement on Transition garbles a classic instrument with electronic processing.

albums.title: Potential
albums.label: Domino
albums.description: James Hinton, the Brooklyn-based producer who records as The Range, doesn't do anything new, but his music crackles with the air of discovery. Potential recalls the optimistic rave moment when the right combination of people and the right DJ could make you feel like you were part of something that mattered.

albums.title: Before a Million Universes
albums.label: Tough Love
albums.description: On their second album, the Brooklyn post-hardcore band Big Ups place a greater emphasis on quiet moments, on gradual buildups.

albums.title: More Rain
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: M. Ward's More Rain is the kind of record you put on when the day is soaked with gloom and dimness, the one you listen to when you’re loafing so hard that you can barely bring yourself to flip the record, much less leave the house and brave the elements.

albums.title: Oh Inhuman Spectacle
albums.label: 4AD
albums.description: Perth's Methyl Ethel makes dream-pop for insomniacs—shadowy, nocturnal music whose surface shimmer barely conceals the fidgety, restless soul lurking underneath.

albums.title: Long Way Home
albums.label: XL
albums.description: 19-year-old British musician Låpsley makes shimmering synth-pop shot through with longing. The best songs on her XL Recordings debut sound both intimate and enormous, while the less-inspired ones feel like trying to recall something boring that happened to you once.

albums.title: Jettison The Valley
albums.label: Western Vinyl
albums.description: Carter Tanton has played with artists like Lower Dens, Twin Shadow, and Marissa Nadler. For his latest solo record, he transforms himself into a Laurel Canyon singer-songwriter, building a record around a single theme: the slow destruction of a relationship.

albums.title: Paid For It
albums.label: Moniker
albums.description: Paid For It is San Francisco songwriter Mark Treise's second album as Jealousy. The shapeshifting, odd grooves underline stories of indulgence and guilt.

albums.title: No Fantasy Required
albums.label: Counter
albums.description: Canadian rave pioneer Tiga Sontag’s fidgety new album features three tracks co-produced by Matthew Dear and a collaboration with Hudson Mohawke.

albums.title: Brute
albums.label: Hyperdub
albums.description: Conceived of as a celebration of the right of protest, Fatima Al Qadiri’s Brute is a piece of music ideally suited to a time of shadowy corporate manipulation and apocalyptic political theater.

albums.title: Post Pop Depression
albums.label: Loma Vista
albums.description: Iggy Pop's newest, which he co-wrote and recorded with Queens of the Stone Age's Josh Homme, recaptures the avant-rock frisson of his early collaborations with David Bowie.

albums.title: Forever Sounds
albums.label: Shake It
albums.description: Wussy's sixth LP is bleaker and more difficult than its predecessor, 2014's tentatively anthemic Attica!. The album is full of darkly valiant shoegaze, music that is cozy enough to hibernate under.

albums.title: Empire Underground EP
albums.label: B3SCI
albums.description: After their most recent and extremely spotty album Future This, the Big Pink try and reconnect with the bombastic electro-rock sound that made them popular while casting around for a viable future.

albums.title: Collegrove
albums.label: Def Jam
albums.description: 2 Chainz made a name for himself by following his mentor Lil Wayne’s lead, but the pair’s new collaborative album finds the teacher struggling to keep up with his student.

albums.title: Glitterbust
albums.label: Burger
albums.description: Kim Gordon's noise project with surfer Alex Knost shares some qualities with her band Body/Head. In a sense, it's the sound of the most New York woman to ever live returning to her West Coast roots.

albums.title: Fovere
albums.label: Young Art
albums.description: At seven tracks and 24 minutes, Jennifer Lee's (aka TOKiMONSTA) Fovere is a brief, rounded project that does not ask very much of its listener.

albums.title: Blue Cheese
albums.label: Ba Da Bing!
albums.description: Dunedin, New Zealand-based singer-guitarist Kane Strang's songs have a way of making modest acts seem heroic. At his best, he comes off like Panda Bear doing a one-man garage-band remount of Pixies slow jams.

albums.title: When You Walk a Long Distance You Are Tired
albums.label: Grand Jury
albums.description: The Athens, GA indie-folk outfit Mothers’ debut record finds its strength in the raw, striking vulnerability of frontwoman Kristine Leschper.

albums.title: He Has Risen
albums.label: SRFSCHL
albums.description: Brooklyn producer Harry Fraud handles all of the production on Smoke DZA's latest project. Fraud's diamantine, jazzy cuts push Smoke DZA to give one of his best performances yet.

albums.title: United Crushers
albums.label: Mom & Pop
albums.description: Poliça's United Crushers is a political record, but it's too exhausted to work as a protest album so much as an album for when all the protest's been sapped out.

albums.title: untitled unmastered.
albums.label: Top Dawg
albums.description: In execution, untitled unmastered. is the complete inverse of Kanye West's recent The Life of Pablo—it's a small and quiet statement from an artist with little to prove at this moment.

albums.title: At the Dam
albums.label: Ghostly
albums.description: Harpist Mary Lattimore traveled across the country with her harp; At the Dam, the album she made on the journey, bursts with ambition and ideas.

albums.title: Surface Noise
albums.label: Kiam
albums.description: Featuring songs about handling love and fear, Jennifer O'Connor's sixth album seems to be an effort to reconcile the places in life that are rough around the edges.

albums.title: A Man Alive
albums.artist: Thao & the Get Down Stay Down
albums.label: Ribbon Music
albums.description: Produced by Merrill Garbus, aka tUnE-yArDs, Thao Nguyen's fourth album, A Man Alive!, is her most rhythmically robust and gleefully discordant release to date.

albums.title: Hiperasia
albums.label: Nacional
albums.description: The Spanish producer who made his name with buzzing, colorful, maximalist free-for-alls returns with his most resolutely electronic work yet.

albums.title: Varmints
albums.label: PIAS
albums.description: Composer and producer Anna Meredith's wild music blends synthesizers and acoustic instruments. She makes it feel as if you're strapped in her spaceship's sidecar as she goes rampaging around the universe.

albums.title: Under Summer
albums.label: Burnt Toast Vinyl
albums.description: Although Yndi Halda use every post-rock cliché imaginable on their long-awaited sophomore LP, they use them sparingly, along with more daring instrumentation and their first use of lyrics.

albums.title: Zelalem
albums.label: Rvng Intl.
albums.description: The 28-year-old makes Addis producer makes what he and his peers call "Ethiopiyawi Electronic," which crosses Ethiopian folk and religious traditions with electronica. His latest album collapses not only the past and the present, but also different sacred and secular music forms, and, importantly, the artist’s inner and outer worlds.

albums.title: The Ridge
albums.label: Paper Bag
albums.description: Composer and violinist Sarah Neufeld is a career-long touring and recording member of Arcade Fire. Her second solo album of compositions The Ridge feels less exploratory than Neufield’s previous work, but it is still a moving document of her engaging, virtuosic playing.

albums.title: Belgica Original Soundtrack
albums.label: Play It Again Sam
albums.description: Soulwax's first LP in eleven years is a soundtrack to a Belgian film about two brothers who run a hedonistic nightclub in Ghent, Soulwax's hometown. For the sixteen-track album, the band invented fifteen fictional personas, each with its own sound, aesthetic, and backstory that draw from different decades of club culture.

albums.title: Emily’s D+Evolution
albums.label: EMI
albums.description: Emily’s D+Evolution marks a radical shift in the style of upright bassist and singer Esperanza Spalding. The Grammy Award-winning artist reemerges from a two-year hiatus with a rock/funk hybrid that brings Prince and Janelle Monae to mind.

albums.title: Värähtelijä
albums.label: 20 Buck Spin
albums.description: Four albums into their career, the Finnish quintet Oranssi Pazuzu may have at last sidestepped the confines of the tag “black metal." Their latest 69-minute opus folds in Krautrock, electric Miles Davs, stoner, thrash and more, finding the band lost—wonderfully, strangely—somewhere between heaven and hell.

albums.title: Petrol
albums.label: Friends of Friends
albums.description: Anenon is Brian Allen Simon, an electronic producer and saxophone player, and his third album Petrol is a major step forward for him. It's a portrait of his native Los Angeles, and the setting is somewhere just past sundown, the sky steadily leeched of color as lines of cars streak toward the horizon.

albums.title: Heron Oblivion
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: Heron Oblivion features members of Comets on Fire and Meg Baird, formerly of Philadelphia folk collective Espers. Their self-titled debut LP triggers nostalgia for the mid-'00s moment when bands like Six Organs of Admittance, Dead Meadow, and OM were ascendant, drawing both from underground American noise music and vintage psychedelic rock.

albums.title: We Can Do Anything
albums.label: PIAS
albums.description: The charitable way to describe We Can Do Anything, the first Violent Femmes record in 15 years, is that it's a back-to-basics record; a less charitable perspective is that it's a pale Silly Putty copy of their still-beloved self-titled record from 33 years ago.

albums.title: Full Circle
albums.label: Legacy
albums.description: Loretta Lynn's first album since 2004's Jack White-produced Van Lear Rose reflects poignantly on her past. She makes a grab-bag late-late-career album feel not only emotionally grounded, but like a powerful choice.

albums.title: January Sun
albums.label: 2MR
albums.description: Where so many artists give their work the sonic equivalent of a fake tan when they try to "warm" it up with analog sounds, the Russian singer and producer Kedr Livanskiy captures the charm of listening to dance music that’s been taped off a late-night radio broadcast.

albums.title: Lullabies for the Broken Brain
albums.label: Mello Music Group
albums.description: Quelle Chris' production has always been unorthodox, but Lullabies for the Broken Brain is a step further for the rapper/producer. This isn’t your average beat tape: Lullabies is made of divergent sounds, loosely built to set a pensive vibe shaded with desperation and hopelessness.

albums.title: Music for Listening to Music to
albums.label: Polyvinyl
albums.description: Music for Listening to Music to is La Sera's fourth album and its first with singer/bassist Katy Goodman's husband Todd Wisenbaker officially on board. Produced by Ryan Adams, it finds its way to a blend of Adams' alt-country and their winsome take on alt-rock.

albums.title: Arcology
albums.label: Software
albums.description: Like so much electronic music, Thug Entrancer's Arcology plays with heady futurist themes on the surface. Beneath that, however, it is a satisfying collection of variations on footwork and techno, seen through the eyes of a producer with his own skewed vision.

albums.title: Bowie At The Beeb
albums.label: Parlophone
albums.description: This four-LP collection spans David Bowie's second-ever BBC session, in 1968, through to May 1972. Unlike other more carefully curated Bowie box sets, Bowie at the Beeb is an anatomy of how he became a rock star.

albums.title: Carta
albums.label: Victor
albums.description: Carta is the third album and major label debut from Especia, a five-piece frequently billed as "Japanese vaporwave idols." Although it doesn’t reach the heights of earlier works, it’s a solid snapshot of what Especia has done so well in recent times: real-deal city pop blessed with big hooks and copious saxophone solos.

albums.title: Plaza
albums.label: Mexican Summer
albums.description: The third album from indie/psych/folk quartet Quilt offers a rebuttal to all those people who argue that every artist steals. Some, like Quilt, know the difference between stealing from and honoring their influences.

albums.title: HXLT
albums.label: G.O.O.D. Music
albums.description: The self-titled G.O.O.D. Music debut from HXLT (F.K.A. rapper Hollywood Holt) aims to revisit a time when Debbie Harry and Grandmaster Flash rubbed elbows at New York’s Danceteria, but ends up feeling like getting invited to a friend's art show—you’re rooting for the guy, but man, some of this stuff is brutal.

albums.title: LNZNDRF
albums.label: 4AD
albums.description: The National's other pair of brothers, Brian and Scott Devendorf, team up with Beirut's Benjamin Lanz to pay homage to the headier aspects of the 4AD catalog with an enjoyable yet uneven debut.

albums.title: Outer Acid EP
albums.label: Alleviated
albums.description: Chicago house legend Larry Heard's new Outer Acid EP is his first release as Mr. Fingers since 2005. But his return isn't to rehash or cash in on his old work, but rather to elucidate it, to carry on this dialogue with his machines in a new century.

albums.title: God Don't Never Change: The Songs of Blind Willie Johnson
albums.label: Alligator
albums.description: God Don’t Never Change is an 11-song ode to the great blues howler and gospel progenitor Blind Willie Johnson, including contributions from Tom Waits, Lucinda Williams, and more.

albums.title: Cellar EP
albums.label: Fade to Mind
albums.description: Producer Daniel Pineda, who is one half of Nguzunguzu, has transformed club dancefloors into zones of unmitigated free expression.

albums.title: Stranger Things
albums.label: Mamé
albums.description: Soldiering on without one-time frontman Daniel Blumberg, Yuck continue to pay homage to '90s indie rock, but the most telling reference point may be their former selves.

albums.title: Jerome Raheem Fortune
albums.label: Fool's Gold
albums.description: Atlanta rapper Rome Fortune is an independent artist who has paid his dues on the mixtape circuit. His new album offers a look behind the veil of moderate Internet-based fame.

albums.title: Get Disowned
albums.label: Saddle Creek
albums.description: It originally came out in 2012, but Hop Along's brilliant Get Disowned, now reissued, feels like it could’ve been the complicated, difficult follow-up to last year's Painted Shut.

albums.title: Drumkit Quartets
albums.label: Cantaloupe
albums.description: Wilco drummer Glenn Kotche has been successful as both a composer and a performer in the modern classical scene. His album with the elite contemporary classical group So Percussion seems inevitable, in the best possible way.

albums.title: Eraser Stargazer
albums.label: DFA
albums.description: Guerilla Toss make a "Donkey Kong"*-*soundtrack version of punk, with synthesizers ping-ponging against screeching guitars. It's brainy music that feels immediate and visceral.

albums.title: Grandfeathered
albums.label: Club AC30
albums.description: Like early-'00s bands like Asobi Seksu, Serena-Maneesh, or Mahogany, Pinkshinyultrablast are rooted in shoegaze while maintaining a basis in electronic noise. The effect is like getting showered with a firehose pumping spangly glitter.

albums.title: No Burden
albums.label: EggHunt
albums.description: Richmond-based singer/songwriter Lucy Dacus' No Burden is an uncommonly warm indie rock record. Lead guitar lines pour in like slow columns of sunlight, and Dacus' voice itself is a comforting blur.

albums.title: This Unruly Mess I've Made
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: Three years after they reached superstardom with The Heist, Macklemore & Ryan Lewis return with This Unruly Mess I’ve Made, a blend of juvenile joke raps, inquisitive woke raps, and diaristic contemplations of Macklemore’s life that attempts to prove they belong—that they’re not just white saviors trying to project their face onto the culture.

albums.title: Wave Gods
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: French Montana has spent most of his career as the weakest rapper in the room. On Wave Gods, he imagines a woozier, wavier alternate world, one in which he takes center stage for the first time.

albums.title: Principe del Norte
albums.label: Smalltown Supersound
albums.description: This is a record with nothing to prove, a vision of ambient music clad in bathrobe and slippers. You come to it to kick back, get lost in texture, and forget about time for a while.

albums.title: M:FANS / Music for a New Society
albums.label: Domino
albums.description: Cale's 1982 solo album Music for a New Society is reissued and bundled with a vastly different new version of the record, allowing him to wring new meaning from old songs.

albums.title: In My Mind
albums.label: Motown
albums.description: BJ the Chicago Kid's first major-label release is a tender update on classic Chicago soul, featuring guest spots from Kendrick Lamar, Chance the Rapper, and Big K.R.I.T.

albums.title: I like it when you sleep, for you are so beautiful yet so unaware of it
albums.label: Interscope
albums.description: The 1975's second album has a much more distinct and iconoclastic character than their slick debut, drawing from the effervescent polish of early '80s Hot 100 pop.

albums.title: Talk to Me So I Can Fall Asleep
albums.label: Help Yourself
albums.description: The Seattle electro-pop duo Crater populate their debut album with distant couples who hide behind glowing screens, barely speaking, and veiling their limited exchanges in so many layers of irony that they can hardly decode each other when they speak.

albums.title: Euphoria EP
albums.label: Sick Wid It
albums.description: A collaboration between Bay Area rapper/producer Droop-E and L.A. songwriter Nite Jewel, Euphoria revels in the distance between two musicians and styles.

albums.title: Going Down in History
albums.label: Bloodshot
albums.description: Jon Langford, frontman for the legendary punk band the Mekons, has explored Americana both with his main group and in a series of side projects, one of which is the Waco Brothers. Going Down in History is their first studio LP since 2005’s Freedom and Weep and a tight set of aggressive heartland rock.

albums.title: George Fest: A Night to Celebrate the Music of George Harrison
albums.label: Vagrant
albums.description: George Fest: A Night to Celebrate the Music of George Harrison is a live double album with the ramshackle, collaborative warmth of a Traveling Wilburys set. It features contributions from Britt Daniel of Spoon, Brian Wilson, the Flaming Lips, Brandon Flowers of the Killers, George's son Dhani, and many more.

albums.title: Off the Wall
albums.label: Legacy
albums.description: Off the Wall is the sound of young Michael Jackson's liberation. Though he would become even more successful in the '80s, Off the Wall remains unabashedly fun to return to for its joy and lack of baggage. For 41 minutes, we can live in the eternally young Neverland Michael longed for, a universe largely without consequence or death.

albums.title: Outdoor Museum of Fractals / 555Hz
albums.label: Border Community
albums.description: When Terry Riley turned 80 last year, a number of commemorative concerts were played. A couple of the most interesting took place at London’s Barbican Centre and Amsterdam’s Muziekgebouw where James Holden and Luke Abbott were invited to compose live improvisational electronic pieces influenced by Riley’s work. The recordings on Outdoor Museum of Fractals / 555Hz are taken from their rehearsals prior to the concerts.

albums.title: Higher Power
albums.label: Dine Alone
albums.description: The Ontario band Dirty Nil's Higher Power offers punk with high-end production values meant for big rooms. However antisocial they may get, the music here is intended to be a communal experience.

albums.title: Songs From the Shoebox
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: Songs From the Shoebox is a rough-around-the-edges record that bursts at the seams with excitement. Two of the band's members, bassist William Cashion and frontman Sam Herring, have higher profiles with their band Future Islands, but the Snails puts a greater emphasis on pure fun.

albums.title: The Art of Hustle
albums.label: Epic
albums.description: At the age of 36, and after two decades in hip-hop, Memphis rapper Yo Gotti has scored his biggest-ever hit with "Down in the DM." The album it comes from, The Art of Hustle, is the biggest of his career, featuring guest spots from Nicki Minaj, Future, Pusha T, and more.

albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: After her darker sophomore effort 2012's Master of My Make-Believe, Santigold returns with a sunshine-bright pop album, shaded with biting commentary on consumerism and the price of art. It comes across as a pointed reaction to her own success over the past decade: If Master of My Make-Believe was a trip down the rabbit hole post-Santogold, 99¢ tries to be the yin to its yang: a hyper-positive, yet self-aware, happy-pill remedy.

albums.title: Traditional Synthesizer Music
albums.label: Planet Mu
albums.description: Aaron Funk's latest album was created and performed live on a modular synth with no overdubbing and editing; it's one of the more beautiful records from the project in recent memory.

albums.title: Death Index
albums.label: Deathwish
albums.description: Death Index is the collaboration between Carson Cox, lead singer for Merchandise, and Marco Rapisarda, a regular in Italy's hardcore scene. Unlike most hardcore or punk records, Death Index was made layer-by-layer in a studio, creating a cool distance between vocals and music that allows for some fascinating contrasts.

albums.title: Love Yes
albums.label: Carpark
albums.description: Brooklyn electro-pop outfit TEEN offer dense, synth-swirling tracks about sexuality, love, and the cultural dictates of desire that can feel claustrophobic and exhilarating at the same time.

albums.title: Void Beats / Invocation Trex
albums.label: Duophonic
albums.description: Cavern of Anti-Matter is the new project of Stereolab founder Tim Gane. The songs here cover ground from techno to krautrock to electro and beyond. The unifying element is the loose, jammy feeling to everything: It's easy to imagine these pieces being worked out in the studio in just one or two takes, even with their many moving pieces. Bradford Cox guests on one of two tracks with vocals.

albums.title: Star Wars Headspace
albums.label: American
albums.description: Star Wars Headspace is a new album of electronic music inspired by the Star Wars films. Executive produced by Rick Rubin, the record is alive with adolescent energy, thanks to a well-chosen roster of producers including Flying Lotus, Shlohmo, Baauer, and more.

albums.title: The Heretic's Bargain
albums.label: Drag City
albums.description: Rangda is a trio composed of avant-garde guitarists Richard Bishop and Ben Chasny alongside drummer Chris Corsano. Each of their records features riff-heavy, tightly packed instrumental rock tunes with moments of abandon, and on The Heretic's Bargain they are as precise and wild as they've ever been.

albums.title: Need Your Light
albums.label: Barsuk
albums.description: Over their 10-year career, Ra Ra Riot have swung between extremes, from the literary baroque pop of their breakout The Rhumb Line to the electro-pop of Beta Love. On their new album Need Your Light, they find a sweet spot, finding a bright synth-pop sound not far from Passion Pit.

albums.title: Seth Bogart
albums.label: Burger
albums.description: After releasing three album as sweaty hedonist Hunx (two with His Punx, one by himself), Seth Bogart releases his first truly self-titled record. The fried garage pop and retro balladry of albums past has been swapped for a club-ready sound that plays like a fever dream set inside an episode of "Miami Vice": bright colors, buzzing synthesizers, chipmunked vocals, the smooth confidence of adults on the prowl for meaningful sex.

albums.title: Jesu/Sun Kil Moon
albums.label: Rough Trade
albums.description: The album-length collaboration between Mark Kozelek and Justin Broaderick is an appealing change-up in Kozelek's recent work; Kozelek hasn't necessarily "gone metal" here, but he's definitely using his voice in different ways.

albums.title: Breadwoman & Other Tales
albums.label: Rvng Intl.
albums.description: In 1985, Los Angeles performance artist Anna Homler recorded a series of shamanistic dream-songs with Southern California composer Steve Moshier, who accompanied Homler's chants with watery synthesizers and rubbery electronic pulses. If anyone is going to make sense of this 31-year-old séance in 2016, it's the New York label RVNG Intl., which has just reissued it.

albums.title: Mowing
albums.label: Suicide Squeeze
albums.description: Michael Nau has been the frontman for Page France and Cotton Jones. On his solo debut, he displays his penchant for uplift: Sumptuously warm, the set feels invitingly casual, loose-strung, and slightly accidental, a collection of messy indie-rock demos that he fleshes out into surprising songs.

albums.title: Phase
albums.label: Island
albums.description: Hotly hyped UK singer/songwriter Jack Garratt blends earnest bluesman's style with a light fizz of electronica and quavering voice. His debut seems forged from equal parts James Blake and Jai Paul, and somewhere inside the sentiment and bombast you can hear a sensitive man who's trying to explore his flaws and desires candidly.

albums.title: Livin' on a High Note
albums.label: Anti-
albums.description: Featuring production by M. Ward and boasting songwriting credits from Nick Cave, Neko Case, Justin Vernon, and others, Mavis Staples' Livin' on a High Note is a happy record. Its beneficent energy is refreshing after the cloistered prayer of last year’s Your Good Fortune and two thoughtful Jeff Tweedy-produced records.

albums.title: Ultimate Care II
albums.label: Thrill Jockey
albums.description: Matmos have drawn inspiration from many far-flung and mundane sources, and on Ultimate Care II they source every sound from the Whirlpool washing machine of the same name.

albums.title: Life of Pause
albums.label: Captured Tracks
albums.description: Wild Nothing's third full-length is their cheeriest and most fleshed out recording to date. Jack Tatum let his love of soul music and even some disco seep into his dream-pop project, and the best moments are the most PG-13 Wild Nothing has been on record yet.

albums.title: Benny...
albums.label: Moraine Music Group
albums.description: Benny Hester is considered one of the pioneers of the Contemporary Christian Music movement, and he has written many of the genre's standards. But in the early '60s and '70s, he made a lovely, strange, and sincere baroque psych-pop record with Elvis' backing band, which has just been reissued.

albums.title: Daze
albums.label: Tri Angle
albums.description: Brood Ma, a London-based producer and recent signee to the label Tri Angle, joins forward-thinking artists like Rabit, Roly Porter, and Lotic. Rather than maintain a singular focus, the producer skips from idea to idea, uniting decades of club music under a singular industrial umbrella.

albums.title: Ritualize
albums.label: Western Vinyl
albums.description: On Lushlife's latest full-length, the Philly rapper and producer's curatorial instincts have kicked into overdrive. Unfortunately, despite an impressive roster of guests, Ritualize fails to add up to much.

albums.title: How to Dance
albums.label: Merge
albums.description: On their third album, Mount Moriah no longer sound like an indie band playing country music; they sound like a country band, full stop. It’s the band’s fullest, peppiest album yet, with punchier tempos, flashier accompaniments, and a little more of a fighting spirit.

albums.title: DJ-Kicks
albums.label: !K7
albums.description: You might expect a set of dusty disco and deep house from the house legend Moodymann. But his first officially licensed mix CD, for the 51st entry in the DJ-Kicks series, confounds expectations throughout, detouring at peak moments, going left where he might build momentum, all of it leading to luminous results.

albums.title: Under the Perspective Tree EP
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: Why Khaliq, a young upstart from St. Paul, is turning out some of the Twin Cities’ most forward-thinking rap music, and he does so by circling way back. His new seven-song EP takes the visual and musical signifiers of late-'90s and early-'00s conscious rap and injects into them welcome doses of immediacy and personal detail, and at least a half-dozen new flows.

albums.title: Né So
albums.label: Nonesuch
albums.description: The Malian singer/songwriter returns with another album produced by John Parish. The music is an intimate and minimalistic mix of Mandingue and Western pop/rock influences, and Devendra Banhart guests.

albums.title: neo
albums.label: Sub Pop
albums.description: Minimalist force is what Seattle punk band So Pitted does. They excel at it. On neo, their debut, the trio sound like the proverbial (mechanical) bull in a china shop—except that bull is intentionally there to fuck up some fine dinnerware and is determined to have a hell of a time doing it.

albums.title: Basar
albums.label: Golf Channel
albums.description: On their debut album, the German duo Africaine 808 reinvent the entire concept of "world music" from the ground up. Although they sample styles ranging from Nigerian funk to spiritual jazz to cumbia, what unifies their work is its deep sense of musicality. The songs evolve as inscrutably and as naturally as the movements of a crowd.

albums.title: Painting With
albums.label: Domino
albums.description: Like 2012's Centipede Hz, Painting With is a bright, epileptically busy piece of music that crams every element of Animal Collective's sound into a landscape without depth or recess. It feels, more than anything, like a kind of construction project: Each sound meticulously built and only faintly familiar, each second crammed with doodads, as though the band was worried either they or their audience might get bored.

albums.title: Landless
albums.label: Battleground
albums.description: Eight Bells is the doom metal project of Melynda Jackson, formerly of the defunct, long-running instrumental collective SubArachnoid Space. Landless veers between shoegaze-inflected dreaminess and blackened blurs without lapsing into metalgaze tropes.

albums.title: Holographic
albums.label: New Amsterdam
albums.description: Composer Daniel Wohl specializes in pieces that bridge the divide between acoustic and programmed elements; at their best, his works confuse your sense of what is played live and what is manipulated. His new album Holographic features singers Olga Bell and Caroline Shaw.

albums.title: On Vacation
albums.label: International Feel
albums.description: Vacation, the second in a new series of mini-albums for the Ibiza-based International Feel label, is rich with Balearic textures: marimbas, choral synth pads, creamy soprano sax, acoustic guitars run through shimmering digital reverb. It takes cues from genre staples like Penguin Café Orchestra, Wally Badarou, and Sade.

albums.title: Skifflin'
albums.label: Spiritual Pajamas
albums.description: The Skiffle Players is a ragtag outfit featuring Cass McCombs alongside members of Circles Around the Sun and the faded alt-country group Beachwood Sparks. Their enjoyably low-stakes debut LP captures the liberal, halfway-stoned spirit that’s demanded of musicians past thirty living in California.

albums.title: The Life of Pablo
albums.label: Def Jam
albums.description: Finally, after a protracted and often chaotic roll-out, the new Kanye West album is here. The Life of Pablo is the first Kanye West album that's just an album: No major statements, no reinventions, no zeitgeist wheelie-popping. But a madcap sense of humor animates all his best work, and the new record has a freewheeling energy that is infectious and unique to his discography.

albums.title: A Minor Thought
albums.label: Smallville
albums.description: On Berlin house producer Moomin's second album, ruminative, dewy-eyed house music remains the name of the game—one part Larry Heard, one part '70s tearjerker, and as richly textured as it gets. These songs scratch a very particular emotional itch in extremely satisfying ways: They're both melancholy and zippy at the same time, downcast yet fleet of foot.

albums.title: Personal Life
albums.label: Exploding in Sound
albums.description: Silver Spring, Md.'s Two Inch Astronaut is a deft, bristling post-punk act whose energy stems from the uneasy suturing of uplifting, persistent melodies to an overactive rhythm section that threatens to dismantle it—and the lopsided pop hooks that result.

albums.title: Rot Forever
albums.label: Broken World Media
albums.description: Rot Forever, the debut double album from Portland band Sioux Falls, swells from indie rock into six- or seven-minute epics, like early Modest Mouse or Built to Spill. At 72 minutes, the album is too long, but they have the energy and gravity to support this kind of cinematic ambition; the band plays as if they are trying very hard to pull something up through the earth.

albums.title: Out My Feelings (In My Past)
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: Released shortly after Boosie's emotionally gripping In My Feelings mixtape, which grappled with his cancer diagnosis, Out My Feelings reflects on a life covered in scars and pain—not just his own, but those of the people around him and people he’s interacted with. Since his release from prison in 2014, the Baton Rouge rapper seems committed to living up to the 2Pac comparisons his ardent supporters have given him.

albums.title: Khalifa
albums.label: Atlantic
albums.description: Wiz Khalifa's sixth album has been promoted as his most "personal" project, but the introspection here mostly entails reiterating his come-up tale, punctuating it with an ellipsis and "but I’m rich now" tacked on for good measure.

albums.title: Janus
albums.label: Driftless
albums.description: The singer/songwriter's third album, Janus, is a change-up. Kivel has generally been known for spare and hushed songs, with only a few instruments creating a ripple of distress in his lovely folk melodies. Many songs here are chaotic and noisy, however, disrupting his reveries with scribbles of atonal clamor.

albums.title: My Wild West
albums.label: Cooking Vinyl
albums.description: Lissie's debut boasted some venerable personnel—collaborators of Tom Waits and Modest Mouse, among others—and her impressively yarling voice, which got her discovered. My Wild West, her first album on her own label, is full of sturdily crafted but MOR songs.

albums.title: Wraptaypes
albums.label: All City
albums.description: The prolific veteran producer Knxwledge enjoyed a national breakthrough when he was featured on Kendrick Lamar's To Pimp a Butterfly in 2015. His Wraptaypes series, which is anthologized here, is a good place to get a feel for his aesthetic: Basically, he strips original works of their elements, samples the remains he deems useful, and engraves them with his signature.

albums.title: EVOL
albums.label: Epic
albums.description: EVOL arrives less than a month after Future's surprise mixtape Purple Reign, and while it has slightly more misses than hits, the highs are high—arguably higher than Purple Reign's—and ultimately, the lows aren't enough to break his current all-timer run.

albums.title: Wriggling
albums.label: Sad Cactus
albums.description: Abi Reimold is a Philadelphia artist whose dark voice bears similarities to Mitski and Angel Olsen, yet sticking a singer/songwriter tag on Reimold feels like a disservice. Reimold isn’t just playing her music; she’s living it, and it sounds goddamn exhausting.

albums.title: Why the Mountains Are Black: Primeval Greek Village Music
albums.label: Third Man
albums.description: Why The Mountains Are Black is Third Man’s two-disc collection compiling over 50 years of "primeval Greek village music." Remastered from Grammy-award-winning producer Christopher King's expansive archive of 78rpm recordings, every square inch of these songs brims with primal indignance, a sense that when times are tough, you break out the booze, sing louder, and dance more fervently.

albums.title: Voix
albums.label: The Ajna Offensive
albums.description: French power trio Aluk Todolo have used the basic instruments and fundamental techniques of hard rock and metal to pursue what may seem a musical unicorn—hyperkinetic, heavy instrumental music that’s meditative and absorbing. Voix feels meditative like Sunn O))) or Bardo Pond, Ash Ra Tempel or even Les Rallizes Dénudés. This is, as intended, music meant for submission.

albums.title: Super Saiyan Vol. 3
albums.label: self-released
albums.description: On Super Saiyan Vol. 3, the standard bearers for Chicago’s kinetic bop scene inch closer toward rap’s center, with mixed results.

albums.title: Cardinal
albums.label: Run for Cover
albums.description: Montclair, N.J. band Pinegrove's debut LP Cardinal recalls some of the most consistently likeable rock bands of the past 20 years in their most easygoing phases: There’s the rootsy shamble of early Wilco, the wiggly guitar solos and general guilelessness of pre-prog Built to Spill. But beneath the amiable surface is an intense work about one of the most important things imaginable: how to make our friendships really matter.

albums.title: Heaven Adores You Soundtrack
albums.label: Interscope
albums.description: With Heaven Adores You, the soundtrack to last year's Kickstarter-funded Elliott Smith documentary of the same name, we get sweet, refreshing peeks at the real person behind the Sad Guy cartoon people know best. The endearing scraps, and at least one previously unreleased masterpiece, help rewrite the details of an important story.

albums.title: All I Need
albums.label: Sony
albums.description: Foxes (aka Louisa Rose Allen) sang the hook on Zedd's pristine EDM super-hit "Clarity" but has struggled for solo momentum.  After listening to All I Need for the first time, nothing remains or sticks with you, which is maybe the most damning thing you can say about a pop record aimed at big international markets and radio takeovers.

albums.title: Man Made Object
albums.label: Blue Note
